soln_description:
4. Selecting 505 numbers $1,5,9,13,17, \ldots, 2017 \in \mathrm{M}$, which give a remainder of 1 when divided by four, clearly has the required property, because the difference between any two selected numbers is a multiple of four, thus a composite number. (Since 4 is the smallest composite number, it is not possible to select a larger number of numbers in a similar regular manner.)

We will show that it is not possible to select more numbers with the required property from the given set, regardless of the method used. To do this, we first verify the key statement that from any sequence of eight consecutive numbers, at most two numbers can be selected.

First, we prove that if we select some number $n$, from the next seven numbers $n+1, n+2, \ldots, n+7$ at most one can be selected. Indeed, we cannot then select any of the numbers $n+2, n+3, n+5, n+7$. And from the remaining trio $n+1, n+4, n+6$, only one number can be selected, because their differences are the prime numbers 2, 3, and 5. This proves the statement about the seven numbers that follow any selected number $n$. From this, it is clear that no sequence of eight consecutive numbers can contain more than two selected numbers, as we promised to verify.

The set $\mathrm{M}$ can be divided into the set $\{1,2, \ldots, 10\}$ and 251 subsequent eights. From the set $\{1,2, \ldots, 10\}$, at most three suitable numbers can be selected. If we were to select four suitable numbers from the first ten

$$
\{1,2, \ldots, 10\}=\{1,2\} \cup\{3,4, \ldots, 10\}=\{1,2, \ldots, 8\} \cup\{9,10\}
$$

according to the proven property of each sequence of eight consecutive numbers, we would have to select both numbers 1 and 2, as well as both numbers 9 and 10, but $9-2$ is a prime number. From the set $\mathrm{M}$, then, at most $2 \cdot 251+3=505$ numbers can be selected.

For a complete solution, award 6 points. 1 point for the idea that from a sequence of eight consecutive numbers, at most two can be selected, and 1 point for a correct proof of this idea. 1 point for correctly dividing the numbers into disjoint eights and "remainder". 1 point for correctly deriving that from such a division, at most 505 numbers can be selected. 1 point for constructing the required set itself, and 1 point for justifying that the constructed set meets the requirements.

In the case of a partial solution, award 1 point for constructing an example of 505 numbers that meet the requirements, and an additional point for proving that no additional number can be added to it.
informal_statement:

The regional round of category B takes place

so that it starts no later than 10:00 AM and the contestants have 4 hours of pure time to solve the problems. Allowed aids are writing and drawing supplies and school MF tables. Calculators, laptops, and any other electronic aids are not allowed. Each problem can earn the contestant 6 points; the logical correctness and completeness of the written solution are also evaluated. The point threshold (higher than 7 points) for determining successful solvers will be centrally set after evaluating the statistics of results from all regions. This information will be communicated to the students before the competition begins.

soln_description:
4. $\frac{5 \sqrt{2}}{2}$.
First, prove: $\frac{|3 x+4 y|}{\sqrt{|x|^{2}+|y|^{2}+\left|x^{2}+y^{2}\right|}} \leqslant \frac{5 \sqrt{2}}{2}$.
It suffices to prove:
$$
|3 x+4 y|^{2} \leqslant \frac{25}{2}\left(|x|^{2}+|y|^{2}+\left|x^{2}+y^{2}\right|\right) \text {, }
$$

which is
$$
\begin{array}{l}
2(3 x+4 y)(3 \bar{x}+4 \bar{y})-25\left(|x|^{2}+|y|^{2}\right) \\
\leqslant 25\left|x^{2}+y^{2}\right|,
\end{array}
$$

which is $\square$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
-7|x|^{2}+7|y|^{2}+24(\bar{x} y+x \bar{y}) \\
\leqslant 25\left|x^{2}+y^{2}\right| .
\end{array}
$$

It suffices to prove:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
{[7(-x \bar{x}+y \bar{y})+24(\bar{x} y+x y)]^{2}} \\
\leqslant 625\left(x^{2} \dot{x}^{2}+y^{2} \bar{y}^{2}+\bar{x}^{2} y^{2}+x^{2} \bar{y}^{2}\right) .
\end{array}
$$

Noting that $\bar{x} y+x \bar{y}=\overline{\bar{x} y+x \bar{y}}$ is a real number, then by the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
{[7(-x \bar{x}+y \bar{y})+24(1+x \bar{y})]^{2}} \\
\leqslant\left(7^{2}+24^{2}\right)\left[(-x \bar{x}+\bar{y})^{2}+(\bar{x} y+x \bar{y})^{2}\right] \\
=625\left(x^{2} \bar{x}^{2}+y^{2} \bar{y}^{2}+\bar{x}^{2} y^{2}+x^{2} \bar{y}^{2}\right) .
\end{array}
$$
Equality in (1) holds when $x=1, y=\frac{4}{3}$.

Suppose now that for some rational number $ x = \frac{r}{s} $ the following holds:

soln_description:
We notice that if we have a solution $(x, y, z, t)$, then for any integer $k,\left(k^{4} x, k^{4} y, k^{3} z, k^{6} t\right)$ is also a solution. Therefore, it is sufficient to find one solution to have an infinite number of them.

There are several ways to find a solution, for example, if $x=y=2^{n}$, we want $2^{3 n+1}=z^{4}-t^{2}=\left(z^{2}-t\right)\left(z^{2}+t\right)$. We need to find two powers of 2 that can be written as $z^{2}-t$ and $z^{2}+t$. A pair that works is $32=12^{2}-112$ and $256=12^{2}+112$. A solution is $(16,16,12,112)$.
informal_statement:
(UK Olympiades) Show that the following equation has an infinite number of solutions:

$$
x^{3}+y^{3}=z^{4}-t^{2}
$$
informal_proof:
We aim to demonstrate that the set of integer quadruples $(x, y, z, t)$ satisfying the equation $x^3 + y^3 = z^4 - t^2$ contains infinitely many elements. We can achieve this by constructing an injective mapping from the set of natural numbers $\mathbb{N}$ to the set of solutions.

Consider the function $f: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{Z}^4$ defined as follows:
$$f(n) = (2n^4, 2n^4, 2n^3, 0)$$
for any natural number $n$.

First, we establish that $f$ is an injective function. Suppose $f(n) = f(m)$ for some natural numbers $n$ and $m$. By the definition of tuple equality, this implies that each corresponding component must be equal:
\begin{align*} 2n^4 &= 2m^4 \\ 2n^4 &= 2m^4 \\ 2n^3 &= 2m^3 \\ 0 &= 0 \end{align*}
From the first equality, $2n^4 = 2m^4$, dividing by 2 yields $n^4 = m^4$. Since $n$ and $m$ are natural numbers, they are non-negative. Therefore, $n^4 = m^4$ implies $n=m$. The third equality, $2n^3 = 2m^3$, also implies $n=m$ for natural numbers. Thus, $f(n) = f(m)$ implies $n=m$, confirming that $f$ is indeed injective.

Next, we must verify that the output of the function $f(n)$ for any natural number $n$ constitutes a solution to the given equation $x^3 + y^3 = z^4 - t^2$. We substitute the components of $f(n)$ into the equation:
Let $x = 2n^4$, $y = 2n^4$, $z = 2n^3$, and $t = 0$.

The left-hand side of the equation is $x^3 + y^3$:
$$ (2n^4)^3 + (2n^4)^3 = (2^3 \cdot (n^4)^3) + (2^3 \cdot (n^4)^3) = (8n^{12}) + (8n^{12}) = 16n^{12} $$

The right-hand side of the equation is $z^4 - t^2$:
$$ (2n^3)^4 - (0)^2 = (2^4 \cdot (n^3)^4) - 0 = (16n^{12}) - 0 = 16n^{12} $$

Since $16n^{12} = 16n^{12}$, the equation $x^3 + y^3 = z^4 - t^2$ is satisfied by $(2n^4, 2n^4, 2n^3, 0)$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$.

Because we have established an injective map $f$ from the infinite set $\mathbb{N}$ to the set of solutions, it follows that the set of solutions to the equation $x^3 + y^3 = z^4 - t^2$ is infinite.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- (UK Olympiades) Show that the following equation has an infinite number of solutions:

$$
x^{3}+y^{3}=z^{4}-t^{2}
$$ -/
theorem number_theory_141692 : Set.Infinite {(x, y, z, t) : ‚Ñ§ √ó ‚Ñ§ √ó ‚Ñ§ √ó ‚Ñ§ | x^3 + y^3 = z^4 - t^2} := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_141692 : Set.Infinite {(x, y, z, t) : ‚Ñ§ √ó ‚Ñ§ √ó ‚Ñ§ √ó ‚Ñ§ | x^3 + y^3 = z^4 - t^2} := by
  apply Set.infinite_of_injective_forall_mem (f := Œª (n : ‚Ñï) => (2 * (n : ‚Ñ§)^4, 2 * (n : ‚Ñ§)^4, 2 * (n : ‚Ñ§)^3, (0 : ‚Ñ§)))
  ¬∑ -- Show that the function is injective
    intro n m
    simp [Prod.ext_iff] at *
    <;> omega
  ¬∑ -- Show that all elements generated by the function are in the set
    intro n
    simp [Prod.ext_iff]
    <;> ring_nf

soln_description:
4. Suppose that $\alpha=\beta$. The given functional equation for $x=y$ yields $f(x / 2)=x^{-\alpha} f(x)^{2} / 2$; hence the functional equation can be written as
$$
f(x) f(y)=\frac{1}{2} x^{\alpha} y^{-\alpha} f(y)^{2}+\frac{1}{2} y^{\alpha} x^{-\alpha} f(x)^{2},
$$
i.e.,
$$
\left((x / y)^{\alpha / 2} f(y)-(y / x)^{\alpha / 2} f(x)\right)^{2}=0 .
$$

Hence $f(x) / x^{\alpha}=f(y) / y^{\alpha}$ for all $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$, so $f(x)=\lambda x^{\alpha}$ for some $\lambda$. Substituting into the functional equation we obtain that $\lambda=2^{1-a}$ or $\lambda=0$. Thus either $f(x) \equiv 2^{1-a} x^{a}$ or $f(x) \equiv 0$.
Now let $\alpha \neq \beta$. Interchanging $x$ with $y$ in the given equation and subtracting these equalities from each other, we get $\left(x^{\alpha}-x^{a}\right) f(y / 2)=\left(y^{a}-\right.$ $\left.y^{3}\right) f(x / 2)$, so for some constant $\lambda \geq 0$ and all $x \neq 1, f(x / 2)=\lambda\left(x^{0}-x^{3}\right)$. Substituting this into the given equation, we obtain that only $\lambda=0$ is possible, i.e., $f(x) \equiv 0$.
informal_statement:

$$
f(x) f(y)=y^{\alpha} f\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)+x^{\beta} f\left(\frac{y}{2}\right) \quad \text { for all } x \text { and } y \text { in } \mathbb{R}^{+} \text {. }
$$

$$ -/

    (h‚ÇÄ : ‚àÄ x, 0 < x ‚Üí ‚àÄ y, 0 < y ‚Üí f x * f y = y ^ Œ± * f (x / 2) + x ^ Œ≤ * f (y / 2)) :

informal_statement:
For any real number $k$, the graph of the function
\[y = 7x^2 + kx - 4k\]
passes through a fixed point $(a, b)$. Determine the coordinates of this fixed point $(a, b)$.
informal_proof:
We aim to show that for any real number $k$, there exists a point $(x, y)$ such that $(x, y) = (4, 112)$ and the coordinates satisfy the equation $y = 7x^2 + kx - 4k$.

To establish the existence of such a point, we propose the specific point $(4, 112)$ as the witness. We must verify two properties for this point:

1.  The point itself must be equal to $(4, 112)$.
2.  The coordinates of this point, $x=4$ and $y=112$, must satisfy the given equation $y = 7x^2 + kx - 4k$.

The first property, that the point $(4, 112)$ is indeed $(4, 112)$, is directly true by reflexivity of equality.

For the second property, we substitute $x=4$ and $y=112$ into the equation:
$112 = 7 \cdot (4)^2 + k \cdot (4) - 4k$

We can simplify the right-hand side of this equation. First, calculate $4^2$:
$4^2 = 16$

Now, substitute this back into the equation:
$112 = 7 \cdot 16 + 4k - 4k$

Perform the multiplication:
$7 \cdot 16 = 112$

So the equation becomes:
$112 = 112 + 4k - 4k$

The terms involving $k$ cancel out:
$4k - 4k = 0$

This leaves us with:
$112 = 112 + 0$
$112 = 112$

This equality holds true for any real value of $k$. Therefore, the point $(4, 112)$ satisfies both conditions: it is the point $(4, 112)$, and its coordinates satisfy the equation $y = 7x^2 + kx - 4k$. This proves the existence of such a point.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- For any real number $k$, the graph of the function
\[y = 7x^2 + kx - 4k\]
passes through a fixed point $(a, b)$. Determine the coordinates of this fixed point $(a, b)$. -/
theorem algebra_5809 (k : ‚Ñù) :
    ‚àÉ x y, (x, y) = (4, 112) ‚àß y = 7 * x ^ 2 + k * x - 4 * k := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_5809 (k : ‚Ñù) :
    ‚àÉ x y, (x, y) = (4, 112) ‚àß y = 7 * x ^ 2 + k * x - 4 * k := by 
  use 4, 112
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Show (4,112) = (4,112)
    rfl
  ¬∑ -- Show 112 = 7 * 4 ^ 2 + k * 4 - 4 * k
    ring

From $f(f(x))=x$

\Rightarrow(f(x)-x)(f(x)+x-1)=0 .

According to the problem, we know that the equation $f(x)+x-1=0$ has no real roots or has the same roots as the equation $f(x)-x=0$.

Solving this, we get $a \geqslant \frac{5}{4}$.
Therefore, the range of real number $a$ is $\left[\frac{5}{4},+\infty\right)$.

soln_description:
11. Given
$$
f^{\prime}(x)=x^{2}-2(2 a+1) x+3 a(a+2) \text {. }
$$
(1) The x-coordinates of the intersection points of the graph of the function $y=f^{\prime}(x)$ with the x-axis are the real roots of the quadratic equation
$$
x^{2}-2(2 a+1) x+3 a(a+2)=0
$$

which are
$$
x_{1}=a+2, x_{2}=3 a \text {. }
$$

We will discuss the following three cases.
(i) When $x_{1}=x_{2}$, we have
$$
a+2=3 a \Rightarrow a=1 \text {. }
$$

Thus, $x_{1}=x_{2}=3$ is the only intersection point of the graph of the function $y=f^{\prime}(x)$ with the x-axis in the interval $(0,6)$, so $a=1$ is the solution.
(ii) When $x_{1}>x_{2}$, we have
$$
a+2>3 a \Rightarrow a<1 \text {. }
$$

Thus, $x_{2}<x_{1}<3$.
Since the graph of the function $y=f^{\prime}(x)$ has only one intersection point with the x-axis in the interval $(0,6)$, we have $3<x_{1}<6 \leqslant x_{2}$, which means
$$
3<a+2<6 \leqslant 3 a \text {. }
$$

Solving this, we get $2 \leqslant a<4$.
Therefore, the range of real values for $a$ is $-2<a \leqslant 0$, or $a=1$, or $2 \leqslant a<4$.
(2) When $a=-1$, we have
$$
f(x)=\frac{1}{3} x^{3}+x^{2}-3 x+\frac{2}{3} \text {, }
$$

and the roots of $f^{\prime}(x)=x^{2}+2 x-3=0$ are $x_{1}=1, x_{2}=-3$, with only $x_{1}=1$ in the interval $[0,6]$.

Thus, $f(x)$ is decreasing on $[0,1]$ and increasing on $[1,6]$, and
$$
f(0)=\frac{2}{3}, f(1)=-1, f(6)=90 \frac{2}{3} .
$$

Therefore, the maximum value of the function $y=f(x)$ on $[0,6]$ is $90 \frac{2}{3}$, and the minimum value is -1.

soln_description:
1. **Assume the contrary**: Suppose there do not exist three distinct numbers \(a, b, c \in X\) such that \(c = a + b\).

2. **Show that \(0 \notin X\)**: By the Pigeonhole Principle, if \(0 \in X\), then there must be two elements \(a\) and \(-a\) in \(X\) such that \(a + (-a) = 0\). This contradicts our assumption. Hence, \(0 \notin X\).

3. **Induction base cases**: 
   - For \(n = 1\): The set \(X\) has \(n + 2 = 3\) elements, each of absolute value at most 1. The possible elements are \(\{-1, 1\}\). Clearly, there must be a repetition, and thus \(a + b = c\) for some \(a, b, c \in X\).
   - For \(n = 2\): The set \(X\) has \(n + 2 = 4\) elements, each of absolute value at most 2. The possible elements are \(\{-2, -1, 1, 2\}\). Again, by the Pigeonhole Principle, there must be a repetition or a combination such that \(a + b = c\).

4. **Induction hypothesis**: Assume the statement is true for some \(n\). That is, for any set \(X\) of \(n + 2\) integers each of absolute value at most \(n\), there exist three distinct numbers \(a, b, c \in X\) such that \(c = a + b\).

5. **Induction step**: Prove the statement for \(n + 1\). Consider a set \(X\) of \(n + 3\) integers each of absolute value at most \(n + 1\).

6. **Case analysis**:
   - If \(\left|\{n + 1, -n - 1\} \cap X\right| \leq 1\), then the set \(X' = X \setminus \{n + 1, -n - 1\}\) has at least \(n + 2\) elements, all of absolute value at most \(n\). By the induction hypothesis, there exist three distinct numbers \(a, b, c \in X'\) such that \(c = a + b\). Hence, the statement holds for \(n + 1\).
   - Suppose both \(n + 1\) and \(-n - 1\) are in \(X\). Let \(A = \{x \in X \mid x > 0, x \neq n + 1\}\) and \(B = \{x \in X \mid x < 0, x \neq -n - 1\}\). Let \(e = |A|\) and \(f = |B|\).

7. **Subcase analysis**:
   - **\(n\) even**: Let \(n = 2k\). Then \(e + f = n + 1 = 2k + 1\). By the Pigeonhole Principle, some two elements of \(A\) will belong to the same subset among \(\{1, 2k\}, \{2, 2k - 1\}, \ldots, \{k, k + 1\}\). Their sum will be \(2k + 1 \in X\).
   - **\(n\) odd**: Let \(n = 2k + 1\). Then \(e + f = n + 1 = 2k + 2\). If one of \(e\) or \(f\) is greater than \(k + 1\), say \(e > k + 1\), then by the Pigeonhole Principle, some two elements of \(A\) will belong to the same subset among \(\{1, 2k + 1\}, \{2, 2k\}, \ldots, \{k, k + 2\}, \{k + 1\}\). Their sum will be \(2k + 2 \in X\). If \(e = f = k + 1\), then each of the \(k + 1\) sets contains exactly one element of \(A\). Consequently, \(k + 1 \in A\) and \(-k - 1 \in B\). Thus, \(k + 1, -k - 1, 2k + 2 \in X\) and \(k + 1 = (-k - 1) + 2k + 2\), which is a contradiction.

Therefore, the assumption that there do not exist three distinct numbers \(a, b, c \in X\) such that \(c = a + b\) is false.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Let $n$ be an integer, and let $X$ be a set of $n+2$ integers each of absolute value at most $n$. Show that there exist three distinct numbers $a, b, c \in X$ such that $c=a+b$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $n$ be an integer, and let $X$ be a set of $n+2$ integers each of absolute value at most $n$. Show that there exist three distinct numbers $a, b, c \in X$ such that $c=a+b$. -/
theorem number_theory_73735 (n : ‚Ñ§) (X : Finset ‚Ñ§) (hX : X.card = n + 2)
    (hX1 : ‚àÄ x ‚àà X, |x| ‚â§ n) :
    ‚àÉ a ‚àà X, ‚àÉ b ‚àà X, ‚àÉ c ‚àà X, a ‚â† b ‚àß b ‚â† c ‚àß c ‚â† a ‚àß c = a + b := by

Since $\left(1-\frac{1}{z}\right)^{7}=1$, we have,

\begin{array}{l}

\Rightarrow z_{k}=\frac{1}{1-\cos \frac{2 k \pi}{7}-\mathrm{i} \sin \frac{2 k \pi}{7}} \\

=-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{i} \cot \frac{k \pi}{7}(k=0,1, \cdots, 6) . \\
\end{array}
$$

Proof Let $a=\sqrt{x-1}, b=\sqrt{y-1}, c=\sqrt{z-1}$, then

i.e. $\square$

a^{2} b^{2}+b^{2} c^{2}+c^{2} a^{2}+2 a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}=1
\end{array}$$

Thus, equation (25) can be rewritten as

i.e. $\square$

Let $p=b c, q=c a, r=a b$, then equation (26) becomes $p^{2}+q^{2}+r^{2}+2 p q r=1$, and equation (27) can be rewritten as

Using trigonometric transformations, let $p=\cos A, q=\cos B, r=\cos C$, where $A, B, C \in \left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$, and

soln_description:
Proof: First, we prove: $\frac{a}{a^{2}+a b+b c} \leq \frac{1}{b c+b+1}$, which is equivalent to $a(b c+b+1) \leq a^{2}+a b+b c$, or
$$1+a \leq a^{2}+\frac{1}{a}$$

By the two-variable and three-variable mean inequalities, we get
$$\begin{array}{l}
a^{2}+1 \geq 2 a \\
a^{2}+\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{a} \geq 3
\end{array}$$

Adding these two inequalities, we immediately obtain inequality (*). Therefore, we have
$$\begin{array}{l}
\frac{a}{a^{2}+a b+b c} \leq \frac{1}{b c+b+1} \\
\frac{b}{b^{2}+b c+c a} \leq \frac{1}{c a+c+1} \\
\frac{c}{c^{2}+c a+a b} \leq \frac{1}{a b+a+1}
\end{array}$$

Adding these three inequalities, we immediately get
$$\frac{a b}{a^{2}+a b+b c}+\frac{b c}{b^{2}+b c+c a}+\frac{c a}{c^{2}+c a+a b} \leq \frac{1}{a b+a+1}+\frac{1}{b c+b+1}+\frac{1}{c a+c+1}$$

Since $\frac{1}{a b+a+1}+\frac{1}{b c+b+1}+\frac{1}{c a+c+1}$
$$\begin{array}{l}
=\frac{1}{a b+a+1}+\frac{1(a)}{b c(a)+b(a)+1(a)}+\frac{1(a b)}{c a(a b)+c(a b)+1(a b)} \\
=\frac{1}{a b+a+1}+\frac{a}{a b c+a b+a}+\frac{a b}{a+1+a b} \\
=1
\end{array}$$

Therefore, $\frac{a}{a^{2}+a b+b c}+\frac{b}{b^{2}+b c+c a}+\frac{c}{c^{2}+c a+a b} \leq 1$. Q.E.D.
informal_statement:

/- Example 39: Let $a, b, c$ be positive numbers, and satisfy $a b c=1$. Prove:

    (habc : a * b * c = 1) :
    a / (a^2 + a * b + b * c) + b / (b^2 + b * c + c * a) +
    c / (c^2 + c * a + a * b) ‚â§ 1 := by

soln_description:
By Lemma 10, we have $\varphi(p)=p-1$. Since $p$ is a prime number and $p \nmid a$, we get $(p, a)=1$. Taking $m=p$ in Theorem 1, we obtain
$$a^{p-1} \equiv 1(\bmod p)$$

Since $341=11 \times 31$, 341 is not a prime number. By $1024=341 \times 3 + 1$, we get $1024 \equiv 1(\bmod 341)$. By $2^{340}=(2^{10})^{34}=(1024)^{34}$ and Lemma 3, we obtain $2^{340} \equiv 1(\bmod 341)$. Therefore, there exists a positive integer $m$ and an integer $a, m \nmid a$, where $m$ is not a prime number, such that $a^{m-1} \equiv 1(\bmod m)$, which means the converse of Theorem 2 does not hold.
informal_statement: Theorem 2 (Fermat) If $p$ is a prime, $p \nmid a$, then we have $a^{p-1} \equiv 1(\bmod p)$.
informal_proof:
Let $p$ be a prime number and $a$ be a natural number such that $p$ does not divide $a$. We aim to prove that $a^{p-1} \equiv 1 \pmod{p}$.

The proof utilizes the properties of modular arithmetic. We first establish that $p$ is indeed a prime number. The condition that $p$ does not divide $a$ means that $a$ is an element of the multiplicative group of integers modulo $p$. The size of this group, for a prime modulus $p$, is known to be $p-1$.

A fundamental result in number theory states that for any element $a$ in this multiplicative group, raising $a$ to the power of the group's order results in the multiplicative identity, which is $1$ in this context. The order of the group is $p-1$.

Thus, by raising $a$ to the power of $p-1$, we obtain:
$$a^{p-1} \equiv 1 \pmod{p}$$
This directly confirms the statement of the theorem.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Theorem 2 (Fermat) If $p$ is a prime, $p \nmid a$, then we have $a^{p-1} \equiv 1(\bmod p)$. -/
theorem number_theory_7053
    (p a : ‚Ñï)
    (hp : Nat.Prime p)
    (hpa : ¬¨ p ‚à£ a) :
    a^(p - 1) ‚â° 1 [MOD p] := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_7053
    (p a : ‚Ñï)
    (hp : Nat.Prime p)
    (hpa : ¬¨ p ‚à£ a) :
    a^(p - 1) ‚â° 1 [MOD p] := by
  have h1 : Fact p.Prime := ‚ü®hp‚ü©
  rw [‚Üê ZMod.eq_iff_modEq_nat p]
  simp [ZMod.pow_card_sub_one_eq_one, ZMod.natCast_zmod_eq_zero_iff_dvd, h1, hpa]

informal_statement:
Find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that $ 1 ^ { 3 } + 2 ^ { 3 } + 3 ^ { 3 } + \cdots + n ^ { 3 } $ is divisible by $2023$.

Find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that $ 1 ^ { 3 } + 2 ^ { 3 } + 3 ^ { 3 } + \cdots + n ^ { 3 } $ is divisible by $2023$.
informal_proof:
We want to prove that $34$ is the smallest positive integer $n$ for which the sum of the cubes of the first $n$ positive integers, $1^3 + 2^3 + \cdots + n^3$, is divisible by $2023$.

To establish this, we need to show two things:
1.  $34$ itself satisfies the condition.
2.  No positive integer smaller than $34$ satisfies the condition.

**Part 1: Verification that 34 satisfies the condition.**
First, we confirm that $34$ is a positive integer, which is true ($0 < 34$).
Next, we need to show that $2023$ divides the sum of the cubes from $1$ to $34$. The sum of the first $n$ cubes is given by the formula $\left(\frac{n(n+1)}{2}\right)^2$.
For $n=34$, the sum is $\left(\frac{34(34+1)}{2}\right)^2 = \left(\frac{34 \times 35}{2}\right)^2 = (17 \times 35)^2 = (595)^2$.
A direct computation or check confirms that $595^2 = 354025$, and $354025$ is indeed divisible by $2023$. Specifically, $354025 = 175 \times 2023$. Thus, $34$ belongs to the set of integers satisfying the condition.

**Part 2: Verification of minimality.**
Now, we must show that $34$ is the smallest such positive integer. We will do this by contradiction.
Assume there exists a positive integer $n$ such that $n < 34$ and $2023$ divides the sum of the cubes from $1$ to $n$. Let $S_n = \sum_{i=1}^n i^3$. The assumption is $0 < n < 34$ and $2023 \mid S_n$.

We examine the values of $n$ from $1$ to $33$:
*   If $n=0$, the condition $0 < n$ is not met.
*   For $n=1$, $S_1 = 1^3 = 1$. $2023$ does not divide $1$.
*   For $n=2$, $S_2 = 1^3 + 2^3 = 1 + 8 = 9$. $2023$ does not divide $9$.
*   For $n=3$, $S_3 = 1^3 + 2^3 + 3^3 = 1 + 8 + 27 = 36$. $2023$ does not divide $36$.

We systematically check all positive integers $n$ such that $1 \le n \le 33$. For each such $n$, we calculate $S_n = \left(\frac{n(n+1)}{2}\right)^2$ and verify if $2023$ divides $S_n$.
It turns out that for every $n$ in the range $\{1, 2, \ldots, 33\}$, the sum $S_n$ is not divisible by $2023$. This contradicts our assumption that there exists an $n < 34$ for which $2023 \mid S_n$.

Therefore, $34$ is indeed the smallest positive integer for which the sum of the first $n$ cubes is divisible by $2023$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that $ 1 ^ { 3 } + 2 ^ { 3 } + 3 ^ { 3 } + \cdots + n ^ { 3 } $ is divisible by $2023$.

Find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that $ 1 ^ { 3 } + 2 ^ { 3 } + 3 ^ { 3 } + \cdots + n ^ { 3 } $ is divisible by $2023$. -/
theorem number_theory_4845 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : n > 0) :
    IsLeast {n | 0 < n ‚àß 2023 ‚à£ ‚àë i in Finset.Icc 1 n, i^3} 34 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_4845 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : n > 0) :
    IsLeast {n | 0 < n ‚àß 2023 ‚à£ ‚àë i in Finset.Icc 1 n, i^3} 34 := by
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Show that 34 is in the set, i.e., 0 < 34 and 2023 divides the sum of cubes from 1 to 34
    constructor
    ¬∑ -- Show 0 < 34
      norm_num
    ¬∑ -- Show 2023 divides the sum of cubes from 1 to 34
      native_decide
  ¬∑ -- Show that 34 is the smallest
    intro n hn
    rcases hn with ‚ü®hn_pos, hn_div‚ü©
    by_contra h
    push_neg at h
    interval_cases n <;> try { norm_num [Finset.sum_Icc_succ_top] at hn_div <;> all_goals omega }
    <;> try { contradiction }

soln_description:
[Solution] In the original identity, let $y=1$, then we get the identity

that is $\square$
$$f(x) \equiv f(x) f(1)-f(x+1)+1, x \in Q .$$
$$f(x+1) \equiv f(x)+1$$

Thus, for all $x \in Q, n \in Z$, we have $f(x+n)=f(x)+n$.
Therefore $\square$
$$f(n)=f(1)+n-1=n+1$$

Next, in the original identity, take $x=\frac{1}{n}, y=n, x \in Z$, we get
$$f\left(\frac{1}{n} \cdot n\right)=f\left(\frac{1}{n}\right) \cdot f(n)-f\left(\frac{1}{n}+n\right)+1$$

Thus $2=f\left(\frac{1}{n}\right)(n+1)-f\left(\frac{1}{n}\right)-n+1$,
which means $f\left(\frac{1}{n}\right)=1+\frac{1}{n}$.
Finally, take $x=p, y=\frac{1}{q}, p \in Z, q \in N$, we get
$$f\left(p \cdot \frac{1}{q}\right)=f(p) \cdot f\left(\frac{1}{q}\right)-f\left(p+\frac{1}{q}\right)+1 .$$

This leads to $f\left(\frac{p}{q}\right)=(p+1)\left(\frac{1}{q}+1\right)-\frac{1}{q}-p$
$$=\frac{p}{q}+1$$

Therefore, the only function $f(x)=x+1$ satisfies all the conditions in the problem.
informal_statement:
$6 \cdot 140$ Find all functions $f: Q \rightarrow Q$ (where $Q$ is the set of rational numbers) satisfying $f(1)=2$ and
$f(x y) \equiv f(x) f(y)-f(x+y)+1, x, y \in Q$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $6 \cdot 140$ Find all functions $f: Q \rightarrow Q$ (where $Q$ is the set of rational numbers) satisfying $f(1)=2$ and
$f(x y) \equiv f(x) f(y)-f(x+y)+1, x, y \in Q$. -/
theorem algebra_601199 {f : ‚Ñö ‚Üí ‚Ñö} (h1 : f 1 = 2) (h2 : ‚àÄ x y, f (x * y) = f x * f y - f (x + y) + 1) :
    ‚àÄ x, f x = x + 1 := by

soln_description: 4. Replace 2011 by any positive odd integer $n$. We first show by induction that $a_{m}=$ $3^{m} 2^{n-m}-1$ for $m=0,1, \ldots, n-1$. This is certainly true for $m=0$. Suppose it's true for some $m1$, the odd part is $3^{m+1} 2^{n-m-1}-1$ which is $a_{m+1}$. Now $a_{n-1}=3^{n-1} 2^{1}-1$. Thus $3 a_{n-1}+1=3^{n} 2-2=2\left(3^{n}-1\right)$. When $n$ is odd, $3^{n} \equiv-1 \quad(\bmod 4)$. Thus $4 \nmid 3^{n}-1$. Hence the odd part of $2\left(3^{n}-1\right)$ is $\frac{3^{n}-1}{2}$ and this is the value of $a_{n}$.
informal_statement: 4. Any positive integer $n$ can be written in the form $n=2^{a} q$, where $a \geq 0$ and $q$ is odd. We call $q$ the odd part of $n$. Define the sequence $a_{0}, a_{1}, \ldots$, as follows: $a_{0}=2^{2011}-1$ and for $m \geq 0, a_{m+1}$ is the odd part of $3 a_{m}+1$. Find $a_{2011}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def odd_part (n : ‚Ñï) := n / (2 ^ (Nat.factorization n 2))

/- 4. Any positive integer $n$ can be written in the form $n=2^{a} q$, where $a \geq 0$ and $q$ is odd. We call $q$ the odd part of $n$. Define the sequence $a_{0}, a_{1}, \ldots$, as follows: $a_{0}=2^{2011}-1$ and for $m \geq 0, a_{m+1}$ is the odd part of $3 a_{m}+1$. Find $a_{2011}$. -/
theorem number_theory_99961 {a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï}
    (ha0 : a 0 = 2 ^ 2011 - 1)
    (ham : ‚àÄ m, a (m + 1) = odd_part (3 * a m + 1)) :
    a 2011 = (3 ^ 2011 - 1) / 2 := by

soln_description:
Let $u=\sqrt{x-\frac{1}{x}}, v=\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{x}}$.
Then $u+v=x \neq 0, u^{2}-v^{2}=x-1$.
Dividing the two equations gives $u-v=1-\frac{1}{x}$.
Thus $2 u=x+1-\frac{1}{x}=u^{2}+1$
$\Rightarrow(u-1)^{2}=0 \Rightarrow u=\sqrt{x-\frac{1}{x}}=1$
$\Rightarrow x=\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2}$ (negative value discarded).
informal_statement: Example 2 Solve the equation $\sqrt{x-\frac{1}{x}}+\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{x}}=x$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 2 Solve the equation $\sqrt{x-\frac{1}{x}}+\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{x}}=x$. -/
theorem algebra_296721 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : x ‚â† 0) :
    Real.sqrt (x - 1/x) + Real.sqrt (1 - 1/x) = x ‚Üî
    x = (1 + Real.sqrt 5)/2 := by

informal_statement: Applying Zu Geng's principle (geometric bodies between two parallel planes, if any plane parallel to these two planes cuts the bodies and the areas of the two cross-sections are equal, then the volumes of these two geometric bodies are equal), please calculate: the area of the plane geometric figure enclosed by the curves $y=\ln x$, $y=\ln \left( x-3 \right)$, and the lines $y=\pm 1$ is equal to¬†___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Applying Zu Geng's principle (geometric bodies between two parallel planes, if any plane parallel to these two planes cuts the bodies and the areas of the two cross-sections are equal, then the volumes of these two geometric bodies are equal), please calculate: the area of the plane geometric figure enclosed by the curves $y=\ln x$, $y=\ln \left( x-3 \right)$, and the lines $y=\pm 1$ is equal to¬†___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___. -/
theorem calculus_11081 :
  ‚à´ x in (3)..(4), max (max (log x - 1) (log (x - 3) - 1)) 0 = 6 := by

soln_description:
II. (50 points)
Since $f(x)=f(x)-f\left(x_{3}\right)$
$$
=\left(x-x_{3}\right)\left[x^{2}+\left(a+x_{3}\right) x+x_{3}^{2}+a x_{3}+b\right] \text {. }
$$

Therefore, $x_{1}, x_{2}$ are the roots of the equation $x^{2}+\left(a+x_{3}\right) x+x_{3}^{2}+a x_{3}+b=0$. From (1), we have
$$
\left(a+x_{3}\right)^{2}-4\left(x_{3}^{2}+a x_{3}+b\right)=\lambda^{2},
$$

which simplifies to
$$
3 x_{3}^{2}+2 a x_{3}+\lambda^{2}+4 b-a^{2}=0 \text {. }
$$

From (2), we get
$$
\begin{array}{c}
x_{3}=\frac{1}{3}\left[-a+\sqrt{4 a^{2}-12 b-3 \lambda^{2}}\right] \\
4 a^{2}-12 b-3 \lambda^{2} \geq 0
\end{array}
$$

and
$$
4 a^{2}-12 b-3 \lambda^{2} \geq 0
$$

It is easy to see that $f(x)=x^{3}+a x^{2}+b x+c$
$$
=\left(x+\frac{a}{3}\right)^{3}-\left(\frac{a^{2}}{3}-b\right)\left(x+\frac{a}{3}\right)+\frac{2}{27} a^{3}+c-\frac{1}{3} a b .
$$

From $f\left(x_{3}\right)=0$, we get $\frac{1}{3} a b-\frac{2}{27} a^{3}-c=\left(x_{3}+\frac{a}{3}\right)^{3}-\left(\frac{a^{2}}{3}-b\right)\left(x_{3}+\frac{a}{3}\right)$

From (1), we have $x_{1}+\frac{a}{3}=\frac{1}{3} \sqrt{4 a^{2}-12 b-3 \lambda^{2}}=\frac{2 \sqrt{3}}{3} \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}}{3}-b-\frac{\lambda^{2}}{4}}$.
Let $p=\frac{a^{2}}{3}-b$, from (2) and (3) we know $p \geqslant \frac{\lambda^{2}}{4}$, so
$$
\frac{1}{3} a b-\frac{2}{27} a^{3}-c=\frac{2 \sqrt{3}}{9} \sqrt{p-\frac{\lambda^{2}}{4}}\left(p-\lambda^{2}\right) .
$$

Let $y=\sqrt{p-\frac{\lambda^{2}}{4}}$, then $y \geqslant 0$ and $\frac{1}{3} a b-\frac{2}{27} a^{3}-c=\frac{2 \sqrt{3}}{9} y\left(y^{2}-\frac{3}{4} \lambda^{2}\right)$.
Since $y^{3}-\frac{3 \lambda^{2}}{4} y+\frac{\lambda^{3}}{4}=y^{3}-\frac{3 \lambda^{2}}{4} y=\left(\frac{\lambda}{2}\right)^{3}+\frac{3 \lambda^{2}}{4} \cdot \frac{\lambda}{2}$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
=\left(y-\frac{\lambda}{2}\right)\left(y^{2}+\frac{\lambda}{2} y+\frac{\lambda^{2}}{4}-\frac{3 \lambda^{2}}{4}\right) \\
=\left(y-\frac{\lambda}{2}\right)^{2}(y+\lambda) \geqslant 0,
\end{array}
$$

Therefore,
$$
\frac{1}{3} a b-\frac{2}{27} a^{3}-c \geqslant-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{18} \lambda^{3} \text {. }
$$

Thus,
$$
2 a^{3}+27 c-9 a b \leqslant \frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{2} \lambda^{3} .
$$

Hence,
$$
\frac{2 a^{3}+27 c-9 a b}{\lambda^{3}} \leqslant \frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{2} \text {. }
$$

Taking $a=2 \sqrt{3}, b=2, c=0, \lambda=2$, then $f(x)=x^{3}+2 \sqrt{3} x^{2}+2 x$ has roots $-\sqrt{3}-1, -\sqrt{3}+1, 0$. Clearly, the assumptions hold, and
$$
\frac{2 a^{3}+27 c-9 a b}{\lambda^{3}}=\frac{1}{8}(48 \sqrt{3}-36 \sqrt{3})=\frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{2} .
$$

In conclusion, the maximum value of $\frac{2 a^{3}+27 c-9 a b}{\lambda^{3}}$ is $\frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{2}$.
informal_statement:
II. (50 points)
Real numbers $a, b, c$ and a positive number $\lambda$ make $f(x)=x^{3}+a x^{2}+b x+c$ have 3 real roots $x_{1}, x_{2}$, $x_{3}$, and satisfy
(1) $x_{2}-x_{1}=\lambda$;
(2) $x_{3}>\frac{1}{2}\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)$.
Find the maximum value of $\frac{2 a^{3}+27 c-9 a b}{\lambda^{3}}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- II. (50 points)
Real numbers $a, b, c$ and a positive number $\lambda$ make $f(x)=x^{3}+a x^{2}+b x+c$ have 3 real roots $x_{1}, x_{2}$, $x_{3}$, and satisfy
(1) $x_{2}-x_{1}=\lambda$;
(2) $x_{3}>\frac{1}{2}\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)$.
Find the maximum value of $\frac{2 a^{3}+27 c-9 a b}{\lambda^{3}}$. -/
theorem algebra_283485 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (lambda : ‚Ñù) (hlambda : lambda > 0)
    (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hf : f = fun x => x^3 + a * x^2 + b * x + c)
    (x1 x2 x3 : ‚Ñù) (hx1 : f x1 = 0) (hx2 : f x2 = 0) (hx3 : f x3 = 0)
    (hxs : x2 - x1 = lambda) (hxs' : x3 > (x1 + x2) / 2) :
    (2 * a^3 + 27 * c - 9 * a * b) / lambda^3 ‚â§ 3 * Real.sqrt 3 / 2 := by

soln_description:
Solution (Vivi and Jana): It works trivially for one. The inequality is satisfied for three. The inequality can be factorized as follows:

$$
\frac{1}{6}\left(x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}\right)^{2}\left(\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)^{2}+\left(x_{2}-x_{3}\right)^{2}+\left(x_{3}-x_{1}\right)^{2}\right) \geq 0
$$

It does not work for all other figures. We provide counterexamples:

- $n=2: x_{1}=0, x_{2}=-1$.
- $n>3$ : $x_{1}=x_{2}=-2, x_{3}=3, x_{4}=\ldots=x_{n}=0$. Since the second bracket is -1, we still have to show that the first bracket is positive. This is of the form

$$
\left(\frac{(-2)^{n}+(-2)^{n}+3^{n}+0^{n}+\ldots+0^{n}}{n}-(-2) \cdot(-2) \cdot 3 \cdot \ldots \cdot 0\right)=\frac{2 \cdot(-2)^{n}+3^{n}}{n}
$$

Exclusion leads to

$$
\frac{8 \cdot(-2)^{n-2}+9 \cdot 3^{n-2}}{n}
$$

This is positive for $n \geq 2$.

## Marking Scheme:

- The case $n=3$ gives 3 points.
- An upper bound is worth 1 point.
- The remaining cases are worth 3 points, with 1 point deducted for each forgotten case.
informal_statement:
4. determine all natural numbers $n$ so that for any real numbers $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}$ applies:

$$
\left(\frac{x_{1}^{n}+\ldots+x_{n}^{n}}{n}-x_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot x_{n}\right)\left(x_{1}+\ldots+x_{n}\right) \geq 0
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 4. determine all natural numbers $n$ so that for any real numbers $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}$ applies:

$$
\left(\frac{x_{1}^{n}+\ldots+x_{n}^{n}}{n}-x_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot x_{n}\right)\left(x_{1}+\ldots+x_{n}\right) \geq 0
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_266310 (n : ‚Ñï) :
    (‚àÄ x : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù,
      ((‚àë i : Fin n, (x i)^n) / n - ‚àè i : Fin n, x i) * (‚àë i : Fin n, x i) ‚â• 0) ‚Üî
    n = 1 ‚à® n = 3 := by

soln_description:
1. Let \( a \) be an odd integer. We need to prove that \( a^{2^m} + 2^{2^m} \) and \( a^{2^n} + 2^{2^n} \) are relatively prime for all positive integers \( n \) and \( m \) with \( n \neq m \).

2. Without loss of generality, assume \( n > m \). Consider any prime \( p \) that divides \( a^{2^m} + 2^{2^m} \). We have:
   \[
   a^{2^m} \equiv -2^{2^m} \pmod{p}
   \]

3. Raise both sides to the power of \( 2^{n-m} \):
   \[
   \left(a^{2^m}\right)^{2^{n-m}} \equiv \left(-2^{2^m}\right)^{2^{n-m}} \pmod{p}
   \]
   Simplifying, we get:
   \[
   a^{2^n} \equiv (-1)^{2^{n-m}} \cdot 2^{2^n} \equiv 2^{2^n} \pmod{p}
   \]

4. This implies that \( p \) divides \( a^{2^n} - 2^{2^n} \).

5. Now, assume for contradiction that \( \gcd(a^{2^m} + 2^{2^m}, a^{2^n} + 2^{2^n}) \neq 1 \). This means there exists a prime \( p \) that divides both \( a^{2^m} + 2^{2^m} \) and \( a^{2^n} + 2^{2^n} \).

6. Since \( p \) divides \( a^{2^n} - 2^{2^n} \) and \( a^{2^n} + 2^{2^n} \), it must also divide their difference:
   \[
   (a^{2^n} + 2^{2^n}) - (a^{2^n} - 2^{2^n}) = 2 \cdot 2^{2^n} = 2^{2^n + 1}
   \]

7. Since \( a \) is an odd integer, \( a^{2^m} + 2^{2^m} \) is also odd. Therefore, \( p \neq 2 \).

8. However, \( p \) must divide \( 2^{2^n + 1} \), which is a power of 2. This is a contradiction because \( p \) cannot be 2 and there are no other prime factors of \( 2^{2^n + 1} \).

9. Therefore, our assumption that \( \gcd(a^{2^m} + 2^{2^m}, a^{2^n} + 2^{2^n}) \neq 1 \) must be false. Hence, \( \gcd(a^{2^m} + 2^{2^m}, a^{2^n} + 2^{2^n}) = 1 \) for all positive integers \( n \) and \( m \) with \( n \neq m \).

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Let $a$ be an odd integer. Prove that $a^{2^m}+2^{2^m}$ and $a^{2^n}+2^{2^n}$ are relatively prime for all positive integers $n$ and $m$ with $n\not= m$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a$ be an odd integer. Prove that $a^{2^m}+2^{2^m}$ and $a^{2^n}+2^{2^n}$ are relatively prime for all positive integers $n$ and $m$ with $n\not= m$. -/
theorem number_theory_65091 (a m n : ‚Ñï) (ha : Odd a) (hm : 0 < m) (hn : 0 < n)
    (hmn : m ‚â† n) :
    Nat.Coprime (a^(2^m) + 2^(2^m)) (a^(2^n) + 2^(2^n)) := by

informal_statement:
If $10^{2y} = 25$, then $10^{ - y}$ equals: 
$\textbf{(A)}\ -\frac{1}{5}\qquad \textbf{(B)}\ \frac{1}{625}\qquad \textbf{(C)}\ \frac{1}{50}\qquad \textbf{(D)}\ \frac{1}{25}\qquad \textbf{(E)}\ \frac{1}{5}$
informal_proof:
We are given the equation $10^{2y} = 25$.
We first establish an identity for the left-hand side using properties of exponents: $10^{2y} = (10^y)^2$.
Substituting this into the given equation yields $(10^y)^2 = 25$.
Since $10$ raised to any real power $y$ must be positive, we know $10^y > 0$.
Taking the positive square root of both sides of $(10^y)^2 = 25$, we find that $10^y = 5$.
Now, we consider the expression $10^{-y}$. Using the property of negative exponents, $a^{-b} = \frac{1}{a^b}$, we can write $10^{-y} = \frac{1}{10^y}$.
Substituting the previously found value $10^y = 5$, we obtain $10^{-y} = \frac{1}{5}$.
Therefore, if $10^{2y} = 25$, then $10^{-y} = \frac{1}{5}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If $10^{2y} = 25$, then $10^{ - y}$ equals: 
$\textbf{(A)}\ -\frac{1}{5}\qquad \textbf{(B)}\ \frac{1}{625}\qquad \textbf{(C)}\ \frac{1}{50}\qquad \textbf{(D)}\ \frac{1}{25}\qquad \textbf{(E)}\ \frac{1}{5}$ -/
theorem algebra_96288 (y : ‚Ñù) (h : (10 : ‚Ñù)^(2 * y) = 25) : (10 : ‚Ñù)^(-y) = 1 / 5 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_96288 (y : ‚Ñù) (h : (10 : ‚Ñù)^(2 * y) = 25) : (10 : ‚Ñù)^(-y) = 1 / 5 := by
  have h1 : (10 : ‚Ñù) ^ (2 * y) = ((10 : ‚Ñù) ^ y) ^ 2 := by
    rw [‚Üê Real.rpow_natCast, ‚Üê Real.rpow_mul]
    ring_nf
    all_goals linarith
  rw [h1] at h
  have h2 : (10 : ‚Ñù) ^ y > 0 := by
    positivity
  have h3 : (10 : ‚Ñù) ^ y = 5 := by
    nlinarith [h, h2]
  have h4 : (10 : ‚Ñù) ^ (-y) = 1 / ((10 : ‚Ñù) ^ y) := by
    simp [‚Üê Real.rpow_neg]
  rw [h4]
  rw [h3]

soln_description:
1. Let \( m \) and \( n \) be any two odd numbers with \( n < m \). We need to find the largest integer that divides all possible numbers of the form \( m^2 - n^2 \).

2. We start by expressing \( m^2 - n^2 \) using the difference of squares formula:
   \[
   m^2 - n^2 = (m - n)(m + n)
   \]

3. Since \( m \) and \( n \) are both odd, both \( m - n \) and \( m + n \) are even numbers. This is because the difference and sum of two odd numbers are always even. Therefore, \( m - n \) and \( m + n \) can be written as:
   \[
   m - n = 2a \quad \text{and} \quad m + n = 2b
   \]
   for some integers \( a \) and \( b \).

4. Substituting these into the expression for \( m^2 - n^2 \), we get:
   \[
   m^2 - n^2 = (2a)(2b) = 4ab
   \]
   This shows that \( m^2 - n^2 \) is always divisible by 4.

5. Next, we need to determine if there is a larger integer that always divides \( m^2 - n^2 \). To do this, we consider the possible values of \( m^2 \) and \( n^2 \) modulo 8. The quadratic residues modulo 8 are 0, 1, and 4. Since \( m \) and \( n \) are odd, their squares modulo 8 can only be 1:
   \[
   m^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{8} \quad \text{and} \quad n^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}
   \]

6. Therefore, we have:
   \[
   m^2 - n^2 \equiv 1 - 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{8}
   \]
   This means that \( m^2 - n^2 \) is always divisible by 8.

7. To check if \( m^2 - n^2 \) is divisible by 16, consider specific values of \( m \) and \( n \). For example, let \( m = 3 \) and \( n = 1 \):
   \[
   m^2 - n^2 = 3^2 - 1^2 = 9 - 1 = 8
   \]
   Here, 8 is not divisible by 16, so \( m^2 - n^2 \) is not necessarily divisible by 16.

8. Therefore, the largest integer that divides all possible values of \( m^2 - n^2 \) is 8.

The final answer is \( \boxed{8} \).
informal_statement:
Let $m$ and $n$ be any two odd numbers, with $n$ less than $m$. The largest integer which divides all possible numbers of the form $m^2-n^2$ is:

$ \textbf{(A)}\ 2\qquad\textbf{(B)}\ 4\qquad\textbf{(C)}\ 6\qquad\textbf{(D)}\ 8\qquad\textbf{(E)}\ 16 $
informal_proof:
Let $m$ and $n$ be any two odd integers such that $n < m$. We first show that $m^2 - n^2$ is always divisible by 8.
Since $m$ is odd, $m$ can be written in the form $2k+1$ for some integer $k$. The square of an odd number modulo 8 is always 1. Specifically, if $m \pmod 8 \in \{1, 3, 5, 7\}$, then $m^2 \pmod 8 = 1$. This is because $1^2 \equiv 1 \pmod 8$, $3^2 = 9 \equiv 1 \pmod 8$, $5^2 = 25 \equiv 1 \pmod 8$, and $7^2 = 49 \equiv 1 \pmod 8$.
Since $m$ is odd, $m^2 \equiv 1 \pmod 8$. Similarly, since $n$ is odd, $n^2 \equiv 1 \pmod 8$.
Therefore, $m^2 - n^2 \equiv 1 - 1 \equiv 0 \pmod 8$. This shows that $m^2 - n^2$ is divisible by 8.

Next, we show that 8 is the greatest integer with this property. We need to show that if $x$ is an integer such that for all odd $m, n$ with $n < m$, $x$ divides $m^2 - n^2$, then $x \le 8$.
Consider the specific case where $m=3$ and $n=1$. Both are odd, and $n < m$. Then $m^2 - n^2 = 3^2 - 1^2 = 9 - 1 = 8$. Since $x$ must divide all such differences, $x$ must divide 8.
Consider the specific case where $m=5$ and $n=3$. Both are odd, and $n < m$. Then $m^2 - n^2 = 5^2 - 3^2 = 25 - 9 = 16$. Since $x$ must divide all such differences, $x$ must divide 16.
As $x$ must divide both 8 and 16, it must divide their greatest common divisor, which is 8. Since $x$ divides 8, and $8 \neq 0$, we have $x \le 8$.
Thus, 8 is the greatest integer that divides $m^2 - n^2$ for all odd $m, n$ with $n < m$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $m$ and $n$ be any two odd numbers, with $n$ less than $m$. The largest integer which divides all possible numbers of the form $m^2-n^2$ is:

$ \textbf{(A)}\ 2\qquad\textbf{(B)}\ 4\qquad\textbf{(C)}\ 6\qquad\textbf{(D)}\ 8\qquad\textbf{(E)}\ 16 $ -/
theorem number_theory_72114 :
    IsGreatest {x | ‚àÄ m n : ‚Ñ§, Odd m ‚Üí Odd n ‚Üí n < m ‚Üí x ‚à£ m ^ 2 - n ^ 2} 8 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_72114 :
    IsGreatest {x | ‚àÄ m n : ‚Ñ§, Odd m ‚Üí Odd n ‚Üí n < m ‚Üí x ‚à£ m ^ 2 - n ^ 2} 8 := by
  constructor 
  ¬∑ -- Show that 8 is in the set
    intro m n h_odd_m h_odd_n h_n_lt_m
    have h1 : m % 8 = 1 ‚à® m % 8 = 3 ‚à® m % 8 = 5 ‚à® m % 8 = 7 := by
      rcases h_odd_m with ‚ü®k, hk‚ü©
      omega
    have h2 : n % 8 = 1 ‚à® n % 8 = 3 ‚à® n % 8 = 5 ‚à® n % 8 = 7 := by
      rcases h_odd_n with ‚ü®k, hk‚ü©
      omega
    have h3 : m^2 % 8 = 1 := by
      rcases h1 with (h | h | h | h)
      ¬∑ norm_num [pow_two, Int.mul_emod, h]
      ¬∑ norm_num [pow_two, Int.mul_emod, h]
      ¬∑ norm_num [pow_two, Int.mul_emod, h]
      ¬∑ norm_num [pow_two, Int.mul_emod, h]
    have h4 : n^2 % 8 = 1 := by
      rcases h2 with (h | h | h | h)
      ¬∑ norm_num [pow_two, Int.mul_emod, h]
      ¬∑ norm_num [pow_two, Int.mul_emod, h]
      ¬∑ norm_num [pow_two, Int.mul_emod, h]
      ¬∑ norm_num [pow_two, Int.mul_emod, h]
    have h5 : (m^2 - n^2) % 8 = 0 := by
      omega
    exact Int.dvd_of_emod_eq_zero h5
  ¬∑ -- Show that 8 is greatest
    intro x h_x
    have h1 := h_x 3 1 (by decide) (by decide) (by norm_num)
    have h2 := h_x 5 3 (by decide) (by decide) (by norm_num)
    norm_num at h1 h2
    have h3 : x ‚â§ 8 := by
      exact Int.le_of_dvd (show (0 : ‚Ñ§) < 8 by norm_num) h1
    linarith

soln_description:
To prove that (1) is equivalent to (under the condition that the left side is not less than the right side)
$$2 m \equiv a^{20}+b^{11}\left(\bmod 2^{2011}\right)$$

We first prove: there exist odd numbers $a, b$ satisfying (2).
Notice that, for any odd numbers $x, y$, we have
$$x^{11}-y^{11}=(x-y)\left(x^{10}+x^{9} y+\cdots+y^{10}\right),$$

The right side of the above equation, $x^{10}+x^{9} y+\cdots+y^{10}$, is the sum of 11 odd numbers, which must be odd. Therefore, $x^{11}-y^{11} \equiv 0\left(\bmod 2^{2011}\right) \Leftrightarrow x \equiv y\left(\bmod 2^{2011}\right)$. This indicates that, modulo $2^{2011}$, the numbers $1^{2011}$, $3^{2011}, \cdots, \left(2^{2011}-1\right)^{11}$ are a permutation of the numbers $1, 3, 5, \cdots, 2^{2011}-1$. Thus, there exists an odd number $b_{0}$ such that $b_{0}^{11} \equiv 2 m-1\left(\bmod 2^{2011}\right)$.

Now, take a sufficiently small negative odd number $b$ such that $b \equiv b_{0}\left(\bmod 2^{2011}\right)$ and $2 m-1-b^{11} \geqslant 0$, then $2 m-1-b^{11} \equiv 2 m-1-b_{0}^{11} \equiv 0\left(\bmod 2^{2011}\right)$. Therefore, let $(a, b, k) = \left(1, b, \frac{2 m-1-b^{11}}{2^{2011}}\right)$, which satisfies (1).

Thus, there exist $a, b, k$ that satisfy the conditions.
informal_statement:
Example 6 Let $m$ be a positive integer, prove: there exist integers $a, b, k$, such that $a, b$ are both odd, and $k \geqslant 0$, and
$$2 m=a^{20}+b^{11}+k \cdot 2^{2011}.$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 6 Let $m$ be a positive integer, prove: there exist integers $a, b, k$, such that $a, b$ are both odd, and $k \geqslant 0$, and
$$2 m=a^{20}+b^{11}+k \cdot 2^{2011}.$$ -/
theorem number_theory_7923 (m : ‚Ñ§) (hm : m > 0) :
    ‚àÉ a b k : ‚Ñ§, Odd a ‚àß Odd b ‚àß k ‚â• 0 ‚àß 2 * m = a ^ 20 + b ^ 11 + k * 2 ^ 2011 := by

soln_description: 3. When $n$ is even, we can take $a=2n, b=n$. If $n$ is odd, let $p$ be the smallest odd prime that does not divide $n$, then $p-1$ either has no odd prime factors (i.e., is a power of 2), or its odd prime factors all divide $n$. Therefore, $a=pn, b=(p-1)n$ have the number of distinct prime factors equal to the number of distinct prime factors of $n$ plus 1.
informal_statement: 3 Prove: Any positive integer $n$ can be expressed as $a-b$, where $a$ and $b$ are positive integers, and the number of distinct prime factors of $a$ and $b$ is the same.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3 Prove: Any positive integer $n$ can be expressed as $a-b$, where $a$ and $b$ are positive integers, and the number of distinct prime factors of $a$ and $b$ is the same. -/
theorem number_theory_8073 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : n > 0) :
    ‚àÉ a b, a > 0 ‚àß b > 0 ‚àß a - b = n ‚àß
      (Nat.primeFactors a).card = (Nat.primeFactors b).card := by

soln_description:
Consider the polynomial $P_{a}(x)=P(a+x)+P(a-x)$. The sign of the coefficient of this polynomial at $x^{k}$ coincides with the sign of the $k$-th derivative of the function $P_{a}$ at $x=0$. For even $k$, this derivative is equal to $2 P^{(k)}(a)$, and for odd $k$, it is zero. In turn, the sign of $P^{(k)}(a)$ for large $a$ coincides with the sign of the leading coefficient of the polynomial $P$. Therefore, for sufficiently large in absolute value $a$, all coefficients of the polynomial $P_{a}$ at odd powers are zero, and at even powers - of the same sign. Hence, it has no roots.

If $P(m)+P(n)=0$, then the number $x=1 / 2(m-n)$ is a root of the polynomial $P_{a}$, where $a=1 / 2(m+n)$. This means that the sum $m+n=2 a$ is bounded in absolute value. Therefore, one of the values of $2 a$ of this sum occurs infinitely many times.

Thus, the corresponding polynomial $P_{a}$ has infinitely many roots, which means it is identically zero.

But the equality $P(-x+a) \equiv-P(x+a)$ means that the graph of the polynomial $P$ is symmetric with respect to the point $(a, 0)$.
informal_statement:
## [

## [ Graphs and GMT on the Coordinate Plane ]

$\left[\begin{array}{lll}\text { Central Symmetry (other) } \\ \text { M } \quad \text { Monotonicity and Boundedness }\end{array}\right]$

A polynomial $P(x)$ with real coefficients is such that the equation $P(m)+P(n)=0$ has infinitely many solutions in integers $m$ and $n$.

Prove that the graph of $y=P(x)$ has a center of symmetry.

#
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## [

## [ Graphs and GMT on the Coordinate Plane ]

$\left[\begin{array}{lll}\text { Central Symmetry (other) } \\ \text { M } \quad \text { Monotonicity and Boundedness }\end{array}\right]$

A polynomial $P(x)$ with real coefficients is such that the equation $P(m)+P(n)=0$ has infinitely many solutions in integers $m$ and $n$.

Prove that the graph of $y=P(x)$ has a center of symmetry.

# -/
theorem algebra_137692 {P : Polynomial ‚Ñù} (hP : ‚àÄ N : ‚Ñï, ‚àÉ m n : ‚Ñ§,
    m > N ‚àß n > N ‚àß P.eval (m : ‚Ñù) + P.eval (n : ‚Ñù) = 0) :
    ‚àÉ c : ‚Ñù, ‚àÄ x : ‚Ñù, P.eval x = -P.eval (c - x) := by

soln_description:
Let $k$ satisfy the conditions of the problem.
From the given, we have
$y_{3}=2 k-2, y_{4}=8 k^{2}-20 k+13$.
Since $y_{3}$ is an even number, there exists an integer $a \geqslant 0$ such that $2 k-2=4 a^{2}$, then $k=2 a^{2}+1$, i.e., $k \geqslant 1$.
Thus, $y_{4}=32 a^{4}-8 a^{2}+1$.
When $a=0$, $k=1$.
When $a>0$, let $b (b \geqslant 0)$ be an integer satisfying $y_{4}=b^{2}$.
Thus, $16 a^{4}-8 a^{2}+1+16 a^{4}=b^{2}$, i.e., $\left(4 a^{2}-1\right)^{2}+\left(4 a^{2}\right)^{2}=b^{2}$.
Since $4 a^{2}-1$ and $4 a^{2}$ are coprime, $4 a^{2}-1, 4 a^{2}, b$ form a primitive Pythagorean triple. Therefore, there exist coprime positive integers $m, n$ such that
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
4 a^{2}-1=n^{2}-m^{2}, \\
4 a^{2}=2 m n, \\
b=n^{2}+m^{2} .
\end{array}\right.
$$

From (1) and (2), we get
$n^{2}-m^{2}+1=2 m n$, i.e.,
$(n+m)^{2}-2 n^{2}=1$.
From (2), we have $n m=2 a^{2}$. Since $m, n$ are coprime, $m, n$ have different parities. But $m$ cannot be even, otherwise, it would imply $n^{2} \equiv-1(\bmod 4)$, which is impossible.
Therefore, $m$ is odd, and $n$ is even.
Thus, there exists an integer $t \geqslant 0$ such that $n=2 t^{2}$.
Using (4), we get
$$
2 n^{2}=8 t^{4}=(n+m-1)(n+m+1).
$$

So, $2 t^{4}=\frac{n+m-1}{2} \cdot \frac{n+m+1}{2}=u(u+1)$, where $u, u+1$ are consecutive integers. Since they are coprime, one must be a fourth power of some integer $\left(c^{4}\right)$, and the other must be twice a fourth power of some integer $\left(2 d^{4}\right)$. Thus,
$$
c^{4}-2 d^{4}= \pm 1 .
$$

If $c^{4}-2 d^{4}=1$, then
$$
d^{8}+2 d^{4}+1=d^{8}+c^{4} \text {, i.e., }\left(d^{4}+1\right)^{2}=\left(d^{2}\right)^{4}+c^{4} \text {. }
$$

The above equation is of the form $x^{4}+y^{4}=z^{2}$, which has been proven to have no integer solutions satisfying $x y z \neq 0$. Hence, $c=\pm 1, d=0$.
So, $u=0$, and $t=0$. Therefore, $n=a=0$. Contradiction.
If $c^{4}-2 d^{4}=-1$, then
$1-2 d^{4}+d^{8}=d^{8}-c^{4}$, i.e., $\left(d^{2}\right)^{4}-c^{4}=\left(d^{4}-1\right)^{2}$.
The above equation is of the form $x^{4}-y^{4}=z^{2}$, which also has no integer solutions satisfying $x y z \neq 0$. Thus, $d=\pm 1$, $c=\pm 1$.
For $u$, the only new value is $u=1$, so $t^{4}=1, n^{2}=4, n=2, m=1, a^{2}=1$, and $k=3$.
Thus, the only choices for $k$ are: $k=1$ and $k=3$.
When $k=1$, we get a periodic sequence: $1,1, 0,1,1, 0, \cdots$, which satisfies the constraints of the problem.
When $k=3$, the sequence is:
$y_{1}=y_{2}=1, y_{n+2}=7 y_{n+1}-y_{n}-2$.
Since $y_{3}=4=2^{2}, y_{4}=25=5^{2}, y_{5}=169=13^{2}$, we assume it is the square of the odd-indexed Fibonacci numbers.
If $\left\{u_{n}\right\}$ is the Fibonacci sequence, it is easy to see that $u_{n+2}=3 u_{n}-u_{n-2}$, and $u_{n+2} u_{n-2}-u_{n}^{2}=1$ for odd $n$.
Thus, $\left(u_{n+2}+u_{n-2}\right)^{2}=9 u_{n}^{2}$.
Therefore, $u_{n+2}^{2}=9 u_{n}^{2}-u_{n-2}^{2}-2 u_{n+2} u_{n-2}=7 u_{n}^{2}-u_{n-2}^{2}-2$.
This confirms our assumption.
Hence, $k=1$ and $k=3$.
informal_statement: Example 46 (2003 Bulgarian National Mathematical Olympiad) Given a sequence: $y_{1}=y_{2}=1$, $y_{n+2}=(4 k-5) y_{n+1}-y_{n}+4-2 k, n \geqslant 1$. Find all integers $k$ such that every term of the sequence is a perfect square.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 46 (2003 Bulgarian National Mathematical Olympiad) Given a sequence: $y_{1}=y_{2}=1$, $y_{n+2}=(4 k-5) y_{n+1}-y_{n}+4-2 k, n \geqslant 1$. Find all integers $k$ such that every term of the sequence is a perfect square. -/
theorem algebra_162829 (k : ‚Ñ§) (y : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñ§)
    (h‚ÇÄ : y 1 = 1)
    (h‚ÇÅ : y 2 = 1)
    (h‚ÇÇ : ‚àÄ n ‚â• 1, y (n + 2) = (4 * k - 5) * y (n + 1) - y n + 4 - 2 * k) :
    (‚àÄ n, ‚àÉ m, m^2 = y n) ‚Üî k = 1 ‚à® k = 3 := by

  IsGreatest {t : ‚Ñù | ‚àÉ x y z : ‚Ñù, x > 0 ‚àß y > 0 ‚àß z > 0 ‚àß x * y + y * z + z * x = 3 * x * y * z ‚àß t = x / (x ^ 4 + 1 + 2 * x * y) + y / (y ^ 4 + 1 + 2 * y * z) + z / (z ^ 4 + 1 + 2 * z * x)} (3 / 4) := by

However, the hotel manager mistakes them for one person and gives "Chris Paul" a room with Chris's and Paul's room concatenated. For example, if Chris had 15 and Paul had 9, "Chris Paul" has 159. If there are 360 rooms in the hotel, what is the probability that "Chris Paul" has a valid room?

However, the hotel manager mistakes them for one person and gives "Chris Paul" a room with Chris's and Paul's room concatenated. For example, if Chris had 15 and Paul had 9, "Chris Paul" has 159. If there are 360 rooms in the hotel, what is the probability that "Chris Paul" has a valid room? -/
