soln_description:
ÔºªSolutionÔºΩLet this natural number be $x$. According to the problem, we have
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x-45=m^{2} \\
x+44=n^{2} .
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $m, n$ are natural numbers.
Eliminating $x$ from (1) and (2), we get
$$
n^{2}-m^{2}=89,
$$

which is
$$
(n-m)(n+m)=89 .
$$

From (1) and (2), we know that $n>m$, and since 89 is a prime number, it follows from (3) that
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
n-m=1, \\
n+m=89
\end{array}\right.
$$

Solving this, we get
$$
n=45 \text {. }
$$

Thus,
$$
x=45^{2}-44=1981 \text {. }
$$

The natural number sought is 1981.
informal_statement:
10.12 A natural number minus 45 is a perfect square, and this natural number plus 44 is also a perfect square. Try to find this natural number.
(China Beijing Junior High School Grade 3 Mathematics Competition, 1981)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 10.12 A natural number minus 45 is a perfect square, and this natural number plus 44 is also a perfect square. Try to find this natural number.
(China Beijing Junior High School Grade 3 Mathematics Competition, 1981) -/
theorem number_theory_280876 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : ‚àÉ m, n - 45 = m^2) (hn' : ‚àÉ p, n + 44 = p^2) :
    n = 1981 := by

soln_description:
Solution to Exercise 9 For any integer $k$, we denote $r_{n+1}(k)$ as the remainder of the Euclidean division of $k$ by $n+1$, that is, the smallest natural number such that $n+1$ divides $k-r_{n+1}(k)$. The double sum on the left can then be rewritten as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{S} & =\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=0}^{n} \frac{i j-r_{n+1}(i j)}{n+1} \\
& =\frac{1}{n+1}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} i\right)\left(\sum_{j=0}^{n} j\right)-\frac{1}{n+1} \sum_{i=0}^{n} \sum_{j=0}^{n} r_{n+1}(i j) \\
& =\frac{1}{n+1} \frac{n(n+1)}{2} \frac{n(n+1)}{2}-\frac{1}{n+1} \sum_{i=0}^{n} \sum_{j=0}^{n} r_{n+1}(i j) \\
& =\frac{n^{2}(n+1)}{4}-\frac{1}{n+1} \sum_{i=0}^{n} \sum_{j=0}^{n} r_{n+1}(i j)
\end{aligned}
$$

It is therefore necessary to find the integers $n$ for which

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=0}^{n} r_{n+1}(i j)=(n+1)\left(\frac{n^{2}(n+1)}{4}-\frac{n^{2}(n-1)}{4}\right)=\frac{n^{2}(n+1)}{2}
$$

Let $i$ be an integer, and let $d=\operatorname{PGCD}(i, n+1)$ and $k=(n+1) / d$ and $\ell=i / d$. The integers $k$ and $\ell$ are coprime, so the $k$ integers $0, \ell, 2 \ell, \ldots,(k-1) \ell$ represent the $k$ residues modulo $k$, and the $k$ integers $0, i, 2 i, \ldots,(k-1) i$ represent the $k$ residues $0, d, 2 d, \ldots,(k-1) d$ modulo $n+1=k d$. In particular, for any integer $t$, we know that

$$
\sum_{j=k t}^{(k+1) t-1} r_{n+1}(i j)=\sum_{j=0}^{k-1} j d=d \frac{k(k-1)}{2}
$$

so that

$$
\sum_{j=0}^{n-1} r_{n+1}(i j)=\sum_{t=0}^{d-1} \sum_{j=k t}^{(k+1) t-1} r_{n+1}(i j)=d^{2} \frac{k(k-1)}{2}=\frac{(n+1)(n+1-d)}{2}
$$

In particular,

$$
\sum_{j=0}^{n-1} r_{n+1}(i j) \leqslant \frac{n(n+1)}{2}
$$

with equality if and only if $d=1$, so if $i$ and $n+1$ are coprime. Thus,

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=0}^{n} r_{n+1}(i j) \leqslant \frac{n^{2}(n+1)}{2}
$$

with equality if and only if $n+1$ is coprime with each of the integers $1,2, \ldots, n$, that is, if $n+1$ is a prime number.

In conclusion, the integers sought are the integers $n$ such that $n+1$ is prime.

$\underline{\text { Alternative Solution } n^{\circ} 1}$ In the following, we set $s_{i, j}=i j /(n+1)$ and $\mathcal{S}_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}\left\lfloor s_{i, j}\right\rfloor$. For all $j \leqslant n$, we note that $s_{i, j}+s_{i, n+1-j}=i$. Consequently, if we set $s_{i, j}=k+x$ with $k$ an integer and $0 \leqslant x<1$, we deduce that

$$
\left\lfloor s_{i, j}\right\rfloor+\left\lfloor s_{i, n+1-j}\right\rfloor=\lfloor k+x\rfloor+\lfloor(i-k-1)+(1-x)\rfloor=i-1+\lfloor 1-x\rfloor
$$

so that $\left\lfloor s_{i, j}\right\rfloor+\left\lfloor s_{i, n+1-j}\right\rfloor \geqslant i-1$ with equality if and only if $x \neq 0$, that is, if $n+1$ does not divide $i j$.

Now, when $j$ runs through the set $\{1,2, \ldots, n-1\}, n+1-j$ also runs through this set. We deduce that

$$
2 \mathcal{S}_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}\left\lfloor s_{i, j}\right\rfloor+\left\lfloor s_{i, n+1-j}\right\rfloor \geqslant \sum_{j=1}^{n}(i-1)=n(i-1)
$$

with equality if and only if $n+1$ does not divide any product $i j$, that is, if $n+1$ is coprime with $i$. We then conclude that

$$
\mathcal{S}=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathcal{S}_{i} \geqslant \frac{n}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}(i-1)=\frac{n^{2}(n-1)}{4}
$$

with equality if and only if $n+1$ is coprime with all integers $i$, that is, if $n+1$ is a prime number.

Thus, the integers $n$ sought are exactly those for which $n+1$ is prime.

Graders' Comment The exercise was difficult, and few students managed to make progress. A real challenge was to convince oneself that there exist arbitrarily large integers $n$ for which the statement is true. Here, working through small cases gave a good intuition of the solutions, but many cases had to be considered. Consequently, many students tried to use inequalities to show that, when $n$ was arbitrarily large, the sum would become larger or smaller than $n^{2}(n-1) / 4$. Given the solution to this exercise, this strategy was unfortunately doomed to fail.

Students who solved the problem did so as in Solution 2, whose main trick is not unlike the solution to Problem 16 of the Animath Fall Cup: it is important to read the solutions to problems not solved, as they can help advance in very different problems.
informal_statement:
Exercise 9. Find the integers $n$ for which the equality

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n}\left\lfloor\frac{i \times j}{n+1}\right\rfloor=\frac{n^{2}(n-1)}{4}
$$

is satisfied.

We recall that, for any real number $x$, the notation $\lfloor x\rfloor$ denotes the floor of $x$, that is, the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Exercise 9. Find the integers $n$ for which the equality

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n}\left\lfloor\frac{i \times j}{n+1}\right\rfloor=\frac{n^{2}(n-1)}{4}
$$

is satisfied.

We recall that, for any real number $x$, the notation $\lfloor x\rfloor$ denotes the floor of $x$, that is, the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$. -/
theorem number_theory_292293 (n : ‚Ñï) :
    (‚àë i in Finset.Icc 1 n, ‚àë j in Finset.Icc 1 n, ‚åä(i * j / (n + 1 : ‚Ñù))‚åã =
     n ^ 2 * (n - 1) / 4) ‚Üî n + 1 = 2 := by

soln_description:
„ÄêAnalysis„ÄëAccording to the problem, the speed ratio of A and B is $1.2: 1=6: 5$, so the time ratio is 5: 6. Let's assume A takes $5 t$, then B's original time is $6 t$. The delay time due to the fault for B is $\frac{1}{6} \times 6 t=t$, and the total time taken for the entire journey is $5 t$. Therefore, after the fault is resolved, B's increased speed saves $2 t$ of time. The speed ratio after the increase is $1.6: 1=8: 5$, so the time ratio is $5: 8$, saving three parts of time, so each part is $\frac{2}{3} t$. Therefore, the original planned time for this section is $\frac{2}{3} t \times 8=\frac{16}{3} t$, so the original planned time for the initial 5 kilometers is $6 t-\frac{16}{3} t=\frac{2}{3} t$. Therefore, the distance between A and B is $5 \times\left(6 t \div \frac{2}{3} t\right)$, and then we can calculate it.

„ÄêSolution„ÄëSolution: The speed ratio of A and B is $1.2: 1=6: 5$, so the time ratio is 5: 6; assume A takes $5 t$, then B's original time is $6 t$;

The delay time due to the fault for B is $\frac{1}{6} \times 6 t=t$, and the total time taken for the entire journey is $5 t$, so after the fault is resolved, B's increased speed saves $2 t$ of time.

The speed ratio after the increase is $1.6: 1=8: 5$, so the time ratio is $5: 8$, saving three parts of time, so each part is $\frac{2}{3} t$,
Therefore, the original planned time for this section is $\frac{2}{3} t \times 8=\frac{16}{3} t$, so the original planned time for the initial 5 kilometers is $6 t-\frac{16}{3} t=\frac{2}{3} t$, so the distance between A and B is:
$5 \times\left(6 t \div \frac{2}{3} t\right)$,
$=5 \times 9$,
$=45$ (kilometers);
Therefore, the answer is: 45.
informal_statement: 3. (3 points) Person A and Person B start riding bicycles from place $A$ to place $B$ at the same time. Person A's speed is 1.2 times that of Person B. After riding 5 kilometers, Person B's bicycle breaks down, and the time spent fixing it is equivalent to riding $\frac{1}{6}$ of the total distance. After fixing the bicycle, Person B's speed increases by 60%, and as a result, both Person A and Person B arrive at place $B$ at the same time. The distance between $A$ and $B$ is $\qquad$ kilometers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. (3 points) Person A and Person B start riding bicycles from place $A$ to place $B$ at the same time. Person A's speed is 1.2 times that of Person B. After riding 5 kilometers, Person B's bicycle breaks down, and the time spent fixing it is equivalent to riding $\frac{1}{6}$ of the total distance. After fixing the bicycle, Person B's speed increases by 60%, and as a result, both Person A and Person B arrive at place $B$ at the same time. The distance between $A$ and $B$ is $\qquad$ kilometers. -/
theorem algebra_236525 (d : ‚Ñù) (h : d > 0) (h1 : 1.2 * (d / 6) = (d - 5) / 1.6) :
    d = 45 := by

soln_description: Prove that according to the Pigeonhole Principle, among the 3 numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}$, at least two numbers are either both even or both odd. Without loss of generality, assume these two numbers are $a_{1}$ and $a_{2}$, and they are both odd. Then, among $a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}$, there is at most one even number. Hence, according to the Pigeonhole Principle, at least one of $b_{1}$ and $b_{2}$ is odd. And one of them is equal to one of $a_{1}, a_{2}$. The difference between two odd numbers is even. Therefore, among $a_{1}-b_{1}, a_{2}-b_{2}$, at least one is even. If $a_{1}, a_{2}$ are both even, the result is also correct, as the difference between two even numbers is still even.
informal_statement: Example 3-29 Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}$ be 3 arbitrary integers; $b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}$ be any permutation of $a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}$, then $a_{1}-b_{1}$, $a_{2}-b_{2}$, $a_{3}-b_{3}$ at least one is even.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 3-29 Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}$ be 3 arbitrary integers; $b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}$ be any permutation of $a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}$, then $a_{1}-b_{1}$, $a_{2}-b_{2}$, $a_{3}-b_{3}$ at least one is even. -/
theorem number_theory_230585 (a b : Fin 3 ‚Üí ‚Ñ§) (h : ‚àÉ p : Equiv.Perm (Fin 3), ‚àÄ i, a i = b (p i)) :
    Even (a 0 - b 0) ‚à® Even (a 1 - b 1) ‚à® Even (a 2 - b 2) := by

informal_statement:
Let $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$ denote the set of integers considered modulo $n$ (hence $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$ has $n$ elements). Find all positive integers $n$ for which there exists a bijective function $g: \mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$, such that the 101 functions
\[g(x), \quad g(x) + x, \quad g(x) + 2x, \quad \dots, \quad g(x) + 100x\]
are all bijections on $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$.

[i]Ashwin Sah and Yang Liu[/i]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$ denote the set of integers considered modulo $n$ (hence $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$ has $n$ elements). Find all positive integers $n$ for which there exists a bijective function $g: \mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$, such that the 101 functions
\[g(x), \quad g(x) + x, \quad g(x) + 2x, \quad \dots, \quad g(x) + 100x\]
are all bijections on $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$.

[i]Ashwin Sah and Yang Liu[/i] -/
theorem number_theory_26375 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : 0 < n) :
    ‚àÉ g : ZMod n ‚Üí ZMod n, Function.Bijective g ‚àß
      ‚àÄ i ‚àà Finset.range 101, Function.Bijective (fun x => g x + (i * x)) ‚Üî
    Nat.gcd n (Nat.factorial 101) = 1 := by

soln_description:
Since the number of tiles lying on both diagonals is $37$, counting one tile twice, there are $37=2x-1\implies x=19$ tiles on each side. Therefore, our answer is $19^2=361=\boxed{\textbf{(C)}\ 361}$.
~AllezW
informal_statement:
A square-shaped floor is covered with congruent square tiles. If the total number of tiles that lie on the two diagonals is 37, how many tiles cover the floor?

$\textbf{(A) }148\qquad\textbf{(B) }324\qquad\textbf{(C) }361\qquad\textbf{(D) }1296\qquad\textbf{(E) }1369$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset

/- A square-shaped floor is covered with congruent square tiles. If the total number of tiles that lie on the two diagonals is 37, how many tiles cover the floor?

$\textbf{(A) }148\qquad\textbf{(B) }324\qquad\textbf{(C) }361\qquad\textbf{(D) }1296\qquad\textbf{(E) }1369$ -/
theorem number_theory_93043 (s : ‚Ñï) (hs : s > 0) (h : ‚àë i ‚àà range s, ‚àë j ‚àà range s,
    (if (i = j ‚à® i = s - j - 1) then 1 else 0) = 37) :
    s^2 = 361 := by

soln_description:
To prove that if one of the numbers \(a^p\) and \(a^q\) is divisible by \(p\), then the other number must also be divisible by \(p\), we will proceed as follows:

1. **Assume \(p \mid a^p\) or \(p \mid a^q\):**
   - We are given that \(p \leq q\).
   - We need to show that if \(p \mid a^p\) or \(p \mid a^q\), then both \(a^p\) and \(a^q\) are divisible by \(p\).

2. **Case \(p = 1\):**
   - If \(p = 1\), then \(a^p = a\) and \(a^q = a^q\).
   - Since any integer is divisible by 1, the statement is trivially true.

3. **Case \(p \geq 2\):**
   - Assume \(p \geq 2\).
   - Consider any prime \(t\) that divides \(p\). Let \(u \geq 1\) be the exponent of \(t\) in the prime factorization of \(p\), and let \(v \geq 1\) be the exponent of \(t\) in the prime factorization of \(a\).

4. **Prime factorization and divisibility:**
   - Since \(t^u \mid p\), we have \(p = t^u \cdot k\) for some integer \(k\).
   - If \(t\) divides \(a\), then \(a = t^v \cdot m\) for some integer \(m\).

5. **Exponent comparison:**
   - We need to show that \(t^u \mid a^p\) and \(t^u \mid a^q\).
   - Since \(a = t^v \cdot m\), we have \(a^p = (t^v \cdot m)^p = t^{vp} \cdot m^p\).
   - Similarly, \(a^q = (t^v \cdot m)^q = t^{vq} \cdot m^q\).

6. **Divisibility by \(t^u\):**
   - Since \(p = t^u \cdot k\), we have \(u \leq vp\) because \(u\) is the exponent of \(t\) in \(p\) and \(v\) is the exponent of \(t\) in \(a\).
   - Therefore, \(t^u \mid t^{vp}\), which implies \(t^u \mid a^p\).
   - Similarly, since \(q \geq p\), we have \(vq \geq vp\), and thus \(t^u \mid t^{vq}\), which implies \(t^u \mid a^q\).

7. **Conclusion:**
   - If \(p \mid a^p\), then \(t^u \mid a^p\) for all primes \(t\) dividing \(p\), and hence \(p \mid a^p\).
   - Since \(a^p \mid a^q\) (because \(q \geq p\)), it follows that \(p \mid a^q\).
   - Similarly, if \(p \mid a^q\), then \(t^u \mid a^q\) for all primes \(t\) dividing \(p\), and hence \(p \mid a^q\).
   - Since \(a^q = (a^p)^{q/p}\), it follows that \(p \mid a^p\).

Therefore, if one of the numbers \(a^p\) and \(a^q\) is divisible by \(p\), then the other number must also be divisible by \(p\).

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: 4.	Let $a$, $p$ and $q$  be positive integers with  $p \le q$. Prove that if one of the numbers $a^p$ and $a^q$ is divisible by $p$  , then the other number must also be divisible by $p$ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4.	Let $a$, $p$ and $q$  be positive integers with  $p \le q$. Prove that if one of the numbers $a^p$ and $a^q$ is divisible by $p$  , then the other number must also be divisible by $p$ . -/
theorem number_theory_61927 (a p q : ‚Ñï) (ha : 0 < a) (hp : 0 < p) (hq : 0 < q)
    (hle : p ‚â§ q) (hdiv : p ‚à£ a ^ p ‚à® p ‚à£ a ^ q) :
    p ‚à£ a ^ p ‚àß p ‚à£ a ^ q := by

soln_description:
1. We start by analyzing the given equation \(a! + b^3 = 18 + c^3\). We need to find the number of triples \((a, b, c)\) of positive integers that satisfy this equation.

2. First, consider the equation modulo 7. We know that the possible values of \(c^3 \mod 7\) are \(-1, 0, 1\) because the cubes of integers modulo 7 can only be these values. Therefore, \(18 + c^3 - b^3 \mod 7\) can be \(2, 3, 4, 5, 6 \mod 7\).

3. Next, consider \(a!\) modulo 7. For \(a \geq 7\), \(a!\) is divisible by 7, so \(a! \equiv 0 \mod 7\). Therefore, \(a\) must be less than 7 for \(a! + b^3 = 18 + c^3\) to hold.

4. We now check the values of \(a\) from 1 to 6:
   - For \(a = 1\), \(1! = 1\). The equation becomes \(1 + b^3 = 18 + c^3\). Rearranging, we get \(b^3 - c^3 = 17\). There are no integer solutions for \(b\) and \(c\) such that \(b^3 - c^3 = 17\).
   - For \(a = 2\), \(2! = 2\). The equation becomes \(2 + b^3 = 18 + c^3\). Rearranging, we get \(b^3 - c^3 = 16\). There are no integer solutions for \(b\) and \(c\) such that \(b^3 - c^3 = 16\).
   - For \(a = 3\), \(3! = 6\). The equation becomes \(6 + b^3 = 18 + c^3\). Rearranging, we get \(b^3 - c^3 = 12\). There are no integer solutions for \(b\) and \(c\) such that \(b^3 - c^3 = 12\).
   - For \(a = 4\), \(4! = 24\). The equation becomes \(24 + b^3 = 18 + c^3\). Rearranging, we get \(b^3 - c^3 = -6\). There are no integer solutions for \(b\) and \(c\) such that \(b^3 - c^3 = -6\).
   - For \(a = 5\), \(5! = 120\). The equation becomes \(120 + b^3 = 18 + c^3\). Rearranging, we get \(b^3 - c^3 = -102\). There are no integer solutions for \(b\) and \(c\) such that \(b^3 - c^3 = -102\).
   - For \(a = 6\), \(6! = 720\). The equation becomes \(720 + b^3 = 18 + c^3\). Rearranging, we get \(b^3 - c^3 = -702\). There are no integer solutions for \(b\) and \(c\) such that \(b^3 - c^3 = -702\).

5. We have checked all possible values of \(a\) from 1 to 6 and found that none of them satisfy the equation \(a! + b^3 = 18 + c^3\).

The final answer is \(\boxed{0}\)
informal_statement:
How many triples of positive integers $(a,b,c)$ are there such that $a!+b^3 = 18+c^3$?

$ 
\textbf{(A)}\ 4
\qquad\textbf{(B)}\ 3
\qquad\textbf{(C)}\ 2
\qquad\textbf{(D)}\ 1
\qquad\textbf{(E)}\ 0
$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- How many triples of positive integers $(a,b,c)$ are there such that $a!+b^3 = 18+c^3$?

$ 
\textbf{(A)}\ 4
\qquad\textbf{(B)}\ 3
\qquad\textbf{(C)}\ 2
\qquad\textbf{(D)}\ 1
\qquad\textbf{(E)}\ 0
$ -/
theorem number_theory_59485 :
    {(a, b, c) : ‚Ñï √ó ‚Ñï √ó ‚Ñï | a > 0 ‚àß b > 0 ‚àß c > 0 ‚àß Nat.factorial a + b^3 = 18 + c^3}.ncard = 0 := by

soln_description:
ii. $6 \cdot \frac{1}{9}$.
Point $M(x, y)(x, y \in\{1,2, \cdots, 6\})$ totals 36, among which, points $(1,6) „ÄÅ(6,1) „ÄÅ(2,3) „ÄÅ(3,2)$ lie on the hyperbola $y=\frac{6}{x}$. Therefore, the required probability equals $\frac{1}{9}$.

import Mathlib

/- 6. A die is rolled twice. If the number of dots that appear on the first roll is $x$, and the number of dots that appear on the second roll is $y$, then the probability that the point $M(x, y)$ determined by $x$ and $y$ lies on the hyperbola $y=\frac{6}{x}$ is . $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_318592 :
    (Set.ncard {p : Fin 2 ‚Üí ‚Ñï | p 0 ‚àà Finset.Icc 1 6 ‚àß p 1 ‚àà Finset.Icc 1 6 ‚àß p 1 = 6 / p 0}) / 36 = 1 / 9 := by

informal_statement: 1. Let the desired number be $\overline{a b c d}=1000 a+100 b+10 c+d$. Then the other number will be $\overline{d c b a}=1000 d+100 c+10 b+a$. The sum of these numbers will be $1001 a+110 b+110 c+1001 d$. Since the division of this sum by 143 resulted in 136, we have the equation: $1001(a+d)+110(b+c)=19448$. Since $(b+c)$ does not exceed 18, and thus $110(b+c)$ does not exceed 1980, we can deduce from the equation that the equality is only possible when $a=d=9$. Then we have: $110(b+c)=19448-18018$, which is equivalent to the equation: $b+c=13$. By enumeration, we find all possible values for the letters $b$ and $c$, and thus obtain 6 variants of four-digit numbers that satisfy the condition: 9949, 9859, 9769, 9679, 9589, 9499.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Let the desired number be $\overline{a b c d}=1000 a+100 b+10 c+d$. Then the other number will be $\overline{d c b a}=1000 d+100 c+10 b+a$. The sum of these numbers will be $1001 a+110 b+110 c+1001 d$. Since the division of this sum by 143 resulted in 136, we have the equation: $1001(a+d)+110(b+c)=19448$. Since $(b+c)$ does not exceed 18, and thus $110(b+c)$ does not exceed 1980, we can deduce from the equation that the equality is only possible when $a=d=9$. Then we have: $110(b+c)=19448-18018$, which is equivalent to the equation: $b+c=13$. By enumeration, we find all possible values for the letters $b$ and $c$, and thus obtain 6 variants of four-digit numbers that satisfy the condition: 9949, 9859, 9769, 9679, 9589, 9499. -/
theorem number_theory_102213 (a b c d : ‚Ñï) (ha : a ‚â† 0) (h : 1000 * a + 100 * b + 10 * c + d = 9949 ‚à®
    1000 * a + 100 * b + 10 * c + d = 9859 ‚à® 1000 * a + 100 * b + 10 * c + d = 9769 ‚à®
    1000 * a + 100 * b + 10 * c + d = 9679 ‚à® 1000 * a + 100 * b + 10 * c + d = 9589 ‚à®
    1000 * a + 100 * b + 10 * c + d = 9499) :
    a = 9 ‚àß d = 9 ‚àß b + c = 13 := by

soln_description:
35. Fix $i$, by the generalization of Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we get
$$\prod_{j=1}^{n}\left(1+\frac{a_{i}}{a_{j}}\right) \geqslant\left[1+\frac{a i}{\left(\prod_{j=1}^{n} a_{j}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}}\right]^{n}$$

Therefore,
$$\left\{\prod_{i=1}^{n} \prod_{j=1}^{n}\left(1+\frac{a_{i}}{a_{j}}\right)\right\}^{\frac{1}{n}} \geqslant\left\{\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left[1+\frac{\left(\prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}}{\left(\prod_{j=1}^{n} a_{j}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}}\right]^{n}\right\}^{\frac{1}{n}}=2^{n}$$
informal_statement: 35. Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}>0$, then $\left.\prod_{i=1}^{n} \prod_{j=1}^{n}\left(1+\frac{a_{i}}{a_{j}}\right)\right|^{\frac{1}{n}} \geqslant 2^{n}$. (Generalization of a 1988 Australian Mathematical Olympiad problem)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 35. Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}>0$, then $\left.\prod_{i=1}^{n} \prod_{j=1}^{n}\left(1+\frac{a_{i}}{a_{j}}\right)\right|^{\frac{1}{n}} \geqslant 2^{n}$. (Generalization of a 1988 Australian Mathematical Olympiad problem) -/
theorem inequalities_598037 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : 0 < n) (a : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (ha : ‚àÄ i, 0 < a i) :
    (‚àè i, ‚àè j, (1 + a i / a j)) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / n) ‚â• 2 ^ n := by

soln_description:
3. $-\frac{2}{3} \leqslant x<0$.

Let $y=\sqrt[3]{3 x+1}$. Then $3= \pm i=y^{3}, 3 x=y^{3}$, the original inequality becomes
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{(3 x)^{2}}{1-\sqrt[3]{3}-x+1)^{2}} \leqslant 3 x+6+3 \sqrt[3]{3 x+1}, \\
\frac{\left(y^{3}-1\right)^{2}}{(1-y)^{2}} \leqslant y^{3}+5+3 y, \\
\left(y^{2}+y+1\right)^{2} \leqslant y^{3}+5+3 y .
\end{array}
$$

Simplifying and organizing, we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
y^{4}+y^{3}+3 y^{2}-y-4 \leqslant 0, \\
(y+1)(y-1)\left(y^{2}+y+4\right) \leqslant 0 .
\end{array}
$$
Since $y^{2}+y+4$ is always positive,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\therefore-1 \leqslant y \leqslant 1, \\
-1 \leqslant \sqrt[3]{3 x+1} \leqslant 1 .
\end{array}
$$

Solving, we get $-\frac{2}{3} \leqslant x \leqslant 0$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Also, } \because 1-\sqrt[3]{3 x+1} \neq 0, \\
\therefore x \neq 0 .
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, the solution set of the original inequality is: $-\frac{2}{3} \leqslant x<0$.
informal_statement: 3. The solution set of the inequality $\frac{3 x^{2}}{(1-\sqrt[3]{3 x+1})^{2}} \leqslant x+2+$ $\sqrt[3]{3 x+1}$ is $\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 3. The solution set of the inequality $\frac{3 x^{2}}{(1-\sqrt[3]{3 x+1})^{2}} \leqslant x+2+$ $\sqrt[3]{3 x+1}$ is $\qquad$ -/
theorem inequalities_319563 (x : ‚Ñù) :
  (3 * x ^ 2 / (1 - (3 * x + 1) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3)) ^ 2 ‚â§
   x + 2 + (3 * x + 1) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3)) ‚Üî
  (-2 / 3 ‚â§ x ‚àß x < 0) := by

soln_description: 50 Solution Put h = (n+1) 1/3 , k = (n-1) 1/3 , so g(n) = h 2 + hk + k 2 = (h 3 - k 3 )/(h - k) = 2/(h-k) and 1/g(n) = (h-k)/2. So 1/g(1) + 1/g(3) + 1/g(5) + ... + 1/g(999999) = (1/2) (2 1/3 + 4 1/3 - 2 1/3 + 6 1/3 - 4 1/3 + ... + 1000000 1/3 - 999998 1/3 ) = 50. Thanks to Suat Namli Solutions are also available in Australian Mathematical Olympiads 1979-1995 by H Lausch and P J Taylor, ISBN 0858896451, published by Australian Mathematics Trust. It can be ordered from AMT by email. 12th Aus 1991 ¬© John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 5 February 2004 Last corrected/updated 5 Feb 04

1. Let \( a \) and \( b \) be the two positive real numbers, where \( a > b \).
2. According to the problem, the average of the two numbers is equal to their difference. This can be written as:
   \[
   \frac{a + b}{2} = a - b
   \]
3. To eliminate the fraction, multiply both sides of the equation by 2:
   \[
   a + b = 2(a - b)
   \]
4. Distribute the 2 on the right-hand side:
   \[
   a + b = 2a - 2b
   \]
5. To isolate \( a \), subtract \( a \) from both sides:
   \[
   b = 2a - 2b - a
   \]
   Simplifying, we get:
   \[
   b = a - 2b
   \]
6. Add \( 2b \) to both sides to isolate \( a \):
   \[
   a = 3b
   \]
7. The ratio of the larger number \( a \) to the smaller number \( b \) is:
   \[
   \frac{a}{b} = \frac{3b}{b} = 3
   \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{3}\).
informal_statement:
The average of two positive real numbers is equal to their difference. What is the ratio of the larger number to the smaller one?

[i]Author: Ray Li[/i]
informal_proof:
Let \(x\) and \(y\) be two positive real numbers. We are given the condition that their average is equal to their difference:
$$ \frac{x + y}{2} = x - y $$
Multiplying both sides of this equation by 2 to eliminate the fraction, we obtain:
$$ x + y = 2(x - y) $$
Distributing the 2 on the right-hand side gives:
$$ x + y = 2x - 2y $$
To find the relationship between \(x\) and \(y\), we rearrange the terms. Subtracting \(x\) from both sides yields:
$$ y = x - 2y $$
Adding \(2y\) to both sides, we isolate \(x\):
$$ y + 2y = x $$
$$ 3y = x $$
We are given that \(y > 0\). From the derived relationship \(x = 3y\), it follows that \(x\) must also be positive, since \(3\) is positive and \(y\) is positive.

Now we need to evaluate the ratio \(\frac{\max x y}{\min x y}\).
Given that \(x = 3y\) and \(y > 0\), we can compare \(x\) and \(y\). Since \(y > 0\), \(3y\) is strictly greater than \(y\). Therefore, \(x > y\).
This implies that the maximum of \(x\) and \(y\) is \(x\), and the minimum of \(x\) and \(y\) is \(y\).
$$ \max x y = x $$
$$ \min x y = y $$
The ratio we are asked to find is:
$$ \frac{\max x y}{\min x y} = \frac{x}{y} $$
Substituting \(x = 3y\) into this expression, we get:
$$ \frac{3y}{y} $$
Since \(y\) is a positive real number, we can cancel \(y\) from the numerator and the denominator:
$$ \frac{3y}{y} = 3 $$
Thus, the ratio of the larger number to the smaller number is 3.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The average of two positive real numbers is equal to their difference. What is the ratio of the larger number to the smaller one?

[i]Author: Ray Li[/i] -/
theorem algebra_42109 {x y : ‚Ñù} (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y)
    (h : (x + y) / 2 = x - y) : max x y / min x y = 3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_42109 {x y : ‚Ñù} (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y)
    (h : (x + y) / 2 = x - y) : max x y / min x y = 3 := by 
  have h1 : x + y = 2 * (x - y) := by linarith
  have h2 : x = 3 * y := by
    linarith
  have h3 : y > 0 := hy
  have h4 : x > 0 := by linarith [h2, hy]
  have h5 : max x y = x := by
    apply max_eq_left
    nlinarith [h2, hy]
  have h6 : min x y = y := by
    apply min_eq_right
    nlinarith [h2, hy]
  rw [h5, h6]
  have h7 : x / y = 3 := by
    rw [h2]
    field_simp [hy]
    <;> nlinarith
  linarith [h7]

soln_description:
SolutION. Let \( x = \frac{\sqrt{2bc}}{\sqrt{a(a+b)}}, y = \frac{\sqrt{2ca}}{\sqrt{b(b+c)}}, z = \frac{\sqrt{2ab}}{\sqrt{c(c+a)}} \). We need to prove that \( x + y + z \geq 3 \). However, it suffices to prove the following stronger result as follows:
\[ 3 \leq xy + yz + zx = \frac{2c}{\sqrt{(a+b)(b+c)}} + \frac{2a}{\sqrt{(b+c)(c+a)}} + \frac{2b}{\sqrt{(c+a)(a+b)}} \]

Denote \( u = \sqrt{b+c}, v = \sqrt{c+a}, w = \sqrt{a+b} \). We get
\[ yz = \frac{w^2 + v^2 - u^2}{uv}, zx = \frac{u^2 + w^2 - v^2}{vw}, xy = \frac{v^2 + u^2 - w^2}{wu} \]

The inequality becomes
\[ \begin{array}{c}
v(v^2 + u^2 - w^2) + w(w^2 + v^2 - u^2) + u(u^2 + w^2 - v^2) \geq 3uvw \\
\Leftrightarrow (u^3 + v^3 + w^3) + (u^2v + v^2w + w^2u) \geq (v^2u + w^2v + u^2w) + 3uvw
\end{array} \]

But
\[ \begin{aligned}
(v^3 + u^2v) + (w^3 + v^2w) + (u^3 + w^2u) & \geq 2(v^2u + w^2v + u^2w) \\
v^2u + w^2v + u^2w & \geq 3uvw
\end{aligned} \]

The proof is finished and equality holds iff \( a = b = c \).

theorem inequalities_603085 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    3 / Real.sqrt (2 * a * b * c) ‚â§ 1 / (a * Real.sqrt (a + b)) +
    1 / (b * Real.sqrt (b + c)) + 1 / (c * Real.sqrt (c + a)) := by

soln_description: $26\left(\frac{4}{5}, 0\right)$. The x-coordinate of the required intersection point, i.e., the root of the equation $(3 x-1)\left(\sqrt{(3 x-1)^{2}+4}+1\right)=$ $(3-2 x)\left(\sqrt{(3-2 x)^{2}+4}+1\right)$. Consider $f(t)=t\left(\sqrt{t^{2}+4}+1\right)$, it is easy to know that $f(-t)$ $=-f(t), f(t)$ is an odd function. When $t_{1}>t_{2} \geqslant 0$, it is easy to prove that $f\left(t_{1}\right)>f\left(t_{2}\right) . f(t)$ is a strictly increasing function, so over the entire real number set, $f(t)$ is monotonically increasing. From $f(3 x-1)=f(3-2 x)$ we get $3 x-1=3-2 x$, so $x=\frac{4}{5}$.
informal_statement:
26 On the $x O y$ coordinate plane, the curve
$$
y=(3 x-1)\left(\sqrt{9 x^{2}-6 x+5}+1\right)+(2 x-3)\left(\sqrt{4 x^{2}-12 x+13}+1\right)
$$

intersects the $x$-axis at the point with coordinates $\qquad$ .
informal_proof:
We need to show that there exists a real number $x$ such that $f(x) = 0$ and $x = 4/5$. We assert that such an $x$ is $4/5$ and then verify the two conditions.

First, we verify that $f(4/5) = 0$.
The function $f(x)$ is given by:
$$
f(x)=(3 x-1)\left(\sqrt{9 x^{2}-6 x+5}+1\right)+(2 x-3)\left(\sqrt{4 x^{2}-12 x+13}+1\right)
$$
We substitute $x = 4/5$ into the expression.

Let's evaluate the terms inside the square roots:
For the first term:
$$ 9 \left(\frac{4}{5}\right)^2 - 6 \left(\frac{4}{5}\right) + 5 = 9 \left(\frac{16}{25}\right) - \frac{24}{5} + 5 = \frac{144}{25} - \frac{120}{25} + \frac{125}{25} = \frac{149}{25} $$
Thus, $\sqrt{9 x^{2}-6 x+5} = \sqrt{\frac{149}{25}} = \frac{\sqrt{149}}{5}$.

For the second term:
$$ 4 \left(\frac{4}{5}\right)^2 - 12 \left(\frac{4}{5}\right) + 13 = 4 \left(\frac{16}{25}\right) - \frac{48}{5} + 13 = \frac{64}{25} - \frac{240}{25} + \frac{325}{25} = \frac{149}{25} $$
Thus, $\sqrt{4 x^{2}-12 x+13} = \sqrt{\frac{149}{25}} = \frac{\sqrt{149}}{5}$.

Now substitute these results back into the expression for $f(4/5)$:
$$
f\left(\frac{4}{5}\right) = \left(3\left(\frac{4}{5}\right) - 1\right)\left(\frac{\sqrt{149}}{5} + 1\right) + \left(2\left(\frac{4}{5}\right) - 3\right)\left(\frac{\sqrt{149}}{5} + 1\right)
$$
$$
f\left(\frac{4}{5}\right) = \left(\frac{12}{5} - \frac{5}{5}\right)\left(\frac{\sqrt{149}}{5} + 1\right) + \left(\frac{8}{5} - \frac{15}{5}\right)\left(\frac{\sqrt{149}}{5} + 1\right)
$$
$$
f\left(\frac{4}{5}\right) = \left(\frac{7}{5}\right)\left(\frac{\sqrt{149}}{5} + 1\right) + \left(-\frac{7}{5}\right)\left(\frac{\sqrt{149}}{5} + 1\right)
$$
$$
f\left(\frac{4}{5}\right) = \left(\frac{7}{5} - \frac{7}{5}\right)\left(\frac{\sqrt{149}}{5} + 1\right) = 0 \cdot \left(\frac{\sqrt{149}}{5} + 1\right) = 0
$$
We have successfully shown that $f(4/5) = 0$. The second condition, $x = 4/5$, is satisfied by our choice of $x$. Therefore, there exists an $x$ ($x=4/5$) such that $f(x) = 0$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 26 On the $x O y$ coordinate plane, the curve
$$
y=(3 x-1)\left(\sqrt{9 x^{2}-6 x+5}+1\right)+(2 x-3)\left(\sqrt{4 x^{2}-12 x+13}+1\right)
$$

intersects the $x$-axis at the point with coordinates $\qquad$ . -/
theorem algebra_279148 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù}
    (hf : f = fun x => (3 * x - 1) * (sqrt (9 * x ^ 2 - 6 * x + 5) + 1) +
      (2 * x - 3) * (sqrt (4 * x ^ 2 - 12 * x + 13) + 1)) :
    ‚àÉ x, f x = 0 ‚àß x = 4 / 5 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real

theorem algebra_279148 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù}
    (hf : f = fun x => (3 * x - 1) * (sqrt (9 * x ^ 2 - 6 * x + 5) + 1) +
      (2 * x - 3) * (sqrt (4 * x ^ 2 - 12 * x + 13) + 1)) :
    ‚àÉ x, f x = 0 ‚àß x = 4 / 5 := by
  use 4 / 5
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Show that f(4/5) = 0
    rw [hf]
    have h1 : sqrt (9 * (4 / 5) ^ 2 - 6 * (4 / 5) + 5) = Real.sqrt 149 / 5 := by
      rw [Real.sqrt_eq_iff_sq_eq] <;> norm_num
      <;> ring_nf <;> norm_num
    have h2 : sqrt (4 * (4 / 5) ^ 2 - 12 * (4 / 5) + 13) = Real.sqrt 149 / 5 := by
      rw [Real.sqrt_eq_iff_sq_eq] <;> norm_num
      <;> ring_nf <;> norm_num
    simp [h1, h2]
    <;> field_simp <;> ring_nf <;> norm_num
    <;> ring
  ¬∑ -- Trivial since we use the specific x
    rfl

It's not difficult to find that the coefficients of the first 3 terms are $1, \frac{1}{2} n, \frac{1}{8} n(n-1)$. Since these 3 numbers form an arithmetic sequence, we have $2 \cdot \frac{1}{2} n=1+\frac{1}{8} n(n-1)$. Solving this, we get: $n=8$ and $n=1$ (discard).
When $\pi=8$, $T_{r+1}=C_{8}^{r}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{r} x^{\frac{(16-3 r)}{4}}$. Here $r=0,1, \cdots, 8$. $r$ should satisfy $41(16-3 r)$, so $r$ can only be $0,4,8$.

  ‚à´ x : ‚Ñù, 1 / (2 + sin x) = tan (œÄ / 4 + x / 2) + C ‚àß
  ‚à´ x : ‚Ñù, 1 / (1 - sin x) = -tan (œÄ / 4 + x / 2) + C ‚àß

soln_description:
Since $1024$ is greater than $1000$.
$\log (1024) > 3$
$10 * \log (2) > 3$
and $\log (2) > 3/10$.

Similarly, $8192 < 10000$, so $\log (8192) < 4$
$13 * \log (2) < 4$
and $\log (2) < 4/13$

Therefore  $3/10 < \log 2 < 4/13$ 
so the answer is $\fbox{C}$
informal_statement:
If one uses only the tabular information $10^3=1000$, $10^4=10,000$, $2^{10}=1024$, $2^{11}=2048$, $2^{12}=4096$, $2^{13}=8192$, then the strongest statement one can make for $\log_{10}{2}$ is that it lies between:
$\textbf{(A)}\ \frac{3}{10} \; \text{and} \; \frac{4}{11}\qquad \textbf{(B)}\ \frac{3}{10} \; \text{and} \; \frac{4}{12}\qquad \textbf{(C)}\ \frac{3}{10} \; \text{and} \; \frac{4}{13}\qquad \textbf{(D)}\ \frac{3}{10} \; \text{and} \; \frac{40}{132}\qquad \textbf{(E)}\ \frac{3}{11} \; \text{and} \; \frac{40}{132}$
informal_proof:
We aim to establish the conjunction of two inequalities: $\frac{3}{10} < \log_{10} 2$ and $\log_{10} 2 < \frac{4}{13}$. We will prove each part individually.

To show that $\frac{3}{10} < \log_{10} 2$, we utilize the fact that $2^{10} = 1024$ and $10^3 = 1000$. Since $1024 > 1000$, it follows that $2^{10} > 10^3$. Because the base of the logarithm is $10$, which is greater than $1$, the function $\log_{10}$ is strictly increasing. Applying $\log_{10}$ to both sides of the inequality $2^{10} > 10^3$ yields $\log_{10}(2^{10}) > \log_{10}(10^3)$. Using the logarithm property $\log_b(a^c) = c \log_b(a)$, we rewrite the left side as $10 \log_{10} 2$. The right side simplifies to $\log_{10}(10^3) = 3$. Thus, we have $10 \log_{10} 2 > 3$. Dividing both sides by $10$, we obtain $\log_{10} 2 > \frac{3}{10}$.

To show that $\log_{10} 2 < \frac{4}{13}$, we use the facts that $2^{13} = 8192$ and $10^4 = 10000$. Since $8192 < 10000$, it follows that $2^{13} < 10^4$. Applying the strictly increasing function $\log_{10}$ to both sides of this inequality, we get $\log_{10}(2^{13}) < \log_{10}(10^4)$. Using the logarithm property $\log_b(a^c) = c \log_b(a)$, the left side becomes $13 \log_{10} 2$. The right side simplifies to $\log_{10}(10^4) = 4$. Therefore, we have $13 \log_{10} 2 < 4$. Dividing both sides by $13$, we obtain $\log_{10} 2 < \frac{4}{13}$.

Having established both $\frac{3}{10} < \log_{10} 2$ and $\log_{10} 2 < \frac{4}{13}$, their conjunction is proven.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- If one uses only the tabular information $10^3=1000$, $10^4=10,000$, $2^{10}=1024$, $2^{11}=2048$, $2^{12}=4096$, $2^{13}=8192$, then the strongest statement one can make for $\log_{10}{2}$ is that it lies between:
$\textbf{(A)}\ \frac{3}{10} \; \text{and} \; \frac{4}{11}\qquad \textbf{(B)}\ \frac{3}{10} \; \text{and} \; \frac{4}{12}\qquad \textbf{(C)}\ \frac{3}{10} \; \text{and} \; \frac{4}{13}\qquad \textbf{(D)}\ \frac{3}{10} \; \text{and} \; \frac{40}{132}\qquad \textbf{(E)}\ \frac{3}{11} \; \text{and} \; \frac{40}{132}$ -/
theorem number_theory_95224 : 3 / 10 < logb 10 2 ‚àß logb 10 2 < 4 / 13 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real

theorem number_theory_95224 : 3 / 10 < logb 10 2 ‚àß logb 10 2 < 4 / 13 := by
  have h1 : 3 / 10 < logb 10 2 := by
    have h2 : logb 10 (2 ^ 10) > logb 10 (10 ^ 3) := by 
      have h3 : (2 ^ 10 : ‚Ñù) > (10 ^ 3 : ‚Ñù) := by
        norm_num
      have h4 : logb 10 (2 ^ 10) > logb 10 (10 ^ 3) := by 
        apply Real.logb_lt_logb
        all_goals 
          try norm_num 
          all_goals
            try linarith
      linarith [h4]
    have h5 : logb 10 (2 ^ 10) = 10 * logb 10 2 := by
      simp [logb_pow, mul_comm]
      <;> ring_nf
    have h6 : logb 10 (10 ^ 3) = (3 : ‚Ñù) := by
      simp [logb_pow]
    linarith [h2, h5, h6]

  have h7 : logb 10 2 < 4 / 13 := by
    have h8 : logb 10 (2 ^ 13) < logb 10 (10 ^ 4) := by 
      have h9 : (2 ^ 13 : ‚Ñù) < (10 ^ 4 : ‚Ñù) := by
        norm_num
      have h10 : logb 10 (2 ^ 13) < logb 10 (10 ^ 4) := by 
        apply Real.logb_lt_logb
        all_goals 
          try norm_num 
          all_goals
            try linarith 
      linarith [h10]
    have h5 : logb 10 (2 ^ 13) = 13 * logb 10 2 := by
      simp [logb_pow, mul_comm]
      <;> ring_nf
    have h6 : logb 10 (10 ^ 4) = (4 : ‚Ñù) := by
      simp [logb_pow]
    linarith [h8, h5, h6]

  constructor
  ¬∑ linarith 
  ¬∑ linarith

soln_description:
24. Let $a_{1}=x_{1}, a_{2}=x_{2}-x_{1}, \cdots, a_{n}=a-x_{n-1}, M=\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right)^{k+1}$,

From the given, $a_{i}>0(i=1,2, \cdots, n)$ and $\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}=a$,
Let $c_{i}=\frac{a_{i}}{a}$, then
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} c_{i}=\frac{1}{a} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}=1
$$

By the AM-GM inequality, $\frac{b_{i}^{k+1}}{c_{i}^{k}}+\underbrace{M c_{i}+M c_{i}+\cdots+M c_{i}}_{k \uparrow} \geqslant(k+1) \sqrt[k+1]{M^{*} b_{i}^{k+1}}$,
i.e., $\frac{b_{i}^{k-1}}{c_{i}^{k}}+k M c_{i} \geqslant(k+1)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right)^{k} \cdot b_{i}$,
then $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{b_{i}^{k+1}}{c_{i}^{k}}+k M \sum_{i=1}^{n} c_{i} \geqslant(k+1)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right)^{k+1}$.
Thus, $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{b_{i}^{k+1}}{c_{i}^{k}} \geqslant\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right)^{k+1}$,
i.e., $a^{k} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{b_{i}^{k-1}}{a_{i}^{k}} \geqslant\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right)^{k+1}, \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{b_{i}^{k+1}}{a_{i}^{k}} \geqslant \frac{\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right)^{k+1}}{\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)^{k}}$,
with equality if and only if $a_{i}=\left[\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}}{\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}}\right] b_{i}=\frac{a b_{i}}{\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}}$.
Therefore, $\frac{b_{1}^{k+1}}{x_{1}^{k}}+\frac{b_{2}^{k+2}}{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{k}}+\cdots+\frac{b_{n}^{k+1}}{\left(a-x_{n-1}\right)^{k}} \geqslant \frac{\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right)^{k+1}}{a^{k}}$.
informal_statement:
24. If $0<x_{1}<x_{2}<\cdots<x_{n-1}<a, b_{i} \in \mathbf{R}^{+}(i=1,2, \cdots, n), k \in \mathbf{N}^{*}$, then
$$
\frac{b_{1}^{k+1}}{x_{1}^{k}}+\frac{b_{2}^{k+1}}{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{k}}+\cdots+\frac{b_{n}^{k+1}}{\left(a-x_{n-1}\right)^{k}} \geqslant \frac{\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right)^{k+1}}{a^{k}},
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{i}=\frac{a b_{i}}{\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 24. If $0<x_{1}<x_{2}<\cdots<x_{n-1}<a, b_{i} \in \mathbf{R}^{+}(i=1,2, \cdots, n), k \in \mathbf{N}^{*}$, then
$$
\frac{b_{1}^{k+1}}{x_{1}^{k}}+\frac{b_{2}^{k+1}}{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{k}}+\cdots+\frac{b_{n}^{k+1}}{\left(a-x_{n-1}\right)^{k}} \geqslant \frac{\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right)^{k+1}}{a^{k}},
$$

with equality if and only if $a_{i}=\frac{a b_{i}}{\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}}$. -/
theorem inequalities_128004 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : 0 < n) (x : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (hx : StrictMono x) (a : ‚Ñù) (ha : a > 0) (b : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (hb : ‚àÄ i, 0 < b i) (k : ‚Ñï) (hk : 0 < k) :
    ‚àë i, (b i) ^ (k + 1) / (x i) ^ k ‚â• (‚àë i, b i) ^ (k + 1) / a ^ k ‚àß
    (‚àë i, (b i) ^ (k + 1) / (x i) ^ k = (‚àë i, b i) ^ (k + 1) / a ^ k ‚Üî
      ‚àÄ i, x i = a * b i / ‚àë j, b j) := by

soln_description:
[Proof] (1) Since $5 \mid (x+9y)$, then
$$
5 \mid (2x+18y).
$$

Also, $(2x+18y) + (8x+7y) = 10x+25y$.
Since $5 \mid (10x+25y)$, then
$$
5 \mid (8x+7y).
$$
(2) Since $4(3x-7y+12z) + 3(7x+2y-5z)$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
= 33x - 22y + 33z \\
= 11(3x - 2y + 3z).
\end{array}
$$

Since $11 \mid 11(3x-2y+3z)$,
and given $11 \mid (7x+2y-5z)$,

then $11 \mid (3x-7y+12z)$.
informal_statement:
$1 \cdot 7$ (1) $x, y$ are integers. If 5 ‡•§ $(x+9 y)$, prove that 5 ‡•§ $(8 x+7 y)$.
(2) $x, y, z$ are integers. If 11 ‡•§ $(7 x+2 y-5 z)$. Prove that 11 ‡•§ $(3 x-7 y+12 z)$.
(China Beijing Junior High School Grade 2 Mathematics Competition, 1987)
informal_proof:
We need to prove two distinct statements.

First, we prove that for any integers $x$ and $y$, if $5$ divides $(x + 9y)$, then $5$ divides $(8x + 7y)$.
Assume $5 \mid (x + 9y)$.
Multiplying the expression $(x + 9y)$ by $2$, we get $2(x + 9y) = 2x + 18y$.
Since $5 \mid (x + 9y)$, it follows that $5 \mid (2x + 18y)$.
Now consider the sum of $(2x + 18y)$ and $(8x + 7y)$:
$$ (2x + 18y) + (8x + 7y) = 10x + 25y $$
We can factor out $5$ from this sum: $10x + 25y = 5(2x + 5y)$.
This shows that $5 \mid (10x + 25y)$.
Since $5 \mid (2x + 18y)$ and $5 \mid (10x + 25y)$, it must divide their difference:
$$ (10x + 25y) - (2x + 18y) = 8x + 7y $$
Thus, $5 \mid (8x + 7y)$.

Second, we prove that for any integers $x$, $y$, and $z$, if $11$ divides $(7x + 2y - 5z)$, then $11$ divides $(3x - 7y + 12z)$.
Assume $11 \mid (7x + 2y - 5z)$.
Consider the following linear combination: $4 \cdot (3x - 7y + 12z) + 3 \cdot (7x + 2y - 5z)$.
$$
4(3x - 7y + 12z) + 3(7x + 2y - 5z) = (12x - 28y + 48z) + (21x + 6y - 15z)
$$
$$
= (12x + 21x) + (-28y + 6y) + (48z - 15z)
$$
$$
= 33x - 22y + 33z
$$
We can factor out $11$ from this result: $33x - 22y + 33z = 11(3x - 2y + 3z)$.
This shows that $4(3x - 7y + 12z) + 3(7x + 2y - 5z)$ is divisible by $11$.
Since $11 \mid (7x + 2y - 5z)$, it follows that $11 \mid 3(7x + 2y - 5z)$.
As the sum $4(3x - 7y + 12z) + 3(7x + 2y - 5z)$ is divisible by $11$, and the second term $3(7x + 2y - 5z)$ is divisible by $11$, their difference must also be divisible by $11$.
$$
[4(3x - 7y + 12z) + 3(7x + 2y - 5z)] - [3(7x + 2y - 5z)] = 4(3x - 7y + 12z)
$$
Therefore, $11 \mid 4(3x - 7y + 12z)$.
Since $11$ is a prime number and $11$ does not divide $4$, it must be that $11 \mid (3x - 7y + 12z)$.

Both statements have been proven.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $1 \cdot 7$ (1) $x, y$ are integers. If 5 ‡•§ $(x+9 y)$, prove that 5 ‡•§ $(8 x+7 y)$.
(2) $x, y, z$ are integers. If 11 ‡•§ $(7 x+2 y-5 z)$. Prove that 11 ‡•§ $(3 x-7 y+12 z)$.
(China Beijing Junior High School Grade 2 Mathematics Competition, 1987) -/
theorem number_theory_254742 :
    (‚àÄ x y : ‚Ñ§, 5 ‚à£ x + 9 * y ‚Üí 5 ‚à£ 8 * x + 7 * y) ‚àß
    (‚àÄ x y z : ‚Ñ§, 11 ‚à£ 7 * x + 2 * y - 5 * z ‚Üí 11 ‚à£ 3 * x - 7 * y + 12 * z) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_254742 :
    (‚àÄ x y : ‚Ñ§, 5 ‚à£ x + 9 * y ‚Üí 5 ‚à£ 8 * x + 7 * y) ‚àß
    (‚àÄ x y z : ‚Ñ§, 11 ‚à£ 7 * x + 2 * y - 5 * z ‚Üí 11 ‚à£ 3 * x - 7 * y + 12 * z) := by
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Assume h : 5 ‚à£ x + 9 * y, prove 5 ‚à£ 8 * x + 7 * y
    intro x y h
    omega
  ¬∑ -- Assume h : 11 ‚à£ 7 * x + 2 * y - 5 * z, prove 11 ‚à£ 3 * x - 7 * y + 12 * z
    intro x y z h
    omega

soln_description:
Solution. If $x_{1}$ and $x_{2}$ are roots of the equation $x^{2}+p x+q=0$, then according to Vieta's formulas we have

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x_{1}+x_{2}=-p \\
x_{1} x_{2}=q
\end{array}\right.
$$

From the above equations and the given equation (the dependence between $p$ and $q$), we get

$$
198=p+q=-\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)+x_{1} x_{2}=\left(x_{1}-1\right)\left(x_{2}-1\right)-1
$$

According to this, $\left(x_{1}-1\right)\left(x_{2}-1\right)=199$. Since $x_{1}, x_{2}$ are integers and $x_{1}-1, x_{2}-1$ are integers, and 199 is a prime number, we get

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x_{1}-1=1 \\
x_{2}-1=199
\end{array} \text { or } \quad \left\{\begin{array}{l}
x_{1}-1=-1 \\
x_{2}-1=-199
\end{array}\right.\right.
$$

The solutions $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)$ of the above systems are $(2,200)$ and $(0,198)$. For the solution $(2,200)$, according to Vieta's formulas, we get $p=-2-200=-202, q=2 \cdot 200=400$, and for the solution $(0,198)$ we have $p=-198, q=0$.
informal_statement: 3A. It is known that the roots of the equation $x^{2}+p x+q=0$ are integers. If $p+q=198$, determine the roots of the equation and the numbers $p$ and $q$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3A. It is known that the roots of the equation $x^{2}+p x+q=0$ are integers. If $p+q=198$, determine the roots of the equation and the numbers $p$ and $q$. -/
theorem algebra_251111 {p q : ‚Ñ§} (hroots : ‚àÉ x y, x ‚â† y ‚àß x^2 + p * x + q = 0 ‚àß y^2 + p * y + q = 0)
    (hsum : p + q = 198) :
    (x = 2 ‚àß y = 200) ‚à® (x = -202 ‚àß y = 400) ‚à® (x = 0 ‚àß y = 198) ‚à® (x = -198 ‚àß y = 0) := by

soln_description:
Proof. By the Cauchy inequality for three non-negative terms, we have:

$$
\frac{(p-a)+(p-b)+(p-c)}{3} \geq \sqrt[3]{(p-a)(p-b)(p-c)}
$$

or

$$
\frac{p}{3} \geq \sqrt[3]{(p-a)(p-b)(p-c)}
$$

After cubing, we get: $\frac{p^{3}}{27} \geq(p-a)(p-b)(p-c)$, or $\frac{p^{4}}{27} \geq p(p-a)(p-b)(p-c)$, i.e., $S^{2} \leq \frac{p^{4}}{27}$, from which $S \leq \frac{p^{2}}{3 \sqrt{3}}$.

The inequality is proved.
informal_statement:
Problem 19. Prove the inequality for triangle $ABC$ with area $S$ and perimeter $2p$:

$$
S \leq \frac{p^{2}}{3 \sqrt{3}}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- Problem 19. Prove the inequality for triangle $ABC$ with area $S$ and perimeter $2p$:

$$
S \leq \frac{p^{2}}{3 \sqrt{3}}
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_237773 (A B C : EuclideanSpace ‚Ñù (Fin 2))
  (hABC : ¬¨Collinear ‚Ñù {A, B, C}) (S p : ‚Ñù)
  (hS : S = (MeasureTheory.volume (convexHull ‚Ñù {A, B, C})).toReal)
  (hp : p = (dist B C + dist A C + dist A B) / 2) :
  S ‚â§ p^2 / (3 * sqrt 3) :=

soln_description:
The domain of the function includes all numbers except 1, $a$, and $b$, where the function is undefined.

To determine the range, we can simplify the function as follows:

$$
y=\frac{1}{1-x}\left(x+\frac{a}{1-a}+\frac{b-x}{(1-a)(1-b)}\right)
$$

Then, we add the fractions inside the large parentheses. A suitable common denominator is the denominator of the third fraction, so by extending the fractions, the sum of the numerators is

$$
\begin{gathered}
x(1-a)(1-b)+a(1-b)+b-x= \\
=(a+b-a b)-x(a+b-a b)=(1-x)(a+b-a b)
\end{gathered}
$$

(we expanded and then factored the sum back into a product). Noticing the possibility of simplification,

$$
y=\frac{1}{1-x} \cdot \frac{(1-x)(a+b-a b)}{(1-a)(1-b)}=\frac{a+b-a b}{(1-a)(1-b)}
$$

(since $1-x \neq 0$, as $x=1$ is not in the domain). Thus, the value of $y$ is independent of $x$ and is the number on the right-hand side, which alone constitutes the range of our function.

Pint√©r J√°nos (Sz√©kesfeh√©rv√°r, Teleki B. Gymnasium II. grade)
informal_statement:
A function is given by the following formula, where $x$ is the variable, and $a$ and $b$ are constants, neither of which is equal to 1. What could be the domain of the function? What is its range?

$$
\frac{x}{1-x}+\frac{a}{(1-x) \cdot(1-a)}+\frac{b-x}{(1-x) \cdot(1-a) \cdot(1-b)}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- A function is given by the following formula, where $x$ is the variable, and $a$ and $b$ are constants, neither of which is equal to 1. What could be the domain of the function? What is its range?

$$
\frac{x}{1-x}+\frac{a}{(1-x) \cdot(1-a)}+\frac{b-x}{(1-x) \cdot(1-a) \cdot(1-b)}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_162117 {a b : ‚Ñù} (ha : a ‚â† 1) (hb : b ‚â† 1)
    (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hf : f = fun x => x / (1 - x) + a / ((1 - x) * (1 - a)) +
      (b - x) / ((1 - x) * (1 - a) * (1 - b))) :
    ‚àÄ x, f x = (b - x) / ((1 - x) * (1 - b)) := by

soln_description:
For a number to be divisible by $36=4 \times 9$, it must be divisible by 4 and by 9. Therefore, the sum of the digits of the number $n$ we are looking for must be divisible by 9.

On the other hand, since all the digits are even, the sum of the digits is also even. Thus, the sum of the digits is at least 18. Since $0+2+4+6+8=20$, the number $n$ must be formed by the digits $0, 4, 6$, and 8.

The largest number we can form with these digits, without repeating, is 8640, which is also divisible by 4, ensuring that this is the number we are looking for.
informal_statement: Determine the largest multiple of 36 that has all even and different digits.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Determine the largest multiple of 36 that has all even and different digits. -/
theorem number_theory_252667 :
    IsGreatest {n | 36 ‚à£ n ‚àß (Nat.digits 10 n).length = 4 ‚àß ‚àÄ d ‚àà (Nat.digits 10 n), Even d ‚àß
      (Nat.digits 10 n).toFinset.card = 4} 8640 := by

soln_description:
Establishment.
Let $z^{n}=1$, then $z=\cos \frac{2 k \pi}{n}+i \sin \frac{2 k \pi}{n}, k=0,1,2, \cdots, n-1$.
$$
z^{n}-1=(z-1)\left(z^{n-1}+z^{n-2}+\cdots+z+1\right),
$$

Therefore, $z^{n-1}+z^{n-2}+\cdots+z+1$
$$
\begin{aligned}
= & \left(z-\cos \frac{2 \pi}{n}-i \sin \frac{2 \pi}{n}\right)\left(z-\cos \frac{4 \pi}{n}-i \sin \frac{4 \pi}{n}\right) \cdots \\
& \left(z-\cos \frac{2(n-1) \pi}{n}-i \sin \frac{2(n-1) \pi}{n}\right).
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $z=1$, we get
$n=\left(1-a_{1}\right)\left(1-a_{2}\right) \cdots\left(1-a_{n-1}\right)$, where $a_{k}=\cos \frac{2 k \pi}{n}+i \sin \frac{2 k \pi}{n}$.
$$
1-a_{k}=1-\cos \frac{2 k \pi}{n}-i \sin \frac{2 k \pi}{n}=2 \sin \frac{k \pi}{n}\left(\sin \frac{k \pi}{n}+i \cos \frac{k \pi}{n}\right).
$$

Therefore, $\left|1-a_{k}\right|=2\left|\sin \frac{k \pi}{n}\right|=2 \sin \frac{k \pi}{n}$,
So $n=2^{n-1} \sin \frac{\pi}{n} \sin \frac{2 \pi}{n} \cdots \sin \frac{(n-1) \pi}{n}$,
That is, $\sin \frac{\pi}{n} \sin \frac{2 \pi}{n} \cdots \sin \frac{(n-1) \pi}{n}=\frac{n}{2^{n-1}}$.
Substituting $2 n$ for $n$ in the above equation, we get $\sin \frac{\pi}{2 n} \sin \frac{2 \pi}{2 n} \cdots \sin \frac{(2 n-1) \pi}{2 n}=\frac{2 n}{2^{2 n-1}}$.
From (2) ‚ë¥, we get $\sin \frac{\pi}{2 n} \sin \frac{3 \pi}{2 n} \sin \frac{5 \pi}{2 n} \cdots \sin \frac{(2 n-1) \pi}{2 n}=\frac{1}{2^{n-1}}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- (1) $a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}=b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}$;
(2) $0<a_{1}=a_{2}, a_{t}+a_{i+1}=a_{i+2}(i=1,2, \cdots, n-2)$;
(3) $0<b_{1} \leqslant b_{2}, b_{i}+b_{i+1} \leqslant b_{i+2}(i=1,2, \cdots, n-2)$.

Prove: $a_{n-1}+a_{n} \leqslant b_{n-1}+b_{n}$
I. (50 points)
Is the equation $\quad \sin \frac{\pi}{2 n} \sin \frac{3 \pi}{2 n} \sin \frac{5 \pi}{2 n} \cdots \sin \frac{(2 n-1) \pi}{2 n}=\frac{1}{2^{n-1}}$ true for any natural number? Prove your conclusion. -/
theorem algebra_273850 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : 0 < n) :
    ‚àè i ‚àà Finset.range n, sin ((2 * i + 1) * œÄ / (2 * n)) =
    1 / 2 ^ (n - 1) := by

soln_description: We show that for x, y >= m >= 0, we have (1 + x)/(1 + y)  x, then y - x < y - m unless x = m and 1/(1 + y) < 1/(1 + m) unless y = m, so (y - m)(y - x)/( (1 + m)(1 + y) ) < (y - m) 2 /(1 + m) 2 . If x = y, then the lhs is zero and the rhs is positive unless also y = m. So we have proved the claim. Hence ‚àë 1 n (1 + x i )/(1 + x i+1 ) ‚â§ n + ‚àë (x i - x i+1 )/(1 + m) + ‚àë (x i - m) 2 /(1 + m) 2 , which is the required inequality since ‚àë (x i - x i+1 ) = 0. From the previous discussion we have equality iff all x i are equal. 7th Chinese 1992 ¬© John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 1 May 2002
informal_statement: 7th Chinese 1992 Problem A2 x i are non-negative reals with minimum m. Show that ‚àë 1 n (1 + x i )/(1 + x i+1 ) ‚â§ n + ‚àë (x i - m) 2 /(m + 1) 2 , where we take x n+1 to be x 1 . Show that we have equality iff all x i are equal.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset Real

/- 7th Chinese 1992 Problem A2 x i are non-negative reals with minimum m. Show that ‚àë 1 n (1 + x i )/(1 + x i+1 ) ‚â§ n + ‚àë (x i - m) 2 /(m + 1) 2 , where we take x n+1 to be x 1 . Show that we have equality iff all x i are equal. -/
theorem inequalities_143097 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : 0 < n) (x : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (hx : ‚àÄ i ‚àà Icc 1 n, 0 ‚â§ x i) (m : ‚Ñù) (hm : m = sInf {x i | i ‚àà Icc 1 n}) :
    ‚àë i ‚àà Icc 1 n, (1 + x i) / (1 + x ((i + 1) % n)) ‚â§ n + ‚àë i ‚àà Icc 1 n, (x i - m) ^ 2 / (m + 1) ^ 2 ‚àß
    (‚àë i ‚àà Icc 1 n, (1 + x i) / (1 + x ((i + 1) % n)) = n + ‚àë i ‚àà Icc 1 n, (x i - m) ^ 2 / (m + 1) ^ 2 ‚Üî
      ‚àÄ i ‚àà Icc 1 n, x i = m) := by

soln_description:
## First Solution.

Substitute $y=0$ into the initial expression and we get that for every $x \in \mathbb{Z}$,

$$
f(f(0))=f(x) f(0)
$$

If $f(0) \neq 0$, this means that $f(x)=\frac{f(f(0))}{f(0)}$ for every $x \in \mathbb{Z}$. But then the left side of the initial expression for all $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}$ is equal to $\frac{f(f(0))}{f(0)}$, and the right side is $\frac{f(f(0))^{2}}{f(0)^{2}}+y$. Since it is impossible for $\frac{f(f(0))}{f(0)}=\frac{f(f(0))^{2}}{f(0)^{2}}+y$ to hold for every $y \in \mathbb{Z}$, we conclude that $f(0)=0$. Now substitute $y=1$ into the initial expression. We get that for every $x \in \mathbb{Z}$,

$$
f(x+f(1))=f(x) f(1)+1
$$

In particular, for $x=-f(1)$, using $f(0)=0$, we get $0=f(-f(1)) f(1)+1$, or

$$
f(-f(1)) f(1)=-1
$$

Since $f(1)$ and $f(-f(1))$ are integers, we conclude that $f(1)=1$ or $f(1)=-1$.

If $f(1)=1$, then from (1) we get that for every $x \in \mathbb{Z}$, $f(x+1)=f(x)+1$. It follows that if $f(x)=x$, then $f(x+1)=x+1$ and $f(x-1)=x-1$, and since $f(0)=0$, by mathematical induction we conclude that $f(x)=x$ for every $x \in \mathbb{Z}$. It is easy to verify that this function satisfies the initial condition.

If $f(1)=-1$, then $f(-f(1))=1$. However, using $f(1)=-1$, we get $f(-f(1))=f(-(-1))=f(1)=-1$, which is a contradiction.
informal_statement:
## Task 1.

Determine all functions $f: \mathbb{Z} \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}$ such that for all $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}$,

$$
f(x y + f(y)) = f(x) f(y) + y
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task 1.

Determine all functions $f: \mathbb{Z} \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}$ such that for all $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}$,

$$
f(x y + f(y)) = f(x) f(y) + y
$$ -/
theorem algebra_250495 (f : ‚Ñ§ ‚Üí ‚Ñ§) :
    (‚àÄ x y, f (x * y + f y) = f x * f y + y) ‚Üî ‚àÄ x, f x = x := by

soln_description: Solution. Let $x$ be the smallest natural number such that $2 x=b^{2}, 3 x=c^{3}$, where $b$ and $c$ are natural numbers. From the equation $2 x=b^{2}$, it follows that $x$ is divisible by 2. Since $3 x=c^{3}$, $x$ is divisible by $2^{3}=8$ and by $3^{2}=9$, i.e., $x=2^{3} \cdot 3^{2} a^{6}=72 a^{6}$, where $a$ is any natural number. The smallest $x$ is obtained when $a=1$. Answer: 72.
informal_statement: 19(1260). Find the smallest natural number that, when multiplied by 2, becomes a square, and when multiplied by 3, becomes a cube of a natural number.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 19(1260). Find the smallest natural number that, when multiplied by 2, becomes a square, and when multiplied by 3, becomes a cube of a natural number. -/
theorem number_theory_197050 :
    IsLeast {n | ‚àÉ k, n * 2 = k ^ 2 ‚àß ‚àÉ m, n * 3 = m ^ 3} 72 := by

soln_description:
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text{Since } a_{1}=a_{0}+\frac{1}{n} a_{0}^{2}=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{4 n}=\frac{2 n+1}{4 n}, \text{ it is easy to prove that } \frac{n+1}{2 n+1} \\
& \frac{n+1}{2 n-k+2}+\frac{(n+1)^{2}}{n(2 n-k+2)^{2}} \\
& =\frac{n+1}{2 n-k+1}-\frac{n+1}{(2 n-k+1)(2 n-k+2)}+\frac{(n+1)^{2}}{n(2 n-k+2)^{2}} \\
& =\frac{n+1}{2 n-(k+1)+2}+\frac{n+1}{2 n-k+2}\left[\frac{n+1}{n(2 n-k+2)}-\frac{1}{2 n-k+1}\right] \\
& >\frac{n+1}{2 n-(k+1)+2}
\end{aligned}
$$

From the above two steps, we know that for $k+1 \leqslant n$ it still holds, so (1) holds for all $k=1,2,3$, $\cdots, n$.

Taking $k=n$ in (1), we get $1-\frac{1}{n}<\frac{n+1}{n+2}<a_{n}<\frac{n}{n}=1$.
informal_statement: Example 8 If the sequence $a_{0}, a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots$ satisfies the conditions: $a_{1}=\frac{1}{2}, a_{k+1}=a_{k}+\frac{1}{n} a_{k}^{2}$ $(k=0,1,2, \cdots)$, where $n$ is some fixed positive integer. Prove: $1-\frac{1}{n}<a_{n}<$ 1. (1980 IMO Problem)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 8 If the sequence $a_{0}, a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots$ satisfies the conditions: $a_{1}=\frac{1}{2}, a_{k+1}=a_{k}+\frac{1}{n} a_{k}^{2}$ $(k=0,1,2, \cdots)$, where $n$ is some fixed positive integer. Prove: $1-\frac{1}{n}<a_{n}<$ 1. (1980 IMO Problem) -/
theorem algebra_601165 (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : n > 0)
    (ha1 : a 1 = 1 / 2) (hak : ‚àÄ k, a (k + 1) = a k + (1 / n) * (a k) ^ 2) :
    1 - (1 / n) < a n ‚àß a n < 1 := by

soln_description:
Nineteenth question,
Solution: On the one hand, take \(a_{1}=a_{3}=\ldots=a_{99}=\sqrt{1+\varepsilon}, a_{2}=a_{4}=\ldots=a_{100}=\sqrt{1-\varepsilon}\), where \(\varepsilon \in[-1,1]\), then
\[
\begin{array}{l}
100(\sqrt{1+\varepsilon}-\sqrt{1-\varepsilon})^{2} \leq 50 \lambda(2-(\sqrt{1+\varepsilon}+\sqrt{1-\varepsilon})) \\
\Rightarrow \lambda \geq \frac{2(\sqrt{1+\varepsilon}-\sqrt{1-\varepsilon})^{2}}{2-(\sqrt{1+\varepsilon}+\sqrt{1-\varepsilon})}
\end{array}
\]

Notice that \(\sqrt{1+\varepsilon}+\sqrt{1-\varepsilon} \leq 2\), and \((\sqrt{1+\varepsilon}+\sqrt{1-\varepsilon})^{2}+(\sqrt{1+\varepsilon}-\sqrt{1-\varepsilon})^{2}=4\). Let \(\sqrt{1+\varepsilon}+\sqrt{1-\varepsilon}=2-\omega\), then \((\sqrt{1+\varepsilon}-\sqrt{1-\varepsilon})^{2}=4-(2-\omega)^{2}\), and when \(\varepsilon \rightarrow 0\), \(\omega \rightarrow 0^{+}\). Thus, we know:
\[
\lambda \geq \lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0} \frac{2(\sqrt{1+\varepsilon}-\sqrt{1-\varepsilon})^{2}}{2-(\sqrt{1+\varepsilon}+\sqrt{1-\varepsilon})}=\lim _{\omega \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{2\left(4-(2-\omega)^{2}\right)}{\omega}=8
\]

Next, we prove:
\[
\sum_{i=1}^{100}\left(a_{i}-a_{i+1}\right)^{2} \leq 8\left(100-\left(\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}\right)\right)
\]

In fact,
\[
\begin{array}{l}
8\left(100-\left(\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}\right)\right)=8\left(\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}^{2}-\frac{\left(\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}\right) \sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}^{2}}}{10}\right) \\
=\frac{2}{25}\left(100 \sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}^{2}-\left(\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}\right) \sqrt{100 \cdot \sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}^{2}}\right) \\
=\frac{2}{25} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{100 \cdot \sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{1}^{2}} \cdot\left(100 \sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}^{2}-\left(\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}\right)^{2}\right)}{\sqrt{100 \sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}^{2}}+\left(\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}\right)} \\
\geq \frac{100 \sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}^{2}-\left(\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}\right)^{2}}{25}
\end{array}
\]

Therefore, we only need to prove:
\[
\sum_{i=1}^{100}\left(a_{i}-a_{i+1}\right)^{2} \leq \frac{100 \sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}^{2}-\left(\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}\right)^{2}}{25}
\]

Notice that \(100 \sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}^{2}-\left(\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}\right)^{2}=\sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq 100}\left(a_{i}-a_{j}\right)^{2}\), by translation invariance, we can assume \(\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}=0\), then we only need to prove:
\[
\sum_{i=1}^{100}\left(a_{i}-a_{i+1}\right)^{2} \leq 4 \sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}^{2}
\]

In fact,
\[
\sum_{i=1}^{100}\left(a_{i}-a_{i+1}\right)^{2} \leq 4\left(\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}^{2}\right) \Leftrightarrow \sum_{i=1}^{100}\left(a_{i}+a_{i+1}\right)^{2} \geq 0
\]

The above inequality is obviously true.
In conclusion, the minimum value of \(\lambda\) is 8.
informal_statement: The nineteenth question: Find the smallest real number $\lambda$ such that $\sum_{i=1}^{100}\left(a_{i}-a_{i+1}\right)^{2} \leq \lambda\left(100-\left(\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}\right)\right)$ holds for any real numbers $a_{1} „ÄÅ a_{2} „ÄÅ \ldots „ÄÅ a_{100}$ satisfying $\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}^{2}=100$. Here $a_{101}=a_{1}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- The nineteenth question: Find the smallest real number $\lambda$ such that $\sum_{i=1}^{100}\left(a_{i}-a_{i+1}\right)^{2} \leq \lambda\left(100-\left(\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}\right)\right)$ holds for any real numbers $a_{1} „ÄÅ a_{2} „ÄÅ \ldots „ÄÅ a_{100}$ satisfying $\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_{i}^{2}=100$. Here $a_{101}=a_{1}$. -/
theorem inequalities_191527 :
  IsLeast {x | ‚àÄ a : Fin 101 ‚Üí ‚Ñù, (‚àë i : Fin 100, a i ^ 2) = 100 ‚Üí
    ‚àë i : Fin 100, (a i - a (i + 1)) ^ 2 ‚â§ x * (100 - ‚àë i : Fin 100, a i)} 8 := by

soln_description:
(Hint: Let $a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{14}=1996, a_{1} \leqslant a_{2} \leqslant \cdots \leqslant a_{19}$.

If $a_{19}>a_{1}+1$, then let $a_{19}^{\prime}=a_{19}-1, a_{1}^{\prime}=a_{1}+1$. Such an adjustment keeps the sum of these 19 numbers unchanged. However, because
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a_{1}^{\prime} a_{19}^{\prime}=\left(a_{1}+1\right)\left(a_{19}-1\right) \\
=a_{1} a_{19}+\left(a_{19}-a_{1}-1\right)>a_{1} a_{19},
\end{array}
$$

the product increases. Thus, the 19 positive integers can be adjusted to $106, \underbrace{105,105, \cdots, 105}_{18 \text { of them }}$. At this point, the maximum product is $105^{18} \times 106$. )
informal_statement:
2. Divide 1996 into the sum of 19 positive integers, prove that the maximum value of their product is $105^{18} \times 106$.

Translate the above text into English, please keep the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly.
