Given the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ with the general term
$$
a_{n}=(\sqrt{3}+\sqrt{2})^{2 n}\left(n \in \mathbf{N}_{+}\right) \text {, }
$$

Let $b_{n}=a_{n}+\frac{1}{a_{n}}$.
(1) Find the recurrence relation between $b_{n+2} „ÄÅ b_{n+1} „ÄÅ b_{n}$;
(2) Find the unit digit of the integer part of $a_{2011}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Given the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ with the general term
$$
a_{n}=(\sqrt{3}+\sqrt{2})^{2 n}\left(n \in \mathbf{N}_{+}\right) \text {, }
$$

Let $b_{n}=a_{n}+\frac{1}{a_{n}}$.
(1) Find the recurrence relation between $b_{n+2} „ÄÅ b_{n+1} „ÄÅ b_{n}$;
(2) Find the unit digit of the integer part of $a_{2011}$. -/
theorem algebra_315973 {a b : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù}
    (ha : ‚àÄ n, 0 < n ‚Üí a n = (sqrt 3 + sqrt 2) ^ (2 * n))
    (hb : ‚àÄ n, 0 < n ‚Üí b n = a n + 1 / a n) :
    (‚àÄ n, 0 < n ‚Üí b (n + 2) = b (n + 1) ^ 2) ‚àß
    (Nat.floor (a 2011) % 10 = 9) := by

soln_description:
5. Solution: We have
$$\left(\frac{10}{p}\right)=\left(\frac{2}{p}\right)\left(\frac{5}{p}\right)$$

By Example 2 of this chapter, we have

And by Theorem 9, we have
$$\begin{array}{l}
\left(\frac{5}{p}\right)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
1, & p \equiv \pm 1(\bmod 5), \\
-1, & p \equiv \pm 2(\bmod 5),
\end{array}\right. \\
\text { and } \\
\left(\frac{2}{p}\right)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
1, & p \equiv \pm 1(\bmod 8), \\
-1, & p \equiv \pm 3(\bmod 8) .
\end{array}\right.
\end{array}$$

Solve the following systems of congruences:
$$\begin{array}{l}
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
p \equiv 1(\bmod 5), \\
p \equiv 1(\bmod 8),
\end{array}, \begin{array}{l}
p \equiv 1(\bmod 5), \\
p \equiv-1(\bmod 8)
\end{array},\left\{\begin{array}{l}
p \equiv-1(\bmod 5) \\
p \equiv 1(\bmod 8),
\end{array}\right.\right. \\
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
p \equiv-1(\bmod 5), \\
p=-1(\bmod 8) .
\end{array}\right.
\end{array}$$

We get
$$\begin{array}{l}
p \equiv 1(\bmod 40), p \equiv 31(\bmod 40), p \equiv 9(\bmod 40) \\
p \equiv-1(\bmod 40),
\end{array}$$
Thus, for $p \equiv \pm 1, \pm 9(\bmod 40)$, we have $\left(\frac{10}{p}\right)=1$.
Solve the following systems of congruences:
$$\begin{array}{l}
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
p \equiv 2(\bmod 5), \\
p \equiv 3(\bmod 8),
\end{array},\left\{\begin{array}{l}
p \equiv 2(\bmod 5), \\
p \equiv-3(\bmod 8),
\end{array},\left\{\begin{array}{l}
p \equiv-2(\bmod 5) \\
p \equiv 3(\bmod 8),
\end{array}\right.\right.\right. \\
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
p \equiv=-2(\bmod 5), \\
p \equiv-3(\bmod 8) .
\end{array}\right.
\end{array}$$

We get $p \equiv 27,-3,3,-27(\bmod 40)$, and thus we also know that when $p= \pm 27, \pm 3$, we have $\left(\frac{10}{p}\right)=1$.
Therefore, we conclude that if and only if
$$p \equiv \pm 1, \pm 3, \pm 9, \pm 13,(\bmod 40)$$

$p$ has 10 as a quadratic residue. Similarly, we can prove that if and only if
$$p \equiv \pm 7, \pm 11, \pm 17, \pm 19(\bmod 40)$$

$p$ has 10 as a quadratic non-residue.
informal_statement: 5. Find the prime $p$ for which 10 is a quadratic residue.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. Find the prime $p$ for which 10 is a quadratic residue. -/
theorem number_theory_7315 {p : ‚Ñï} (hp : p.Prime) :
    ‚àÉ x, x^2 ‚â° 10 [MOD p] ‚Üî p ‚â° 1 [ZMOD 40] ‚à® p ‚â° -1 [ZMOD 40] ‚à®
    p ‚â° 3 [ZMOD 40] ‚à® p ‚â° -3 [ZMOD 40] ‚à® p ‚â° 9 [ZMOD 40] ‚à®
    p ‚â° -9 [ZMOD 40] ‚à® p ‚â° 13 [ZMOD 40] ‚à® p ‚â° -13 [ZMOD 40] := by

informal_statement:
Determine if the graph of the equation below is a parabola, circle, ellipse, hyperbola, point, line, two lines, or empty.

$x^2 + 2y^2 - 6x - 20y + 59 = 12$
informal_proof:
We are given the equation $x^2 + 2y^2 - 6x - 20y + 59 = 12$ for real numbers $x$ and $y$. We want to show that there exist positive real numbers $a$ and $b$ such that $\frac{x^2}{a^2} + \frac{y^2}{b^2} = 1$.

First, we establish that for any $x, y$ satisfying the given equation, the quantity $x^2 + y^2$ must be strictly positive. We prove this by contradiction. Assume that $x^2 + y^2 \leq 0$. Since the square of any real number is non-negative, i.e., $x^2 \geq 0$ and $y^2 \geq 0$, the condition $x^2 + y^2 \leq 0$ implies that both $x^2$ and $y^2$ must be zero. This means $x = 0$ and $y = 0$.

Substituting $x=0$ and $y=0$ into the original equation yields:
$0^2 + 2(0)^2 - 6(0) - 20(0) + 59 = 12$
$0 + 0 - 0 - 0 + 59 = 12$
$59 = 12$
This is a false statement, a contradiction. Therefore, our assumption $x^2 + y^2 \leq 0$ must be false. Consequently, $x^2 + y^2 > 0$.

Now, we choose $a = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}$ and $b = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}$. Since $x^2 + y^2 > 0$, both $a$ and $b$ are well-defined positive real numbers.

We now verify the condition $\frac{x^2}{a^2} + \frac{y^2}{b^2} = 1$.
Substituting $a^2 = x^2 + y^2$ and $b^2 = x^2 + y^2$, the expression becomes:
$\frac{x^2}{x^2 + y^2} + \frac{y^2}{x^2 + y^2}$

Since the denominators are identical and non-zero, we can combine the fractions:
$\frac{x^2 + y^2}{x^2 + y^2}$

As $x^2 + y^2 > 0$, this fraction simplifies to $1$. Thus, $\frac{x^2}{a^2} + \frac{y^2}{b^2} = 1$.

We have successfully found positive real numbers $a = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}$ and $b = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}$ that satisfy the required conditions. This indicates that the point $(x, y)$ lies on an ellipse centered at the origin with semi-axes determined by $x$ and $y$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Determine if the graph of the equation below is a parabola, circle, ellipse, hyperbola, point, line, two lines, or empty.

$x^2 + 2y^2 - 6x - 20y + 59 = 12$ -/
theorem algebra_22282 (x y : ‚Ñù) (h : x ^ 2 + 2 * y ^ 2 - 6 * x - 20 * y + 59 = 12) :
    ‚àÉ a b, x ^ 2 / a ^ 2 + y ^ 2 / b ^ 2 = 1 ‚àß a > 0 ‚àß b > 0 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_22282 (x y : ‚Ñù) (h : x ^ 2 + 2 * y ^ 2 - 6 * x - 20 * y + 59 = 12) :
    ‚àÉ a b, x ^ 2 / a ^ 2 + y ^ 2 / b ^ 2 = 1 ‚àß a > 0 ‚àß b > 0 := by 
  use Real.sqrt (x^2 + y^2)
  use Real.sqrt (x^2 + y^2)
  have h1 : x^2 + y^2 > 0 := by
    by_contra H
    push_neg at H
    have h2 : x^2 ‚â• 0 := by
      exact sq_nonneg x
    have h3 : y^2 ‚â• 0 := by
      exact sq_nonneg y
    have h4 : x^2 = 0 := by
      linarith [sq_nonneg x, sq_nonneg y]
    have h5 : y^2 = 0 := by
      linarith [sq_nonneg x, sq_nonneg y]
    have hx : x = 0 := by
      rwa [sq_eq_zero_iff] at h4
    have hy : y = 0 := by
      rwa [sq_eq_zero_iff] at h5
    rw [hx, hy] at h
    nlinarith
  have ha : Real.sqrt (x^2 + y^2) > 0 := by
    positivity
  have hb : Real.sqrt (x^2 + y^2) > 0 := by
    positivity
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Show that x^2 / a^2 + y^2 / b^2 = 1
    field_simp [ha.ne.symm, hb.ne.symm]
    <;> nlinarith [Real.sqrt_pos.mpr h1]
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Show that a > 0
    exact ha
  ¬∑ -- Show that b > 0
    exact hb

soln_description:
Solution: (1) $\frac{x_{n+1}-1}{x_{n+1}+1}=\frac{f\left(x_{n}\right)-1}{f\left(x_{n}\right)+1}=\frac{\frac{x_{n}^{3}+3 x_{n}}{3 x_{n}^{2}+1}-1}{\frac{x_{n}^{3}+3 x_{n}}{3 x_{n}^{2}+1}+1}=\frac{x_{n}^{3}-3 x_{n}^{2}+3 x_{n}-1}{x_{n}^{3}+3 x_{n}^{2}+3 x_{n}+1}=\left(\frac{x_{n}-1}{x_{n}+1}\right)^{3}$
(5 points)
Thus, $\log _{3}\left(\frac{x_{n+1}-1}{x_{n+1}+1}\right)=3 \log _{3}\left(\frac{x_{n}-1}{x_{n}+1}\right)$, i.e., $b_{n+1}=3 b_{n}$, so the sequence $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$ is a geometric sequence. Also, $b_{1}=\log _{3}\left(\frac{2-1}{2+1}\right)=-1$, thus $b_{n}=-3^{n-1}$. Therefore, the general term formula of the sequence $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$ is $b_{n}=-3^{n-1}$.
(10 points)
(II) From (I), we know that $b_{n}=-3^{n-1}$, hence $c_{n}=n \cdot 3^{n-1}$,
$$
\begin{array}{c}
T_{n}=1 \times 3^{0}+2 \times 3^{1}+3 \times 3^{2}+\cdots+n \times 3^{n-1}, \\
3 T_{n}=\quad 1 \times 3^{1}+2 \times 3^{2}+3 \times 3^{3}+\cdots+n \times 3^{n},
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $-2 T_{n}=1+3+3^{2}+\cdots+3^{n-1}-n \times 3^{n}=\frac{3^{n}-1}{2}-n \times 3^{n}$,
i.e., $T_{n}=\frac{n \times 3^{n}}{2}-\frac{3^{n}-1}{4}=\frac{(2 n-1) \cdot 3^{n}+1}{4}$,

Therefore, the sum of the first $n$ terms of the sequence $\left\{c_{n}\right\}$ is $T_{n}=\frac{(2 n-1) \cdot 3^{n}+1}{4}\left(n \in N^{*}\right)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 14. Given the function $f(x)=\frac{x^{3}+3 x}{3 x^{2}+1}$, the sequence $\left\{x_{n}\right\}$ satisfies: $x_{1}=2, x_{n+1}=f\left(x_{n}\right)\left(n \in N^{*}\right)$, and let $b_{n}=\log _{3}\left(\frac{x_{n+1}-1}{x_{n+1}+1}\right) \quad\left(n \in N^{*}\right)$.
(I) Prove that the sequence $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$ is a geometric sequence, and find the general term formula for the sequence $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$;
(II) Let $c_{n}=-n b_{n}\left(n \in N^{*}\right)$, find the sum of the first $n$ terms of the sequence $\left\{c_{n}\right\}$, denoted as $T_{n}$. -/
theorem algebra_102026 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (hf : f = fun x => (x^3 + 3 * x) / (3 * x^2 + 1))
    (x : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hx1 : x 1 = 2) (hxn : ‚àÄ n, x (n + 1) = f (x n))
    (b : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hb : ‚àÄ n, b n = logb 3 ((x (n + 1) - 1) / (x (n + 1) + 1))) :
    (‚àÉ r, ‚àÄ n, b (n + 1) = r * b n) ‚àß
    (‚àÄ n, b n = (2 * n - 1) * 3^n + 1) ‚àß
    (‚àë i in Finset.range n, (-i) * b i = ((2 * n - 1) * 3^n + 1) / 4) := by

informal_statement: A rectangular playground is to be constructed adjacent to a school building, utilizing the building's walls as part of the playground's boundary. The playground will be bordered by the school's walls, which are 30 feet and 50 feet in length, and the remaining sides will be fenced. Given that the total length of the fencing available is 100 feet, determine the dimensions of the playground that maximize the enclosed area. What is the maximum area that can be enclosed under these conditions?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- A rectangular playground is to be constructed adjacent to a school building, utilizing the building's walls as part of the playground's boundary. The playground will be bordered by the school's walls, which are 30 feet and 50 feet in length, and the remaining sides will be fenced. Given that the total length of the fencing available is 100 feet, determine the dimensions of the playground that maximize the enclosed area. What is the maximum area that can be enclosed under these conditions? -/
theorem algebra_5915 {a b : ‚Ñï} (ha : a > 0) (hb : b > 0)
    (h : 2 * (a + b) = 100 + 2 * 30 + 2 * 50) :
    a * b ‚â§ 2000 := by

soln_description:
By analyzing, we compare $E_{1}$ with $x^{2}-x-1=0$ and find that $m, n$ are the two distinct real roots of the equation. By Vieta's formulas, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
m+n= & 1, m n=-1 \\
m^{2}+n^{2} & =(m+n)^{2}-2 m n=3 \\
m^{3}+n^{3} & =(m+n)\left(m^{2}+n^{2}\right)-m n(m+n) \\
& =4 .
\end{aligned}
$$

By analogy with the above process, we can reduce the target expression to a lower-degree algebraic expression in terms of known values.
$$
\begin{array}{l} 
m^{4}+n^{4}=\left(m^{2}+n^{2}\right)^{2}-2 m^{2} n^{2} \\
=9-2 \times 1=7, \\
m^{5}+n^{5}=\left(m^{2}+n^{2}\right)\left(m^{3}+n^{3}\right)-m^{2} n^{2}(m+ \\
n)=11 .
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement: Example 1. If $m^{2}=m+1, n^{2}=n+1$, and $m \neq n$, then $m^{5}+n^{5}=$ $\qquad$ (Math Competition)
informal_proof:
We are given two real numbers, $m$ and $n$, such that $m \neq n$, and they both satisfy the equation $x^2 = x + 1$. We want to show that $m^5 + n^5 = 11$.

First, let's establish a relationship between $m$ and $n$. We are given:
1.  $m^2 = m + 1$
2.  $n^2 = n + 1$

Subtracting the second equation from the first, we get:
$m^2 - n^2 = (m + 1) - (n + 1)$
$m^2 - n^2 = m - n$

Since $m \neq n$, we know that $m - n \neq 0$. We can factor the left side as $(m - n)(m + n)$:
$(m - n)(m + n) = m - n$

Because $m - n \neq 0$, we can divide both sides by $(m - n)$:
$m + n = 1$

Now that we know $m+n=1$, we can compute higher powers of $m$ and $n$ by repeatedly using the relation $x^2 = x + 1$.

Let's find $m^3$:
$m^3 = m \cdot m^2$
Substitute $m^2 = m + 1$:
$m^3 = m(m + 1) = m^2 + m$
Substitute $m^2 = m + 1$ again:
$m^3 = (m + 1) + m = 2m + 1$

Similarly, for $n^3$:
$n^3 = n \cdot n^2 = n(n + 1) = n^2 + n = (n + 1) + n = 2n + 1$

Next, let's find $m^4$:
$m^4 = m \cdot m^3$
Substitute $m^3 = 2m + 1$:
$m^4 = m(2m + 1) = 2m^2 + m$
Substitute $m^2 = m + 1$:
$m^4 = 2(m + 1) + m = 2m + 2 + m = 3m + 2$

Similarly, for $n^4$:
$n^4 = n \cdot n^3 = n(2n + 1) = 2n^2 + n = 2(n + 1) + n = 2n + 2 + n = 3n + 2$

Finally, let's find $m^5$:
$m^5 = m \cdot m^4$
Substitute $m^4 = 3m + 2$:
$m^5 = m(3m + 2) = 3m^2 + 2m$
Substitute $m^2 = m + 1$:
$m^5 = 3(m + 1) + 2m = 3m + 3 + 2m = 5m + 3$

Similarly, for $n^5$:
$n^5 = n \cdot n^4 = n(3n + 2) = 3n^2 + 2n = 3(n + 1) + 2n = 3n + 3 + 2n = 5n + 3$

Now, we can compute $m^5 + n^5$:
$m^5 + n^5 = (5m + 3) + (5n + 3)$
Group the terms:
$m^5 + n^5 = 5m + 5n + 3 + 3$
$m^5 + n^5 = 5(m + n) + 6$

Using the fact that $m + n = 1$:
$m^5 + n^5 = 5(1) + 6$
$m^5 + n^5 = 5 + 6$
$m^5 + n^5 = 11$

This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 1. If $m^{2}=m+1, n^{2}=n+1$, and $m \neq n$, then $m^{5}+n^{5}=$ $\qquad$ (Math Competition) -/
theorem algebra_326667 {m n : ‚Ñù} (h‚ÇÄ : m ‚â† n) (h‚ÇÅ : m^2 = m + 1) (h‚ÇÇ : n^2 = n + 1) :
    m^5 + n^5 = 11 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_326667 {m n : ‚Ñù} (h‚ÇÄ : m ‚â† n) (h‚ÇÅ : m^2 = m + 1) (h‚ÇÇ : n^2 = n + 1) :
    m^5 + n^5 = 11 := by

  have h3 : m + n = 1 := by
    have h : m^2 - n^2 = m - n := by linarith
    have h4 : m - n ‚â† 0 := by
      intro h'
      have h5 : m = n := by linarith
      contradiction
    have h5 : m + n = 1 := by
      apply (mul_left_inj' h4).mp
      linarith
    exact h5

  have eq1 : m^2 = m + 1 := h‚ÇÅ
  have eq2 : n^2 = n + 1 := h‚ÇÇ

  have eq3 : m^3 = 2 * m + 1 := by
    calc
      m^3 = m * m^2 := by ring
      _ = m * (m + 1) := by rw [eq1]
      _ = m^2 + m := by ring
      _ = (m + 1) + m := by rw [eq1]
      _ = 2 * m + 1 := by ring

  have eq4 : n^3 = 2 * n + 1 := by
    calc
      n^3 = n * n^2 := by ring
      _ = n * (n + 1) := by rw [eq2]
      _ = n^2 + n := by ring
      _ = (n + 1) + n := by rw [eq2]
      _ = 2 * n + 1 := by ring

  have eq5 : m^4 = 3 * m + 2 := by
    calc
      m^4 = m * m^3 := by ring
      _ = m * (2 * m + 1) := by rw [eq3]
      _ = 2 * m^2 + m := by ring
      _ = 2 * (m + 1) + m := by rw [eq1]
      _ = 2 * m + 2 + m := by ring
      _ = 3 * m + 2 := by ring

  have eq6 : n^4 = 3 * n + 2 := by
    calc
      n^4 = n * n^3 := by ring
      _ = n * (2 * n + 1) := by rw [eq4]
      _ = 2 * n^2 + n := by ring
      _ = 2 * (n + 1) + n := by rw [eq2]
      _ = 2 * n + 2 + n := by ring
      _ = 3 * n + 2 := by ring

  have eq7 : m^5 = 5 * m + 3 := by
    calc
      m^5 = m * m^4 := by ring
      _ = m * (3 * m + 2) := by rw [eq5]
      _ = 3 * m^2 + 2 * m := by ring
      _ = 3 * (m + 1) + 2 * m := by rw [eq1]
      _ = 3 * m + 3 + 2 * m := by ring
      _ = 5 * m + 3 := by ring

  have eq8 : n^5 = 5 * n + 3 := by
    calc
      n^5 = n * n^4 := by ring
      _ = n * (3 * n + 2) := by rw [eq6]
      _ = 3 * n^2 + 2 * n := by ring
      _ = 3 * (n + 1) + 2 * n := by rw [eq2]
      _ = 3 * n + 3 + 2 * n := by ring
      _ = 5 * n + 3 := by ring

  calc
    m^5 + n^5 = (5 * m + 3) + (5 * n + 3) := by rw [eq7, eq8]
    _ = 5 * (m + n) + 6 := by ring
    _ = 5 * (1) + 6 := by rw [h3]
    _ = 11 := by norm_num

soln_description:
## Solution

We assume the contrary is true. So there are $x$ and $y$ that satisfy the equation. Hence we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
x^{2006}=4 y^{2007}+4 y^{2006}+2007 y+2006 \\
x^{2006}+1=4 y^{2006}(y+1)+2007(y+1) \\
x^{2006}+1=\left(4 y^{2006}+2007\right)(y+1)
\end{gathered}
$$

But $4 y^{2006}+2007 \equiv 3(\bmod 4)$, so $x^{2006}+1$ will have at least one prime divisor of the type $4 k+3$. It is known (and easily obtainable by using Fermat's Little Theorem) that this is impossible.
informal_statement: NT2 Prove that the equation $x^{2006}-4 y^{2006}-2006=4 y^{2007}+2007 y$ has no solution in the set of the positive integers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 
NT2 Prove that the equation $x^{2006}-4 y^{2006}-2006=4 y^{2007}+2007 y$ has no solution in the set of the positive integers.

 -/
theorem number_theory_102246 :
    ¬¨‚àÉ x y : ‚Ñï, x > 0 ‚àß y > 0 ‚àß x^2006 - 4 * y^2006 - 2006 = 4 * y^2007 + 2007 * y := by

soln_description:
## Solution.

Let wheel $A$ make $x$ revolutions, and wheel $B$ make $y$ revolutions. Since the wheels are meshed, the same number of teeth of each wheel will come into contact over the time of their rotation, i.e., $12 x = 54 y$, from which $x = \frac{9}{2} y$. The number $x$ is a natural number, so the smallest value of $y = 2$.

Answer: 9 and 2.
informal_statement: 13.314. Two gears are in mesh. Gear $A$ has 12 teeth, and gear $B$ has 54. How many revolutions will each gear make before both return to their initial position?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 13.314. Two gears are in mesh. Gear $A$ has 12 teeth, and gear $B$ has 54. How many revolutions will each gear make before both return to their initial position? -/
theorem number_theory_176897 : lcm 12 54 = 92 := by

soln_description: 5. $f(x)=\frac{a+x}{a-x}$, then for $x_{1}, x_{2} \in(0, s)$, we have $\left(\frac{a+x_{1}}{a-x_{1}}\right)\left(\frac{a+x_{2}}{a-x_{2}}\right) \geqslant\left(\frac{a+\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}}{2}}{a-\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}}{2}}\right)^{2}$. Thus, $g(x)=\ln f(x)$ is a convex function. It is easy to see that: $\prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{a+x_{i}}{a-x_{i}} \geqslant\left[\frac{a+\frac{1}{n}\left(x_{1}+\cdots+x_{n}\right)}{a-\frac{1}{n}\left(x_{1}+\cdots+x_{n}\right)}\right]^{n}$. Therefore, $\prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{a+x_{i}}{a-x_{i}} \geqslant\left(\frac{n a+s}{n a-s}\right)^{n}$.
informal_statement: 5. Let $x_{i}>0(i=1,2, \cdots, n), a \in \mathbf{R}^{+}$ and $\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}=s \leqslant a$. Prove: $\prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{a+x_{i}}{a-x_{i}} \geqslant\left(\frac{n a+s}{n a-s}\right)^{n}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 5. Let $x_{i}>0(i=1,2, \cdots, n), a \in \mathbf{R}^{+}$ and $\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}=s \leqslant a$. Prove: $\prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{a+x_{i}}{a-x_{i}} \geqslant\left(\frac{n a+s}{n a-s}\right)^{n}$. -/
theorem inequalities_215853 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : 0 < n) (x : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (hx : ‚àÄ i, 0 < x i) (a : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (s : ‚Ñù)
    (hsum : ‚àë i, x i = s) (hle : s ‚â§ a) :
    (‚àè i, (a + x i) / (a - x i)) ‚â• ((n * a + s) / (n * a - s)) ^ n := by

soln_description:
First, we notice that
$$
f(1)=a+b+c=1 .
$$

It is easy to see that the extremum point of this problem is
$$
\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{n}\right)=(1,1, \cdots, 1) \text {. }
$$

Given that $x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{n}$ are positive numbers, and $x_{1} x_{2} \cdots x_{n}=1$, there must be one $x_{i}>1$, one $x_{j}<1$. If $a>0, b>0, c>0$, then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
-b c\left(x_{1}-1\right)\left(x_{2}-1\right)>0, \\
a b x_{1} x_{2}\left(x_{1}+x_{2}-1\right)>0, \\
a c\left(x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}-1\right)>0 .
\end{array}
$$

Therefore,
$$
f\left(x_{1}\right) f\left(x_{2}\right)>f(1) f\left(x_{1} x_{2}\right) .
$$

Thus, we have $f\left(x_{1}\right) f\left(x_{2}\right) \cdots f\left(x_{n}\right)>f\left(x_{1}^{\prime}\right) f\left(x_{2}^{\prime}\right) \cdots f\left(x_{n}^{\prime}\right)$.
If $x_{1}^{\prime}, x_{2}^{\prime}, \cdots, x_{n}^{\prime}$ are not all equal, then there is $x_{i}^{\prime}>1, x_{j}^{\prime}<1$, and we have
$$
f\left(x_{1}^{\prime}\right) f\left(x_{2}^{\prime}\right) \cdots f\left(x_{n}^{\prime}\right)>f\left(x_{1}^{\prime \prime}\right) f\left(x_{2}^{\prime \prime}\right) \cdots f\left(x_{n}^{\prime \prime}\right) .
$$

Since each transformation increases the number of $x_{i}$ equal to 1 by at least one, after at most $n-1$ transformations, all $x_{i}$ will be equal to 1, thus
$$
f\left(x_{1}\right) f\left(x_{2}\right) \cdots f\left(x_{n}\right)>f^{n}(1)=f(1) .
$$
informal_statement:
[Example 3.4.3] Given the quadratic trinomial
$$
f(x)=a x^{2}+b x+c
$$

all of whose coefficients are positive, and $a+b+c=1$.
Prove that for any set of positive numbers $x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{n}$ satisfying $x_{1} x_{2} \cdots x_{n}=1$, we have
$$
f\left(x_{1}\right) f\left(x_{2}\right) \cdots f\left(x_{n}\right) \geqslant 1 .
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- [Example 3.4.3] Given the quadratic trinomial
$$
f(x)=a x^{2}+b x+c
$$

all of whose coefficients are positive, and $a+b+c=1$.
Prove that for any set of positive numbers $x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{n}$ satisfying $x_{1} x_{2} \cdots x_{n}=1$, we have
$$
f\left(x_{1}\right) f\left(x_{2}\right) \cdots f\left(x_{n}\right) \geqslant 1 .
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_100053 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h : a + b + c = 1) (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : 0 < n) (x : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (hx : ‚àÄ i, 0 < x i) (hxp : ‚àè i, x i = 1) :
    ‚àè i, (a * (x i)^2 + b * x i + c) ‚â• 1 := by

soln_description:
[Proof] For $n \in Z^{+}$, use induction. When $n=0$, since $Q(x) \not \equiv 0$, $P(x)=Q(x)$ has at least one coefficient not equal to zero.

Assume the conclusion holds for some $n(n \geqslant 0)$. We will prove that the conclusion also holds for $n+1$.
Indeed, if the conclusion does not hold for $n+1$, then there exists a non-zero polynomial
$$Q(x)=x^{r} \cdot Q_{0}(x)$$

where $r \in Z^{+}, Q_{0}(0) \neq 0$, such that the polynomial
$$P(x)=(x-1)^{n+1} \cdot Q(x)=(x-1)^{n+1} \cdot x^{r} \cdot Q_{0}(x)$$

has at most $n+1$ non-zero coefficients. Thus, the polynomial
$$P_{0}(x)=(x-1)^{n+1} \cdot Q_{0}(x)$$

also has at most $n+1$ non-zero coefficients, so its derivative $P^{\prime}{ }_{0}(x)$ has at most $n$ non-zero coefficients. However,
$$\begin{aligned}
P_{0}^{\prime}(x) & =(x-1)^{n+1} Q^{\prime}(x)+(n+1)(x-1)^{n} Q_{0}(x) \\
& =(x-1)^{n} R(x)
\end{aligned}$$

Since $P_{0}(x)$ is not a constant, $R(x) \neq \equiv 0$. But by the induction hypothesis, $P^{\prime}{ }_{0}(x)$ has at least $n+1$ non-zero coefficients. This is a contradiction. Therefore, the conclusion also holds for $n+1$.
informal_statement:
5.98 Let $Q(x)$ be a non-zero polynomial. Prove: for each $n \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$, the polynomial
$$P(x)=(x-1)^{n} Q(x)$$

has at least $n+1$ non-zero coefficients.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5.98 Let $Q(x)$ be a non-zero polynomial. Prove: for each $n \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$, the polynomial
$$P(x)=(x-1)^{n} Q(x)$$

has at least $n+1$ non-zero coefficients. -/
theorem algebra_602772 {Q : Polynomial ‚Ñù} (hQ : Q ‚â† 0) (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : n > 0)
    (P : Polynomial ‚Ñù) (hP : P = (X - 1)^n * Q) :
    {k | P.coeff k ‚â† 0}.ncard ‚â• n + 1 := by

formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. How many pairs of natural numbers exist for which the number 189 is the LCM? (The numbers in the pair can be the same, the order of the numbers in the pair does not matter) -/
theorem number_theory_209728 :
    {(m, n) : ‚Ñï √ó ‚Ñï | Nat.lcm m n = 189}.encard = 11 := by

soln_description:
To solve this problem, we need to construct a set \( A = \{a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n\} \) such that the product of any two numbers from \( A \) is divisible by the sum of any \( p \) numbers from \( A \). Here is a step-by-step solution:

1. **Define the set \( A \)**:
   Let \( d \) be the product of all possible sums of \( p \) elements chosen from the set \( \{1, 2, \ldots, n\} \). Specifically, let:
   \[
   d = \prod_{1 \leq i_1 < i_2 < \cdots < i_p \leq n} \left( i_1 + i_2 + \cdots + i_p \right)
   \]
   Now, define the set \( A \) as:
   \[
   A = \{d, 2d, 3d, \ldots, nd\}
   \]

2. **Verify the product condition**:
   Consider any two elements \( a_i \) and \( a_j \) from \( A \), where \( a_i = id \) and \( a_j = jd \). The product of these two elements is:
   \[
   a_i \cdot a_j = (id) \cdot (jd) = ijd^2
   \]

3. **Verify the sum condition**:
   Consider the sum of any \( p \) elements from \( A \). Let these elements be \( a_{i_1}, a_{i_2}, \ldots, a_{i_p} \), where \( a_{i_k} = i_k d \) for \( k = 1, 2, \ldots, p \). The sum of these \( p \) elements is:
   \[
   a_{i_1} + a_{i_2} + \cdots + a_{i_p} = (i_1 d) + (i_2 d) + \cdots + (i_p d) = (i_1 + i_2 + \cdots + i_p) d
   \]

4. **Check divisibility**:
   We need to show that the product \( a_i \cdot a_j = ijd^2 \) is divisible by the sum of any \( p \) elements from \( A \). From the previous steps, the sum of any \( p \) elements is:
   \[
   (i_1 + i_2 + \cdots + i_p) d
   \]
   Since \( d \) is defined as the product of all possible sums of \( p \) elements from \( \{1, 2, \ldots, n\} \), it is clear that \( d \) is a multiple of any such sum. Therefore, \( d \) divides \( (i_1 + i_2 + \cdots + i_p) d \).

5. **Conclusion**:
   Since \( d \) divides \( (i_1 + i_2 + \cdots + i_p) d \), it follows that \( ijd^2 \) (the product of any two elements from \( A \)) is divisible by \( (i_1 + i_2 + \cdots + i_p) d \) (the sum of any \( p \) elements from \( A \)).

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: [color=darkred]Let $ p$ be a prime divisor of $ n\ge 2$. Prove that there exists a set of natural numbers $ A \equal{} \{a_1,a_2,...,a_n\}$ such that product of any two numbers from $ A$ is divisible by the sum of any $ p$ numbers from $ A$.[/color]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- [color=darkred]Let $ p$ be a prime divisor of $ n\ge 2$. Prove that there exists a set of natural numbers $ A \equal{} \{a_1,a_2,...,a_n\}$ such that product of any two numbers from $ A$ is divisible by the sum of any $ p$ numbers from $ A$.[/color] -/
theorem number_theory_55586 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : 2 ‚â§ n) (p : ‚Ñï) (hp : Nat.Prime p) :
    p ‚à£ n ‚Üí ‚àÉ A : Finset ‚Ñï, A.card = n ‚àß ‚àÄ x ‚àà A, ‚àÄ y ‚àà A, x ‚â† y ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ s : Finset ‚Ñï, s ‚äÜ A ‚àß s.card = p ‚Üí (x * y) % (‚àë i ‚àà s, i) = 0) := by

soln_description:
Proof: First, we prove the following conclusion: Let $\alpha$ be a real number. If $\cos \alpha$ is a rational number, then for any positive integer $m, \cos m \alpha$ is a rational number.
We use mathematical induction on $m$.
Since $\cos \alpha$ is a rational number, we have $\cos 2 \alpha=2 \cos ^{2} \alpha-1$ is also a rational number.
Assume that for all $m \leqslant l(l \geqslant 2), \cos m \alpha$ is a rational number, then by
$$
\cos (l+1) \alpha=2 \cos l \alpha \cdot \cos \alpha-\cos (l-1) \alpha
$$

we know that $\cos (l+1) \alpha$ is also a rational number, i.e., the proposition also holds when $m=l+1$.
By the above conclusion, for $\alpha=k \theta,(k-1) \theta$, let $m=k, k+1$ respectively, we get $\cos k^{2} \theta, \cos \left(k^{2}-1\right) \theta$ are both rational numbers, and since $k^{2}>k$, the proposition is proved.
informal_statement: 7 Let $k$ be a positive integer no less than 3, and $\theta$ be a real number. Prove: If $\cos (k-1) \theta$ and $\cos k \theta$ are both rational numbers, then there exists a positive integer $n > k$, such that $\cos (n-1) \theta$ and $\cos n \theta$ are both rational numbers. (Supplied by Li Weiguo)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7 Let $k$ be a positive integer no less than 3, and $\theta$ be a real number. Prove: If $\cos (k-1) \theta$ and $\cos k \theta$ are both rational numbers, then there exists a positive integer $n > k$, such that $\cos (n-1) \theta$ and $\cos n \theta$ are both rational numbers. (Supplied by Li Weiguo) -/
theorem algebra_122336 {k : ‚Ñï} (hk : 3 ‚â§ k) (Œ∏ : ‚Ñù)
    (h‚ÇÅ : ‚àÉ q : ‚Ñö, Real.cos ((k - 1) * Œ∏) = q)
    (h‚ÇÇ : ‚àÉ q : ‚Ñö, Real.cos (k * Œ∏) = q) :
    ‚àÉ n : ‚Ñï, 0 < n ‚àß n > k ‚àß ‚àÉ q‚ÇÅ q‚ÇÇ : ‚Ñö,
      Real.cos ((n - 1) * Œ∏) = q‚ÇÅ ‚àß Real.cos (n * Œ∏) = q‚ÇÇ := by

soln_description:
1. **Given Conditions and Objective**:
   - We are given a strictly increasing sequence of positive real numbers \((a_i)_{i \in \mathbb{N}}\) such that \(\lim_{i \to \infty} a_i = +\infty\).
   - For each \(i\), it holds that \(\frac{a_{i+1}}{a_i} \leq 10\).
   - We need to prove that for every positive integer \(k\), there are infinitely many pairs \((i, j)\) such that \(10^k \leq \frac{a_i}{a_j} \leq 10^{k+1}\).

2. **Fixing \(k\) and Considering the Limit**:
   - Fix a positive integer \(k\).
   - Since \(\lim_{s \to \infty} \frac{a_s}{a_j} = \infty\) for any fixed \(j\), there exists an \(i\) such that \(\frac{a_i}{a_j} \geq 10^k\).

3. **Finding the Appropriate \(i\)**:
   - We need to find an \(i\) such that \(10^k \leq \frac{a_i}{a_j} \leq 10^{k+1}\).
   - Since \(\frac{a_{i+1}}{a_i} \leq 10\), it follows that \(\frac{a_{i+1}}{a_j} \leq 10 \cdot \frac{a_i}{a_j}\).

4. **Ensuring the Upper Bound**:
   - Choose \(i\) such that \(\frac{a_{i-1}}{a_j} < 10^k \leq \frac{a_i}{a_j}\).
   - This choice is possible because the sequence \((a_i)\) is strictly increasing and unbounded, ensuring that for any \(j\), there exists an \(i\) such that \(\frac{a_i}{a_j} \geq 10^k\).

5. **Verifying the Inequality**:
   - By the choice of \(i\), we have \(10^k \leq \frac{a_i}{a_j}\).
   - Since \(\frac{a_{i+1}}{a_i} \leq 10\), it follows that \(\frac{a_{i+1}}{a_j} \leq 10 \cdot \frac{a_i}{a_j}\).
   - Therefore, \(\frac{a_i}{a_j} \leq 10^{k+1}\).

6. **Conclusion**:
   - We have shown that for each \(j\), there exists an \(i\) such that \(10^k \leq \frac{a_i}{a_j} \leq 10^{k+1}\).
   - Since \(j\) can be any positive integer and the sequence is strictly increasing and unbounded, there are infinitely many such pairs \((i, j)\).

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Let $(a_i)_{i\in \mathbb N}$ be a strictly increasing sequence of positive real numbers such that $\lim_{i \to \infty} a_i = +\infty$ and $a_{i+1}/a_i \leq 10$ for each $i$. Prove that for every positive integer $k$ there are infinitely many pairs $(i, j)$ with $10^k \leq a_i/a_j \leq 10^{k+1}.$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Real Complex TopologicalSpace Finset
open scoped BigOperators

/- Let $(a_i)_{i\in \mathbb N}$ be a strictly increasing sequence of positive real numbers such that $\lim_{i \to \infty} a_i = +\infty$ and $a_{i+1}/a_i \leq 10$ for each $i$. Prove that for every positive integer $k$ there are infinitely many pairs $(i, j)$ with $10^k \leq a_i/a_j \leq 10^{k+1}.$ -/
theorem number_theory_26874
  (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
  (h‚ÇÄ : StrictMono a)
  (h‚ÇÅ : ‚àÄ n, 0 < a n)
  (h‚ÇÇ : Tendsto a atTop atTop)
  (h‚ÇÉ : ‚àÄ n, a (n + 1) / a n ‚â§ 10) :
  ‚àÄ k, 0 < k ‚Üí
  { (i, j) | 10 ^ k ‚â§ a i / a j ‚àß a i / a j ‚â§ 10 ^ (k + 1) }.Infinite :=

soln_description:
Solution. By Rearrangement inequality,
$$\frac{1}{a(1+a)}+\frac{1}{b(1+b)}+\frac{1}{c(1+c)} \geq \frac{1}{b(1+c)}+\frac{1}{c(1+a)}+\frac{1}{a(1+b)}$$

Hence the inequality will be proved if these relations are fulfilled
$$\sum_{c y c} \frac{1}{b(1+c)} \geq \frac{3}{1+a b c} ; \sum_{c y c} \frac{1}{a(1+c)} \geq \frac{3}{1+a b c}$$

We choose to prove the first inequality (the second one can be proved similarly). Let $a=\frac{k y}{x}, b=\frac{k z}{y}, c=\frac{k x}{z}$. Therefore the inequality is rewritten into the form
$$\sum_{c y c} \frac{1}{\frac{k z}{y}+\frac{k^{2} x}{y}} \geq \frac{3}{1+k^{3}} \Leftrightarrow \sum_{c y c} \frac{y}{z+k x} \geq \frac{3 k}{1+k^{3}}$$

According to Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we have
$$\sum_{c y c} \frac{y}{z+k x} \geq \frac{(x+y+z)^{2}}{(k+1)(x y+y z+z x)} \geq \frac{3}{k+1}$$

So it suffices to prove that
$$\frac{3}{k+1} \geq \frac{3 k}{1+k^{3}} \Leftrightarrow(k-1)^{2}(k+1) \geq 0$$
which is obvious. The equality holds for $x=y=z, k=1 \Leftrightarrow a=b=c=1$.

soln_description:
We prove the proposition by induction on $n$. When $n=1$, it is clear that $A_{1}=G_{1}$, so the proposition holds. When $n=2$, since $\left(\sqrt{c_{1}}-\sqrt{c_{2}}\right)^{2} \geqslant 0$, i.e., $c_{1}+c_{2}-2 \sqrt{c_{1} c_{2}} \geqslant 0$, it follows that $A_{2}=\frac{c_{1}+c_{2}}{2} \geqslant \sqrt{c_{1} c_{2}}=G_{2}$, so the proposition holds. Assume that when $n=k$, the proposition holds, i.e., $A_{\mathbf{k}} \geqslant G_{\mathbf{k}}$. Let
$$
\begin{aligned}
A & =\frac{c_{\mathrm{k}+1}+(k-1) A_{\mathbf{k}+1}}{k}, \\
G & =\sqrt[k]{c_{\mathrm{k}+1} \cdot A_{\mathbf{k}+1}^{\mathbf{k}-1}},
\end{aligned}
$$

Then $A$ is the arithmetic mean of $k$ positive numbers $c \mathbf{k}+1, A_{\mathbf{k}+1}, \cdots, A_{\mathbf{k}+1}$, and $G$ is their geometric mean. By the induction hypothesis, we know $A \geqslant G$.

It is not difficult to verify that $A_{\mathbf{k}+1}=\frac{A_{\mathbf{k}}+A}{2}$, so by the induction hypothesis and the verified result, we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
A_{k+1}^{\geqslant \sqrt{A_{k} A} \geqslant \sqrt{G_{k} G}} \\
=\sqrt{G_{k} \cdot k \sqrt{c_{k+1} \cdot A_{k+1}^{k-1}}} \\
=\sqrt{\frac{k}{c_{1} c_{2} \cdots c_{k} c_{k+1}} \cdot \sqrt[k]{A_{k+1}^{k-1}}} \\
=\sqrt[2 k]{c_{1} c_{2} \cdots c_{k} c_{k+1} \cdot} \sqrt[2 k]{A_{k+1}^{k+1}}
\end{array}
$$

Dividing both sides of this inequality by $\sum^{2 k} \sqrt{A_{\dot{j}}^{k+1}}$, we get
$$
\sqrt[2 k]{A_{k+1}^{k_{k}+1}} \geqslant \sqrt{2 k} \sqrt{c_{1} c_{2} \cdots c_{k} c_{k+1}}
$$

Raising both sides to the $2k$-th power and then taking the $(k+1)$-th root, we obtain
$$
A_{\mathbf{k}+1} \geqslant \mathbf{k}+1 \sqrt{c_{1} c_{2} \cdots c_{\mathbf{k}} c_{\mathbf{k}+1}}=G_{\mathbf{k}+1}.
$$

This shows that the proposition also holds when $n=k+1$. Therefore, for all natural numbers $n$, we have $A_{n} \geqslant G_{n}$.

soln_description:
## Solution

$$
\int_{-4}^{0}\left(x^{2}+7 x+12\right) \cos x d x=
$$

Let:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u=x^{2}+7 x+12 ; d u=(2 x+7) d x \\
& d v=\cos x d x ; v=\sin x
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the integration by parts formula $\int u d v=u v-\int v d u$. We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\left.\left(x^{2}+7 x+12\right) \sin x\right|_{-4} ^{0}-\int_{-4}^{0} \sin x(2 x+7) d x= \\
& =\left(0^{2}+7 \cdot 0+12\right) \sin 0-\left((-4)^{2}+7 \cdot(-4)+12\right) \sin (-4)-\int_{-4}^{0} \sin x(2 x+7) d x= \\
& =12 \cdot 0-(16-28+12) \sin (-4)-\int_{-4}^{0} \sin x(2 x+7) d x=-\int_{-4}^{0} \sin x(2 x+7) d x=
\end{aligned}
$$

Let:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u=2 x+7 ; d u=2 d x \\
& d v=\sin x d x ; v=-\cos x
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the integration by parts formula $\int u d v=u v-\int v d u$. We get:

$$
=-\left(\left.(2 x+7) \cdot(-\cos x)\right|_{-4} ^{0}-\int_{-4}^{0}(-\cos x) \cdot 2 d x\right)=
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =-\left((2 \cdot 0+7) \cdot(-\cos 0)-(2 \cdot(-4)+7) \cdot(-\cos (-4))+2 \int_{-4}^{0} \cos x d x\right)= \\
& =-\left(-7-\cos (-4)+\left.2 \sin x\right|_{-4} ^{0}\right)=-(-7-\cos 4+2 \sin 0-2 \sin (-4))= \\
& =-(-7-\cos 4+2 \sin 4)=7+\cos 4-2 \sin 4
\end{aligned}
$$

soln_description:
For example, we proceed by induction on $n \in \mathbb{N}^{*}$.

## - Initialization

For $n=1$, for any odd integer $a$, $a^{2} \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$ for any odd integer $a$.

- Induction

Let $n \in \mathbb{N}$ and suppose that for any odd integer $a$, $a^{2^{n}} \equiv 1 \pmod{2^{n+2}}$, which means that

$$
2^{n+2} \mid a^{2^{n}}-1
$$

Let $a \in \mathbb{N}$ be an odd integer. By the remarkable identity, we have the factorization

$$
a^{2^{n+1}}-1=\left(a^{2^{n}}-1\right)\left(a^{2^{n}}+1\right)
$$

By the induction hypothesis, $2^{n+2}$ divides $a^{2^{n}}-1$, and by the oddness of $a$, $2$ divides $a^{2^{n}}+1$. Consequently, $2^{n+2+1}$ divides $a^{2^{n+1}}-1$.

## - Conclusion

By induction, we have for any integer $n \geqslant 1$ and any odd integer $a$,

$$
a^{2^{n}} \equiv 1 \pmod{2^{n+2}}
$$

We note that the proposed induction corresponds in fact to the direct factorization.

$$
a^{2^{n}}-1=(a-1)(a+1)\left(a^{2}+1\right)\left(a^{4}+1\right) \cdots\left(a^{2^{n-1}}+1\right)
$$

    a^(2^n) ‚â° 1 [ZMOD 2^(n + 2)] := by

soln_description:
[Solution] Let $\langle a\rangle$ denote the unit digit of the integer $a$. Clearly, if the unit digit of $a$ is $b$, then $\langle a\rangle=\langle b\rangle$, and $\left\langle a^{n}\right\rangle=\left\langle b^{n}\right\rangle$ (where $n$ is a natural number).
Also, $\left\langle 7^{0}\right\rangle=1,\left\langle 7^{1}\right\rangle=7,\left\langle 7^{2}\right\rangle=9,\left\langle 7^{3}\right\rangle=3$.
It is easy to prove that $\left\langle 7^{4 n+r}\right\rangle=\left\langle 7^{r}\right\rangle$, meaning the unit digit of the powers of 7 cycles with a period of 4.
Thus, $\left\langle 2137^{753}\right\rangle=\left\langle 2137^{4 \times 188+1}\right\rangle=\left\langle 2137^{1}\right\rangle=7$.
Therefore, the answer is $(D)$.
Note: Regarding the unit digit (last digit) of $a^{n}$ for natural numbers, the following conclusions can be drawn:
(1) If the unit digit of $a$ is $b$, then $\left\langle a^{n}\right\rangle=\left\langle b^{n}\right\rangle$;
(2) The unit digit of any power of a natural number ending in $0,1,5,6$ remains $0,1,5,6$;
(3) The unit digit of the $n$-th power of $2,3,4,7,8,9$ is as follows:
Table of unit digits of $a$:
\begin{tabular}{c|c|c|c|c|c|c}
\hline$n-a$ & 2 & 3 & 4 & 7 & 8 & 9 \\
\hline $4 k+1$ & 2 & 3 & 4 & 7 & 8 & 9 \\
$4 k+2$ & 4 & 9 & 6 & 9 & 4 & 1 \\
$4 k+3$ & 8 & 7 & 4 & 3 & 2 & 9 \\
$4 k$ & 6 & 1 & 6 & 1 & 6 & 1 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
informal_statement:
$33 \cdot 1$. The units digit of the number $2137^{753}$ is
(A) 1.
(B) 3.
(C) 5.
(D) 7.
(E) 9.
(12th American High School Mathematics Examination, 1961)
informal_proof:
We want to determine the units digit of the number $2137^{753}$. This is equivalent to finding the remainder when $2137^{753}$ is divided by $10$.

First, we observe that the units digit of $2137$ is $7$. This means that $2137 \equiv 7 \pmod{10}$. By the properties of modular arithmetic, the units digit of $2137^{753}$ is the same as the units digit of $7^{753}$.
$$ 2137^{753} \equiv 7^{753} \pmod{10} $$

Next, we examine the pattern of the units digits of powers of $7$ modulo $10$:
\begin{itemize}
    \item $7^1 \equiv 7 \pmod{10}$
    \item $7^2 \equiv 49 \equiv 9 \pmod{10}$
    \item $7^3 \equiv 7 \times 9 \equiv 63 \equiv 3 \pmod{10}$
    \item $7^4 \equiv 7 \times 3 \equiv 21 \equiv 1 \pmod{10}$
\end{itemize}
After $7^4$, the pattern repeats. The units digits of powers of $7$ cycle with a period of $4$: $(7, 9, 3, 1)$.

To find the units digit of $7^{753}$, we need to determine where the exponent $753$ falls within this cycle. This is achieved by finding the remainder of $753$ when divided by $4$.
Performing the division:
$$ 753 \div 4 $$
We can write $753$ as:
$$ 753 = 4 \times 188 + 1 $$
The remainder is $1$. This means that $7^{753}$ will have the same units digit as $7^1$.

Therefore, we can conclude that:
$$ 7^{753} \equiv 7^{4 \times 188 + 1} \equiv (7^4)^{188} \times 7^1 \equiv 1^{188} \times 7 \equiv 1 \times 7 \equiv 7 \pmod{10} $$
Since $2137^{753} \equiv 7^{753} \pmod{10}$, it follows that $2137^{753} \equiv 7 \pmod{10}$.

Thus, the units digit of $2137^{753}$ is $7$.

(A) 1.

(C) 5.
(D) 7.
(E) 9.
(12th American High School Mathematics Examination, 1961) -/
theorem number_theory_268030 : (2137^753) % 10 = 7 := by

theorem number_theory_268030 : (2137^753) % 10 = 7 := by

soln_description:
For example, $6^{669}, 2 \cdot 6^{669}, 3 \cdot 6^{669}$. Their product is $6 \cdot 6^{3 \cdot 669}=6^{2008}$.

## Answer

It can.

## $\begin{array}{ll}\text { Problem } 111651 & \text { Topics: } \\ \text { [Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic. Factorization into prime factors }]\end{array}$  Difficulty: 3+ $[\quad$ Examples and counterexamples. Constructions

Author: Galperin G.A.

Does there exist an arithmetic progression of five different natural numbers, the product of which is a perfect 2008th power of a natural number?

## Solution

For example, $120^{803}, 2 \cdot 120^{803}, 3 \cdot 120^{803}, 4 \cdot 120^{803}, 5 \cdot 120^{803}$. Their product is $120 \cdot 120^{5 \cdot 803}=120^{4016}=$ $\left(120^{2}\right)^{2008}$.

## Answer

It exists.

    ‚àÉ n, n^2008 = a * b * c := by

soln_description: 61.8. Note. $\overline{A B C}+\overline{B C A}+\overline{C A B}=111(A+B+C), \quad$ and $111=3 \cdot 37$
informal_statement: 8. A three-digit number $\overline{A B C}$ is divisible by 37. Prove that the sum of the numbers $\overline{B C A}$ and $\overline{C A B}$ is also divisible by 37.
informal_proof:
Let the three-digit number be represented by $100A + 10B + C$, where $A$, $B$, and $C$ are natural numbers and $A \neq 0$. We are given that this number is divisible by 37. This can be stated as:
$$ 100A + 10B + C \equiv 0 \pmod{37} $$

We need to prove that the sum of the numbers formed by cyclically permuting the digits, $\overline{BCA}$ ($100B + 10C + A$) and $\overline{CAB}$ ($100C + 10A + B$), is also divisible by 37. The sum is:
$$ (100B + 10C + A) + (100C + 10A + B) $$
Combining the terms, we get:
$$ (100B + B) + (10C + 100C) + (A + 10A) $$
$$ = 101B + 110C + 11A $$
So, we need to show that:
$$ 11A + 101B + 110C \equiv 0 \pmod{37} $$

We can use the given information $100A + 10B + C \equiv 0 \pmod{37}$ to manipulate the expression $11A + 101B + 110C$.
Let's consider the sum of all three cyclic permutations:
$$ (100A + 10B + C) + (100B + 10C + A) + (100C + 10A + B) $$
This sum is equal to:
$$ (100A + A + 10A) + (10B + 100B + B) + (C + 10C + 100C) $$
$$ = 111A + 111B + 111C $$
$$ = 111(A + B + C) $$
Since $111 = 3 \times 37$, the sum $111(A + B + C)$ is divisible by 37.
Let $N_1 = 100A + 10B + C$, $N_2 = 100B + 10C + A$, and $N_3 = 100C + 10A + B$.
We are given $N_1 \equiv 0 \pmod{37}$.
We have shown $N_1 + N_2 + N_3 \equiv 0 \pmod{37}$.
Subtracting the first congruence from the second gives:
$$ (N_1 + N_2 + N_3) - N_1 \equiv 0 - 0 \pmod{37} $$
$$ N_2 + N_3 \equiv 0 \pmod{37} $$
This means that the sum of the numbers $\overline{BCA}$ and $\overline{CAB}$ is divisible by 37.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 8. A three-digit number $\overline{A B C}$ is divisible by 37. Prove that the sum of the numbers $\overline{B C A}$ and $\overline{C A B}$ is also divisible by 37. -/
theorem number_theory_203443 (A B C : ‚Ñï) (h‚ÇÄ : A ‚â† 0) (h‚ÇÅ : 37 ‚à£ 100 * A + 10 * B + C) :
    37 ‚à£ (100 * B + 10 * C + A) + (100 * C + 10 * A + B) := by

    5*x2^3-5*(p+1)*x2^2+(71*p-1)*x2+1=66*p ‚àß 5*x3^3-5*(p+1)*x3^2+(71*p-1)*x3+1=66*p) :

soln_description:
Solution. The domain of the inequality is $x \geqslant 0$. By reducing the left part of the inequality to a power with base 3, we get

$$
3^{72}\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{x}\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{\sqrt{x}}=3^{72-x-\sqrt{x}}
$$

Thus, the given inequality is equivalent to the inequality

$$
72-x-\sqrt{x}>0
$$

Let $t=\sqrt{x};$ we have:

$$
\left\{\begin{array} { l } 
{ t \geqslant 0 } \\
{ t ^ { 2 } + t - 7 2 < 0 }
\end{array} \Leftrightarrow \left\{\begin{array}{l}
t \geqslant 0 \\
(t+9)(t-8)<0
\end{array} \Leftrightarrow 0 \leqslant t<8\right.\right.
$$

Thus, the given inequality is equivalent to the double inequality

$$
0 \leqslant \sqrt{x}<8
$$

from which $0 \leqslant x<64$.

Therefore, the interval $[0 ; 64)$ is the set of all solutions to the given inequality.
informal_statement:

$$

informal_statement: 7. In order to clear the inventory, Crab Boss decides to offer a discount promotion on hamburgers. If he offers a 90% of the original price, he can still make a profit of 320 berries per hamburger; if he offers a 70% of the original price, he will incur a loss of 160 berries per hamburger. Then, the purchase price of each hamburger is $\qquad$ berries.
informal_proof:
We are given that `x` is a positive real number. We are also provided with two equations:
1.  `(1 - 90/100) * x = (1 + 320/x) * x`
2.  `(1 - 70/100) * x = (1 - 160/x) * x`

First, we simplify these equations using algebraic properties. Since `x` is a positive real number, it is non-zero, which allows us to perform division by `x`. After simplifying, the equations become:
1.  `1 - 90/100 = 1 + 320/x`
2.  `1 - 70/100 = 1 - 160/x`

Next, we use a method for solving nonlinear arithmetic problems, taking into account that `x` is a positive number. This process involves manipulating the simplified equations to isolate `x`.

Through this arithmetic solution, we determine that the value of `x` that satisfies these conditions is `1840`.

Thus, the purchase price of each hamburger is $1840$ berries.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7. In order to clear the inventory, Crab Boss decides to offer a discount promotion on hamburgers. If he offers a 90% of the original price, he can still make a profit of 320 berries per hamburger; if he offers a 70% of the original price, he will incur a loss of 160 berries per hamburger. Then, the purchase price of each hamburger is $\qquad$ berries. -/
theorem algebra_203891 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : 0 < x) (h1 : (1 - 90 / 100) * x = (1 + 320 / x) * x)
    (h2 : (1 - 70 / 100) * x = (1 - 160 / x) * x) :
    x = 1840 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_203891 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : 0 < x) (h1 : (1 - 90 / 100) * x = (1 + 320 / x) * x)
    (h2 : (1 - 70 / 100) * x = (1 - 160 / x) * x) :
    x = 1840 := by
        have eq1 : (1 - 90 / 100 : ‚Ñù) * x = (1 + 320 / x) * x := h1
        have eq2 : (1 - 70 / 100 : ‚Ñù) * x = (1 - 160 / x) * x := h2
        have hx' : x ‚â† 0 := by linarith
        field_simp at eq1 eq2
        nlinarith [sq_pos_of_pos hx]

soln_description:
The equation can be rewritten as

$$
x^{2}+2 x y+y^{2}-z^{2}=9
$$

thus

$$
(x+y)^{2}-z^{2}=9
$$

and

$$
(x+y-z)(x+y+z)=9
$$

$x+y+z$ is therefore a positive divisor of 9, and thus equals 1, 3, or 9.

- If $x+y+z=9$, then $x+y-z=1$ and by summing, $2(x+y)=10$ so $x+y=5$, thus $z=9-5=4$. We obtain the solutions $(0,5,4),(1,4,4),(2,3,4),(3,2,4),(4,1,4)$ and $(5,0,4)$, and we verify that they work.
- If $x+y+z=3$, then $x+y-z=3$ and by summing, $2(x+y)=6$ so $x+y=3$, thus $z=3-3=0$. We obtain the solutions $(0,3,0),(1,2,0),(2,1,0)$ and $(3,0,0)$, and we verify that they work.
- If $x+y+z=1$, then $x+y-z=9$. However, since $z \geq 0, x+y+z \geq x+y-z$ so this is absurd.
informal_statement:
Find all natural numbers $x, y, z$ such that

$$
x^{2}+y^{2}=9+z^{2}-2 x y
$$

soln_description:
# Solution and Evaluation Criteria:

We need to consider two situations:

The first is when the body tries to float. In this case, the equilibrium condition is:

$F_{a}=m g+F$.

As a result, we get: $\rho_{\text{–∂}} g V=\rho_{T} V g+F$
$\rho_{T}=\frac{\rho_{\text{–∂}} g V-F}{g V}=\frac{10-5}{10 \cdot 10^{-3}}=500 \mathrm{k} 2 / \mathrm{m}^{3}$

The second is when the body tries to sink. In this case, the equilibrium condition is:

$F_{a}+F=m g$.

(4 points)

As a result, we get: $\rho_{\text{–∂}} g V+F=\rho_{T} V g$

$\rho_{T}=\frac{\rho_{\text{–∂}} g V+F}{g V}=\frac{10+5}{10 \cdot 10^{-3}}=1500 \mathrm{k} / \mathrm{m}^{3}$
informal_statement:
# Problem No. 7 (15 points)

For a body completely submerged in a liquid to be in equilibrium, a force $F=5 \mathrm{H}$ is applied to it. Determine the density of the body if its volume $V=1$ l, and the density of the liquid $\rho_{\text {–∂ }}=1000$ kg $/ \mathrm{m}^{3}$.

Answer: $1500 \mathrm{\kappa z} / \boldsymbol{m}^{3}$

#

Answer: $1500 \mathrm{\kappa z} / \boldsymbol{m}^{3}$

theorem algebra_176175 {œÅ : ‚Ñù} (hœÅ : œÅ > 0) (hV : 1 * 1000 = 5 * œÅ) :
    œÅ = 1500 := by

soln_description:
To prove: The original inequality is equivalent to proving $\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(x_{i}^{k}-x_{i}\right)}{k-1} \geq \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(x_{i}^{t}-x_{i}\right)}{t-1}$, so we only need to consider proving the local inequality: $\frac{x_{i}^{k}-x_{i}}{k-1} \geq \frac{x_{i}^{t}-x_{i}}{t-1}$,

and $\frac{x_{i}^{k}-x_{i}}{k-1} \geq \frac{x_{i}^{t}-x_{i}}{t-1} \Leftrightarrow \frac{t-1}{k-1} x_{i}^{k}-\frac{t-1}{k-1} x_{i}+x_{i} \geq x_{i}^{t} \Leftrightarrow \frac{t-1}{k-1} x_{i}^{k}+\left(1-\frac{t-1}{k-1}\right) x_{i} \geq x_{i}^{t}$
By Young's inequality: When $a+b=1, a, b, x, y>0$, $a x+b y \geq x^{a} y^{b}$, we get:
$$
\frac{t-1}{k-1} x_{i}^{k}+\left(1-\frac{t-1}{k-1}\right) x_{i} \geq x_{i}^{k \cdot \frac{t-1}{k-1}} \cdot x_{i}^{1-\frac{t-1}{k-1}}=x_{i}^{t}
$$

Thus, the local inequality holds, and hence the original inequality holds.

$$

soln_description:
Proof: Since $A$ is a finite set composed of positive integers, there exists $m \geqslant 5, m \in \mathbf{N}^{\cdot}$, such that $A \subseteq\{1,2, \cdots, m\}$.
Therefore, we only need to construct a set $B$, such that all elements in $B$ are positive integers, $\{1,2, \cdots, m\} \subseteq B$, and
$$
\prod_{x \in B} x=\sum_{x \in B} x^{2} .
$$

For this purpose, we define the sequence $\left\{x_{n}\right\}$ as follows: $x_{0}=1, x_{k}=(m!) x_{0} \cdots x_{k-1}-1, k \geqslant 1$, then $m0$.
We will prove by mathematical induction that for $i \geqslant 0$, we have $\prod_{x \in B_{i}} x-\sum_{x \in B_{1}} x^{2}=k-i$.
In fact, when $i=0$, by the definition of $k$ and $B_{0}$, (1) holds.
Assume (1) holds for some $i (\geqslant 0)$, then
$$
\begin{aligned}
\prod_{x \in B_{i}} x-\sum_{x \in B_{n},} x^{2} & =\left((m!) x_{0} \cdots x_{i}-1\right) \prod_{x \in B_{0}} x-\sum_{x \in B} x^{2}-\left((m!) x_{0} \cdots x_{i}-1\right)^{2} \\
& =\left((m!) x_{0} \cdots x_{i}-1\right)\left((m!) x_{0} \cdots x_{i}\right)-\sum_{x \in B} x^{2}-\left((m!) x_{0} \cdots x_{i}-1\right)^{2} \\
& =\left((m!) x_{0} \cdots x_{i}-1\right)-\sum_{x \in B_{i}} x^{2} \\
& =\prod_{x \in B_{i}} x-\sum_{x \in B_{0}} x^{2}-1=k-(i+1) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, (1) holds for all $i \geqslant 0$.
In (1), let $B_{i}=B_{k}$, and we know the original proposition holds.
/Comment This is a clever inductive construction, the basic idea is: in the set $B_{0}=\{1,2, \cdots, m\}$ containing $A$, add a number $x_{1}$ to get $B_{1}$, such that $\prod_{x \in B_{1}} x-\sum_{x \in B_{1}} x^{2}=\prod_{x \in B_{1}} x-\sum_{x \in B_{0}} x^{2}-1$; in the set $B_{1}$, add a number $x_{2}=(m!) x_{1}-1$ to get $B_{2}$, such that $\prod_{x \in B_{2}} x-\sum_{x \in B_{2}} x^{2}=\prod_{x \in B_{1}} x-\sum_{x \in B_{1}} x^{2}-1$; in the set $B_{2}$, add a number $x_{3}=(m!) x_{2} x_{1}-1$ to get $B_{3}$, such that $\prod_{x \in B_{1}} x-\sum_{x \in B_{1}} x^{2}=\prod_{x \in B_{1}} x-\sum_{x \in B_{2}} x^{2}-1 ; \cdots \cdots$ After $k$ steps, we get $B_{k}$, such that $\prod_{x \in B} x-\sum_{x \in B} x^{2}=0$, thus the proposition is proved.
informal_statement:
Example 3: Prove that for any finite set $A$ of positive integers, there exists a finite set $B$ of positive integers such that $A \subseteq B$, and $\prod_{x \in B} x = \sum_{x \in B} x^{2}$.
Here, the left side of the equation represents the product of all elements in $B$, and the right side represents the sum of the squares of all elements in $B$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 3: Prove that for any finite set $A$ of positive integers, there exists a finite set $B$ of positive integers such that $A \subseteq B$, and $\prod_{x \in B} x = \sum_{x \in B} x^{2}$.
Here, the left side of the equation represents the product of all elements in $B$, and the right side represents the sum of the squares of all elements in $B$. -/
theorem number_theory_117649 (A : Finset ‚Ñï) (hA : ‚àÄ x ‚àà A, x > 0) :
    ‚àÉ B : Finset ‚Ñï, (‚àÄ x ‚àà B, x > 0) ‚àß A ‚äÜ B ‚àß ‚àè x ‚àà B, x = ‚àë x ‚àà B, x^2 := by

soln_description:
26. By the mean inequality,
$$\frac{a+b+c}{3}=\frac{\frac{a+b}{2}+\frac{b+c}{2}+\frac{c+a}{2}}{2} \geqslant \sqrt[3]{\frac{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}{8}}$$

Using H√∂lder's inequality,
$$\begin{array}{l}
\sqrt[3]{\frac{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}{8}}=\sqrt[3]{\frac{\frac{a+b}{2}+a+b}{3} \cdot \frac{b+\frac{b+c}{2}+c}{3} \cdot \frac{a+c+\frac{c+a}{2}}{3}} \geqslant \\
\frac{1}{3}\left(\sqrt[3]{\frac{a+b}{2} \cdot b \cdot a}+\sqrt[3]{b \cdot \frac{b+c}{2} \cdot c}+\sqrt[3]{a \cdot c \cdot \frac{c+a}{2}}\right) \geqslant \\
\frac{\sqrt{a b}+\sqrt{b c}+\sqrt{c a}}{3}
\end{array}$$

informal_statement:
If the quadratic equation $2x(kx-4)-{{x}^{2}}+6=0$ has real roots, then the maximum integer value of $k$ is (   ).

A:$-1$

B:$0$

C:$1$

D:$2$
informal_proof:
We are given the equation $2x(kx-4)-x^2+6=0$ and the information that there exists a real number $x$ which satisfies this equation. Our goal is to determine the constraint on the integer $k$.

First, we expand and simplify the given equation:
$2x(kx-4) - x^2 + 6 = 0$
$2kx^2 - 8x - x^2 + 6 = 0$

By grouping the terms involving $x^2$, we obtain the equation in a standard quadratic form $ax^2 + bx + c = 0$:
$(2k - 1)x^2 - 8x + 6 = 0$

Here, the coefficients are $a = 2k - 1$, $b = -8$, and $c = 6$.
For a quadratic equation $ax^2 + bx + c = 0$ to have at least one real root, its discriminant, given by $\Delta = b^2 - 4ac$, must be non-negative ($\Delta \geq 0$).

Applying this condition to our equation, we get:
$\Delta = (-8)^2 - 4(2k - 1)(6)$
$\Delta = 64 - 24(2k - 1)$
$\Delta = 64 - 48k + 24$
$\Delta = 88 - 48k$

Since a real root $x$ exists, we must have $\Delta \geq 0$:
$88 - 48k \geq 0$

Now, we solve this inequality for $k$.
$88 \geq 48k$
Dividing both sides by $48$ (which is positive, so the inequality direction remains the same):
$\frac{88}{48} \geq k$

Simplifying the fraction $\frac{88}{48}$ by dividing the numerator and denominator by their greatest common divisor, which is 8:
$\frac{11}{6} \geq k$

This inequality tells us that $k$ must be less than or equal to $\frac{11}{6}$.
The problem statement implies that $k$ is an integer. We are looking for the maximum possible integer value of $k$.
Since $\frac{11}{6} = 1 \frac{5}{6}$, which is approximately $1.833...$, the integers $k$ that satisfy $k \leq \frac{11}{6}$ are $1, 0, -1, -2, \ldots$.
The largest integer in this set is $1$.

Therefore, the maximum integer value $k$ can take is $1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If the quadratic equation $2x(kx-4)-{{x}^{2}}+6=0$ has real roots, then the maximum integer value of $k$ is (   ).

A:$-1$

B:$0$

C:$1$

D:$2$ -/
theorem algebra_2458 (k : ‚Ñ§) (h : ‚àÉ x : ‚Ñù, 2*x*(k*x-4)-x^2+6=0) :
    k ‚â§ 1 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_2458 (k : ‚Ñ§) (h : ‚àÉ x : ‚Ñù, 2*x*(k*x-4)-x^2+6=0) :
    k ‚â§ 1 := by
  rcases h with ‚ü®x, hx‚ü©
  have h_eq : (2 * (k : ‚Ñù) - 1) * x ^ 2 - 8 * x + 6 = 0 := by
    have h1 : 2 * x * (k * x - 4) - x ^ 2 + 6 = 0 := by
      simpa using hx
    ring_nf at h1 ‚ä¢
    linarith
  -- Derive the discriminant from the existence of a real root
  have h_discriminant : (8 : ‚Ñù) ^ 2 - 4 * (2 * (k : ‚Ñù) - 1) * 6 ‚â• 0 := by
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg ((2 * (k : ‚Ñù) - 1) * x - 4)]
  -- Simplify discriminant inequality
  ring_nf at h_discriminant
  -- Now we need to derive the bound on k
  have h' : (k : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (11 / 6 : ‚Ñù) := by
    nlinarith
  -- Convert the real bound to integer constraint
  have h_k : k ‚â§ 1 := by
    by_contra h1
    push_neg at h1
    have h2 : k ‚â• 2 := by omega
    have h3 : (k : ‚Ñù) ‚â• (2 : ‚Ñù) := by exact_mod_cast h2
    -- Contradiction arises because k must be <= 11/6 < 2
    linarith
  exact h_k

From the given information, we have

M=\{(x, y) \mid f(x)+f(y) \leqslant 0\} \\
=\left\{(x, y) \mid(x-2)^{2}+(y-2)^{2} \leqslant 2\right\}, \\

=\{(x, y) \mid(x-y)(x+y-4) \geqslant 0\} .

$$

soln_description:
Solution. The characteristic equation

$$
r^{4}-16=0 \text { or }\left(r^{2}-4\right)\left(r^{2}+4\right)=0
$$

has roots

$$
r_{1}=2, r_{2}=-2, r_{3}=2 i, r_{4}=-2 i
$$

The imaginary conjugate roots $r_{3}$ and $r_{4}$ (for which $\alpha=0, \beta=2$) correspond to the particular solutions

$$
y_{3}=\cos 2 x, y_{4}=\sin 2 x
$$

obtained from formulas (11.13).

Thus, the general solution is

$$
y=C_{1} e^{2 x}+C_{2} e^{-2 x}+C_{3} \cos 2 x+C_{4} \sin 2 x
$$
informal_statement: Example 3. Solve the equation $y^{\text {IV }}-16 y=0$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 3. Solve the equation $y^{\text {IV }}-16 y=0$. -/
theorem algebra_166761 (y : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hy : ‚àÄ x, iteratedDeriv 4 y x - 16 * y x = 0) :
    ‚àÉ c1 c2 c3 c4, ‚àÄ x, y x = c1 * Real.exp (2 * x) + c2 * Real.exp (-2 * x) +
      c3 * Real.cos (2 * x) + c4 * Real.sin (2 * x) := by

soln_description:
Solution. We will prove that ${ }^{1}$

Multiply the equation (a) of the original system

$$
a_{2} b_{3}=a_{3} b_{2}
$$

$$
\begin{cases}a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{3}=1 & (\mathrm{a}) \\ a_{1} b_{2}+a_{2} b_{4}=0 & \text { (b) } \\ a_{3} b_{1}+a_{4} b_{3}=0 & \text { (c) } \\ a_{3} b_{2}+a_{4} b_{4}=1 & \text { (d) }\end{cases}
$$

by $b_{2}$ and subtract from it the equation (b), multiplied by $b_{1}$. As a result, we get

$$
a_{2} \cdot \Delta=b_{2}
$$

Here $\boldsymbol{\Delta}=\mathbf{b}_{\mathbf{2}} \boldsymbol{b}_{\mathbf{3}}-\boldsymbol{b}_{\mathbf{1}} \boldsymbol{b}_{\mathbf{4}}$. Similarly, from (c) and (d) we find that

$$
a_{3} \cdot \Delta=b_{3}
$$

Note that $\Delta \neq 0$, otherwise from (3) it would follow that $b_{3}=0$, and thus $a_{2} b_{3}=0$, which contradicts the condition of the problem. It remains to express $a_{2}$ and $a_{3}$ from (2) and (3) and substitute the obtained expressions into (1). The validity of the relation (1) will thereby be proven.

Further, from equation (d) and equality (1), it follows that $a_{4} b_{4}=1-a_{3} b_{2}=1-a_{2} b_{3}=-6$.

Answer: $a_{4} b_{4}=-6$.

Comment. ${ }^{1}$ The system of equations in the problem is the component-wise recording of the matrix equality $\mathbf{A} \cdot \mathbf{B}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1\end{array}\right)$, where $\mathbf{A}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}a_{1} & a_{2} \\ a_{3} & a_{4}\end{array}\right)$ and $\mathbf{B}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}b_{1} & b_{2} \\ b_{3} & b_{4}\end{array}\right)$. It is well known that if the product of two matrices is equal to the identity matrix, then such matrices commute, which means that the system of equations in the problem will remain valid if all $a_{i}$ are replaced by $b_{i}$ and vice versa. From this observation, equality (1) follows immediately.
informal_statement:
4. Eight numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}, a_{4}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}, b_{4}$ satisfy the relations

$$

a_{1} b_{2}+a_{2} b_{4}=0 \\
a_{3} b_{1}+a_{4} b_{3}=0 \\
a_{3} b_{2}+a_{4} b_{4}=1
\end{array}\right.
$$

It is known that $a_{2} b_{3}=7$. Find $a_{4} b_{4}$.

Interregional Olympiad for Schoolchildren based on Departmental Educational Organizations
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4. Eight numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}, a_{4}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}, b_{4}$ satisfy the relations

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{3}=1 \\
a_{1} b_{2}+a_{2} b_{4}=0 \\
a_{3} b_{1}+a_{4} b_{3}=0 \\
a_{3} b_{2}+a_{4} b_{4}=1
\end{array}\right.
$$

It is known that $a_{2} b_{3}=7$. Find $a_{4} b_{4}$.

Interregional Olympiad for Schoolchildren based on Departmental Educational Organizations -/
theorem algebra_237196 {a b : Fin 4 ‚Üí ‚Ñù}
    (h‚ÇÄ : a 0 * b 0 + a 1 * b 2 = 1)
    (h‚ÇÅ : a 0 * b 1 + a 1 * b 3 = 0)
    (h‚ÇÇ : a 2 * b 0 + a 3 * b 2 = 0)
    (h‚ÇÉ : a 2 * b 1 + a 3 * b 3 = 1)
    (h‚ÇÑ : a 1 * b 2 = 7) :
    a 3 * b 3 = -6 := by

soln_description:
Let $ J_m $ denote the $ m $-digit number whose digits are all ones:

If $ m $ is divisible by $ d $ ($ m $, $ d $ - natural numbers), then $ J_m $ is divisible by $ J_d $. Indeed, if $ m = k \cdot d $ ($ k $ - a natural number), then

where the number $ M $ is an integer.

Let the numbers $ J_m $ and $ J_n $ be given, where $ m > n > 1 $.
a) The proof of the theorem that if $ J_m $ and $ J_n $ are coprime, then $ m $ and $ n $ are also coprime, is immediate, because according to $ \alpha $) if $ d $ is a common divisor of the natural numbers $ m $ and $ n $, then $ J_d $ is a common divisor of the numbers $ J_m $ and $ J_n $.
b) We will prove the converse theorem. Suppose the natural numbers $ m $ and $ n $ are coprime. Applying the Euclidean algorithm, i.e., dividing $ m $ by $ m $, $ n $ by the obtained remainder $ r $, the remainder $ r $ by the new remainder $ r_1 $, etc., we get smaller and smaller remainders, so we eventually reach a remainder equal to zero:

From the sequence of equalities (1), it follows that the natural number $ r_k $ is a common divisor of the numbers $ r_{k-1}, r_{k-2}, \ldots, r, n, m $, so $ r_k = 1 $.
From the first equality (1), we infer, based on $ \beta $), that

Let $ D $ be a common divisor of the natural numbers $ J_m $ and $ J_n $. Since $ J_{nq} $ is divisible by $ J_n $ according to $ \alpha $), $ D $ is also a divisor of the number $ J_r \cdot 10^{nq} $ according to (2). The number $ 10^{nq} $ has no other prime divisors except for the numbers $ 2 $ and $ 5 $, which are not divisors of the number $ J_m $, so $ D $ is coprime with $ 10^{nq} $. Therefore, $ D $ is a divisor of $ J_r $.
In the same way, based on the next equalities (1), we will conclude successively that $ D $ is a divisor of the numbers $ J_{r_1}, J_{r_2}, \ldots, J_{r_k} $. But $ r_k = 1 $, so

This means that $ J_m $ and $ J_n $ are coprime, which is what we had to prove.
Note 1. The part b) of the above proof can be replaced by a much shorter argument, using the following well-known theorem of number theory:
If the natural numbers $ m $ and $ n $ are coprime, then there exist natural numbers $ x $ and $ y $ such that

The converse theorem also holds: if the natural numbers $ m $, $ n $, $ x $, $ y $ satisfy equation (3), then $ m $ and $ n $ are coprime. This follows from equation (3) because any common divisor of the numbers $ m $ and $ n $ is a divisor of the number $ 1 $.
Assume the natural numbers $ m $, $ n $ are coprime, so for some natural numbers $ x $ and $ y $, (3) holds. Then

and since according to ($ \alpha $): $ J_{mx} = J_m \cdot M $ and $ J_{my} = J_m \cdot N $, where the numbers $ M $ and $ N $ are natural, then:

Note 2. The proof of the theorem cited in Note 1 can be derived from the sequence of equalities (1). Substituting the value of $ r $ from the first equality into the second, and then after this substitution the value of $ r_1 $ from the second equality into the third, etc., we eventually arrive, considering that $ r_k = 1 $, at an equality of the form (3).
Note 3. In the above arguments, we assumed that the base of numeration is $ 10 $. The theorem is, however, true for any base of numeration $ g $. The proof remains the same, except that everywhere $ 10 $ must be replaced by $ g $.
informal_statement:
XIV OM - III - Task 1

Prove that two natural numbers, whose digits are all ones, are relatively prime if and only if the numbers of their digits are relatively prime.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- XIV OM - III - Task 1

Prove that two natural numbers, whose digits are all ones, are relatively prime if and only if the numbers of their digits are relatively prime. -/
theorem number_theory_114751 {n m : ‚Ñï} (hn : n > 0) (hm : m > 0)
    (hnm : n.digits 10 = (List.replicate (Nat.digits 10 n).length 1) ‚àß
      m.digits 10 = (List.replicate (Nat.digits 10 m).length 1)) :
    Nat.Coprime n m ‚Üî Nat.Coprime (Nat.digits 10 n).length (Nat.digits 10 m).length := by

soln_description:
If we set $\frac{x-1}{x+1}=\sin \alpha$ (which is possible for $x \geq 0$ because $-1 \leq \frac{x-1}{x+1} \leq 1$), then we have

$$
\cos \alpha=\sqrt{1-\sin ^{2} \alpha}=\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{x-1}{x+1}\right)^{2}}=2 \frac{\sqrt{x}}{x+1}
$$

Thus,

$$
\frac{(x-1) \sqrt{x}}{(x+1)^{2}}=\frac{1}{2} \sin \alpha \cos \alpha=\frac{1}{4} \sin (2 \alpha)<\frac{1}{4}
$$

because $\sin (2 \alpha) \leq 1$. Equality holds for $\sin 2 \alpha=1$, i.e., $\sin \alpha=0.5 \sqrt{2}, \frac{x-1}{x+1}=0.5 \sqrt{2}, x=3+2 \sqrt{2} \approx$ 5.83.
informal_statement:
## Task 18/81

Prove the validity of the inequality

$$
\frac{(x-1) \sqrt{x}}{(x+1)^{2}} \leq \frac{1}{4}
$$

for every nonnegative real number $x$. For which $x$-values does equality hold?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- ## Task 18/81

Prove the validity of the inequality

$$
\frac{(x-1) \sqrt{x}}{(x+1)^{2}} \leq \frac{1}{4}
$$

for every nonnegative real number $x$. For which $x$-values does equality hold? -/
theorem inequalities_159170 (x : ‚Ñù) (hx : x ‚â• 0) :
    (x - 1) * sqrt x / (x + 1)^2 ‚â§ 1 / 4 ‚àß
    ((x - 1) * sqrt x / (x + 1)^2 = 1 / 4 ‚Üî x = 1 / 2) := by

soln_description:
Solution I. From $n \mid p-1$ it follows that $n>0$. So $p \mid n^{2}+n+1$. Due to $n \mid p-1$, we can write $p$ as $k n+1$, with $k$ a positive integer. From $k n+1 \mid n^{2}+n+1$ it follows that

$$
k n+1 \mid k\left(n^{2}+n+1\right)-(n+1)(k n+1)=k-n-1 .
$$

We now distinguish three cases.

Case 1: $k>n+1$. Then $k-n-1$ is positive and it must hold that $k n+1 \leq k-n-1$. From this, we get $(k+1) n \leq k-2$, but the left side is clearly larger than the right side. This case is therefore not possible.

Case 2: $k<n+1$. Then $k-n-1$ is negative and it must hold that $k n+1 \leq n+1-k$. From this, we get $(k-1) n \leq -k$, but the left side is non-negative and the right side is negative. This case is also not possible.

Case 3: $k=n+1$. Now $p=(n+1) n+1=n^{2}+n+1$. So $4 p-3=4 n^{2}+4 n+1=(2 n+1)^{2}$ and this is a square.

We conclude that in the only possible case, $4 p-3$ is a square.
informal_statement: Task 3. Let $n \geq 2$ be a positive integer and $p$ a prime number such that $n \mid p-1$ and $p \mid n^{3}-1$. Prove that $4 p-3$ is a square.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Task 3. Let $n \geq 2$ be a positive integer and $p$ a prime number such that $n \mid p-1$ and $p \mid n^{3}-1$. Prove that $4 p-3$ is a square. -/
theorem number_theory_168161 (n p : ‚Ñï) (hn : 2 ‚â§ n) (hp : Nat.Prime p)
    (hnp : n ‚à£ p - 1) (hpn : p ‚à£ n ^ 3 - 1) :
    ‚àÉ m, m ^ 2 = 4 * p - 3 := by

informal_statement: 8.1. In the expansion of the function $f(x)=\left(1+x-x^{2}\right)^{20}$ in powers of $x$, find the coefficient of $x^{3 n}$, where $n$ is equal to the sum of all coefficients of the expansion.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 8.1. In the expansion of the function $f(x)=\left(1+x-x^{2}\right)^{20}$ in powers of $x$, find the coefficient of $x^{3 n}$, where $n$ is equal to the sum of all coefficients of the expansion. -/
theorem algebra_207068 (f : Polynomial ‚Ñù) (hf : f = (1 + X - X ^ 2) ^ 20)
    (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : n = ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range (f.natDegree + 1), f.coeff i) :
    f.coeff (3 * n) = 760 := by

soln_description:
13. The answer is 042. Let $q(x) = p(x) - 2x$. Since $p(k) = 2k$ for $k = 1, \ldots, 20$, then $q(k) = 0$ for $k = 1, \ldots, 20$. According to the Ruffini's theorem, this means that the polynomial $q(x)$ is divisible by $x-1, x-2, \ldots, x-20$. Therefore, we have

$$
q(x) = (x-1)(x-2) \cdots (x-20) r(x)
$$

for some polynomial $r(x)$. If $r(x)$ had a degree of 1 or higher, $q(x)$ and thus $p(x) = q(x) + 2x$ would have a degree greater than 20, which contradicts the hypothesis. Therefore, $r(x)$ must be a constant, say $r(x) = \alpha$. Expanding the product in equation (2), we see that the leading term (degree 20) of $q(x)$, and thus of $p(x)$, has a coefficient of $\alpha$; hence, $r(x) = \alpha = 1$. We have thus shown that

$$
q(x) = (x-1)(x-2) \cdots (x-20).
$$

From this equality, it follows that

$$
p(x) = (x-1)(x-2) \cdots (x-20) + 2x
$$

and therefore, evaluating the polynomial at $x = 21$, we get

$$
p(21) = 20 \cdot 19 \cdots 1 + 2 \cdot 21 = 20! + 42
$$

The term 20! is a multiple of 1000 (it can be easily verified that it contains enough factors of 2 and 5); more precisely, 20! ends exactly with 4 zeros (there are only 4 factors equal to 5). Therefore, the last three digits of $p(21)$ are 042.
informal_statement: 13. Let $p(x)=x^{20}+a_{19} x^{19}+a_{18} x^{18}+\ldots+a_{1} x+a_{0}$ be a polynomial, with the $a_{i}$ being integers. We know that, for all integers $k$ between 1 and 20, $p(k)=2k$. What are the last 3 digits of $p(21)$?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 13. Let $p(x)=x^{20}+a_{19} x^{19}+a_{18} x^{18}+\ldots+a_{1} x+a_{0}$ be a polynomial, with the $a_{i}$ being integers. We know that, for all integers $k$ between 1 and 20, $p(k)=2k$. What are the last 3 digits of $p(21)$? -/
theorem algebra_134898 {p : Polynomial ‚Ñ§} (hp : p.degree = 20)
    (h : ‚àÄ k ‚àà Finset.Icc 1 20, p.eval k = 2 * k) :
    (p.eval 21) % 1000 = 42 := by

soln_description:
10. When $x \neq 0$,
$$
f\left(\frac{x}{2^{k-1}}\right)-f\left(\frac{x}{2^{k}}\right)=\frac{x^{2}}{2^{2 k}}(k=1,2, \cdots, n) \text {. }
$$

Adding these $n$ equations, we get
$$
f(x)-f\left(\frac{x}{2^{n}}\right)=x^{2} \cdot \frac{\frac{1}{4}\left[1-\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{n}\right]}{1-\frac{1}{4}} \text {. }
$$

Let $n \rightarrow \infty$, then $f\left(\frac{x}{2^{n}}\right)=f(0)=1$.
The right-hand side of the equation above $=\frac{x^{2}}{3}$.
Thus, $f(x)=1+\frac{x^{2}}{3}(x \neq 0)$.
Also, $f(0)=1$ satisfies the condition, therefore,
$$
f(x)=1+\frac{x^{2}}{3} .
$$
informal_statement:
10. (20 points) Given
$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} f(x)=f(0)=1, f(2 x)-f(x)=x^{2}
$$

for any real number $x$. Find the analytical expression of $f(x)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 10. (20 points) Given
$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} f(x)=f(0)=1, f(2 x)-f(x)=x^{2}
$$

for any real number $x$. Find the analytical expression of $f(x)$. -/
theorem calculus_306522 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (hf : ‚àÄ x, f (2 * x) - f x = x ^ 2)
    (hf0 : f 0 = 1) :
    ‚àÄ x, f x = 1 + x ^ 2 / 3 := by

soln_description:
Solution. We use the formula

$$
P(a<X<b)=\mathrm{e}^{-\lambda a}-\mathrm{e}^{-\lambda b} .
$$

Considering that, according to the condition, $a=0.13, b=0.7, \lambda=3$, and using the table of values of the function $\mathrm{e}^{-x}$, we get

$$
\begin{gathered}
P(0.13<X<0.7)=\mathrm{e}^{-3 \cdot 0.13}-\mathrm{e}^{-3 \cdot 0.7}=\mathrm{e}^{-0.39}-\mathrm{e}^{-3.1}= \\
=0.677-0.122=0.555 .
\end{gathered}
$$

/- 350. A continuous random variable $X$ is distributed according to the exponential law, given by the probability density function $f(x)=3 \mathrm{e}^{-3 x}$ for $x \geqslant 0$; for $x<0$, $f(x)=0$. Find the probability that in the experiment, $X$ falls into the interval $(0.13, 0.7)$. -/
theorem calculus_158661 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (hf : ‚àÄ x, x ‚â• 0 ‚Üí f x = 3 * exp (-3 * x))
  (hf' : ‚àÄ x, x < 0 ‚Üí f x = 0) :
  ‚à´ x in (0.13)..0.7, f x = 0.555 := by

soln_description:
Let $a=2-3 \sqrt{2}, b=2, c=2+3 \sqrt{2}$, we get $M \geqslant \frac{9 \sqrt{2}}{32}$.
To prove the inequality
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left|a b\left(a^{2}-b^{2}\right)+b c\left(b^{2}-c^{2}\right)+c a\left(c^{2}-a^{2}\right)\right| \\
\leqslant \frac{9 \sqrt{2}}{32}\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{2}
\end{array}
$$

for all real numbers $a, b$, and $c$.
Since
$$
\begin{aligned}
& a b\left(a^{2}-b^{2}\right)+b c\left(b^{2}-c^{2}\right)+c a\left(c^{2}-a^{2}\right) \\
= & -(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)(a+b+c),
\end{aligned}
$$

it suffices to prove
$$
\begin{aligned}
& |(a-b)(b-c)(c-a)(a+b+c)| \\
\leqslant & \frac{9 \sqrt{2}}{32}\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

By symmetry, assume $a \leqslant b \leqslant c$. Then we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
|(a-b)(b-c)| & =(b-a)(c-b) \\
& \leqslant\left(\frac{(b-a)+(c-b)}{2}\right)^{2} \\
& =\frac{(c-a)^{2}}{4},
\end{aligned}
$$

and
$$
\left(\frac{(c-b)+(b-a)}{2}\right)^{2} \leqslant \frac{(c-b)^{2}+(b-a)^{2}}{2},
$$

so
$$
3(c-a)^{2} \leqslant 2\left[(b-a)^{2}+(c-b)^{2}+(c-a)^{2}\right] \text {, }
$$

thus
$$
\begin{aligned}
& |(b-c)(a-b)(a-c)(a+b+c)| \\
\leqslant & \frac{1}{4}\left|(c-a)^{3}(a+b+c)\right| \\
= & \frac{1}{4} \sqrt{(c-a)^{6}(a+b+c)^{2}} \\
\leqslant & \frac{1}{4} \sqrt{\left(\frac{2\left[(b-a)^{2}+(c-b)^{2}+(c-a)^{2}\right]}{3}\right)^{3}(a+b+c)^{2}} \\
\leqslant & \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\left(\sqrt[4]{\left(\frac{(b-a)^{2}+(c-b)^{2}+(c-a)^{2}}{3}\right)^{3}(a+b+c)^{2}}\right)^{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

By the mean inequality, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
& |(b-c)(a-b)(a-c)(a+b+c)| \\
\leqslant & \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\left(\frac{(b-a)^{2}+(c-b)^{2}+(c-a)^{2}+(a+b+c)^{2}}{4}\right)^{2} \\
= & \frac{9 \sqrt{2}}{32}\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, the minimum value of $M$ is $\frac{9}{32} \sqrt{2}$.
informal_statement:
125 (47-3, Ireland) Find the smallest real number $M$ such that for all real numbers $a, b$, and $c$, we have

\begin{aligned}
& \left|a b\left(a^{2}-b^{2}\right)+b c\left(b^{2}-c^{2}\right)+c a\left(c^{2}-a^{2}\right)\right| \\
\leqslant & M\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib
