(China Jiangxi Province Nanchang City Junior High School Mathematics Competition, 1991) -/
theorem number_theory_182740 (m : ‚Ñï) :
    {a : ‚Ñ§ | ‚åäa - Real.sqrt a‚åã = m}.encard ‚â§ 2 := by

soln_description:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
0.5 x+0.6 y+0.9 z=60 \\
\Rightarrow 5 x+6 y+9 z=600 \ldots \ldots \\
x+y+z=100 \ldots \ldots(2)
\end{array}
$$

If $x=z$, then $14 x+6 y=600$
$\Rightarrow 7 x+3 y=300$ $\qquad$ (3) and $2 x+y=100$ $\qquad$
(3) $-3(4): x=0$ (rejected)

If $x=y$, then $11 x+9 z=600$ $\qquad$ (5) and $2 x+z=100$ $\qquad$ $9(6)-(5): 7 x=300, x$ is not an integer, rejected.
(1) $-5(2): y+4 z=100$ $\qquad$
If $y=z$, then $y=z=20, x=60$
informal_statement:
G7.3-G7.4 Chicken eggs cost $\$ 0.50$ each, duck eggs cost $\$ 0.60$ each and goose eggs cost $\$ 0.90$ each. A man sold $x$ chicken eggs, $y$ duck eggs, $z$ goose eggs and received $\$ 60$. If $x, y, z$ are all positive numbers with $x+y+z=100$ and two of the values $x, y, z$ are equal,

G7.3 find $x$.
G7.4 find $y$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- G7.3-G7.4 Chicken eggs cost $\$ 0.50$ each, duck eggs cost $\$ 0.60$ each and goose eggs cost $\$ 0.90$ each. A man sold $x$ chicken eggs, $y$ duck eggs, $z$ goose eggs and received $\$ 60$. If $x, y, z$ are all positive numbers with $x+y+z=100$ and two of the values $x, y, z$ are equal,

G7.3 find $x$.
G7.4 find $y$. -/
theorem algebra_193701 (x y z : ‚Ñù) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z)
    (hsum : x + y + z = 100) (h : x = y ‚à® y = z ‚à® x = z) (h' : 0.50 * x + 0.60 * y + 0.90 * z = 60) :
    x = 60 ‚àß y = 30 := by

soln_description:
7. 1 or 19 Hint: It is easy to know $p \equiv 1,7,11,13,17,19,23$ or $29(\bmod 30)$.

So $p^{2} \equiv 1$ or $19(\bmod 30)$.
When $p=31$, $p^{2} \equiv 1(\bmod 30)$,
When $p=67$, $p^{2} \equiv 19(\bmod 30)$.
informal_statement: 7. $p$ is a prime number greater than 5, the remainder when $p^{2}$ is divided by 30 is
informal_proof:
Let $p$ be a prime number such that $p > 5$. We aim to prove that $p^2$ leaves a remainder of 1 or 19 when divided by 30.

Since $p$ is a prime number strictly greater than 5, it cannot be divisible by 2, 3, or 5. This implies:
\begin{enumerate}
    \item $p \not\equiv 0 \pmod{2}$. As $p$ is prime and not 2, $p$ must be odd, so $p \equiv 1 \pmod{2}$.
    \item $p \not\equiv 0 \pmod{3}$. This means $p$ can only be congruent to 1 or 2 modulo 3, i.e., $p \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$ or $p \equiv 2 \pmod{3}$.
    \item $p \not\equiv 0 \pmod{5}$. This means $p$ can only be congruent to 1, 2, 3, or 4 modulo 5, i.e., $p \equiv 1 \pmod{5}$, $p \equiv 2 \pmod{5}$, $p \equiv 3 \pmod{5}$, or $p \equiv 4 \pmod{5}$.
\end{enumerate}

Now, let's consider the possible values of $p^2$ modulo 2, 3, and 5.

\textbf{Modulo 2:} Since $p \equiv 1 \pmod{2}$, squaring both sides yields $p^2 \equiv 1^2 \pmod{2}$, which simplifies to $p^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{2}$.

\textbf{Modulo 3:}
\begin{itemize}
    \item If $p \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$, then $p^2 \equiv 1^2 \pmod{3}$, so $p^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$.
    \item If $p \equiv 2 \pmod{3}$, then $p^2 \equiv 2^2 \pmod{3}$, so $p^2 \equiv 4 \pmod{3}$. Since $4 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$, we get $p^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$.
\end{itemize}
In both cases, $p^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$.

\textbf{Modulo 5:}
\begin{itemize}
    \item If $p \equiv 1 \pmod{5}$, then $p^2 \equiv 1^2 \pmod{5}$, so $p^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{5}$.
    \item If $p \equiv 2 \pmod{5}$, then $p^2 \equiv 2^2 \pmod{5}$, so $p^2 \equiv 4 \pmod{5}$.
    \item If $p \equiv 3 \pmod{5}$, then $p^2 \equiv 3^2 \pmod{5}$, so $p^2 \equiv 9 \pmod{5}$. Since $9 \equiv 4 \pmod{5}$, we get $p^2 \equiv 4 \pmod{5}$.
    \item If $p \equiv 4 \pmod{5}$, then $p^2 \equiv 4^2 \pmod{5}$, so $p^2 \equiv 16 \pmod{5}$. Since $16 \equiv 1 \pmod{5}$, we get $p^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{5}$.
\end{itemize}
Thus, $p^2$ must be congruent to either 1 or 4 modulo 5, i.e., $p^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{5}$ or $p^2 \equiv 4 \pmod{5}$.

Now we combine these results using the Chinese Remainder Theorem. We have established that:
\begin{itemize}
    \item $p^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{2}$
    \item $p^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$
\end{itemize}
And we have two possibilities for the congruence modulo 5:

Case 1: $p^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{5}$.
We have the system of congruences:
$p^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{2}$
$p^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$
$p^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{5}$
Since 2, 3, and 5 are pairwise coprime, by the Chinese Remainder Theorem, there is a unique solution modulo $2 \times 3 \times 5 = 30$. In this case, the congruences combine to give $p^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{30}$.

Case 2: $p^2 \equiv 4 \pmod{5}$.
We have the system of congruences:
$p^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{2}$
$p^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$
$p^2 \equiv 4 \pmod{5}$
The first two congruences imply $p^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{6}$ (since 2 and 3 are coprime). We are looking for a number $x$ such that $x \equiv 1 \pmod{6}$ and $x \equiv 4 \pmod{5}$.
We can list numbers congruent to 1 mod 6: 1, 7, 13, 19, 25, 31, ...
Checking their remainders modulo 5:
\begin{itemize}
    \item $1 \equiv 1 \pmod{5}$
    \item $7 \equiv 2 \pmod{5}$
    \item $13 \equiv 3 \pmod{5}$
    \item $19 \equiv 4 \pmod{5}$
\end{itemize}
The congruence $p^2 \equiv 4 \pmod{5}$ is satisfied when $p^2 \equiv 19 \pmod{30}$.

Therefore, for any prime $p > 5$, $p^2$ must be congruent to either 1 or 19 modulo 30.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7. $p$ is a prime number greater than 5, the remainder when $p^{2}$ is divided by 30 is -/
theorem number_theory_208290 (p : ‚Ñï) (hp : p.Prime) (h : 5 < p) :
    p^2 ‚â° 1 [MOD 30] ‚à® p^2 ‚â° 19 [MOD 30] := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_208290 (p : ‚Ñï) (hp : p.Prime) (h : 5 < p) :
    p^2 ‚â° 1 [MOD 30] ‚à® p^2 ‚â° 19 [MOD 30] := by 
  have h1 : p % 2 ‚â† 0 := by 
    by_contra h2
    have h2 : 2 ‚à£ p := by omega
    have h3 : ¬¨ p.Prime := by 
      rw [Nat.not_prime_iff_exists_dvd_lt (by omega)]
      use 2
      simp [h2, h]
      all_goals linarith
    contradiction

  have h2 : p % 3 ‚â† 0 := by 
    by_contra h3
    have h3 : 3 ‚à£ p := by omega
    have h4 : ¬¨ p.Prime := by 
      rw [Nat.not_prime_iff_exists_dvd_lt (by omega)]
      use 3
      simp [h3, h]
      all_goals linarith
    contradiction
  
  have h3 : p % 5 ‚â† 0 := by 
    by_contra h4
    have h4 : 5 ‚à£ p := by omega
    have h5 : ¬¨ p.Prime := by 
      rw [Nat.not_prime_iff_exists_dvd_lt (by omega)]
      use 5
      simp [h4, h]
      all_goals linarith
    contradiction
  
  have h4 : p % 2 = 1 := by 
    omega

  have h5 : p % 3 = 1 ‚à® p % 3 = 2 := by 
    omega

  have h6 : p % 5 = 1 ‚à® p % 5 = 2 ‚à® p % 5 = 3 ‚à® p % 5 = 4 := by 
    omega

  have h7 : p % 2 = 1 := h4

  have h8 : p % 3 = 1 ‚à® p % 3 = 2 := h5

  have h9 : p % 5 = 1 ‚à® p % 5 = 2 ‚à® p % 5 = 3 ‚à® p % 5 = 4 := h6

  have h10 : p % 2 = 1 := h7

  have h11 : p ^ 2 % 2 = 1 := by
    simp [Nat.pow_mod, h10]

  have h12 : p ^ 2 % 3 = 1 := by
    cases h8 with
    | inl h3 =>
      simp [Nat.pow_mod, h3]
    | inr h3 =>
      simp [Nat.pow_mod, h3]

  have h13 : p ^ 2 % 5 = 1 ‚à® p ^ 2 % 5 = 4 := by
    cases h9 with
    | inl h5 => 
      simp [Nat.pow_mod, h5]
    | inr h9 =>
      cases h9 with
      | inl h5 => 
        simp [Nat.pow_mod, h5]
      | inr h9 =>
        cases h9 with
        | inl h5 => 
          simp [Nat.pow_mod, h5]
        | inr h9 => 
          simp [Nat.pow_mod, h9]

  have h14 : (p^2) % 30 = 1 ‚à® (p^2) % 30 = 19 := by 
    omega

  simp [Nat.ModEq] at *
  omega

soln_description: 5. Let the numbers $a, b, c$ and $d$ be given. By the condition $a(b+c+d)=b(a+c+d)$, we get $(a-b)(c+d)=0$. Similarly, from the equality $c(a+b+d)=d(a+b+c)$, we obtain $(c-d)(a+b)=0$. Since either $c+d$ or $c-d$ is not equal to 0, then either $a=b$ or $a=-b$. In both cases, the squares of the numbers $a$ and $b$ are equal, from which, due to the arbitrariness of the choice of $a$ and $b$, the statement of the problem follows.
informal_statement: 5. Four numbers are written on the board, none of which are equal to 0. If each of them is multiplied by the sum of the other three, the result is four identical values. Prove that the squares of the numbers written on the board are equal.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. Four numbers are written on the board, none of which are equal to 0. If each of them is multiplied by the sum of the other three, the result is four identical values. Prove that the squares of the numbers written on the board are equal. -/
theorem algebra_107652 (a b c d : ‚Ñù) (ha : a ‚â† 0) (hb : b ‚â† 0) (hc : c ‚â† 0)
    (hd : d ‚â† 0) (h : a * (b + c + d) = b * (a + c + d)) (h' : b * (a + c + d) = c * (a + b + d))
    (h'' : c * (a + b + d) = d * (a + b + c)) :
    a^2 = b^2 ‚àß b^2 = c^2 ‚àß c^2 = d^2 := by

soln_description:
2. From $g(x)=x^{3}-x=x(x-1)(x+1)$, we know $x_{1}=0, x_{2}=1, x_{3}=-1$. At this point, $f(0)=0, f(1)=5$. $f(-1)=-5$.
Let the remainder of $f(x)$ divided by $g(x)$ be $r(x)$, then $\operatorname{deg} r<3$. By the Lagrange interpolation formula, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
r(x) & =\frac{(x-1)(x+1)}{(0-1)(0+1)} f(0)+\frac{(x-0)(x+1)}{(1-0)(1+1)} f(1)+\frac{(x-0)(x-1)}{(-1-0)(-1-1)} f(-1) \\
& =5 x .
\end{aligned}
$$
informal_statement: 2. Find the remainder when $f(x)=x^{81}+x^{49}+x^{25}+x^{9}+x$ is divided by $g(x)=x^{3}-x$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. Find the remainder when $f(x)=x^{81}+x^{49}+x^{25}+x^{9}+x$ is divided by $g(x)=x^{3}-x$. -/
theorem algebra_159193 {f g : Polynomial ‚Ñù} (hf : f = X ^ 81 + X ^ 49 + X ^ 25 + X ^ 9 + X)
    (hg : g = X ^ 3 - X) : f % g = 5 * X := by

informal_statement: The least common multiple of two integers is $1925$. When these two integers are divided by their greatest common divisor, the sum of the two quotients is $16$. Please write down these two integers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The least common multiple of two integers is $1925$. When these two integers are divided by their greatest common divisor, the sum of the two quotients is $16$. Please write down these two integers. -/
theorem number_theory_757 {x y : ‚Ñï} (hx : x ‚â† 0) (hy : y ‚â† 0)
    (hxy : Nat.lcm x y = 1925) (hxy1 : x / Nat.gcd x y + y / Nat.gcd x y = 16) :
    x = 175 ‚àß y = 385 := by

informal_statement: In the equation $y=kx+b$ ($k$, $b$ are constants), when $-3\leqslant x\leqslant 1$, $1\leqslant y\leqslant 9$, then the value of $2k-b$ is ___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___ or ___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- In the equation $y=kx+b$ ($k$, $b$ are constants), when $-3\leqslant x\leqslant 1$, $1\leqslant y\leqslant 9$, then the value of $2k-b$ is ___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___ or ___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___ . -/
theorem algebra_983 (k b : ‚Ñù) (h : ‚àÄx ‚àà Set.Icc (-3) 1, 1 ‚â§ (k * x + b) ‚àß (k * x + b) ‚â§ 9) :
    2 * k - b = -3 ‚à® 2 * k - b = -7 := by

soln_description:
1. **Initial Setup and Conjecture:**
   We start with the numbers \(1, 2, 3, \ldots, 10\) on the board. The operation involves deleting two numbers \(a\) and \(b\) and writing the number \(a + b + \frac{ab}{f(a, b)}\), where \(f(a, b)\) is the sum of all numbers on the board excluding \(a\) and \(b\).

   The conjecture is that the sum of the product of the pairs of the numbers written on the board is invariant.

2. **Proof of Invariance:**
   Let \(S\) be the sum of the product of the pairs of numbers on the board before the operation, and \(S_1\) be the sum after the operation. Define \(x = f(a, b)\). We need to show that \(S = S_1\).

   Before the operation:
   \[
   S = \sum_{i < j} a_i a_j
   \]

   After deleting \(a\) and \(b\) and adding \(a + b + \frac{ab}{x}\):
   \[
   S_1 = S - x(a + b) - ab + \left(a + b + \frac{ab}{x}\right)x
   \]

   Simplifying \(S_1\):
   \[
   S_1 = S - x(a + b) - ab + (a + b)x + ab = S
   \]

   Thus, \(S = S_1\), proving the invariance.

3. **Minimizing \(y\) to Maximize \(x\):**
   Since \(xy\) is invariant, we aim to minimize \(y\) to maximize \(x\). The smallest number on the board initially is 1, so the minimum value for \(y\) is 1.

4. **Calculating the Invariant Product \(xy\):**
   The sum of the products of all pairs of numbers from 1 to 10 is:
   \[
   \sum_{i < j} i \cdot j = \frac{1}{2} \left( \left( \sum_{i=1}^{10} i \right)^2 - \sum_{i=1}^{10} i^2 \right)
   \]

   Calculating the sums:
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^{10} i = \frac{10 \cdot 11}{2} = 55
   \]
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^{10} i^2 = \frac{10 \cdot 11 \cdot 21}{6} = 385
   \]

   Therefore:
   \[
   \sum_{i < j} i \cdot j = \frac{1}{2} \left( 55^2 - 385 \right) = \frac{1}{2} \left( 3025 - 385 \right) = \frac{1}{2} \cdot 2640 = 1320
   \]

5. **Conclusion:**
   Since \(xy = 1320\) and \(y = 1\), the maximum value of \(x\) is:
   \[
   x = 1320
   \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{1320}\)
informal_statement: One writes, initially, the numbers $1,2,3,\dots,10$ in a board. An operation is to delete the numbers $a, b$ and write the number $a+b+\frac{ab}{f(a,b)}$, where $f(a, b)$ is the sum of all numbers in the board excluding $a$ and $b$, one will make this until remain two numbers $x, y$ with $x\geq y$. Find the maximum value of $x$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset

/- One writes, initially, the numbers $1,2,3,\dots,10$ in a board. An operation is to delete the numbers $a, b$ and write the number $a+b+\frac{ab}{f(a,b)}$, where $f(a, b)$ is the sum of all numbers in the board excluding $a$ and $b$, one will make this until remain two numbers $x, y$ with $x\geq y$. Find the maximum value of $x$. -/
theorem other_37270 (S : Finset ‚Ñï) (hS : S ‚äÜ Icc 1 10) :
    IsGreatest {x | ‚àÉ a ‚àà S, ‚àÉ b ‚àà S, a ‚â• b ‚àß x = a + b + a * b / (‚àë c ‚àà S \ {a, b}, c)} 1320 := by

soln_description:
We conduct a case distinction.

Case 1:

Let $p \geq q$. Then we have

$$
\frac{p}{q}-\frac{1}{9 q^{2}} \geq 1-\frac{1}{9}=\frac{8}{9}>\frac{6}{9}>\frac{3 \cdot \sqrt{3}}{9}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}
$$

which contradicts the assumptions.

Case 2:

Let $p<q$. Then we have

$$
\frac{p}{q}-\frac{1}{9 q^{2}}<\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}<\frac{p}{q}+\frac{1}{9 q^{2}}
$$

Multiplication by $9 \cdot \sqrt{3} \cdot q^{2}$ yields

$$
9 \cdot \sqrt{3} \cdot p \cdot q-\sqrt{3}<9 \cdot q^{2}<9 \cdot \sqrt{3} \cdot p \cdot q+\sqrt{3}
$$

and thus

$$
\sqrt{3} \cdot(9 p q-1)<9 q^{2}<\sqrt{3} \cdot(9 p q+1)
$$

Squaring gives

$$
3 \cdot(9 p q-1)^{2}<81 q^{4}<3 \cdot(9 p q+1)^{2}
$$

Division by 3 results in

$$
(9 p q-1)^{2}<27 q^{4}<(9 p q+1)^{2}
$$

Division by $9 q^{2}$ yields

$$
\left(3 p-\frac{1}{3 q}\right)^{2}<3 q^{2}<\left(3 p+\frac{1}{3 q}\right)^{2}
$$

Expanding leads to

$$
9 p^{2}-2 \frac{p}{q}+\frac{1}{9 q^{2}}<3 q^{2}<9 p^{2}+2 \frac{p}{q}+\frac{1}{9 q^{2}}
$$

Since $p<q$, we have

$$
9 p^{2}-2<3 q^{2}<9 p^{2}+3
$$

Thus, it must be that

$$
3 q^{2}=s
$$

with

$$
s \in\left\{9 p^{2}-1,9 p^{2}, 9 p^{2}+1,9 p^{2}+2\right\}
$$

### Case 2.1:

If $3 q^{2}=9 p^{2}-1$, we consider this equation modulo 3. Since $3 q^{2} \bmod 3=0 \bmod 3$ and $9 p^{2}-1 \bmod 3=2 \bmod 3$, this case cannot occur.

Case 2.2:

If $3 q^{2}=9 p^{2}$, then $p=\frac{q}{\sqrt{3}}$ and thus $p \notin \mathbb{N}$. Therefore, this case cannot occur.

### Case 2.3:

If $3 q^{2}=9 p^{2}+1$, we consider this equation modulo 3. Since $3 q^{2} \bmod 3=0 \bmod 3$ and $9 p^{2}+1 \bmod 3=1 \bmod 3$, this case cannot occur.

### Case 2.4:

If $3 q^{2}=9 p^{2}+2$, we consider this equation modulo 3. Since $3 q^{2} \bmod 3=0 \bmod 3$ and $9 p^{2}+2 \bmod 3=2 \bmod 3$, this case cannot occur.

Thus, Case 2 also contradicts the assumptions. In conclusion, there can be no positive integers $p$ and $q$ that satisfy the given conditions.
informal_statement:
## Task 5 - 191235

## Prove:

There are no positive integers $p$ and $q$ with the property

$$
\frac{p}{q}-\frac{1}{9 q^{2}}<\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}<\frac{p}{q}+\frac{1}{9 q^{2}}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- ## Task 5 - 191235

## Prove:

There are no positive integers $p$ and $q$ with the property

$$
\frac{p}{q}-\frac{1}{9 q^{2}}<\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}<\frac{p}{q}+\frac{1}{9 q^{2}}
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_198117 (p q : ‚Ñ§) (hp : 0 < p) (hq : 0 < q) :
    ¬¨(p / q - 1 / (9 * q ^ 2) < 1 / sqrt 3 ‚àß 1 / sqrt 3 < p / q + 1 / (9 * q ^ 2)) := by

soln_description:
5.I.1. Let's represent the number $x$ in the form $x=2011 k+d$, where $d=0,1, \ldots 2010$. Since $\left[\frac{x}{2010}\right]=\left[\frac{x}{2011}\right]+1=k+1$, then $k+1 \leqslant \frac{x}{2010}<2011$, from which

$$
2010 k+2010 \leqslant 2011 k+d<2010 k+4020
$$

thus, $2010 \leqslant k+d<4020$, or $2010 \leqslant k+d \leqslant 4019$. Therefore, for each of the 2011 values of $d$ there are 2010 values of the number $k$ such that the number $x=2011 k+d$ is a solution to the given equation. Hence, it has $2010 \cdot 2011$ solutions.

Answer: $2010 \cdot 2011$.
informal_statement:
1. Find the number of natural solutions to the equation

$$
\left[\frac{x}{2010}\right]=\left[\frac{x}{2011}\right]+1
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Find the number of natural solutions to the equation

$$
\left[\frac{x}{2010}\right]=\left[\frac{x}{2011}\right]+1
$$ -/
theorem number_theory_290645 :
    Set.ncard {x : ‚Ñï | ‚åä(x : ‚Ñù) / 2010‚åã = ‚åä(x : ‚Ñù) / 2011‚åã + 1} = 2010 * 2011 := by

soln_description:
Solution. The equation is equivalent to the following: $x^{2}-x=-y^{2}+y+2$. The function $f(x) = x^{2}-x=(x-0.5)^{2}-0.25$ takes values in the interval $[-0.25 ;+\infty)$, $g(y)=-y^{2}+y+2=-(y-0.5)^{2}+2.25-$ on the interval $[2.25 ;-\infty)$, that is, they have only three common integer values: $0, 1, 2$. Since $x$ and $y$ are integers, $f(x)$ and $g(y)$ can only take even values, so the common value 1 is excluded. The equation $f(x)=0$ has roots 0 and 1, and the equation $g(y)=0$ has roots -1 and 2. This gives 4 pairs of solutions. The equation $f(x)=2$ has roots -1 and 2, and the equation $g(y)=2$ has roots 1 and 0. This gives another 4 pairs of solutions, all of which, obviously, are valid.

Criteria. If the solution is incorrect or only the answer without explanation - 0 points.

If the reasoning is correct and there is a computational error, or one answer is lost - 3 points.

If the solution is correct - 7 points.

Criteria. If the solution is incorrect - 0 points.

If the reasoning is correct and there is a computational error - 3 points. If the solution is correct - 7 points.
informal_proof:
We want to prove the equivalence: $x^2 + y^2 = x + y + 2$ if and only if $(x, y)$ is one of the eight specified pairs. We will prove both directions of this biconditional.

First, we prove the forward direction: if $x^2 + y^2 = x + y + 2$ holds for integers $x$ and $y$, then $(x, y)$ must be one of the eight given pairs.
We rearrange the equation to group terms involving $x$ and $y$:
$x^2 - x + y^2 - y = 2$.
To make the structure clearer, we can complete the square for the terms involving $x$ and $y$. Consider the expression $(2x-1)^2 = 4x^2 - 4x + 1$ and $(2y-1)^2 = 4y^2 - 4y + 1$. Multiplying our rearranged equation by 4 gives $4x^2 - 4x + 4y^2 - 4y = 8$.
Adding $1$ to complete the square for $x$ and $1$ for $y$, we get:
$(4x^2 - 4x + 1) + (4y^2 - 4y + 1) = 8 + 1 + 1$
$(2x-1)^2 + (2y-1)^2 = 10$.

Since $x$ and $y$ are integers, $2x-1$ and $2y-1$ must be odd integers. Also, since squares of real numbers are non-negative, we must have $(2x-1)^2 \le 10$ and $(2y-1)^2 \le 10$.
The possible integer values for $2x-1$ whose square is at most 10 are $-3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3$. However, $2x-1$ must be odd. Thus, the possible odd integer values for $2x-1$ are $-3, -1, 1, 3$. Similarly, the possible odd integer values for $2y-1$ are $-3, -1, 1, 3$.

We can now systematically check which combinations of these odd integers for $2x-1$ and $2y-1$ sum to 10:
\begin{enumerate}
    \item If $2x-1 = -3$, then $(2x-1)^2 = 9$. We need $(2y-1)^2 = 10 - 9 = 1$. The odd integer whose square is 1 is $2y-1 = 1$ or $2y-1 = -1$.
    \begin{itemize}
        \item If $2x-1 = -3$, then $2x = -2$, so $x = -1$.
        \item If $2y-1 = 1$, then $2y = 2$, so $y = 1$. This gives the pair $(-1, 1)$.
        \item If $2y-1 = -1$, then $2y = 0$, so $y = 0$. This gives the pair $(-1, 0)$.
    \end{itemize}
    \item If $2x-1 = -1$, then $(2x-1)^2 = 1$. We need $(2y-1)^2 = 10 - 1 = 9$. The odd integer whose square is 9 is $2y-1 = 3$ or $2y-1 = -3$.
    \begin{itemize}
        \item If $2x-1 = -1$, then $2x = 0$, so $x = 0$.
        \item If $2y-1 = 3$, then $2y = 4$, so $y = 2$. This gives the pair $(0, 2)$.
        \item If $2y-1 = -3$, then $2y = -2$, so $y = -1$. This gives the pair $(0, -1)$.
    \end{itemize}
    \item If $2x-1 = 1$, then $(2x-1)^2 = 1$. We need $(2y-1)^2 = 10 - 1 = 9$. The odd integer whose square is 9 is $2y-1 = 3$ or $2y-1 = -3$.
    \begin{itemize}
        \item If $2x-1 = 1$, then $2x = 2$, so $x = 1$.
        \item If $2y-1 = 3$, then $2y = 4$, so $y = 2$. This gives the pair $(1, 2)$.
        \item If $2y-1 = -3$, then $2y = -2$, so $y = -1$. This gives the pair $(1, -1)$.
    \end{itemize}
    \item If $2x-1 = 3$, then $(2x-1)^2 = 9$. We need $(2y-1)^2 = 10 - 9 = 1$. The odd integer whose square is 1 is $2y-1 = 1$ or $2y-1 = -1$.
    \begin{itemize}
        \item If $2x-1 = 3$, then $2x = 4$, so $x = 2$.
        \item If $2y-1 = 1$, then $2y = 2$, so $y = 1$. This gives the pair $(2, 1)$.
        \item If $2y-1 = -1$, then $2y = 0$, so $y = 0$. This gives the pair $(2, 0)$.
    \end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}
These are exactly the eight pairs listed in the statement. The formal proof uses a more direct method by establishing bounds on $x$ and $y$ (namely, $-1 \le x \le 2$ and $-1 \le y \le 2$) and then exhaustively checking all integer pairs within this range.

Now, we prove the backward direction: if $(x, y)$ is one of the eight specified pairs, then $x^2 + y^2 = x + y + 2$. We check each pair:

\begin{itemize}
    \item For $(-1, 1)$: $(-1)^2 + 1^2 = 1 + 1 = 2$. And $-1 + 1 + 2 = 2$. The equation holds.
    \item For $(-1, 0)$: $(-1)^2 + 0^2 = 1 + 0 = 1$. And $-1 + 0 + 2 = 1$. The equation holds.
    \item For $(0, -1)$: $0^2 + (-1)^2 = 0 + 1 = 1$. And $0 + (-1) + 2 = 1$. The equation holds.
    \item For $(0, 2)$: $0^2 + 2^2 = 0 + 4 = 4$. And $0 + 2 + 2 = 4$. The equation holds.
    \item For $(1, -1)$: $1^2 + (-1)^2 = 1 + 1 = 2$. And $1 + (-1) + 2 = 2$. The equation holds.
    \item For $(1, 2)$: $1^2 + 2^2 = 1 + 4 = 5$. And $1 + 2 + 2 = 5$. The equation holds.
    \item For $(2, 1)$: $2^2 + 1^2 = 4 + 1 = 5$. And $2 + 1 + 2 = 5$. The equation holds.
    \item For $(2, 0)$: $2^2 + 0^2 = 4 + 0 = 4$. And $2 + 0 + 2 = 4$. The equation holds.
\end{itemize}
In every case, the equation $x^2 + y^2 = x + y + 2$ is satisfied.

Since both implications have been proven, the biconditional is true.
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_160847 (x y : ‚Ñ§) : x^2 + y^2 = x + y + 2 ‚Üî
    (x = -1 ‚àß y = 1) ‚à® (x = -1 ‚àß y = 0) ‚à® (x = 0 ‚àß y = -1) ‚à®
    (x = 0 ‚àß y = 2) ‚à® (x = 1 ‚àß y = -1) ‚à® (x = 1 ‚àß y = 2) ‚à®
    (x = 2 ‚àß y = 1) ‚à® (x = 2 ‚àß y = 0) := by

  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Assume the equation holds; deduce the possible values for x and y
    intro h
    have h1 : x ‚â§ 2 := by 
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 2), sq_nonneg (y - 2), sq_nonneg (x + 1), sq_nonneg (y + 1)]
    have h2 : y ‚â§ 2 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 2), sq_nonneg (y - 2), sq_nonneg (x + 1), sq_nonneg (y + 1)]
    have h3 : x ‚â• -1 := by 
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 2), sq_nonneg (y - 2), sq_nonneg (x + 1), sq_nonneg (y + 1)]
    have h4 : y ‚â• -1 := by 
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 2), sq_nonneg (y - 2), sq_nonneg (x + 1), sq_nonneg (y + 1)]
    
    interval_cases x <;> interval_cases y
      <;> omega

  ¬∑ -- Show that each of the listed solutions satisfies the equation
    rintro (h | h | h | h | h | h | h | h)
    ¬∑ -- Case (-1, 1)
      rcases h with ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü©
      norm_num
    ¬∑ -- Case (-1, 0)
      rcases h with ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü©
      norm_num
    ¬∑ -- Case (0, -1)
      rcases h with ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü©
      norm_num
    ¬∑ -- Case (0, 2)
      rcases h with ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü©
      norm_num
    ¬∑ -- Case (1, -1)
      rcases h with ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü©
      norm_num
    ¬∑ -- Case (1, 2)
      rcases h with ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü©
      norm_num
    ¬∑ -- Case (2, 1)
      rcases h with ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü©
      norm_num
    ¬∑ -- Case (2, 0)
      rcases h with ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü©
      norm_num

informal_statement:
Prove that there exists a function $f: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}$ satisfying the following conditions:
1. $f(1) = 2$
2. $f(f(n)) = f(n) + n$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$
3. $f(n+1) > f(n)$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Prove that there exists a function $f: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}$ satisfying the following conditions:
1. $f(1) = 2$
2. $f(f(n)) = f(n) + n$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$
3. $f(n+1) > f(n)$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$ -/
theorem number_theory_1007 :
    ‚àÉ f : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï, f 1 = 2 ‚àß ‚àÄ n, f (f n) = f n + n ‚àß ‚àÄ n, f (n + 1) > f n := by

soln_description:
2. a) Let's represent the solutions using material points. For this, we will take a segment $AB$ of one unit length (Fig. 172). Let point $A$ represent pure water

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_21_27f86caa754616304e40g-216.jpg?height=89&width=979&top_left_y=1446&top_left_x=119)
[Boda] (cimupm.)

Fig. 172.

$(100\%$ water), and $B$‚Äîpure alcohol ( $100\%$ alcohol). The first solution will then be represented by the material point $K_{1} \equiv\left(K_{1}, 400\right)$, where $A K_{1}=0.3$ (the mark "30" next to point $K_{1}$ indicates that $A K_{1}$ contains 30 parts out of 100). The second solution will be represented by the material point $K_{2} \equiv\left(K_{2}, 600\right)$. The combination of these two solutions will be the solution $K \equiv(K, 1000)$, where $K \equiv Z\left[K_{1}, K_{2}\right]$. According to the lever rule,

$$
\frac{K_{1} K}{K K_{2}}=\frac{600}{400}=\frac{3}{2}
$$

Let $A K=x$. Then we get: $\frac{x-0.3}{0.8-x}=\frac{3}{2}$, from which $x=0.6$. Therefore, the concentration of alcohol in the solution $(1000)$ is $60\%$. The same result could have been obtained from the relation

$$
\operatorname{Mom}_{A} K \equiv \operatorname{Mom}_{A} K_{1}+\text{Mom}_{A} \boldsymbol{K}_{2},
$$

i.e., $1000 \cdot x=400 \cdot 0.3+600 \cdot 0.8$. The problem can also be solved purely graphically.
informal_statement:
2. There are two solutions of wine spirit in water ${ }^{1}$ ): The first solution weighs 4002 and contains $30 \%$ spirit, the second solution weighs 6002 and contains $80 \%$ spirit.

From these two solutions, one solution is made. What percentage of spirit will it contain? (O. 117, U. 126, P. 215.$)$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. There are two solutions of wine spirit in water ${ }^{1}$ ): The first solution weighs 4002 and contains $30 \%$ spirit, the second solution weighs 6002 and contains $80 \%$ spirit.

From these two solutions, one solution is made. What percentage of spirit will it contain? (O. 117, U. 126, P. 215.$)$ -/
theorem algebra_258697 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : x > 0) (h : 4002 * 0.3 + 6002 * 0.8 = x * (4002 + 6002)) :
    x = 0.6 := by

informal_statement: There is an escalator moving upwards. $A$ walks down from its top to the bottom, counting a total of $150$ steps. $B$ walks up from the bottom to the top, counting a total of $75$ steps. Assuming $A$'s speed (number of steps walked per unit time) is $3$ times that of $B$, the number of steps visible on the escalator at any moment is¬†___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___¬†steps. (Assume this number is a constant)
informal_proof:
Let $a$ and $b$ be two natural numbers such that $a \neq 0$ and $b \neq 0$.
We are given the equation $75a = 150b$.

From this given equation, we can derive a relationship between $a$ and $b$. Dividing both sides by $75$, we obtain:
$$a = \frac{150b}{75}$$
$$a = 2b$$

Our goal is to prove that $a \cdot 45 = b \cdot 90$.
We can start with the left side of the equation we want to prove, $a \cdot 45$.
Substituting the relation $a = 2b$ that we derived:
$$a \cdot 45 = (2b) \cdot 45$$
Using the associative and commutative properties of multiplication, we can rearrange the terms:
$$(2b) \cdot 45 = 2 \cdot 45 \cdot b = 90b$$
Since multiplication is commutative, $90b$ is equal to $b \cdot 90$.
Thus, we have shown that $a \cdot 45 = b \cdot 90$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- There is an escalator moving upwards. $A$ walks down from its top to the bottom, counting a total of $150$ steps. $B$ walks up from the bottom to the top, counting a total of $75$ steps. Assuming $A$'s speed (number of steps walked per unit time) is $3$ times that of $B$, the number of steps visible on the escalator at any moment is¬†___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___¬†steps. (Assume this number is a constant) -/
theorem algebra_4716 {a b : ‚Ñï} (ha : a ‚â† 0) (hb : b ‚â† 0)
    (h1 : a * 75 = b * 150) : a * 45 = b * 90 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_4716 {a b : ‚Ñï} (ha : a ‚â† 0) (hb : b ‚â† 0)
    (h1 : a * 75 = b * 150) : a * 45 = b * 90 := by
  have h2 : a = 2 * b := by
    omega
  calc 
    a * 45 = (2 * b) * 45 := by rw [h2]
    _ = 90 * b := by ring
    _ = b * 90 := by ring

soln_description:
1. We start with the sequence defined by \( x_n = 2013 + 317n \). We need to show that this sequence contains infinitely many numbers whose decimal expansions are palindromes.

2. Notice that \( 2013 \equiv 111 \pmod{317} \). This means that \( 2013 = 317 \cdot 6 + 111 \). Therefore, we can rewrite the sequence as:
   \[
   x_n = 2013 + 317n = 111 + 317(6 + n)
   \]
   For simplicity, we can redefine \( n \) to absorb the constant term, so we consider the sequence \( y_n = 111 + 317n \).

3. We need to show that there are infinitely many palindromes in the sequence \( y_n = 111 + 317n \).

4. Consider the product \( 317 \cdot 347 = 109999 \). This product is close to a number with repeating digits, which is useful for constructing palindromes.

5. We can construct a palindrome by adding \( 111 \) to multiples of \( 109999 \). For example:
   \[
   10999900 + 111 = 11000011
   \]
   This number \( 11000011 \) is a palindrome and is in the sequence \( y_n \) because:
   \[
   11000011 = 111 + 317 \cdot 34700
   \]

6. We can continue this process to generate more palindromes. For instance:
   \[
   1099990000000 + 111 = 1100001000011
   \]
   This number \( 1100001000011 \) is also a palindrome and is in the sequence \( y_n \) because:
   \[
   1100001000011 = 111 + 317 \cdot 3470000000
   \]

7. By induction, we can see that we can always construct a new palindrome by adding \( 111 \) to a multiple of \( 109999 \) with additional zeros in between. This process can be repeated indefinitely, ensuring that there are infinitely many palindromes in the sequence \( y_n \).

8. Therefore, the sequence \( x_n = 2013 + 317n \) contains infinitely many numbers with their decimal expansions being palindromes.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
Palindrome is a sequence of digits which doesn't change if we reverse the order of its digits. Prove that a sequence $(x_n)^{\infty}_{n=0}$ defined as

                                     $x_n=2013+317n$

contains infinitely many numbers with their decimal expansions being palindromes.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Palindrome is a sequence of digits which doesn't change if we reverse the order of its digits. Prove that a sequence $(x_n)^{\infty}_{n=0}$ defined as

                                     $x_n=2013+317n$

contains infinitely many numbers with their decimal expansions being palindromes. -/
theorem number_theory_76202 (x : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï) (hx : ‚àÄ n, x n = 2013 + 317 * n) :
    Set.Infinite {n | ‚àÉ k, x n = k ‚àß Nat.digits 10 k = List.reverse (Nat.digits 10 k)} := by

soln_description:
1. Given that \(a\) and \(b\) are positive numbers, and \(a, A_1, A_2, b\) form an arithmetic progression, we can express these terms as:
   \[
   a = x - 3d, \quad A_1 = x - d, \quad A_2 = x + d, \quad b = x + 3d
   \]
   where \(x\) is the midpoint of the progression and \(d\) is the common difference.

2. Given that \(a, G_1, G_2, b\) form a geometric progression, we can express these terms as:
   \[
   a = \frac{y}{q^3}, \quad G_1 = \frac{y}{q}, \quad G_2 = yq, \quad b = yq^3
   \]
   where \(y\) is the geometric mean and \(q\) is the common ratio.

3. We need to show that:
   \[
   A_1 A_2 \ge G_1 G_2
   \]

4. Substituting the expressions for \(A_1\) and \(A_2\) from the arithmetic progression, we get:
   \[
   A_1 A_2 = (x - d)(x + d) = x^2 - d^2
   \]

5. Substituting the expressions for \(G_1\) and \(G_2\) from the geometric progression, we get:
   \[
   G_1 G_2 = \left(\frac{y}{q}\right)(yq) = y^2
   \]

6. Therefore, we need to prove that:
   \[
   x^2 - d^2 \ge y^2
   \]

7. From the given conditions, we know:
   \[
   x - 3d = \frac{y}{q^3} \quad \text{and} \quad x + 3d = yq^3
   \]

8. Multiplying these two equations, we get:
   \[
   (x - 3d)(x + 3d) = \left(\frac{y}{q^3}\right)(yq^3)
   \]
   Simplifying, we obtain:
   \[
   x^2 - 9d^2 = y^2
   \]

9. Substituting \(y^2 = x^2 - 9d^2\) into the inequality \(x^2 - d^2 \ge y^2\), we get:
   \[
   x^2 - d^2 \ge x^2 - 9d^2
   \]

10. Simplifying the inequality, we obtain:
    \[
    x^2 - d^2 \ge x^2 - 9d^2 \implies -d^2 \ge -9d^2 \implies 8d^2 \ge 0
    \]

11. Since \(d^2 \ge 0\) for any real number \(d\), it follows that \(8d^2 \ge 0\) is always true.

Therefore, we have shown that \(A_1 A_2 \ge G_1 G_2\).

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
Given: (i) $a$, $b > 0$; (ii) $a$, $A_1$, $A_2$, $b$ is an arithmetic progression; (iii) $a$, $G_1$, $G_2$, $b$ is a geometric progression.  Show that
\[A_1 A_2 \ge G_1 G_2.\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Given: (i) $a$, $b > 0$; (ii) $a$, $A_1$, $A_2$, $b$ is an arithmetic progression; (iii) $a$, $G_1$, $G_2$, $b$ is a geometric progression.  Show that
\[A_1 A_2 \ge G_1 G_2.\] -/
theorem inequalities_52668 {a b : ‚Ñù} (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b)
    (A : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hA : ‚àÉ d, A 0 = a ‚àß A 1 = A 0 + d ‚àß A 2 = A 1 + d ‚àß A 3 = b)
    (G : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hG : ‚àÉ r, G 0 = a ‚àß G 1 = G 0 * r ‚àß G 2 = G 1 * r ‚àß G 3 = b) :
    A 1 * A 2 ‚â• G 1 * G 2 := by

soln_description:
Answer: 8.8%.

The effective interest rate implies the capitalization of interest, that is, adding it to the deposit amount. Let's say Petya deposited X rubles into the described deposit, then by the end of the year, he will have

$X *(1+0.1 / 4) *(1+0.08 / 4) *(1+0.08 / 4) *(1+0.08 / 4) \approx X * 1.0877$.

That is, the effective interest rate is approximately $8.8 \%$.
informal_statement:
6. Petya saw a bank advertisement: "Deposit 'Super-Income' - up to $10 \%$ annually!". He became interested in this offer and found it on the bank's website. The conditions turned out to be slightly different, as reflected in the table.

| Interest period | from 1 to 3 months | from 4 to 6 months | from 7 to 9 months | from 10 to 12 months |
| :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: |
| Rate | $10 \%$ | $8 \%$ | $8 \%$ | $8 \%$ |

*     - interest is credited at the end of the period.

What is the actual effective annual interest rate of this deposit? Round your answer to the tenths.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6. Petya saw a bank advertisement: "Deposit 'Super-Income' - up to $10 \%$ annually!". He became interested in this offer and found it on the bank's website. The conditions turned out to be slightly different, as reflected in the table.

| Interest period | from 1 to 3 months | from 4 to 6 months | from 7 to 9 months | from 10 to 12 months |
| :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: |
| Rate | $10 \%$ | $8 \%$ | $8 \%$ | $8 \%$ |

*     - interest is credited at the end of the period.

What is the actual effective annual interest rate of this deposit? Round your answer to the tenths. -/
theorem algebra_282165 (P : ‚Ñù) (hP : P > 0) (r : ‚Ñù) (hr : r > 0)
    (h : P * 1.1 + P * 1.08 + P * 1.08 + P * 1.08 = P * (1 + r / 100)) :
    r = 8.8 := by

soln_description:
6. 957
6. Note that $\frac{m+4}{m^{2}+7}$ is in lowest term if and only of $\frac{m^{2}+7}{m+4}$ is in lowest term. Since
$$
\frac{m^{2}+7}{m+4}=\frac{m^{2}-16}{m+4}+\frac{23}{m+4}=m-4+\frac{23}{m+4},
$$
the fraction is in lowest term except when $m+4$ is a multiple of 23 . Since $m$ may be equal to $1,2, \ldots, 1000$, we shall count the number of multiples of 23 from 5 to 1004 . The first one is $23=23 \times 1$ and the last one is $989=23 \times 43$. Hence there are 43 such multiples. It follows that the answer is $1000-43=957$.
informal_statement:
6. If $m$ is a positive integer not exceeding 1000 and the fraction $\frac{m+4}{m^{2}+7}$ is in its lowest term, how many possible values of $m$ are there?
(1 mark)
Ëã• $m$ ÊòØ‰∏çË∂ÖÈÅé 1000 ÁöÑÊ≠£Êï¥Êï∏, ‰∏î $\frac{m+4}{m^{2}+7}$ ÊòØÊúÄÁ∞°ÂàÜÊï∏, Âïè $m$ ÊúâÂ§öÂ∞ëÂÄãÂèØËÉΩÂÄºÔºü
informal_proof:
We are asked to find the number of positive integers $m$ such that $m \leq 1000$ and $m+4$ and $m^2+7$ are coprime.

Two integers are coprime if their greatest common divisor (GCD) is 1. We need to find the number of $m \in \{1, 2, \ldots, 1000\}$ such that $\text{gcd}(m+4, m^2+7) = 1$.

We can use the property of the GCD that $\text{gcd}(a, b) = \text{gcd}(a, b - k \cdot a)$ for any integer $k$. Let $a = m+4$ and $b = m^2+7$. We want to simplify $\text{gcd}(m+4, m^2+7)$.

Consider the expression $m^2+7$. We can rewrite it in terms of $m+4$:
$m^2+7 = (m^2 - 16) + 16 + 7 = (m-4)(m+4) + 23$.

Using the GCD property, we have:
$\text{gcd}(m+4, m^2+7) = \text{gcd}(m+4, (m-4)(m+4) + 23)$.
Since $(m-4)(m+4)$ is a multiple of $m+4$, we can subtract it:
$\text{gcd}(m+4, m^2+7) = \text{gcd}(m+4, 23)$.

For $m+4$ and $m^2+7$ to be coprime, their GCD must be 1. Therefore, we require $\text{gcd}(m+4, 23) = 1$.
Since 23 is a prime number, $\text{gcd}(m+4, 23) = 1$ if and only if $m+4$ is not divisible by 23.

So, we need to count the number of integers $m$ in the range $[1, 1000]$ such that $m+4$ is not a multiple of 23.
It is easier to count the complement: the number of $m$ in $[1, 1000]$ such that $m+4$ *is* a multiple of 23.

Let $m+4 = 23k$ for some integer $k$.
This means $m = 23k - 4$.

Now we need to find the range of $k$ such that $m$ is within $[1, 1000]$:
$1 \leq m \leq 1000$
$1 \leq 23k - 4 \leq 1000$

Add 4 to all parts of the inequality:
$1+4 \leq 23k \leq 1000+4$
$5 \leq 23k \leq 1004$

Divide by 23:
$\frac{5}{23} \leq k \leq \frac{1004}{23}$

Calculating the approximate values:
$0.217... \leq k \leq 43.65...$

Since $k$ must be an integer, the possible values for $k$ are $1, 2, \ldots, 43$.
The number of such integer values for $k$ is $43 - 1 + 1 = 43$.

These 43 values of $k$ correspond to 43 values of $m$ in the range $[1, 1000]$ for which $m+4$ is a multiple of 23, meaning $m+4$ and $m^2+7$ are *not* coprime.

The total number of possible values for $m$ is 1000 (from 1 to 1000).
The number of values of $m$ for which the condition fails is 43.
Therefore, the number of values of $m$ for which the condition holds is $1000 - 43 = 957$.

Thus, there are 957 possible values of $m$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6. If $m$ is a positive integer not exceeding 1000 and the fraction $\frac{m+4}{m^{2}+7}$ is in its lowest term, how many possible values of $m$ are there?
(1 mark)
Ëã• $m$ ÊòØ‰∏çË∂ÖÈÅé 1000 ÁöÑÊ≠£Êï¥Êï∏, ‰∏î $\frac{m+4}{m^{2}+7}$ ÊòØÊúÄÁ∞°ÂàÜÊï∏, Âïè $m$ ÊúâÂ§öÂ∞ëÂÄãÂèØËÉΩÂÄºÔºü -/
theorem number_theory_205029 :
    Set.ncard {m : ‚Ñï | 0 < m ‚àß m ‚â§ 1000 ‚àß Nat.Coprime (m + 4) (m ^ 2 + 7)} = 957 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_205029 :
    Set.ncard {m : ‚Ñï | 0 < m ‚àß m ‚â§ 1000 ‚àß Nat.Coprime (m + 4) (m ^ 2 + 7)} = 957 := by
  have h1 : {m : ‚Ñï | 0 < m ‚àß m ‚â§ 1000 ‚àß Nat.Coprime (m + 4) (m ^ 2 + 7)} = Finset.filter (fun m => 0 < m ‚àß m ‚â§ 1000 ‚àß Nat.Coprime (m + 4) (m ^ 2 + 7)) (Finset.Icc 0 1000) := by 
    ext m
    simp 
    <;> omega 
  rw [h1]
  rw [Set.ncard_coe_Finset]
  native_decide

soln_description:
7. 2 .

Let the parametric equation of line $l$ be
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=a+t \cos \alpha, \\
y=t \sin \alpha,
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $t$ is the parameter, $\alpha$ is the inclination angle, and $\alpha \in(0, \pi)$.
Substituting into the parabola equation yields
$$
t^{2} \sin ^{2} \alpha-4 t \cos \alpha-4 a=0 \text {. }
$$

Let the two roots of this equation be $t_{1}$ and $t_{2}$. Then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
t_{1}+t_{2}=\frac{4 \cos \alpha}{\sin ^{2} \alpha}, t_{1} t_{2}=-\frac{4 a}{\sin ^{2} \alpha} . \\
\text { Hence } \frac{1}{|P M|^{2}}+\frac{1}{|Q M|^{2}}=\frac{1}{t_{1}^{2}}+\frac{1}{t_{2}^{2}} \\
=\frac{t_{1}^{2}+t_{2}^{2}}{\left(t_{1} t_{2}\right)^{2}}=\left(\frac{t_{1}+t_{2}}{t_{1} t_{2}}\right)^{2}-\frac{2}{t_{1} t_{2}} \\
=\frac{2 \cos ^{2} \alpha+a \sin ^{2} \alpha}{2 a^{2}} \text { (constant). }
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, $a=2$.
informal_statement: 7. Let the line $l$ passing through the fixed point $M(a, 0)$ intersect the parabola $y^{2}=4 x$ at points $P$ and $Q$. If $\frac{1}{|P M|^{2}}+\frac{1}{|Q M|^{2}}$ is a constant, then the value of $a$ is $\qquad$ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7. Let the line $l$ passing through the fixed point $M(a, 0)$ intersect the parabola $y^{2}=4 x$ at points $P$ and $Q$. If $\frac{1}{|P M|^{2}}+\frac{1}{|Q M|^{2}}$ is a constant, then the value of $a$ is $\qquad$ . -/
theorem algebra_323008 (a : ‚Ñù) (P Q M : ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù)
    (hP : P.2^2 = 4 * P.1) (hQ : Q.2^2 = 4 * Q.1)
    (hM : M = (a, 0)) (h : 1 / (dist P M)^2 + 1 / (dist Q M)^2 = 1 / 4) :
    a = 2 := by

soln_description:
Answer: 63, 106, 228, 291, or 673.

Solution. Suppose that for some $n$ there exist $n$ consecutive natural numbers $a$, $a+1, \ldots, a+(n-1)$, the sum of which is 2016. Then $n a + (n-1) n / 2 = 2016$, or, after algebraic transformations, $n(2 a + n - 1) = 4032 = 2^{6} \cdot 3^{2} \cdot 7$.

Note that $n$ and $2 a + n - 1$ have different parities. Therefore, if $n$ is even, then $n$ must be divisible by $2^{6} = 64$, hence $n \geq 64, 2 a + n - 1 \leq 4032 / 64 = 63$, which contradicts $2 a + n - 1 > n$.

Thus, $n$ is an odd divisor of the number 4032, i.e., a divisor of the number 63. Let's check that each of them works and find the corresponding value of $a + (n-1)$. If $n=3: 2 a + 3 - 1 = 1344, a = 671$, $a + (n-1) = 673$; if $n=7: 2 a + 7 - 1 = 576, a = 285, a + (n-1) = 291$; if $n=9: 2 a + 9 - 1 = 448$, $a = 220, a + (n-1) = 228$; if $n=21: 2 a + 21 - 1 = 192, a = 86, a + (n-1) = 106$; if $n=63$: $2 a + 63 - 1 = 64, a = 1, a + (n-1) = 63$.
informal_statement: Problem 3. Several (more than one) consecutive natural numbers are written on the board, the sum of which is 2016. What can the largest of these numbers be?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Problem 3. Several (more than one) consecutive natural numbers are written on the board, the sum of which is 2016. What can the largest of these numbers be? -/
theorem number_theory_244929 (n : ‚Ñï) (h‚ÇÄ : n > 0) (h‚ÇÅ : ‚àÉ k, ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range n, (k + i) = 2016) :
    k + n - 1 ‚â§ 63 ‚à® k + n - 1 ‚â§ 106 ‚à® k + n - 1 ‚â§ 228 ‚à® k + n - 1 ‚â§ 291 ‚à® k + n - 1 ‚â§ 673 := by

Suppose the two roots $\alpha$ and $\beta$ of this equation satisfy $\left| \alpha -\beta \right|=2\sqrt{7}$. Find the maximum and minimum values of $\left| m \right|$.

Suppose the two roots $\alpha$ and $\beta$ of this equation satisfy $\left| \alpha -\beta \right|=2\sqrt{7}$. Find the maximum and minimum values of $\left| m \right|$. -/

informal_statement: Show that $\sum_{n=0}^{2013}\frac{4026!}{(n!(2013-n)!)^2}$ is a perfect square.
informal_proof:
We are asked to prove that the sum $\sum_{n=0}^{2013}\frac{4026!}{(n!(2013-n)!)^2}$ is a perfect square.

The expression $\frac{4026!}{n!(2013-n)!}$ can be recognized as the binomial coefficient $\binom{4026}{n}$, where $n$ ranges from $0$ to $2013$.
Therefore, the sum can be rewritten as:
$$ \sum_{n=0}^{2013} \left( \binom{4026}{n} \right)^2 $$

By evaluating this sum using computational methods, we find the precise numerical value of the expression. Upon evaluation, the result is confirmed to be a perfect square.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Show that $\sum_{n=0}^{2013}\frac{4026!}{(n!(2013-n)!)^2}$ is a perfect square. -/
theorem number_theory_52385 : IsSquare (‚àë n in Finset.Icc 0 2013, Nat.factorial 4026 / (Nat.factorial n * Nat.factorial (2013 - n))^2) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_52385 : IsSquare (‚àë n in Finset.Icc 0 2013, Nat.factorial 4026 / (Nat.factorial n * Nat.factorial (2013 - n))^2) := by
  native_decide

soln_description:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sqrt{1+\tan x}-\sqrt{1+\sin x}}{x^{3}}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{(\sqrt{1+\tan x}-\sqrt{1+\sin x})(\sqrt{1+\tan x}+\sqrt{1+\sin x})}{x^{3}(\sqrt{1+\tan x}+\sqrt{1+\sin x})}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1+\tan x-(1+\sin x)}{x^{3}(\sqrt{1+\tan x}+\sqrt{1+\sin x})}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\tan x-\sin x}{x^{3}(\sqrt{1+\tan x}+\sqrt{1+\sin x})}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\tan x-\frac{\sin x \cdot \cos x}{\cos x}}{x^{3}(\sqrt{1+\tan x}+\sqrt{1+\sin x})}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\tan x-\tan x \cdot \cos x}{x^{3}(\sqrt{1+\tan x}+\sqrt{1+\sin x})}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\tan x(1-\cos x)}{x^{3}(\sqrt{1+\tan x}+\sqrt{1+\sin x})}=
\end{aligned}
$$

$\tan x \sim x$, as $x \rightarrow 0$

$1-\cos x \sim \frac{x^{2}}{2}$, as $x \rightarrow 0$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x\left(\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right)}{x^{3}(\sqrt{1+\tan x}+\sqrt{1+\sin x})}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x^{3}}{2 x^{3}(\sqrt{1+\tan x}+\sqrt{1+\sin x})}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{2(\sqrt{1+\tan x}+\sqrt{1+\sin x})}=\frac{1}{2(\sqrt{1+\tan 0}+\sqrt{1+\sin 0})}= \\
& =\frac{1}{2(\sqrt{1+0}+\sqrt{1+0})}=\frac{1}{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

soln_description:
1. Let \( p \) be a prime number and \( h \) be a natural number smaller than \( p \). We set \( n = ph + 1 \).
2. We need to prove that if \( 2^{n-1} - 1 \) is divisible by \( n \), but \( 2^h - 1 \) is not divisible by \( n \), then \( n \) is a prime number.
3. Assume \( n \) is not a prime number. Then there exists a prime number \( q \) and an integer \( m \geq 1 \) such that \( q^m \mid n \) and \( q^m \nmid 2^h - 1 \).
4. Since \( q^m \mid n \), we have \( q^m \mid 2^{n-1} - 1 \). Given \( n = ph + 1 \), it follows that \( q^m \mid 2^{ph} - 1 \).
5. Let \( \mathrm{ord}_{q^m}(2^h) \) denote the order of \( 2^h \) modulo \( q^m \). Since \( q^m \mid 2^{ph} - 1 \), we have \( \mathrm{ord}_{q^m}(2^h) \mid p \).
6. Since \( q^m \nmid 2^h - 1 \), we have \( \mathrm{ord}_{q^m}(2^h) \neq 1 \). Therefore, \( \mathrm{ord}_{q^m}(2^h) = p \).
7. By definition of order, \( p \mid \phi(q^m) \), where \( \phi \) is Euler's totient function. We have \( \phi(q^m) = q^{m-1}(q-1) \).
8. Since \( p \mid q^{m-1}(q-1) \), and \( p \) is a prime, \( p \) must divide either \( q^{m-1} \) or \( q-1 \). Since \( p \neq q \) (because \( q \mid n \) and \( n \equiv 1 \pmod{p} \)), it follows that \( p \mid q-1 \). Thus, \( p < q \).
9. Given \( n = ph + 1 \) and \( h < p \), we have \( n < p^2 \). Since \( q \mid n \), \( q < p^2 \).
10. Since \( p < q \) and \( q < p^2 \), we must have \( m = 1 \) (otherwise \( q^m \) would be too large). Therefore, \( n = aq \) for some integer \( a \).
11. Since \( n = ph + 1 \), we have \( ph + 1 = aq \). Reducing modulo \( p \), we get \( 1 \equiv aq \pmod{p} \). Thus, \( a \equiv 1 \pmod{p} \), implying \( a = 1 \).
12. Therefore, \( n = q \), which means \( n \) is a prime number.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Let $p$ be a prime number and $h$ be a natural number smaller than $p$. We set $n = ph + 1$. Prove that if $2^{n-1}-1$, but not $2^h-1$, is divisible by $n$, then $n$ is a prime number.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $p$ be a prime number and $h$ be a natural number smaller than $p$. We set $n = ph + 1$. Prove that if $2^{n-1}-1$, but not $2^h-1$, is divisible by $n$, then $n$ is a prime number. -/
theorem number_theory_37433 (p h n : ‚Ñï) (hp : Nat.Prime p) (hh : h < p)
    (hn : n = p * h + 1) (h1 : n ‚à£ 2 ^ (n - 1) - 1) (h2 : ¬¨n ‚à£ 2 ^ h - 1) :
    Nat.Prime n := by

soln_description:
According to Vieta's formulas, the sum of the squares of the roots of each of the four equations, including complex roots, is $\left({ }^{18} /\right)^{2}-2 \cdot 6=8,25$. Let's find the number of real roots of each equation.

The derivative of the function $f(x)=4 x^{3}-18 x^{2}+24 x$ is $12\left(x^{2}-3 x+2\right)$ and equals zero at points $x_{1}=1$ and $x_{2}=$ 2. At these points, $f(1)=10$ and $f(2)=8$.

a) Both equations have three roots (the second equation has a multiple root $x_{2}=2$). Therefore, the sums of their squares are the same.
b) Both equations have one root, and due to the increasing nature of the function $f$ on the interval $(2,+\infty)$, the root of the second equation is greater.

## Answer

a) The same; b) the root of the second equation is greater.
informal_statement:
In which of the two equations is the sum of the squares of the roots greater

a) $4 x^{3}-18 x^{2}+24 x=8, \quad 4 x^{3}-18 x^{2}+24 x=9$

b) $4 x^{3}-18 x^{2}+24 x=11, \quad 4 x^{3}-18 x^{2}+24 x=12 ?$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- In which of the two equations is the sum of the squares of the roots greater

a) $4 x^{3}-18 x^{2}+24 x=8, \quad 4 x^{3}-18 x^{2}+24 x=9$

b) $4 x^{3}-18 x^{2}+24 x=11, \quad 4 x^{3}-18 x^{2}+24 x=12 ?$ -/
theorem algebra_167475 (f g : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (hf : f = fun x => 4 * x ^ 3 - 18 * x ^ 2 + 24 * x - 8)
    (hg : g = fun x => 4 * x ^ 3 - 18 * x ^ 2 + 24 * x - 9) :
    (‚àÉ x1 x2 : ‚Ñù, x1 ‚â† x2 ‚àß f x1 = 0 ‚àß f x2 = 0 ‚àß x1 ^ 2 + x2 ^ 2 = 16) ‚àß
    ¬¨‚àÉ x1 x2 : ‚Ñù, x1 ‚â† x2 ‚àß g x1 = 0 ‚àß g x2 = 0 ‚àß x1 ^ 2 + x2 ^ 2 = 16 := by

informal_statement: Suppose $a_i, b_i, c_i, i=1,2,\cdots ,n$, are $3n$ real numbers in the interval $\left [ 0,1 \right ].$ Define $$S=\left \{ \left ( i,j,k \right ) |\, a_i+b_j+c_k<1 \right \}, \; \; T=\left \{ \left ( i,j,k \right ) |\, a_i+b_j+c_k>2 \right \}.$$ Now we know that $\left | S \right |\ge 2018,\, \left | T \right |\ge 2018.$ Try to find the minimal possible value of $n$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset Real

/- Suppose $a_i, b_i, c_i, i=1,2,\cdots ,n$, are $3n$ real numbers in the interval $\left [ 0,1 \right ].$ Define $$S=\left \{ \left ( i,j,k \right ) |\, a_i+b_j+c_k<1 \right \}, \; \; T=\left \{ \left ( i,j,k \right ) |\, a_i+b_j+c_k>2 \right \}.$$ Now we know that $\left | S \right |\ge 2018,\, \left | T \right |\ge 2018.$ Try to find the minimal possible value of $n$.  -/
theorem inequalities_71550 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : 0 < n) (a b c : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (ha : ‚àÄ i, a i ‚àà Set.Icc 0 1) (hb : ‚àÄ i, b i ‚àà Set.Icc 0 1)
    (hc : ‚àÄ i, c i ‚àà Set.Icc 0 1) (hS : {x | ‚àÉ i j k, x = (i, j, k) ‚àß a i + b j + c k < 1}.ncard ‚â• 2018)
    (hT : {x | ‚àÉ i j k, x = (i, j, k) ‚àß a i + b j + c k > 2}.ncard ‚â• 2018) :
    n ‚â• 20 := by

soln_description:
3. (2007.03.30) Simplify: Let $s_{1}=a+b+c=3, s_{2}=bc+ca+ab, s_{3}=abc$, then
$$\begin{aligned}
\sum \frac{5-3bc}{1+a}-\sum bc= & \frac{45-7s_{2}-3s_{2}^{2}+27s_{3}}{4+s_{2}+s_{3}}-s_{1}= \\
& \frac{45-11s_{2}-4s_{2}^{2}-s_{2}s_{3}+27s_{3}}{4+s_{2}+s_{3}}
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, it suffices to prove
$$45-11s_{2}-4s_{2}^{2}-s_{2}s_{3}+27s_{3} \geqslant 0$$

Homogenizing equation (1) yields the equivalent form

Since
$$5s_{1}^{5}-11s_{1}^{3}s_{2}-36s_{1}s_{2}^{2}-27s_{2}s_{3}+81s_{1}^{2}s_{3} \geqslant 0$$

That is
$$\begin{array}{c}
\left(s_{1}^{3}-4s_{1}s_{2}+9s_{3}\right)\left(s_{1}^{2}-3s_{2}\right) \geqslant 0 \\
s_{1}^{5}-7s_{1}^{3}s_{2}+12s_{1}s_{2}^{2}-27s_{2}s_{3}+9s_{1}^{2}s_{3} \geqslant 0
\end{array}$$

Thus
The left side of equation (2) $=5\left(s_{1}^{5}-7s_{1}^{3}s_{2}+12s_{1}s_{2}^{2}-27s_{2}s_{3}+9s_{1}^{2}s_{3}\right)+$
$$24s_{2}\left(s_{1}^{3}-4s_{1}s_{2}+9s_{3}\right)+36s_{3}\left(s_{1}^{2}-3s_{2}\right) \geqslant 0$$

Therefore, the original inequality holds.

theorem inequalities_599403 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 ‚â§ a) (hb : 0 ‚â§ b) (hc : 0 ‚â§ c)

soln_description:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
(x+y+z)^{4}=\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}+2 x y+2 y z+2 z x\right)^{2} \\
\geqslant 4\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)(2 x y+2 y z+2 z x)=8\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)(x y+y z+z x) \\
=8\left[x y\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)+y z\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)+z x\left(z^{2}+x^{2}\right)+x y z(x+y+z)\right]
\end{array}
$$
$\geqslant 8\left[x y\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)+y z\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)+z x\left(z^{2}+x^{2}\right)\right]$, equality holds when 2 of $x, y, z$ are equal, and 1 is 0. Therefore, the minimum value of $\lambda$ is $\frac{1}{8}$.

    IsLeast {l | ‚àÄ x y z, 0 ‚â§ x ‚Üí 0 ‚â§ y ‚Üí 0 ‚â§ z ‚Üí f x y z ‚â§ l * (x + y + z) ^ 4} (1 / 8) := by

soln_description:
1. **Define the problem and initial assumptions:**
   We need to find all functions \( f: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N} \) such that for all positive integers \( x \) and \( y \), the expression 
   \[
   \frac{f(x+y) - f(x)}{f(y)}
   \]
   is a positive integer not exceeding \( 2022^{2022} \). Let \( C = 2022^{2022} \).

2. **Assume \( f \) is a solution and consider scaling:**
   If \( f \) is a solution, then \( Af \) for any constant \( A \) is also a solution. We can assume without loss of generality that \( \gcd(f(1), f(2), \dots) = 1 \). This implies that \( f(1) \) divides all \( f(x) \).

3. **Determine \( f(1) \):**
   Since \( f(1) \) divides all \( f(x) \), we can assume \( f(1) = 1 \). This simplifies our problem because now \( f(x) \) must be such that \( \frac{f(x+y) - f(x)}{f(y)} \leq C \).

4. **Express \( f(x+1) \) in terms of \( f(x) \):**
   Let \( f(x+1) = f(x) + g(x) \), where \( g(x) \) is a bounded function because \( \frac{g(x)}{f(1)} \leq C \). This implies \( g(x) \leq C \).

5. **Analyze the divisibility condition:**
   Swapping \( x \) and \( y \) in the original condition, we get:
   \[
   \frac{f(x+y) - f(x)}{f(y)} \quad \text{and} \quad \frac{f(x+y) - f(y)}{f(x)}
   \]
   Since \( f(x) \mid f(x+1) - f(1) = f(x+1) - 1 \), it follows that \( f(x) \mid g(x) - 1 \).

6. **Boundedness and strict monotonicity:**
   Since \( f \) is strictly increasing and \( g(x) \) is bounded, \( g(x) \) must eventually be 1. This means that for sufficiently large \( n \), \( f(n+1) = f(n) + 1 \).

7. **Inductive step:**
   Fix some \( t \). For large \( n \), we have \( f(n+t) = f(n) + t \). This implies \( t/f(t) \in \mathbb{Z} \). Given \( f(1) = 1 \) and \( f \) is increasing, by induction, \( f(n) \geq n \) for all \( n \).

8. **Conclusion:**
   Since \( f(n) \geq n \) and \( f(n) \) is strictly increasing, the only function that satisfies all conditions is \( f(n) = n \).

\(\blacksquare\)

The final answer is \( \boxed{ f(n) = n } \).
informal_statement:
Find all function $f:\mathbb{N} \longrightarrow \mathbb{N}$ such that

forall positive integers $x$ and $y$, $\frac{f(x+y)-f(x)}{f(y)}$  is again a positive integer not exceeding $2022^{2022}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find all function $f:\mathbb{N} \longrightarrow \mathbb{N}$ such that

forall positive integers $x$ and $y$, $\frac{f(x+y)-f(x)}{f(y)}$  is again a positive integer not exceeding $2022^{2022}$. -/
theorem number_theory_34160 (f : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï) :
    (‚àÄ x y, 0 < x ‚Üí 0 < y ‚Üí ‚àÉ n, 0 < n ‚àß n ‚â§ 2022^2022 ‚àß f (x + y) - f x = n * f y) ‚Üî
    ‚àÄ n, f n = n := by

    a / b + b / c + c / a := by

informal_statement:
Given $A$, $B$ and $C$ are three non-zero distinct digits and the $3$-digit numbers formed by these three digits have the following properties:

$1$. $ \overline { B B C }$ is divisible by $4$;

$2$. $ \overline { A B C } $ is a cubic number.

Find the maximum possible value of $3$-digit number $ \overline { A A B } $.

Given $A$, $B$ and $C$ are three non-zero distinct digits and the $3$-digit numbers formed by these three digits have the following properties:

$1$. $ \overline { B B C } $ can be divided by $4$;

$2$. $ \overline { A B C } $ is a cubic number.

Find the maximum possible value of the $3$-digit number $ \overline { A A B } $.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Given $A$, $B$ and $C$ are three non-zero distinct digits and the $3$-digit numbers formed by these three digits have the following properties:

$1$. $ \overline { B B C }$ is divisible by $4$;

$2$. $ \overline { A B C } $ is a cubic number.

Find the maximum possible value of $3$-digit number $ \overline { A A B } $.

Given $A$, $B$ and $C$ are three non-zero distinct digits and the $3$-digit numbers formed by these three digits have the following properties:

$1$. $ \overline { B B C } $ can be divided by $4$;

$2$. $ \overline { A B C } $ is a cubic number.

Find the maximum possible value of the $3$-digit number $ \overline { A A B } $. -/
theorem number_theory_13563 :
    IsGreatest {n | ‚àÉ A B C : ‚Ñï, A ‚â† 0 ‚àß B ‚â† 0 ‚àß C ‚â† 0 ‚àß A ‚â† B ‚àß A ‚â† C ‚àß B ‚â† C ‚àß
      4 ‚à£ (100 * B + 10 * B + C) ‚àß ‚àÉ k : ‚Ñï, k^3 = 100 * A + 10 * B + C} 551 := by

soln_description: By setting $x=y=1$ in (1), we know that $f(1)=2 f(1), f(1)=0$. By setting $y=\frac{1}{x}$, we know that $f(1)=f(x)+f\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)$, so when $x \neq 0$, we have $f(x)=-f\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)$. Therefore, $f\left(\frac{1}{64}\right)=-f(64)$. By setting $(x, y)=(2,2),(2,4),(8,8)$ in (1) successively, we know that $f(4)=2 f(2)=2$, $f(8)=f(4)+f(2)=3, f(64)=2 f(8)=6$. Therefore, $f\left(\frac{1}{64}\right)=-6$.
informal_statement:
Given
$$
f(x y)=f(x)+f(y)
$$

and $f(2)=1$. Find the value of $f\left(\frac{1}{64}\right)$.
informal_proof:
We are given that for a function $f: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$, the following properties hold:
1. $f(x y) = f(x) + f(y)$ for all $x, y \in \mathbb{R}$.
2. $f(2) = 1$.

We aim to find the value of $f(1/64)$.

First, we establish the value of $f(1)$. By setting $x=1$ and $y=1$ in the first property, we get:
$f(1 \cdot 1) = f(1) + f(1)$
$f(1) = 2 f(1)$
Subtracting $f(1)$ from both sides, we obtain $f(1) = 0$.

Next, we establish a relationship between $f(x)$ and $f(1/x)$ for non-zero $x$. We can write $1 = x \cdot (1/x)$. Applying the first property:
$f(1) = f(x \cdot (1/x))$
$f(1) = f(x) + f(1/x)$
Since we know $f(1) = 0$, this implies $0 = f(x) + f(1/x)$, which means $f(1/x) = -f(x)$.

Now we compute values of $f$ for powers of 2, starting from $f(2)=1$.
For $f(4)$:
$f(4) = f(2 \cdot 2) = f(2) + f(2) = 1 + 1 = 2$.

For $f(8)$:
$f(8) = f(4 \cdot 2) = f(4) + f(2) = 2 + 1 = 3$.

For $f(16)$:
$f(16) = f(8 \cdot 2) = f(8) + f(2) = 3 + 1 = 4$.

For $f(32)$:
$f(32) = f(16 \cdot 2) = f(16) + f(2) = 4 + 1 = 5$.

For $f(64)$:
$f(64) = f(32 \cdot 2) = f(32) + f(2) = 5 + 1 = 6$.

Finally, we can determine $f(1/64)$ using the relationship $f(1/x) = -f(x)$. Substituting $x=64$:
$f(1/64) = -f(64)$
Since $f(64) = 6$, we have:
$f(1/64) = -6$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Given
$$
f(x y)=f(x)+f(y)
$$

and $f(2)=1$. Find the value of $f\left(\frac{1}{64}\right)$. -/
theorem algebra_239962 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (h : ‚àÄ x y, f (x * y) = f x + f y) (h' : f 2 = 1) :
    f (1 / 64) = -6 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_239962 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (h : ‚àÄ x y, f (x * y) = f x + f y) (h' : f 2 = 1) :
    f (1 / 64) = -6 := by 
  have f4 : f 4 = 2 := by 
    have h1 := h 2 2
    norm_num at h1
    linarith [h']
  have f8 : f 8 = 3 := by 
    have h1 := h 2 4
    norm_num at h1
    linarith [h', f4]
  have f16 : f 16 = 4 := by 
    have h1 := h 2 8
    norm_num at h1
    linarith [h', f8]
  have f32 : f 32 = 5 := by 
    have h1 := h 2 16
    norm_num at h1
    linarith [h', f16]
  have f64 : f 64 = 6 := by 
    have h1 := h 2 32
    norm_num at h1
    linarith [h', f32]
  have f1 : f 1 = 0 := by 
    have h1 := h 1 1
    norm_num at h1
    linarith
  have h1 := h (1 / 64 : ‚Ñù) 64
  have eq1 : (1 / 64 : ‚Ñù) * (64 : ‚Ñù) = 1 := by norm_num
  rw [eq1] at h1
  linarith [f1, f64, h1]

soln_description:
## Solution

$$
\int \frac{x^{3}+6 x^{2}+11 x+7}{(x+1)(x+2)^{3}} d x=
$$

Decompose the proper rational fraction into partial fractions using the method of undetermined coefficients:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{x^{3}+6 x^{2}+11 x+7}{(x+1)(x+2)^{3}}=\frac{A}{x+1}+\frac{B_{1}}{x+2}+\frac{B_{2}}{(x+2)^{2}}+\frac{B_{3}}{(x+2)^{3}}= \\
& =\frac{A(x+2)^{3}+B_{1}(x+1)(x+2)^{2}+B_{2}(x+1)(x+2)+B_{3}(x+1)}{(x+1)(x+2)^{3}}= \\
& =\frac{A\left(x^{3}+6 x^{2}+12 x+8\right)+B_{1}\left(x^{3}+5 x^{2}+8 x+4\right)+B_{2}\left(x^{2}+3 x+2\right)+B_{3}(x+}{(x+1)(x+2)^{3}} \\
& =\frac{\left(A+B_{1}\right) x^{3}+\left(6 A+5 B_{1}+B_{2}\right) x^{2}+\left(12 A+8 B_{1}+3 B_{2}+B_{3}\right) x+\left(8 A+4 B_{1}+\right.}{(x+1)(x+2)^{3}} \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
A+B_{1}=1 \\
6 A+5 B_{1}+B_{2}=6 \\
12 A+8 B_{1}+3 B_{2}+B_{3}=11 \\
8 A+4 B_{1}+2 B_{2}+B_{3}=7
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Subtract the fourth equation from the third:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
A+B_{1}=1 \\
6 A+5 B_{1}+B_{2}=6 \\
4 A+4 B_{1}+B_{2}=4 \\
8 A+4 B_{1}+2 B_{2}+B_{3}=7
\end{array}\right.
$$

Add the first equation multiplied by -4 to the third equation:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
A+B_{1}=1 \\
6 A+5 B_{1}+B_{2}=6 \\
B_{2}=0 \\
8 A+4 B_{1}+2 B_{2}+B_{3}=7
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
A+B_{1}=1 \\
6 A+5 B_{1}=6 \\
B_{2}=0 \\
8 A+4 B_{1}+B_{3}=7
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Add the first equation multiplied by -5 to the second equation:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
A+B_{1}=1 \\
A=1 \\
B_{2}=0 \\
8 A+4 B_{1}+B_{3}=7
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
B_{1}=0 \\
A=1 \\
B_{2}=0 \\
B_{3}=-1
\end{array}\right. \\
& \frac{x^{3}+6 x^{2}+11 x+7}{(x+1)(x+2)^{3}}=\frac{1}{x+1}-\frac{1}{(x+2)^{3}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then:

$$
\int \frac{x^{3}+6 x^{2}+11 x+7}{(x+1)(x+2)^{3}} d x=\int\left(\frac{1}{x+1}-\frac{1}{(x+2)^{3}}\right) d x=\ln |x+1|+\frac{1}{2(x+2)^{2}}+C
$$

Source ‚Äî ¬´http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ \%D0\%9A\%D1\%83\%D0\%B7\%D0\%BD\%D0\%B5\%D1\%86\%D0\%BE\%D0\%B2_\%D0\%98\%D0\%BD\%D1\%82 $\% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 5 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 3 \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 80 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 0 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{BB} \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 8 \mathrm{~B} 6-6$ ¬ª

informal_statement:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the indefinite integral:

$$
\int \frac{x^{3}+6 x^{2}+11 x+7}{(x+1)(x+2)^{3}} d x
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Problem Statement

Calculate the indefinite integral:

$$
\int \frac{x^{3}+6 x^{2}+11 x+7}{(x+1)(x+2)^{3}} d x
$$ -/
theorem calculus_132490 : ‚à´ x, (x^3 + 6 * x^2 + 11 * x + 7) / ((x + 1) * (x + 2)^3) =
    Real.log (abs (x + 1)) + 1 / (2 * (x + 2)^2) + C := by

soln_description:
Suppose it does not hold, then there exists a positive integer $N$, such that when $n \geq N$, $\varphi\left(a^{n}-1\right)=b^{m}-b^{t}$ has positive integer solutions $(m, t)$.
Let $c=a^{N}$. Then for any $n \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}$,
$$
\varphi\left(c^{n}-1\right)=b^{m}-b^{t}
$$

has positive integer solutions $(m, t)$.
Take an odd prime $p$, such that $(p, b)=(p, c)=1$. Consider
$$
\begin{array}{l}
c^{2^{n} p}-1 \\
=\left(c^{p}-1\right)\left(c^{p}+1\right)\left(c^{2 p}+1\right) \cdots\left(c^{2^{n-1} p}+1\right) .
\end{array}
$$

Note that the greatest common divisor of any two factors on the right side of the above equation is 1 (if $c$ is even) or 2 (if $c$ is odd). Hence $\varphi\left(c^{2^{n} p}-1\right)=M$ or $2^{n} M$, (1)
where, $M=\varphi\left(c^{p}-1\right) \varphi\left(c^{p}+1\right) \cdots \varphi\left(c^{2^{n-1} p}+1\right)$.
Let $A_{k}=c^{2^{k}} p+1(0 \leq k \leq n-1)$.
Then $\left(c, A_{k}\right)=1$.
Hence
$$
\begin{array}{l}
c^{\varphi\left(A_{k}\right)} \equiv 1\left(\bmod A_{k}\right) \\
c^{2^{k} p} \equiv-1\left(\bmod A_{k}\right) \\
c^{2^{k+1} p} \equiv 1\left(\bmod A_{k}\right)
\end{array}
$$

Let the order of $c$ modulo $A_{k}$ be $\delta_{k}$. Then
$$ \delta_k \mid \left( \varphi\left(A_k\right), 2^{k+1} p \right), \text{ and } \delta_k \nmid 2^k p.
$$
Hence $\delta_{k}=2^{k+1}$ or $\delta_{k}=2^{k+1} p$.
By $0\varphi\left(c^{2^{n} p}-1\right) \geq b^{s}-1 \geq b^{p^{n-1}}-1,
\end{array}
$$

where, $c^{p}$ and $b$ are given constants, $l$ is a fixed value.
And when $n$ is sufficiently large, $2^{n} \ll p^{n-l}$, hence the right side of equation (2) is greater than the left side, a contradiction.
Therefore, the proposition is proved.
informal_statement: For any two integers $a, b$ greater than 1, prove: there exist infinitely many $n \in \mathbb{Z}^{*}$, such that $\varphi\left(a^{n}-1\right)=b^{m}-b^{t}$ does not hold for any $m, t \in \mathbb{Z}^{*}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- For any two integers $a, b$ greater than 1, prove: there exist infinitely many $n \in \mathbb{Z}^{*}$, such that $\varphi\left(a^{n}-1\right)=b^{m}-b^{t}$ does not hold for any $m, t \in \mathbb{Z}^{*}$. -/
theorem number_theory_108416 (a b : ‚Ñï) (ha : 1 < a) (hb : 1 < b) :
    ‚àÄ N, ‚àÉ n : ‚Ñï, n > N ‚àß ¬¨‚àÉ m t : ‚Ñï, 0 < m ‚àß 0 < t ‚àß
      (a ^ n - 1).totient = b ^ m - b ^ t := by

soln_description:
1.4 .

The original equation simplifies to $x(x|x|-5|x|+2)=0$. After removing the absolute value signs and discussing, we get
$$
x_{1}=0, x_{2}=\frac{5+\sqrt{17}}{2}, x_{3}=\frac{5-\sqrt{17}}{2}, x_{4}=\frac{5-\sqrt{33}}{2}
$$

as the four real roots of the original equation.
informal_statement: 1. Question: How many real roots does the equation $x^{2}|x|-5 x|x|+2 x=0$ have (where $|x|$ represents the absolute value of $x$)?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Question: How many real roots does the equation $x^{2}|x|-5 x|x|+2 x=0$ have (where $|x|$ represents the absolute value of $x$)? -/
theorem algebra_312140 : {x : ‚Ñù | x^2 * abs x - 5 * x * abs x + 2 * x = 0}.encard = 4 := by

soln_description:
Solution. Let $x_{1} \quad x_{2}$ be the solutions of the equation $x^{2}+p x+q=0$.

Assume that $\left|x_{1}\right|=\left|x_{2}\right|=1$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& |p|=\left|x_{1}+x_{2}\right| \leq\left|x_{1}\right|+\left|x_{2}\right|=2, \\
& |q|=\left|x_{1} x_{2}\right|=\left|x_{1}\right|\left|x_{2}\right|=1, \\
& \frac{p^{2}}{q}=\frac{\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)^{2}}{x_{1} x_{2}}=2+\frac{x_{1}}{x_{2}}+\frac{x_{2}}{x_{2}}=2+x_{1} \overline{x_{2}}+\overline{x_{1}} x_{2} \\
& \quad=2+2 \operatorname{Re}\left(x_{1} \overline{x_{2}}\right) \geq 2+2(-1)=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Assume that $|p| \leq 2,|q|=1$ and $\frac{p^{2}}{q}$ is a non-negative real number. Let $r$ be a complex number such that $r^{2}=q$. Then $|r|=1$. Let $k=\frac{p}{r}$. Since $\frac{p^{2}}{q}=\frac{p^{2}}{r^{2}}=k^{2}$ is a non-negative number, we get that $k$ is a real number and

$$
|k|=\left|\frac{p}{r}\right|=|p| \leq 2, k^{2} \leq 4
$$

Further,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x_{1,2}=\frac{-p \pm \sqrt{p^{2}-4 q}}{2}=\frac{-k r \pm \sqrt{k^{2} r^{2}-4 r^{2}}}{2}=\frac{-k \pm i \sqrt{4-k^{2}}}{2} r \\
& \left|x_{1}\right|=\left|x_{2}\right|=\frac{|r|}{2} \sqrt{k^{2}+\left(4-k^{2}\right)}=1
\end{aligned}
$$
informal_statement: 1. Let $p$ and $q$ be complex numbers. The solutions to the equation $x^{2} + p x + q = 0$ have a modulus equal to 1 if and only if $|p| \leq 2$, $|q| = 1$, and $\frac{p^{2}}{q}$ is a non-negative real number. Prove!
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Let $p$ and $q$ be complex numbers. The solutions to the equation $x^{2} + p x + q = 0$ have a modulus equal to 1 if and only if $|p| \leq 2$, $|q| = 1$, and $\frac{p^{2}}{q}$ is a non-negative real number. Prove! -/
theorem algebra_246999 (p q : ‚ÑÇ) :
    (‚àÄ x : ‚ÑÇ, x^2 + p * x + q = 0 ‚Üí ‚Äñx‚Äñ = 1) ‚Üî
    ‚Äñp‚Äñ ‚â§ 2 ‚àß ‚Äñq‚Äñ = 1 ‚àß ‚àÉ r : ‚Ñù, r ‚â• 0 ‚àß p^2 / q = r := by

informal_statement: Given ${{0}^{\circ }}\leqslant x\leqslant {{90}^{\circ }}$ and $\cos x=\frac{1}{6}$, find the value of $\tan x$.
informal_proof:
Let $x$ be a real number such that $x$ is in the closed interval $[0, \pi/2]$ and $\cos x = 1/6$. We want to show that $\tan x = \sqrt{35}$.

First, since $x \in [0, \pi/2]$, we know that $x$ is in the first quadrant (or on the boundary axes). In this interval, the sine function is non-negative. That is, $\sin x \ge 0$.

We will use the fundamental trigonometric identity:
$$ \sin^2 x + \cos^2 x = 1 $$
We are given that $\cos x = 1/6$. Substituting this value into the identity, we get:
$$ \sin^2 x + \left(\frac{1}{6}\right)^2 = 1 $$
Calculating the square of $1/6$:
$$ \sin^2 x + \frac{1}{36} = 1 $$
Now, we solve for $\sin^2 x$:
$$ \sin^2 x = 1 - \frac{1}{36} $$
$$ \sin^2 x = \frac{36}{36} - \frac{1}{36} $$
$$ \sin^2 x = \frac{35}{36} $$
To find $\sin x$, we take the square root of both sides. Since we established that $\sin x \ge 0$, we take the positive square root:
$$ \sin x = \sqrt{\frac{35}{36}} $$
Using the property of square roots that $\sqrt{a/b} = \sqrt{a}/\sqrt{b}$ (for $b>0$), we can simplify this to:
$$ \sin x = \frac{\sqrt{35}}{\sqrt{36}} $$
$$ \sin x = \frac{\sqrt{35}}{6} $$
Finally, we use the definition of the tangent function, which is $\tan x = \frac{\sin x}{\cos x}$. Substituting the values we have for $\sin x$ and $\cos x$:
$$ \tan x = \frac{\frac{\sqrt{35}}{6}}{\frac{1}{6}} $$
To simplify this expression, we multiply the numerator by the reciprocal of the denominator:
$$ \tan x = \frac{\sqrt{35}}{6} \times \frac{6}{1} $$
$$ \tan x = \sqrt{35} $$
Therefore, if $x \in [0, \pi/2]$ and $\cos x = 1/6$, then $\tan x = \sqrt{35}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Given ${{0}^{\circ }}\leqslant x\leqslant {{90}^{\circ }}$ and $\cos x=\frac{1}{6}$, find the value of $\tan x$. -/
theorem algebra_3233 (x : ‚Ñù) (hx : x ‚àà Set.Icc (0) (Real.pi / 2)) (h : Real.cos x = 1 / 6) :
    Real.tan x = Real.sqrt 35 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_3233 (x : ‚Ñù) (hx : x ‚àà Set.Icc (0) (Real.pi / 2)) (h : Real.cos x = 1 / 6) :
    Real.tan x = Real.sqrt 35 := by
  have hx1 : 0 ‚â§ x := hx.1
  have hx2 : x ‚â§ Real.pi / 2 := hx.2
  have h1 : Real.sin x ‚â• 0 := by 
    apply Real.sin_nonneg_of_nonneg_of_le_pi
    ¬∑ linarith [hx1]
    ¬∑ linarith [hx2, Real.pi_pos]
  have hsin2 : Real.sin x ^ 2 + Real.cos x ^ 2 = 1 := Real.sin_sq_add_cos_sq x
  rw [h] at hsin2
  have hsin2' : Real.sin x ^ 2 = 35 / 36 := by
    nlinarith
  have hsin : Real.sin x = Real.sqrt 35 / 6 := by 
    have h4 : Real.sin x = Real.sqrt (35 / 36) := by
      have h5 : Real.sqrt (Real.sin x ^ 2) = Real.sin x := by
        rw [Real.sqrt_sq]
        linarith
      have h6 : Real.sqrt (Real.sin x ^ 2) = Real.sqrt (35 / 36) := by
        rw [hsin2']
      rw [h5] at h6
      linarith
    rw [h4]
    have : Real.sqrt (35 / 36) = Real.sqrt 35 / 6 := by
      calc
        Real.sqrt (35 / 36) = Real.sqrt ((35 : ‚Ñù) / (6 ^ 2)) := by norm_num
        _ = Real.sqrt (35 : ‚Ñù) / 6 := by 
          have h7 : Real.sqrt ((35 : ‚Ñù) / (6 : ‚Ñù) ^ 2) = Real.sqrt (35 : ‚Ñù) / (6 : ‚Ñù) := by 
            have h9 : Real.sqrt ((35 : ‚Ñù) / (6 : ‚Ñù) ^ 2) = Real.sqrt (35 : ‚Ñù) / Real.sqrt ((6 : ‚Ñù) ^ 2) := by 
              field_simp [Real.sqrt_div, Real.sqrt_sq]
            have h10 : Real.sqrt ((6 : ‚Ñù) ^ 2) = (6 : ‚Ñù) := by 
              rw [Real.sqrt_sq]
              all_goals linarith
            rw [h9, h10]
          rw [show (35 / 36 : ‚Ñù) = (35 : ‚Ñù) / (6 : ‚Ñù) ^ 2 by ring] at *
          rw [h7]
          all_goals ring_nf <;> norm_num
    rw [this]
    all_goals norm_num
  rw [Real.tan_eq_sin_div_cos, hsin, h]
  field_simp
  <;> nlinarith

informal_statement: If $192x^2 -16 = 0$, find the value of $\frac{1}{x^4}$.
informal_proof:
We are given the equation $192x^2 - 16 = 0$, with the condition that $x \neq 0$. We want to determine the value of $\frac{1}{x^4}$.

First, we manipulate the given equation to find the value of $x^2$.
From $192x^2 - 16 = 0$, we add 16 to both sides to get:
$192x^2 = 16$

Next, we divide both sides by 192:
$x^2 = \frac{16}{192}$

Simplifying the fraction, we find that $\frac{16}{192} = \frac{1}{12}$. Thus, we have:
$x^2 = \frac{1}{12}$

Now, we need to find $x^4$. We can obtain $x^4$ by squaring $x^2$:
$x^4 = (x^2)^2$

Substituting the value of $x^2$ we found:
$x^4 = \left(\frac{1}{12}\right)^2$

Calculating the square:
$x^4 = \frac{1^2}{12^2} = \frac{1}{144}$

Finally, we want to find the value of $\frac{1}{x^4}$. Since we know $x^4 = \frac{1}{144}$, we can substitute this into the expression:
$\frac{1}{x^4} = \frac{1}{\frac{1}{144}}$

This simplifies to:
$\frac{1}{x^4} = 144$

Therefore, if $192x^2 - 16 = 0$ and $x \neq 0$, then $\frac{1}{x^4} = 144$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If $192x^2 -16 = 0$, find the value of $\frac{1}{x^4}$. -/
theorem algebra_21903 (x : ‚Ñù) (hx : x ‚â† 0) (h : 192 * x ^ 2 - 16 = 0) : 1 / x ^ 4 = 144 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_21903 (x : ‚Ñù) (hx : x ‚â† 0) (h : 192 * x ^ 2 - 16 = 0) : 1 / x ^ 4 = 144 := by 
  have h1 : x ^ 2 = 1 / 12 := by
    nlinarith
  have h2 : x ^ 4 = 1 / 144 := by 
    calc
      x ^ 4 = (x ^ 2) ^ 2 := by ring
      _ = (1 / 12) ^ 2 := by rw [h1]
      _ = 1 / 144 := by norm_num
  rw [h2]
  norm_num

8.4025.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Given } a_{n+1}=\frac{2 n}{n+1} a_{n}-\frac{n-1}{n+1} a_{n-1} \\
\begin{array}{l} 
\Rightarrow a_{n}-a_{n-1}=\frac{n-2}{n}\left(a_{n-1}-a_{n-2}\right) \\
=\frac{n-2}{n} \cdot \frac{n-3}{n-1}\left(a_{n-2}-a_{n-3}\right)=\cdots \\
= \frac{n-2}{n} \cdot \frac{n-3}{n-1} \cdots \cdots \frac{1}{3}\left(a_{2}-a_{1}\right) \\
= \frac{1 \times 2}{n(n-1)}=2\left(\frac{1}{n-1}-\frac{1}{n}\right) \\
\Rightarrow a_{n}=a_{1}+\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}\left(a_{k+1}-a_{k}\right) \\
=1+2\left(1-\frac{1}{n}\right)=3-\frac{2}{n} .
\end{array}
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $a_{m}>2+\frac{2011}{2012}$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\Leftrightarrow 3-\frac{2}{m}>3-\frac{1}{2012} \\
\Leftrightarrow m>4024 .
\end{array}
$$

In summary, the smallest value of $m$ that satisfies the condition is 4025.

soln_description:
1. We start with the given recurrence relation for the sequence \(a_n\):
   \[
   a_{n+1} - (k+1)a_n + a_{n-1} = 0
   \]
   with initial conditions \(a_1 = 1\) and \(a_2 = k\).

2. To solve the recurrence relation, we assume a solution of the form \(a_n = r^n\). Substituting \(a_n = r^n\) into the recurrence relation, we get:
   \[
   r^{n+1} - (k+1)r^n + r^{n-1} = 0
   \]
   Dividing through by \(r^{n-1}\), we obtain the characteristic equation:
   \[
   r^2 - (k+1)r + 1 = 0
   \]

3. Solving the characteristic equation using the quadratic formula \(r = \frac{-(k+1) \pm \sqrt{(k+1)^2 - 4}}{2}\), we get:
   \[
   r = \frac{(k+1) \pm \sqrt{(k+1)^2 - 4}}{2}
   \]
   Let \(r_1\) and \(r_2\) be the roots of the characteristic equation.

4. The general solution to the recurrence relation is:
   \[
   a_n = A r_1^n + B r_2^n
   \]
   where \(A\) and \(B\) are constants determined by the initial conditions.

5. Using the initial conditions \(a_1 = 1\) and \(a_2 = k\), we set up the following system of equations:
   \[
   A r_1 + B r_2 = 1
   \]
   \[
   A r_1^2 + B r_2^2 = k
   \]

6. Solving this system for \(A\) and \(B\), we find:
   \[
   A = \frac{k - r_2}{r_1 - r_2}, \quad B = \frac{r_1 - k}{r_1 - r_2}
   \]

7. We need to find all positive integers \(n\) such that \(a_n\) is a power of \(k\). Suppose \(a_n = k^m\) for some integer \(m\). Then:
   \[
   A r_1^n + B r_2^n = k^m
   \]

8. We know that \(r_1\) and \(r_2\) are roots of the characteristic equation and are given by:
   \[
   r_1 = \frac{(k+1) + \sqrt{(k+1)^2 - 4}}{2}, \quad r_2 = \frac{(k+1) - \sqrt{(k+1)^2 - 4}}{2}
   \]

9. Since \(r_1\) and \(r_2\) are not rational numbers (except for specific values of \(k\)), the expression \(A r_1^n + B r_2^n\) is generally not an integer, making it unlikely for \(a_n\) to be a power of \(k\) for most \(n\).

10. However, we can check small values of \(n\) to see if any satisfy the condition \(a_n = k^m\). For \(n = 1\) and \(n = 2\), we have:
    \[
    a_1 = 1 = k^0
    \]
    \[
    a_2 = k = k^1
    \]

11. For \(n > 2\), we need to check if \(a_n\) can be expressed as \(k^m\). Given the recurrence relation and the nature of the roots, it is unlikely that \(a_n\) for \(n > 2\) will be a power of \(k\).

Conclusion:
The only positive integers \(n\) such that \(a_n\) is a power of \(k\) are \(n = 1\) and \(n = 2\).

The final answer is \( \boxed{ n = 1 } \) and \(n = 2\).

Find all positive integers $n$ such that $a_n$ is a power of $k$.

informal_statement:
Consider the sequence of numbers: $4,7,1,8,9,7,6,\dots$ For $n>2$, the $n$-th term of the sequence is the units digit of the sum of the two previous terms. Let $S_n$ denote the sum of the first $n$ terms of this sequence. The smallest value of $n$ for which $S_n>10,000$ is: 
$\text{(A) }1992 \qquad \text{(B) }1999 \qquad \text{(C) }2001 \qquad \text{(D) }2002 \qquad \text{(E) }2004$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def f (n : ‚Ñï) : ‚Ñï := match n with
  | 0 => 4
  | 1 => 7
  | n + 2 => (f n + f (n + 1)) % 10

def S (n : ‚Ñï) : ‚Ñï := ‚àë i in Finset.range n, f i

/- Consider the sequence of numbers: $4,7,1,8,9,7,6,\dots$ For $n>2$, the $n$-th term of the sequence is the units digit of the sum of the two previous terms. Let $S_n$ denote the sum of the first $n$ terms of this sequence. The smallest value of $n$ for which $S_n>10,000$ is: 
$\text{(A) }1992 \qquad \text{(B) }1999 \qquad \text{(C) }2001 \qquad \text{(D) }2002 \qquad \text{(E) }2004$ -/
theorem number_theory_95417 :
    IsLeast {n | 10000 < S n} 1999 := by

soln_description:
Let $P=c(P) P_{1}$ and $Q=c(Q) Q_{1}$ with $P_{1}$ and $Q_{1}$ in $\mathbb{Z}[X]$ : then we have $c\left(P_{1}\right)=1=c\left(Q_{1}\right)$. Thus $P Q=c(P) c(Q) P_{1} Q_{1}$ : it suffices to show that $c\left(P_{1} Q_{1}\right)=1$ to have $c(P Q)=c(P) c(Q)$.

Suppose that $c\left(P_{1} Q_{1}\right) \neq 1$, then there exists a prime factor $p$ dividing all the coefficients of $P_{1} Q_{1}$. In particular, by passing to $\mathbb{Z} / p \mathbb{Z}[X], \overline{P_{1} Q_{1}}=0$, so $\overline{P_{1}}=0$ or $\overline{Q_{1}}=0$ (otherwise the product of the leading coefficients of $\overline{P_{1} Q_{1}}$ would appear in the product). This gives that $p$ divides $c\left(P_{1}\right)$ or $c\left(Q_{1}\right)$, which is contradictory. Thus we have $c\left(P_{1} Q_{1}\right)=1$, which concludes.

soln_description:
Proof: First, we homogenize it:
$$\begin{array}{r}
\frac{x^{5}-x^{2}}{x^{5}+y^{2}+z^{2}} \geqslant \frac{x^{5}-x^{2} \cdot x y z}{x^{5}+\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right) x y z} \geqslant \frac{x^{4}-x^{2} y z}{x^{4}+y z\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)} \\
\frac{x^{4}-x^{2} y z}{x^{4}+y z\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)} \geqslant \frac{2 x^{4}-x^{2}\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)}{2 x^{4}+\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)}
\end{array}$$

Let $a=x^{2}, b=y^{2}, c=z^{2}$, we need to prove
$$\begin{array}{l}
\sum \frac{2 c^{2}-a(b+c)}{2 a^{2}+(b+c)^{2}} \geqslant 0 \Leftrightarrow \\
\sum(a-b)\left(\frac{a}{2 a^{2}+(b+c)^{2}}-\frac{b}{2 b^{2}+(a+c)^{2}}\right) \geqslant 0 \Leftrightarrow \\
\sum(a-b)^{2} \frac{c^{2}+c(a+b)+a^{2}-a b+b^{2}}{\left(2 a^{2}+(b+c)^{2}\right)\left(2 b^{2}+(a+c)^{2}\right)} \geqslant 0
\end{array}$$

The above inequality clearly holds. Equality holds when $a=b=c=1$.

soln_description:
Raising to the square, we rewrite the inequality as

$S=\frac{x_{1} x_{2} \ldots x_{n}}{\left(1+x_{1}\right)^{2}\left(1+x_{1}+x_{2}\right)^{2} \ldots\left(1+x_{1}+x_{2}+\ldots+x_{n}\right)^{2}} \leq \frac{1}{(n+1)^{n+1}}$.
Let $y_{1}=\frac{x_{1}}{1+x_{1}}, \quad y_{2}=\frac{x_{2}}{\left(1+x_{1}\right)\left(1+x_{1}+x_{2}\right)}, \quad y_{3}=\frac{x_{3}}{\left(1+x_{1}+x_{2}\right)\left(1+x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}\right)}$

$y_{n}=\frac{x_{n}}{\left(1+x_{1}+x_{2}+\ldots+x_{n-1}\right)\left(1+x_{1}+x_{2}+\ldots+x_{n}\right)}, \quad y_{n+1}=\frac{1}{1+x_{1}+x_{2}+\ldots+x_{n}}$.

Then $y_{1} y_{2} \ldots y_{n+1}=S$ and

$y_{1}+\ldots+y_{n+1}=y_{1}+\ldots+y_{n-1}+\left(y_{n}+\frac{1}{1+x_{1}+\ldots+x_{n}}\right)=$

$y_{1}+\ldots+y_{n-2}+\left(y_{n-1}+\frac{1}{1+x_{1}+\ldots+x_{n-1}}\right)=\ldots=\frac{x_{1}}{1+x_{1}}+\frac{1}{1+x_{1}}=1$.

By the Cauchy inequality $S=y_{1} \ldots y_{n+1} \leq\left(\frac{y_{1}+\ldots+y_{n+1}}{n+1}\right)^{n+1}=\frac{1}{(n+1)^{n+1}}$.
