soln_description:
Solution

a) See that in line 1 the number 1 is added in each of the 8 cells, in line 20 the number 2 is also added eight times, and so on. Thus, we can account for the contribution of the rows by:

$$
\begin{aligned}
8 \cdot(1+2+3+4+5+6+7+8) & =8 \cdot 36 \\
& =288
\end{aligned}
$$

The same applies to the contribution of the columns, also totaling 288. We conclude that the sum of all the cells is $2 \cdot 288=576$.

b) This difference can also be analyzed by considering the contribution of each row and each column, but in this case, for each black cell, we must add its number, while for each white cell, we must subtract it. Since each row and each column has exactly four black cells and four white cells, the number written in a row or column must be added and subtracted 4 times, that is, it contributes $4-4=0$. Therefore, we conclude that $S_{\text {black }}-S_{\text {white }}=0$.

c) Combining the two pieces of information from items $a$) and $b$), we have

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
S_{\text {black }}+S_{\text {white }}=576 \\
S_{\text {black }}-S_{\text {white }}=0 .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Adding the two lines, we get $2 S_{\text {black }}=576$, that is, $S_{\text {black }}=288$.
informal_statement:
A chessboard has its rows and columns numbered as shown in the following figure. In each square, the number written is the sum of the numbers of the row and column of that square. For example, in the square that is in row 4 and column 5, the number $4+5=9$ is written.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_01_360f8ce7ec440aed2c7ag-20.jpg?height=445&width=446&top_left_y=563&top_left_x=702)

a) What is the sum of the numbers written in all the squares of the board?

b) Let $S_{\text {black }}$ be the sum of all the numbers written in the black squares and $S_{\text {white }}$ be the sum of all the numbers written in the white squares. What is the value of the difference $S_{\text {black }}-S_{\text {white }}$?

c) What is the value of $S_{\text {black }}$?
informal_proof:
We want to establish that the sum of numbers on the black squares of a chessboard, denoted by $S_{\text {black }}$, is equal to 288.

The number in each square is defined as the sum of its row number and column number. The problem uses 1-based indexing for rows and columns, ranging from 1 to 8.

The squares are colored black if the sum of their 0-indexed row and column coordinates, $(i+j)$, is even. The number written in a square at 0-indexed coordinates $(i, j)$ is $(i+1) + (j+1)$.

Thus, $S_{\text {black }}$ can be expressed as a double summation:
$$ S_{\text {black }} = \sum_{i=0}^{7} \sum_{j=0}^{7} \begin{cases} (i+1) + (j+1) & \text { if } (i+j) \text{ is even} \\ 0 & \text { if } (i+j) \text{ is odd} \end{cases} $$

To compute this sum, we consider the contribution of each row $i$ (from 0 to 7). For a fixed row $i$, the value $(i+1)$ is constant. We need to sum $(i+1) + (j+1)$ for all columns $j$ (from 0 to 7) such that $(i+j)$ is even.

For any given row $i$, there are exactly four columns $j$ for which $(i+j)$ is even.

Case 1: Row $i$ is even (i.e., $i \in \{0, 2, 4, 6\}$).
For $(i+j)$ to be even, the column $j$ must also be even. So, we sum over $j \in \{0, 2, 4, 6\}$.
The sum for such a row $i$ is:
$$ \sum_{j \in \{0,2,4,6\}} ((i+1) + (j+1)) = 4 \cdot (i+1) + \sum_{j \in \{0,2,4,6\}} (j+1) $$
The sum of the column contributions is $1+3+5+7 = 16$.
So, the sum for an even row $i$ is $4(i+1) + 16$.

Case 2: Row $i$ is odd (i.e., $i \in \{1, 3, 5, 7\}$).
For $(i+j)$ to be even, the column $j$ must be odd. So, we sum over $j \in \{1, 3, 5, 7\}$.
The sum for such a row $i$ is:
$$ \sum_{j \in \{1,3,5,7\}} ((i+1) + (j+1)) = 4 \cdot (i+1) + \sum_{j \in \{1,3,5,7\}} (j+1) $$
The sum of the column contributions is $2+4+6+8 = 20$.
So, the sum for an odd row $i$ is $4(i+1) + 20$.

Now, we sum these row contributions over all $i$:
For the even rows $i \in \{0, 2, 4, 6\}$ (corresponding to 1-indexed rows $\{1, 3, 5, 7\}$):
$$ \sum_{i \in \{0,2,4,6\}} (4(i+1) + 16) = (4(1)+16) + (4(3)+16) + (4(5)+16) + (4(7)+16) $$
$$ = 20 + 28 + 36 + 44 = 128 $$

For the odd rows $i \in \{1, 3, 5, 7\}$ (corresponding to 1-indexed rows $\{2, 4, 6, 8\}$):
$$ \sum_{i \in \{1,3,5,7\}} (4(i+1) + 20) = (4(2)+20) + (4(4)+20) + (4(6)+20) + (4(8)+20) $$
$$ = 28 + 36 + 44 + 52 = 160 $$

The total sum $S_{\text {black }}$ is the sum of these two contributions:
$$ S_{\text {black }} = 128 + 160 = 288 $$
Thus, we have shown that $S_{\text {black }} = 288$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- A chessboard has its rows and columns numbered as shown in the following figure. In each square, the number written is the sum of the numbers of the row and column of that square. For example, in the square that is in row 4 and column 5, the number $4+5=9$ is written.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_01_360f8ce7ec440aed2c7ag-20.jpg?height=445&width=446&top_left_y=563&top_left_x=702)

a) What is the sum of the numbers written in all the squares of the board?

b) Let $S_{\text {black }}$ be the sum of all the numbers written in the black squares and $S_{\text {white }}$ be the sum of all the numbers written in the white squares. What is the value of the difference $S_{\text {black }}-S_{\text {white }}$?

c) What is the value of $S_{\text {black }}$? -/
theorem algebra_250154 (Sblack Swhite : ‚Ñï)
    (hSblack : Sblack = ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range 8, ‚àë j ‚àà Finset.range 8,
      if (i + j) % 2 = 0 then (i + 1) + (j + 1) else 0)
    (hSwhite : Swhite = ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range 8, ‚àë j ‚àà Finset.range 8,
      if (i + j) % 2 ‚â† 0 then (i + 1) + (j + 1) else 0) :
    Sblack = 288 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_250154 (Sblack Swhite : ‚Ñï)
    (hSblack : Sblack = ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range 8, ‚àë j ‚àà Finset.range 8,
      if (i + j) % 2 = 0 then (i + 1) + (j + 1) else 0)
    (hSwhite : Swhite = ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range 8, ‚àë j ‚àà Finset.range 8,
      if (i + j) % 2 ‚â† 0 then (i + 1) + (j + 1) else 0) :
    Sblack = 288 := by 
  rw [hSblack]
  norm_num [Finset.sum_range_succ]

soln_description: 73.1. Answer. In the first store, there were 658 textbooks, in the second - 615, and in the third - 700.
informal_statement: 1. In three stores, there were 1973 textbooks. In the first three days, the first store sold respectively $1 / 47, 1 / 7$ and $1 / 2$ of its textbooks, the second store - $1 / 41, 1 / 5$ and $1 / 3$ of its textbooks, and the third store - $1 / 25, 1 / 20$ and $1 / 10$ of its textbooks. How many textbooks were in each store?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. In three stores, there were 1973 textbooks. In the first three days, the first store sold respectively $1 / 47, 1 / 7$ and $1 / 2$ of its textbooks, the second store - $1 / 41, 1 / 5$ and $1 / 3$ of its textbooks, and the third store - $1 / 25, 1 / 20$ and $1 / 10$ of its textbooks. How many textbooks were in each store? -/
theorem algebra_207706 (x y z : ‚Ñï) (h‚ÇÄ : x + y + z = 1973)
    (h‚ÇÅ : (1 / 47 : ‚Ñö) * x + (1 / 7 : ‚Ñö) * x + (1 / 2 : ‚Ñö) * x = (1 / 41 : ‚Ñö) * y + (1 / 5 : ‚Ñö) * y + (1 / 3 : ‚Ñö) * y)
    (h‚ÇÇ : (1 / 41 : ‚Ñö) * y + (1 / 5 : ‚Ñö) * y + (1 / 3 : ‚Ñö) * y = (1 / 25 : ‚Ñö) * z + (1 / 20 : ‚Ñö) * z + (1 / 10 : ‚Ñö) * z) :
    x = 658 ‚àß y = 615 ‚àß z = 700 := by

soln_description:
## Solution.

Domain of definition: $\sin z \neq 0$.

Rewrite the equation as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\frac{\cos z}{\sin z}-1\right) \cdot\left(\cos ^{2} z+2 \sin z \cos z+\sin ^{2} z\right)-\left(1+\frac{\cos z}{\sin z}\right)=0 \Leftrightarrow \\
& \Leftrightarrow \frac{(\cos z-\sin z)(\cos z+\sin z)^{2}}{\sin z}-\frac{\sin z+\cos z}{\sin z}=0 \Leftrightarrow \\
& \Leftrightarrow(\sin z+\cos z)((\cos z-\sin z)(\cos z+\sin z)-1)=0 \Leftrightarrow \\
& \Leftrightarrow(\sin z+\cos z)\left(\cos ^{2} z-\sin ^{2} z-\cos ^{2} z-\sin ^{2} z\right)=0 \Leftrightarrow \\
& \Leftrightarrow-2(\sin z+\cos z) \sin ^{2} z=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\sin z \neq 0$, then $\sin z+\cos z=0, \sin z=-\cos z, \operatorname{tg} z=-1$, $z=-\frac{\pi}{4}+\pi n=\frac{\pi}{4}(4 n-1), n \in Z$.

Answer: $z=\frac{\pi}{4}(4 n-1), n \in Z$.
informal_statement:
8.288. $(\operatorname{ctg} z-1)(1+\sin 2 z)=1+\operatorname{ctg} z$.

8.288. $(\cot z-1)(1+\sin 2z)=1+\cot z$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 8.288. $(\operatorname{ctg} z-1)(1+\sin 2 z)=1+\operatorname{ctg} z$.

8.288. $(\cot z-1)(1+\sin 2z)=1+\cot z$. -/
theorem algebra_169168 (z : ‚Ñù) :
    (1 / Real.tan z - 1) * (1 + Real.sin (2 * z)) = 1 + 1 / Real.tan z := by

informal_statement: Compute the value of the expression $(\sqrt{3755}+\sqrt{3752})(-\sqrt{3755}-\sqrt{3752})(\sqrt{3755}-\sqrt{3752})(\sqrt{3752}-\sqrt{3755})$.
informal_proof:
We are asked to compute the value of the expression $(\sqrt{3755}+\sqrt{3752})(-\sqrt{3755}-\sqrt{3752})(\sqrt{3755}-\sqrt{3752})(\sqrt{3752}-\sqrt{3755})$.
Let the expression be denoted by $E$.
We can rewrite the second term as $-(\sqrt{3755}+\sqrt{3752})$.
We can rewrite the fourth term as $-(\sqrt{3755}-\sqrt{3752})$.

Substituting these into the expression, we get:
$$ E = (\sqrt{3755}+\sqrt{3752}) \cdot [-(\sqrt{3755}+\sqrt{3752})] \cdot (\sqrt{3755}-\sqrt{3752}) \cdot [-(\sqrt{3755}-\sqrt{3752})] $$
We can group the terms:
$$ E = [(\sqrt{3755}+\sqrt{3752}) \cdot (\sqrt{3755}-\sqrt{3752})] \cdot [(-1)(\sqrt{3755}+\sqrt{3752})] \cdot [(-1)(\sqrt{3755}-\sqrt{3752})] $$
Combining the negative signs, we have $(-1) \cdot (-1) = 1$:
$$ E = [(\sqrt{3755}+\sqrt{3752}) \cdot (\sqrt{3755}-\sqrt{3752})] \cdot [(\sqrt{3755}+\sqrt{3752}) \cdot (\sqrt{3755}-\sqrt{3752})] $$
This can be written as:
$$ E = [(\sqrt{3755}+\sqrt{3752}) \cdot (\sqrt{3755}-\sqrt{3752})]^2 $$
Now, we use the difference of squares formula, $(a+b)(a-b) = a^2 - b^2$, with $a = \sqrt{3755}$ and $b = \sqrt{3752}$.
The expression inside the square becomes:
$$ (\sqrt{3755})^2 - (\sqrt{3752})^2 $$
Since $\sqrt{3755}$ and $\sqrt{3752}$ are real numbers and the values under the square root are positive, $(\sqrt{x})^2 = x$. Thus,
$$ 3755 - 3752 $$
Calculating the difference:
$$ 3 $$
Substituting this back into the expression for $E$:
$$ E = [3]^2 $$
$$ E = 9 $$
The value of the expression is 9.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Compute the value of the expression $(\sqrt{3755}+\sqrt{3752})(-\sqrt{3755}-\sqrt{3752})(\sqrt{3755}-\sqrt{3752})(\sqrt{3752}-\sqrt{3755})$. -/
theorem algebra_3010 : (Real.sqrt 3755 + Real.sqrt 3752) * (-Real.sqrt 3755 - Real.sqrt 3752) * (Real.sqrt 3755 - Real.sqrt 3752) * (Real.sqrt 3752 - Real.sqrt 3755) = 9 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_3010 : (Real.sqrt 3755 + Real.sqrt 3752) * (-Real.sqrt 3755 - Real.sqrt 3752) * (Real.sqrt 3755 - Real.sqrt 3752) * (Real.sqrt 3752 - Real.sqrt 3755) = 9 := by
  nlinarith [Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (3755 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num),
           Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (3752 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num),
           sq_nonneg (Real.sqrt 3755 - Real.sqrt 3752),
           sq_nonneg (Real.sqrt 3755 + Real.sqrt 3752),
           sq_nonneg (Real.sqrt 3752 - Real.sqrt 3755),
           sq_nonneg (Real.sqrt 3752 + Real.sqrt 3755),
           Real.sqrt_nonneg 3755, Real.sqrt_nonneg 3752,
           mul_nonneg (Real.sqrt_nonneg 3755) (Real.sqrt_nonneg 3752),
           mul_self_nonneg (Real.sqrt 3755 - Real.sqrt 3752),
           mul_self_nonneg (Real.sqrt 3752 - Real.sqrt 3755)
           ]

soln_description:
Solution:

Simplify $\frac{a x^{2}-a x-12 a+x^{2}+x+12}{a x+3 a-x-3}=\frac{a x^{2}-x^{2}+(-a x+x)+(-12 a+12)}{a(x+3)-(x+3)}=$

$=\frac{x^{2}(a-1)-x(a-1)-12(a-1)}{(x+3)(a-1)}=\frac{(a-1)\left(x^{2}-x-12\right)}{(x+3)(a-1)}=$

$=\frac{x^{2}+3 x-4 x-12}{x+3}=\frac{(x+3)(x-4)}{x+3}=x-4$

We get $\left\{\begin{array}{c}(|x-4|-a) \cdot|4 a+3 x-19|=0 \\ a \neq 1 \\ x \neq-3\end{array} ;\left\{\begin{array}{c}{\left[\begin{array}{c}|x-4|-a=0 \\ 4 a+3 x-19=0 \\ a \neq 1 \\ x \neq-3\end{array} ;\right.} \\ \text {; }\end{array}\right.\right.$

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{c}
a=|x-4| \\
a=-0.75 x+4.75 \\
\quad a \neq 1 \\
x \neq-3
\end{array}\right.
$$

Construct the graph in the coordinate system $\chi O a$ $a=-0.75 x+4.75-$ line

| $x$ | -3 | 5 |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| $y$ | 7 | 1 |

$a=|x-4|$ the graph is obtained from $a=|x|$ by shifting 4 units to the right

Since $x \neq-3$, then $a \neq 7$

$a \neq 1$, then $x \neq 3 ; x \neq 5$

Points $(-3 ; 7) ;(3 ; 1) ;(5 ; 1)$ - are excluded

For $a \in(-\infty ; 0) \cup\{7\}$ - one solution

For $a \in(0 ; 1) \cup(1 ; 7) \cup(7 ;+\infty)$ - three solutions

For $a=0$ two solutions

For $a=1$ no solutions

Answer: 7

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_06_166d4fdfa0c802c9882dg-2.jpg?height=693&width=785&top_left_y=316&top_left_x=1132)

## ‚Ññ3: Triangles.
informal_statement:

$$

$$

has one solution. In your answer, write the largest value of the parameter $a$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. Find all values of the parameter $a$ for which the equation

$$
\left(\left|\frac{a x^{2}-a x-12 a+x^{2}+x+12}{a x+3 a-x-3}\right|-a\right) \cdot|4 a-3 x-19|=0
$$

has one solution. In your answer, write the largest value of the parameter $a$ -/
theorem algebra_228959 (a : ‚Ñù) :
    (‚àÉ! x : ‚Ñù, ((|a * x ^ 2 - a * x - 12 * a + x ^ 2 + x + 12| / (a * x + 3 * a - x - 3)) - a) *
      |4 * a - 3 * x - 19| = 0) ‚Üî a ‚â§ 7 := by

soln_description:
1. We start with the given series:
   \[
   \sum_{n=2}^\infty \left( \log(n^3 + 1) - \log(n^3 - 1) \right)
   \]
   Using the properties of logarithms, we can combine the terms inside the logarithm:
   \[
   \log(n^3 + 1) - \log(n^3 - 1) = \log \left( \frac{n^3 + 1}{n^3 - 1} \right)
   \]
   Thus, the series becomes:
   \[
   \sum_{n=2}^\infty \log \left( \frac{n^3 + 1}{n^3 - 1} \right)
   \]

2. We can express the series as a limit of partial sums:
   \[
   \sum_{n=2}^\infty \log \left( \frac{n^3 + 1}{n^3 - 1} \right) = \lim_{m \to \infty} \sum_{n=2}^m \log \left( \frac{n^3 + 1}{n^3 - 1} \right)
   \]

3. Using the property of logarithms that the sum of logarithms is the logarithm of the product, we get:
   \[
   \sum_{n=2}^m \log \left( \frac{n^3 + 1}{n^3 - 1} \right) = \log \left( \prod_{n=2}^m \frac{n^3 + 1}{n^3 - 1} \right)
   \]

4. We now need to evaluate the product:
   \[
   \prod_{n=2}^m \frac{n^3 + 1}{n^3 - 1}
   \]
   Notice that:
   \[
   \frac{n^3 + 1}{n^3 - 1} = \frac{(n+1)(n^2 - n + 1)}{(n-1)(n^2 + n + 1)}
   \]
   Therefore, the product becomes:
   \[
   \prod_{n=2}^m \frac{(n+1)(n^2 - n + 1)}{(n-1)(n^2 + n + 1)}
   \]

5. This product can be split into two separate products:
   \[
   \prod_{n=2}^m \frac{n+1}{n-1} \cdot \prod_{n=2}^m \frac{n^2 - n + 1}{n^2 + n + 1}
   \]

6. The first product is a telescoping product:
   \[
   \prod_{n=2}^m \frac{n+1}{n-1} = \frac{3}{1} \cdot \frac{4}{2} \cdot \frac{5}{3} \cdots \frac{m+1}{m-1} = \frac{(m+1)m}{2}
   \]

7. The second product is also a telescoping product:
   \[
   \prod_{n=2}^m \frac{n^2 - n + 1}{n^2 + n + 1} = \frac{3}{2} \cdot \frac{8}{7} \cdot \frac{15}{14} \cdots \frac{m^2 - m + 1}{m^2 + m + 1}
   \]
   This product simplifies to:
   \[
   \frac{3}{2} \cdot \frac{m^2 - m + 1}{m^2 + m + 1}
   \]

8. Combining these results, we get:
   \[
   \prod_{n=2}^m \frac{n^3 + 1}{n^3 - 1} = \frac{(m+1)m}{2} \cdot \frac{3}{2} \cdot \frac{m^2 - m + 1}{m^2 + m + 1}
   \]

9. Taking the limit as \( m \to \infty \):
   \[
   \lim_{m \to \infty} \frac{(m+1)m}{2} \cdot \frac{3}{2} \cdot \frac{m^2 - m + 1}{m^2 + m + 1} = \lim_{m \to \infty} \frac{3m(m+1)}{2(m^2 + m + 1)}
   \]

10. Simplifying the limit:
    \[
    \lim_{m \to \infty} \frac{3m(m+1)}{2(m^2 + m + 1)} = \lim_{m \to \infty} \frac{3m^2 + 3m}{2m^2 + 2m + 2} = \frac{3}{2}
    \]

11. Therefore, the series sum is:
    \[
    \log \left( \frac{3}{2} \right)
    \]

The final answer is \( \boxed{ \log \left( \frac{3}{2} \right) } \)
informal_statement: Calculate the exact value of the series $\sum _{n=2} ^\infty \log (n^3 +1) - \log (n^3 - 1)$ and provide justification.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Calculate the exact value of the series $\sum _{n=2} ^\infty \log (n^3 +1) - \log (n^3 - 1)$ and provide justification. -/
theorem calculus_92209 : ‚àë' n : ‚Ñï, (if n ‚â• 2 then (log (n ^ 3 + 1) - log (n ^ 3 - 1)) else 0) = log (3 / 2) := by

soln_description:
Solution. The required derivative is found using formula (3.13). We find the necessary partial derivatives

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}=\frac{2 x}{\sqrt{1-\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+t^{2}\right)^{2}}} ; \frac{\partial z}{\partial y}=\frac{2 y}{\sqrt{1-\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+t^{2}\right)^{2}}} \\
\frac{\partial z}{\partial t}=\frac{2 t}{\sqrt{1-\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+t^{2}\right)^{2}}} ; \frac{d x}{d t}=2 ; \frac{d y}{d t}=8 t
\end{gathered}
$$

Substituting into (3.13), we get:

$$
\frac{d z}{d t}=\frac{2 t+2 x \cdot 2+2 y \cdot 8 t}{\sqrt{1-\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+t^{2}\right)^{2}}}=\frac{2 t\left(1+4 t+32 t^{2}\right)}{\sqrt{1-\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+t^{2}\right)^{2}}}
$$
informal_statement: Example 3.27. Find $\frac{d z}{d t}$, if $z=\arcsin \left(x^{2}+y^{2}+t^{2}\right)$, where $x=2 t, y=4 t^{2}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Example 3.27. Find $\frac{d z}{d t}$, if $z=\arcsin \left(x^{2}+y^{2}+t^{2}\right)$, where $x=2 t, y=4 t^{2}$. -/
theorem calculus_145269 (x y t : ‚Ñù) (hx : x = 2 * t) (hy : y = 4 * t ^ 2)
  (z : ‚Ñù) (hz : z = arcsin (x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 + t ^ 2)) :
  deriv (Œª t => arcsin (x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 + t ^ 2)) t =
  2 * (1 + 4 + 32 ^ 2) / sqrt (1 - (x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 + t ^ 2) ^ 2) := by

soln_description:
Answer: 602.

Solution. First, consider the numbers from 1 to 2000. Then the digit 7 can be in the third position from the end: numbers of the form $7 * *$ or $17 * *$ - there are 200 such numbers. It can be in the second position: $* 7 *$ or $1 * 7 *$ - there are also 200 such numbers; or the last position: $* * 7$ or $1 * * 7$ - there are also 200 such numbers. In addition, there are 2007 and 2017 - two more 7s.
informal_statement: 4.1. All natural numbers from 1 to 2017 inclusive were written in a row. How many times was the digit 7 written?
informal_proof:
We are asked to find the total number of times the digit '7' appears when writing out all natural numbers from 1 to 2017 inclusive. This is equivalent to calculating the sum:
$$ \sum_{n=1}^{2017} \text{count of digit 7 in the decimal representation of } n $$
A direct computational method is employed to determine this sum. By enumerating each number from 1 to 2017 and counting the occurrences of the digit '7' in its decimal representation, and then summing these counts, the total number of times the digit '7' appears is found to be 602.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4.1. All natural numbers from 1 to 2017 inclusive were written in a row. How many times was the digit 7 written? -/
theorem number_theory_198410 : ‚àë n in Finset.Icc 1 2017, (Nat.digits 10 n).count 7 = 602 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_198410 : ‚àë n in Finset.Icc 1 2017, (Nat.digits 10 n).count 7 = 602 := by 
  native_decide

soln_description:
23. Answer: 0
Solution. Let $x_{n}=\tan \alpha_{n}$. Since $2-\sqrt{3}=\tan \left(\frac{\pi}{12}\right)$, it follows that
$$
x_{n+1}=\tan \alpha_{n+1}=\frac{\tan \alpha_{n}+\tan \left(\frac{\pi}{12}\right)}{1-\tan \alpha_{n} \tan \left(\frac{\pi}{12}\right)}=\tan \left(\alpha_{n}+\frac{\pi}{12}\right)
$$

So, $x_{n+12}=\tan \left(\alpha_{n}+\pi\right)=\tan \alpha_{n}=x_{n}$, implying that this sequence has a period of 12 . Observe that $1001 \equiv 5(\bmod 12)$ and $401 \equiv 5(\bmod 12)$. Consequently,
$$
x_{1001}-x_{401}=x_{5}-x_{5}=0
$$
informal_statement:
23. The sequence $\left(x_{n}\right)_{n-1}^{\infty}$ is defined recursively by
$$
x_{n+1}=\frac{x_{n}+(2-\sqrt{3})}{1-x_{n}(2-\sqrt{3})}
$$
with $x_{1}=1$. Determine the value of $x_{1001}-x_{401}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open scoped BigOperators

/- 23. The sequence $\left(x_{n}\right)_{n-1}^{\infty}$ is defined recursively by
$$
x_{n+1}=\frac{x_{n}+(2-\sqrt{3})}{1-x_{n}(2-\sqrt{3})}
$$
with $x_{1}=1$. Determine the value of $x_{1001}-x_{401}$. -/
theorem algebra_100764 {x : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù}
  (hx : ‚àÄ n, x (n + 1) = (x n + (2 - Real.sqrt 3)) / (1 - x n * (2 - Real.sqrt 3)))
  (hx1 : x 1 = 1) :
  x 1001 - x 401 = 0 := by

soln_description:
Answer 2.
Solution Let the parametric equation of the line $l$ be $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x=a+t \cos \alpha \\ y=t \sin \alpha\end{array}\right.$ (where $t$ is the parameter, $\alpha$ is the angle of inclination and $\left.\alpha \in(0, \pi)\right)$, substituting into the parabola equation yields:
$$
t^{2} \sin ^{2} \alpha-4 t \cos \alpha-4 a=0
$$

Let the two roots of this equation be $t_{1}, t_{2}$, then
$$
t_{1}+t_{2}=\frac{4 \cos \alpha}{\sin ^{2} \alpha}, \quad t_{1} \cdot t_{2}=\frac{4 a}{\sin ^{2} \alpha}
$$

Then
$$
\frac{1}{|P M|^{2}}+\frac{1}{|P Q|^{2}}=\frac{1}{t_{1}^{2}}+\frac{1}{t_{2}^{2}}=\frac{t_{1}^{2}+t_{2}^{2}}{\left(t_{1} t_{2}\right)^{2}}=\frac{\left(t_{1}+t_{2}\right)^{2}-2 t_{1} t_{2}}{\left(t_{1} t_{2}\right)^{2}}=\frac{\frac{16 \cos ^{2} \alpha}{\sin ^{4} \alpha}+\frac{8 a}{\sin ^{2} \alpha}}{\frac{16 a^{2}}{\sin ^{4} \alpha}}=\frac{2 \cos ^{2} \alpha+a \sin ^{2} \alpha}{2 a^{2}} \text { is a constant }
$$

Therefore, $a=2$.
informal_statement: 7. Let the line $l$ passing through the fixed point $M(a, 0)$ intersect the parabola $y^{2}=4 x$ at points $P, Q$. If $\frac{1}{|P M|^{2}}+\frac{1}{|Q M|^{2}}$ is a constant, then the value of $a$ is $\qquad$ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7. Let the line $l$ passing through the fixed point $M(a, 0)$ intersect the parabola $y^{2}=4 x$ at points $P, Q$. If $\frac{1}{|P M|^{2}}+\frac{1}{|Q M|^{2}}$ is a constant, then the value of $a$ is $\qquad$ . -/
theorem algebra_147837 (a : ‚Ñù) (P Q M : ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù)
    (hP : P.1 = (a + 2 * P.2 ^ 2) / 2) (hQ : Q.1 = (a + 2 * Q.2 ^ 2) / 2)
    (hM : M = (a, 0)) (h : 1 / dist P M ^ 2 + 1 / dist Q M ^ 2 = 1 / 4) :
    a = 2 := by

soln_description:
Let the first term of the arithmetic sequence be $a$, and the common difference be $d$. According to the problem, we have $n a + \frac{1}{2} n(n-1) d = 97^2$, which means
$$
[2 a + (n-1) d] n = 2 \times 97^2
$$

Since $n$ is a positive integer no less than 3, and 97 is a prime number, the value of $n$ can only be one of $97$, $2 \times 97$, $97^2$, or $2 \times 97^2$. If $d > 0$, then from (1) we know $2 \times 97^2 \geqslant n(n-1) d \geqslant n(n-1)$, so $n$ can only be $97$. Thus, (1) becomes $a + 48 d = 97$, from which we can get $n=97, d=1, a=49$ or $n=97, d=2, a=1$; If $d=0$, then from (1) we get $n a = 97^2$, in which case $n=97, a=97$ or $n=97^2, a=1$. Therefore, there are 4 arithmetic sequences that meet the conditions.
informal_statement: Let 7 be the first term and the common difference of an arithmetic sequence both be non-negative integers, the number of terms is no less than 3, and the sum of all terms is $97^{2}$. How many such sequences are there?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let 7 be the first term and the common difference of an arithmetic sequence both be non-negative integers, the number of terms is no less than 3, and the sum of all terms is $97^{2}$. How many such sequences are there? -/
theorem number_theory_285079 :
    Set.ncard {a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñ§ | ‚àÉ d : ‚Ñï, a 0 = 7 ‚àß ‚àÄ n : ‚Ñï, a (n + 1) = a n + d ‚àß
      ‚àÉ k : ‚Ñï, k ‚â• 3 ‚àß ‚àë i in Finset.range k, a i = 97 ^ 2} = 4 := by

soln_description:
1. Let \( P(x, y) \) be the assertion \( f(x + g(y)) = g(x) + 2y + f(y) \).

2. Let \( a = f(0) \).

3. Consider \( P(x - g(x), x) \):
   \[
   f((x - g(x)) + g(x)) = g(x - g(x)) + 2x + f(x)
   \]
   Simplifying, we get:
   \[
   f(x) = g(x - g(x)) + 2x + f(x)
   \]
   Thus:
   \[
   g(x - g(x)) = -2x
   \]
   This implies that \( g(x) \) is surjective because for any \( y \in \mathbb{Q} \), there exists an \( x \) such that \( g(x) = y \).

4. If \( g(x) = 0 \), then:
   \[
   g(x - g(x)) = g(x) = 0 \implies -2x = 0 \implies x = 0
   \]
   Therefore, \( g(0) = 0 \).

5. Subtracting \( P(0, y) \) from \( P(x, y) \):
   \[
   f(x + g(y)) = g(x) + 2y + f(y)
   \]
   \[
   f(g(y)) = g(0) + 2y + f(y) = 2y + f(y)
   \]
   Subtracting these, we get:
   \[
   f(x + g(y)) - f(g(y)) = g(x)
   \]
   Since \( g(x) \) is surjective, let \( g(y) = t \):
   \[
   f(x + t) - f(t) = g(x)
   \]
   Thus:
   \[
   f(x + y) = g(x) + f(y)
   \]

6. Consider \( P(x, 0) \):
   \[
   f(x + g(0)) = g(x) + 2 \cdot 0 + f(0)
   \]
   \[
   f(x) = g(x) + a
   \]
   Substituting \( f(x) = g(x) + a \) into \( f(x + y) = g(x) + f(y) \):
   \[
   g(x + y) + a = g(x) + g(y) + a
   \]
   \[
   g(x + y) = g(x) + g(y)
   \]
   This shows that \( g(x) \) is an additive function. Since we are in \( \mathbb{Q} \), \( g(x) \) must be linear:
   \[
   g(x) = cx
   \]

7. Substituting \( g(x) = cx \) into \( f(x) = g(x) + a \):
   \[
   f(x) = cx + a
   \]

8. Plugging \( f(x) = cx + a \) and \( g(x) = cx \) back into the original equation:
   \[
   f(x + g(y)) = f(x + cy) = c(x + cy) + a = cx + c^2y + a
   \]
   \[
   g(x) + 2y + f(y) = cx + 2y + cy + a = cx + (c + 2)y + a
   \]
   Equating both sides:
   \[
   cx + c^2y + a = cx + (c + 2)y + a
   \]
   \[
   c^2y = (c + 2)y
   \]
   For this to hold for all \( y \in \mathbb{Q} \):
   \[
   c^2 = c + 2
   \]
   Solving the quadratic equation:
   \[
   c^2 - c - 2 = 0
   \]
   \[
   (c - 2)(c + 1) = 0
   \]
   \[
   c = 2 \quad \text{or} \quad c = -1
   \]

9. Therefore, the solutions are:
   \[
   \boxed{\text{S1: } f(x) = a - x \text{ and } g(x) = -x \quad \forall x \in \mathbb{Q}}
   \]
   \[
   \boxed{\text{S2: } f(x) = 2x + a \text{ and } g(x) = 2x \quad \forall x \in \mathbb{Q}}
   \]
   where \( a \in \mathbb{Q} \).
informal_statement:
Find all functions $f, g : Q \to  Q$ satisfying the following equality $f(x + g(y)) = g(x) + 2 y + f(y)$ for all $x, y \in  Q$.

(I. Voronovich)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find all functions $f, g : Q \to  Q$ satisfying the following equality $f(x + g(y)) = g(x) + 2 y + f(y)$ for all $x, y \in  Q$.

(I. Voronovich) -/
theorem other_91534 {f g : ‚Ñö ‚Üí ‚Ñö} :
    (‚àÄ x y, f (x + g y) = g x + 2 * y + f y) ‚Üî
    ‚àÉ a, ‚àÄ x, f x = 2 * x + a ‚àß g x = 2 * x := by

soln_description:
**Analysis**

This problem requires us to investigate the monotonicity of the function $y = \frac{\ln x}{x}$ using calculus. To do this, we'll find the derivative, set it greater than zero, and solve the resulting inequality. Make sure to consider the function's domain during the process.

**Solution**

The function's domain is $(0,+\infty)$.

Taking the derivative, we have $y' = \frac{1-\ln x}{x^2}$. Setting it greater than zero, we obtain $y' = \frac{1-\ln x}{x^2} > 0$.

Solving the inequality, we find that the function is strictly increasing on the interval $(0,e)$.

Thus, the answer is $\boxed{(0,e)}$.
informal_statement: Determine the interval(s) where the function $y = \frac{\ln x}{x}$ is strictly increasing.
informal_proof:
We want to show that the function $f(x) = \frac{\ln x}{x}$ is strictly monotone on the interval $(0, e)$. A standard method to establish strict monotonicity of a differentiable function on an interval is to show that its derivative is strictly positive throughout that interval.

The proof proceeds by verifying the conditions required by a lemma that states a function is strictly monotone if its derivative is strictly positive, the function is continuous, and the domain is convex.

First, we confirm the properties of the interval $(0, e)$:
The interval $(0, e)$ is an open interval. Open intervals are convex sets.

Next, we establish the continuity of the function $f(x) = \frac{\ln x}{x}$ on this interval.
The function $f(x)$ is a quotient of two functions: the numerator $g(x) = \ln x$ and the denominator $h(x) = x$.
The function $g(x) = \ln x$ is known to be continuous for all $x > 0$. Since the interval $(0, e)$ consists of positive numbers, $g(x)$ is continuous on $(0, e)$.
The function $h(x) = x$ is a polynomial and is continuous on all of $\mathbb{R}$, and therefore it is continuous on $(0, e)$.
For $f(x)$ to be continuous, the denominator $h(x)$ must be non-zero on the interval. For any $x \in (0, e)$, we have $x > 0$, so $h(x) = x \neq 0$.
Since both the numerator and the denominator are continuous on $(0, e)$ and the denominator is non-zero on this interval, the function $f(x) = \frac{\ln x}{x}$ is continuous on $(0, e)$.

Now, we compute the derivative of $f(x)$:
Using the quotient rule, $\left(\frac{g}{h}\right)' = \frac{g'h - gh'}{h^2}$:
$$ f'(x) = \frac{\frac{d}{dx}(\ln x) \cdot x - (\ln x) \cdot \frac{d}{dx}(x)}{x^2} $$
The derivative of $\ln x$ is $\frac{1}{x}$, and the derivative of $x$ is $1$. Substituting these into the formula:
$$ f'(x) = \frac{\frac{1}{x} \cdot x - (\ln x) \cdot 1}{x^2} = \frac{1 - \ln x}{x^2} $$
To show that $f(x)$ is strictly monotone on $(0, e)$, we need to show that $f'(x) > 0$ for all $x \in (0, e)$.
The derivative is $f'(x) = \frac{1 - \ln x}{x^2}$.
For $x \in (0, e)$, $x$ is positive, so $x^2$ is strictly positive ($x^2 > 0$).
Therefore, the sign of $f'(x)$ is determined by the sign of the numerator, $1 - \ln x$.
We need to show that $1 - \ln x > 0$, which is equivalent to $\ln x < 1$.
Consider any $x$ in the interval $(0, e)$. Since the natural logarithm function, $\ln$, is strictly increasing, for any $x$ such that $0 < x < e$, it follows that $\ln x < \ln e$.
We know that $\ln e = 1$.
Thus, for all $x \in (0, e)$, we have $\ln x < 1$.
This implies that $1 - \ln x > 0$ for all $x \in (0, e)$.
Since both the numerator ($1 - \ln x$) and the denominator ($x^2$) are strictly positive for all $x \in (0, e)$, their quotient, $f'(x)$, is strictly positive on $(0, e)$.

Since the interval $(0, e)$ is convex, the function $f(x)$ is continuous on $(0, e)$, and its derivative $f'(x)$ is strictly positive on $(0, e)$, the function $f(x)$ is strictly monotone (specifically, strictly increasing) on the interval $(0, e)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_9287 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (hf : f = Œª x => Real.log x / x) :
    StrictMonoOn f (Set.Ioo 0 (Real.exp 1)) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_9287 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (hf : f = Œª x => Real.log x / x) :
    StrictMonoOn f (Set.Ioo 0 (Real.exp 1)) := by
-- Show f(x) is strictly monotone by calculating its deriv.
  apply strictMonoOn_of_deriv_pos
  ¬∑ -- Show that interval $(0,e)$ is convex.
    exact convex_Ioo _ _
  ¬∑ -- Show that f(x) is continuous on $(0,e)$.
    rw [hf]
    apply ContinuousOn.div‚ÇÄ
    ¬∑ intro x hx
      apply ContinuousWithinAt.log
      ¬∑ apply continuousWithinAt_id
      ¬∑ simp at hx
        linarith
    ¬∑ apply continuousOn_id'
    ¬∑ intro x hx
      simp at hx
      linarith
  ¬∑ -- Show that f'(x) is positive on $(0,e)$.
    intro x hx
    simp at hx
    rcases hx with ‚ü®hx‚ÇÅ, hx‚ÇÇ‚ü©
    rw [hf, deriv_div (by apply Real.differentiableAt_log; linarith) (by apply differentiableAt_id) (by linarith), Real.deriv_log, deriv_id'', mul_one, inv_mul_cancel‚ÇÄ (by linarith), div_pos_iff]
    left
    refine ‚ü®?_, by positivity‚ü©
    have h8 : Real.log x < 1 := by
      have h9 : Real.log x < Real.log (Real.exp 1) := by
        apply Real.log_lt_log
        linarith
        linarith
      have h10 : Real.log (Real.exp 1) = 1 := Real.log_exp 1
      linarith [h10, h9]
    linarith [h8]

soln_description:
If for an integer $n>1$, there is $t_{n-1} t_{n}=m^{2}$, where $m$ is a positive integer, then $\left(n^{2}-1\right) n^{2}=$ $(2 m)^{2}$. Since $\left(n^{2}-1, n^{2}\right)=1$, both $n^{2}-1$ and $n^{2}$ must be perfect squares, which is impossible.

Now let $n$ be a given positive integer. The equation $x^{2}-n(n+1) y^{2}=1$ has infinitely many positive integer solutions $x$, $y$. In fact, one solution is $x=2 n+1, y=2$. At the same time, if for some positive integers $x, y$, there is $x^{2}-n(n+$ 1) $y^{2}-1$, then there is also
$$
((2 n+1) x+2 n(n+1) y)^{2}-n(n+1)(2 x+(2 n+1) y)^{2}=1 .
$$

If $x, y$ are positive integers and satisfy $x^{2}-n(n+1) y^{2}=1$, then
$$
t_{n} t_{2 t_{n} y^{2}}=t_{n} t_{n} y^{2}\left(2 t_{n} y^{2}+1\right)=t_{n}^{2} y^{2} x^{2}=\left(t_{n} y x\right)^{2} .
$$

For example, when $n=3$, $t_{3} \cdot t_{24}=30^{2}, t_{3} \cdot t_{2400}=(3 \cdot 20 \cdot 49)^{2}$, etc.
informal_statement: 19.732 * Proof: The product of two consecutive triangular numbers cannot be a square number. However, for each triangular number $t_{n}=\frac{n(n+1)}{2}$, there exist infinitely many triangular numbers $t_{m}$ greater than $t_{n}$ such that $t_{n} \cdot t_{m}$ is a square number.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 19.732 * Proof: The product of two consecutive triangular numbers cannot be a square number. However, for each triangular number $t_{n}=\frac{n(n+1)}{2}$, there exist infinitely many triangular numbers $t_{m}$ greater than $t_{n}$ such that $t_{n} \cdot t_{m}$ is a square number. -/
theorem number_theory_177835 (t : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï) (ht : ‚àÄ n, t n = n * (n + 1) / 2) :
    (‚àÄ n, ¬¨ ‚àÉ m, m^2 = t n * t (n + 1)) ‚àß
    (‚àÄ n, {m | m > n ‚àß ‚àÉ k, k^2 = t n * t m}.Infinite) := by

soln_description:
From the problem, we set
$3 m n+3 m=k\left(2 m^{2}+n^{2}\right)(k \in \mathbf{Z})$.
Then $3 m(n+1)=k\left(2 m^{2}+n^{2}\right) \geqslant 2 \sqrt{2} k m$.
Thus, $k \leqslant \frac{3(n+1)}{2 \sqrt{2} n}=\frac{3}{2 \sqrt{2}}\left(1+\frac{1}{n}\right) \leqslant \frac{3}{\sqrt{2}}$.
From this, we get $k \leqslant 2$.
Considering $3 m n+3 m=k\left(2 m^{2}+n^{2}\right)$ as a quadratic equation in $n$,
$k n^{2}-3 m n+2 k m-3 m=0$.
Thus, $\Delta=9 m^{2}-8 k^{2} m^{2}+12 k m$.
If $k=2$, then $\Delta=24 m-23 m^{2}$.
By $\Delta \geqslant 0$, we get $m=1$.
From equation (1), we get $n=1$.
If $k=1$, then the discriminant is a non-negative integer $t$ squared, i.e.,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
t^{2}=\Delta=m^{2}+12 m=(m+6)^{2}-36 \\
\Rightarrow 36=(m+6+t)(m+6-t) .
\end{array}
$$

Since $t \geqslant 0, m>0$, we have
$$
m+6+t>0 \text {. }
$$

Thus, $m+6-t>0$.
Clearly, $m+6+t$ and $m+6-t$ have the same parity.
Hence, $m+6+t=m+6-t=6$

or $m+6+t=18, m+6-t=2$.
In the second case, we get
$$
m=4, t=8 \text {. }
$$

Therefore, equation (1) has solutions $n=2,10$.
In summary, the positive integer pairs $(m, n)$ that satisfy the problem's requirements are $(1,1),(4,2),(4,10)$.
informal_statement:
Example $\mathbf{4}$ Find all pairs of positive integers $(m, n)$, satisfying $\left(2 m^{2}+n^{2}\right) \mid(3 m n+3 m)$.
(2012, Slovenia National Team Selection Exam)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example $\mathbf{4}$ Find all pairs of positive integers $(m, n)$, satisfying $\left(2 m^{2}+n^{2}\right) \mid(3 m n+3 m)$.
(2012, Slovenia National Team Selection Exam) -/
theorem number_theory_270759 (m n : ‚Ñ§) (hm : 0 < m) (hn : 0 < n)
    (h : 2 * m ^ 2 + n ^ 2 ‚à£ 3 * m * n + 3 * m) :
    (m, n) = (1, 1) ‚à® (m, n) = (4, 2) ‚à® (m, n) = (4, 10) := by

informal_statement: Two numbers have a difference of 3 and a sum of 31. What is the larger of the two numbers?
informal_proof:
Let $x$ and $y$ be two real numbers.
We are given two conditions:
1.  The absolute difference between $x$ and $y$ is 3: $|x - y| = 3$.
2.  The sum of $x$ and $y$ is 31: $x + y = 31$.

We need to determine the value of $\max(x, y)$.

From the first condition, $|x - y| = 3$, there are two possibilities for the relationship between $x$ and $y$:

**Case 1: $x - y = 3$.**
In this case, we have a system of two linear equations:
$$x - y = 3$$
$$x + y = 31$$
To solve for $x$ and $y$, we can add these two equations:
$$(x - y) + (x + y) = 3 + 31$$
$$2x = 34$$
Dividing by 2, we get:
$$x = 17$$
Now, substitute the value of $x$ into the second equation ($x + y = 31$):
$$17 + y = 31$$
Subtracting 17 from both sides gives:
$$y = 14$$
So, in this case, the numbers are $x = 17$ and $y = 14$.
We check if these values satisfy the original conditions: $|17 - 14| = |3| = 3$ (correct) and $17 + 14 = 31$ (correct).
The maximum of these two numbers is $\max(17, 14) = 17$.

**Case 2: $x - y = -3$ (which is equivalent to $y - x = 3$).**
In this case, we have the following system of two linear equations:
$$x - y = -3$$
$$x + y = 31$$
To solve for $x$ and $y$, we can add these two equations:
$$(x - y) + (x + y) = -3 + 31$$
$$2x = 28$$
Dividing by 2, we get:
$$x = 14$$
Now, substitute the value of $x$ into the second equation ($x + y = 31$):
$$14 + y = 31$$
Subtracting 14 from both sides gives:
$$y = 17$$
So, in this case, the numbers are $x = 14$ and $y = 17$.
We check if these values satisfy the original conditions: $|14 - 17| = |-3| = 3$ (correct) and $14 + 17 = 31$ (correct).
The maximum of these two numbers is $\max(14, 17) = 17$.

In both possible cases derived from the given conditions, the larger of the two numbers is 17.
Therefore, $\max(x, y) = 17$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Two numbers have a difference of 3 and a sum of 31. What is the larger of the two numbers? -/
theorem algebra_11190 {x y : ‚Ñù} (h‚ÇÄ : |x - y| = 3) (h‚ÇÅ : x + y = 31) :
    max x y = 17 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_11190 {x y : ‚Ñù} (h‚ÇÄ : |x - y| = 3) (h‚ÇÅ : x + y = 31) :
    max x y = 17 := by
  cases eq_or_eq_neg_of_abs_eq h‚ÇÄ with
  | inl h2 =>
    -- Case where x - y = 3
    have h3 : x = 17 := by
      linarith
    have h4 : y = 14 := by
      linarith [h‚ÇÅ, h3]
    rw [h3, h4]
    norm_num
  | inr h2 =>
    -- Case where -(x - y) = 3, which means y - x = 3
    have h3 : x = 14 := by
      linarith
    have h4 : y = 17 := by
      linarith [h‚ÇÅ, h3]
    rw [h3, h4]
    norm_num

informal_statement:
The curve of the equation $3 x ^ { 2 } - 1219 x - 2023 = 0$ in the plane is translated 3 units to the right to form the curve of the equation $a x ^ { 2 } + b x + c = 0$, where $a$, $b$, and $c$ are real numbers. Find the value of $a + b + c$.

The curve of the equation $3 x ^ { 2 } - 1219 x - 2023 = 0$ in the plane is translated 3 units to the right to form the curve of the equation $a x ^ { 2 } + b x + c = 0$, where $a$, $b$, and $c$ are real numbers. Find the value of $a + b + c$.
informal_proof:
Let the given polynomial identity be:
$$3 (x - 3)^2 - 1219 (x - 3) - 2023 = a x^2 + b x + c$$
This identity holds for all real numbers $x$, where $a$, $b$, and $c$ are real coefficients.

We are asked to find the value of $a + b + c$.

To find the value of $a+b+c$, we can evaluate the given identity at a specific value of $x$ that simplifies the right-hand side to $a+b+c$. This occurs when $x=1$.

Substituting $x=1$ into the identity, we get:
$$3 (1 - 3)^2 - 1219 (1 - 3) - 2023 = a (1)^2 + b (1) + c$$
$$3 (-2)^2 - 1219 (-2) - 2023 = a + b + c$$
Now, we compute the left-hand side:
$$3 (4) - 1219 (-2) - 2023 = a + b + c$$
$$12 + 2438 - 2023 = a + b + c$$
$$2450 - 2023 = a + b + c$$
$$427 = a + b + c$$
Thus, the value of $a+b+c$ is 427.

For completeness, evaluating at $x=0$ gives $c = 3(-3)^2 - 1219(-3) - 2023 = 3(9) + 3657 - 2023 = 27 + 3657 - 2023 = 3684 - 2023 = 1661$.
Evaluating at $x=2$ gives $4a+2b+c = 3(2-3)^2 - 1219(2-3) - 2023 = 3(-1)^2 - 1219(-1) - 2023 = 3(1) + 1219 - 2023 = 3 + 1219 - 2023 = 1222 - 2023 = -801$.
The linear arithmetic solver confirms that these evaluations are consistent with $a+b+c=427$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The curve of the equation $3 x ^ { 2 } - 1219 x - 2023 = 0$ in the plane is translated 3 units to the right to form the curve of the equation $a x ^ { 2 } + b x + c = 0$, where $a$, $b$, and $c$ are real numbers. Find the value of $a + b + c$.

The curve of the equation $3 x ^ { 2 } - 1219 x - 2023 = 0$ in the plane is translated 3 units to the right to form the curve of the equation $a x ^ { 2 } + b x + c = 0$, where $a$, $b$, and $c$ are real numbers. Find the value of $a + b + c$. -/
theorem algebra_4848 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (h : ‚àÄ x, 3 * (x - 3) ^ 2 - 1219 * (x - 3) - 2023 = a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c) : a + b + c = 427 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_4848 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (h : ‚àÄ x, 3 * (x - 3) ^ 2 - 1219 * (x - 3) - 2023 = a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c) : a + b + c = 427 := by
  have eq1 := h 0
  have eq2 := h 1
  have eq3 := h 2
  linarith

soln_description:
2.B.

Let $a^{2}=x+3, b^{2}=x+2007$, where $a, b$ are natural numbers. Then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
y=a+b, \\
b^{2}-a^{2}=(b-a)(b+a) \\
=2004=2^{2} \times 3 \times 167 .
\end{array}
$$

Since $b+a$ and $b-a$ have the same parity, and $b+a > b-a$, we have
$$
\left\{\begin{array} { l } 
{ b + a = 1 0 0 2 , } \\
{ b - a = 2 }
\end{array} \text { or } \left\{\begin{array}{l}
b+a=334, \\
b-a=6 .
\end{array}\right.\right.
$$

Solving these, we get $\left\{\begin{array}{l}a=500, \\ b=502\end{array}\right.$ or $\left\{\begin{array}{l}a=164, \\ b=170 .\end{array}\right.$

soln_description:
In Lemma 9, take $n=2$. At this time, the numbers in (31) are
$$2,4, \cdots, p^{-1}$$

Solving $2 x<\frac{p}{2}$ yields $x<\frac{p}{4}$, so at this time $\lambda=\left[\frac{p}{4}\right]$, thus $\mu=\frac{p-1}{2}-\left\{\frac{p}{4}\right\rceil$, hence
$$\begin{array}{c}
\mu=\left\{\begin{array}{r}
2 n, \text { when } p=8 n+1 \text {, } \\
2 n+1, \text { when } p=8 n+3 \text {, } \\
2 n+1, \text { when } p=8 n+5 \text {, } \\
2 n+2, \text { when } p=8 n+7 \text {, }
\end{array}\right. \\
(-1) \frac{m^{2}-1}{8}=\left\{\begin{array}{r}
1, \text { when } p=8 n+1 \text {, } \\
-1, \text { when } p=8 n+3 \text {, } p=8 n+5 \text {, } \\
1, \text { when } p=8 n+7 \text {, }
\end{array}\right.
\end{array}$$

Therefore, according to Gauss's Lemma, we obtain the conclusion of this lemma.
informal_statement:
Lemma 10 Let $p$ be an odd prime, then
$$\left(\frac{2}{p}\right)=(-1)^{\left(p^{2}-1\right) / 8},$$

that is, when $p \equiv 1$ or $-1(\bmod 8)$, 2 is a quadratic residue modulo $p$, and when $p \equiv 3$ or $-3(\bmod 8)$, 2 is a quadratic non-residue modulo $p$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Lemma 10 Let $p$ be an odd prime, then
$$\left(\frac{2}{p}\right)=(-1)^{\left(p^{2}-1\right) / 8},$$

that is, when $p \equiv 1$ or $-1(\bmod 8)$, 2 is a quadratic residue modulo $p$, and when $p \equiv 3$ or $-3(\bmod 8)$, 2 is a quadratic non-residue modulo $p$. -/
theorem number_theory_7298 (p : ‚Ñï) [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] (hp1 : Odd p) :
    (‚àÉ x, x^2 ‚â° 2 [MOD p]) ‚Üî p ‚â° 1 [ZMOD 8] ‚à® p ‚â° -1 [ZMOD 8] := by

soln_description: $\begin{array}{l}\text { Prove: Let } x=\frac{k}{3}-t, y=\frac{k}{3}-2 t, z=\frac{k}{3} \\ +3 t(t \in R) \text {, then } x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=\left(\frac{k}{3}-t\right)^{2} \\ +\left(\frac{k}{3}-2 t\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{k}{3}+3 t\right)^{2}=\frac{k^{2}}{3}+14 t^{2} \\ \geqslant \frac{k^{2}}{3}\end{array}$
informal_statement:
Example 3. If $x+y+z=k$, then $x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}$
$$
\geqslant \frac{\mathrm{k}^{2}}{3} \text {. }
$$
informal_proof:
Given the equation $x + y + z = k$ for real numbers $x, y, z,$ and $k$.
We want to show that $x^2 + y^2 + z^2 \geq \frac{k^2}{3}$.

First, we acknowledge the given condition $k = x + y + z$.

We will use the property that the square of any real number is non-negative. Consider the following non-negative quantities:
$(x - y)^2 \geq 0$
$(y - z)^2 \geq 0$
$(z - x)^2 \geq 0$

Summing these inequalities, we get:
$(x - y)^2 + (y - z)^2 + (z - x)^2 \geq 0$

Expanding each term:
$(x^2 - 2xy + y^2) + (y^2 - 2yz + z^2) + (z^2 - 2zx + x^2) \geq 0$

Combining like terms, we have:
$2x^2 + 2y^2 + 2z^2 - 2xy - 2yz - 2zx \geq 0$
$2(x^2 + y^2 + z^2) - 2(xy + yz + zx) \geq 0$

Now, consider the square of the sum $x+y+z$:
$(x + y + z)^2 = k^2$
Expanding the left side:
$x^2 + y^2 + z^2 + 2xy + 2yz + 2zx = k^2$
$x^2 + y^2 + z^2 + 2(xy + yz + zx) = k^2$

From this, we can express $2(xy + yz + zx)$ in terms of $k^2$ and the sum of squares:
$2(xy + yz + zx) = k^2 - (x^2 + y^2 + z^2)$

Substitute this expression back into our summed inequality:
$2(x^2 + y^2 + z^2) - (k^2 - (x^2 + y^2 + z^2)) \geq 0$

Simplifying the left side:
$2(x^2 + y^2 + z^2) - k^2 + x^2 + y^2 + z^2 \geq 0$
$3(x^2 + y^2 + z^2) - k^2 \geq 0$

Rearranging the terms to isolate the sum of squares:
$3(x^2 + y^2 + z^2) \geq k^2$

Finally, dividing by 3, we obtain the desired inequality:
$x^2 + y^2 + z^2 \geq \frac{k^2}{3}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 3. If $x+y+z=k$, then $x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}$
$$
\geqslant \frac{\mathrm{k}^{2}}{3} \text {. }
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_305072 (x y z k : ‚Ñù) (h : x + y + z = k) :
    x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 + z ^ 2 ‚â• k ^ 2 / 3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_305072 (x y z k : ‚Ñù) (h : x + y + z = k) :
    x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 + z ^ 2 ‚â• k ^ 2 / 3 := by
  have h1 : k = x + y + z := by linarith
  rw [h1]
  nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - y), sq_nonneg (y - z), sq_nonneg (z - x)]

soln_description:
Answer: -47. Solution. Let $t=\sqrt{x-1}$, then the original problem reduces to finding such values of $a$ for which the inequality $f(t) \equiv a t^{2}-a^{2} t+3 a^{2}-11 a+12>0$ holds for all $t \in[2 ; 3]$. This means that the minimum of the function $f(t)$ on the interval $2 \leq t \leq 3$ is positive.

If $a=0$, then $f(t) \equiv 12$. If $a \neq 0$, then there are two cases:
a) $\left\{\begin{array}{l}f\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)=-\frac{1}{4}(a-2)(a-4)(a-6)>0, \\ 2 \leq \frac{a}{2} \leq 3\end{array} \Leftrightarrow 40, \\ f(3)=2(6-a)>0\end{array} \Leftrightarrow a<3\right.$.

In the end, $a \in(-\infty ; 3) \cup(4 ; 6)$, and the sum of the sought values of $a$ on the interval $[-10 ; 10]$ is: $-10-9-8-\ldots-1+0+1+2+5=(-10-9-\ldots-6)-4-3=-47$.
informal_statement: 10.1. Find the sum of all integer values of $a$ belonging to the interval $[-10 ; 10]$, for each of which the double inequality $5 \leq x \leq 10$ implies the inequality $a x+3 a^{2}-12 a+12>a^{2} \sqrt{x-1}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 10.1. Find the sum of all integer values of $a$ belonging to the interval $[-10 ; 10]$, for each of which the double inequality $5 \leq x \leq 10$ implies the inequality $a x+3 a^{2}-12 a+12>a^{2} \sqrt{x-1}$. -/
theorem inequalities_204729 :
  ‚àë·∂† a ‚àà {a : ‚Ñ§ | a ‚àà Icc (-10) 10 ‚àß ‚àÄ x ‚àà Icc 5 10, a * x + 3 * a^2 - 12 * a + 12 > a^2 * sqrt (x - 1)}, a = -47 := by

soln_description:
Analysis We still transform the boundary angle relationship.
Solution By the sine theorem: $a=2 R \sin A=2 \sin A$
So $\frac{a}{1-\sin A}=\frac{2 \sin A}{1-\sin A}=\frac{2 \sin A(1+\sin A)}{(1-\sin A)(1+\sin A)}$
$$
=\frac{2 \sin A+2 \sin ^{2} A}{\cos ^{2} A}=\frac{2 \tan A}{\cos A}+2 \tan ^{2} A
$$

Similarly: $\frac{b}{1-\sin B}=\frac{2 \tan B}{\cos B}+2 \tan ^{2} B, \frac{c}{1-\sin C}=\frac{2 \tan C}{\cos C}+2 \tan ^{2} C$
Also, by $\tan A+\tan B+\tan C=\tan A \tan B \tan C$
It is easy to know: $\tan A \tan B \tan C \geqslant 3 \sqrt{3}$
And
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\cos A \cos B \cos C \leqslant \frac{1}{8} \\
\tan ^{2} A+\tan ^{2} B+\tan ^{2} C \geqslant 3 \sqrt[3]{(\tan A \tan B \tan C)^{2}}=9 \\
\frac{\tan A}{\cos A}+\frac{\tan B}{\cos B}+\frac{\tan C}{\cos C} \geqslant 3 \sqrt[3]{\frac{\tan A \tan B \tan C}{\cos A \cos B \cos C}} \geqslant 3 \sqrt[3]{\frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{\frac{1}{8}}}=6 \sqrt{3}
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, the left side $\geqslant 2(9+6 \sqrt{3})=18+12 \sqrt{3}$, equality holds if and only if $A=B=C=\frac{\pi}{3}$.
informal_statement:
For example, in the acute triangle $\triangle A B C$, the circumradius $R=1$, and the sides opposite to angles $A, B, C$ are $a, b, c$, respectively. Prove:
$$
\frac{a}{1-\sin A}+\frac{b}{1-\sin B}+\frac{c}{1-\sin C} \geqslant 18+12 \sqrt{3}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- For example, in the acute triangle $\triangle A B C$, the circumradius $R=1$, and the sides opposite to angles $A, B, C$ are $a, b, c$, respectively. Prove:
$$
\frac{a}{1-\sin A}+\frac{b}{1-\sin B}+\frac{c}{1-\sin C} \geqslant 18+12 \sqrt{3}
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_101924 (A B C : Real) (hA : A ‚àà Ioo 0 (œÄ / 2)) (hB : B ‚àà Ioo 0 (œÄ / 2))
    (hC : C ‚àà Ioo 0 (œÄ / 2)) (hABC : A + B + C = œÄ) (R : ‚Ñù) (hR : R = 1)
    (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : a = 2 * R * sin A) (hb : b = 2 * R * sin B) (hc : c = 2 * R * sin C) :
    18 + 12 * sqrt 3 ‚â§ a / (1 - sin A) + b / (1 - sin B) + c / (1 - sin C) := by

informal_statement: Prove that every natural number $n > 17$ can be expressed as the sum of three natural numbers $a$, $b$, and $c$, where $a$, $b$, and $c$ are relatively prime to each other and each is greater than one. Consider the cases where $n$ is of the form $6k$, $6k+1$, $6k+2$, $6k+3$, $6k+4$, and $6k+5$ for some integer $k$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Prove that every natural number $n > 17$ can be expressed as the sum of three natural numbers $a$, $b$, and $c$, where $a$, $b$, and $c$ are relatively prime to each other and each is greater than one. Consider the cases where $n$ is of the form $6k$, $6k+1$, $6k+2$, $6k+3$, $6k+4$, and $6k+5$ for some integer $k$. -/
theorem number_theory_1627 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn1 : 17 < n) :
    ‚àÉ a b c : ‚Ñï, b > 1 ‚àß a > 1 ‚àß c > 1 ‚àß a + b + c = n ‚àß Nat.Coprime a b ‚àß Nat.Coprime b c ‚àß Nat.Coprime a c := by

soln_description:
Solution. 1st method. Apply the method of variation of arbitrary constant.

1st step. Solve the corresponding homogeneous equation $\frac{d y}{d x}+x y=0$ by the method of separation of variables:

$$
\frac{d y}{y}=-x d x ; \int \frac{d y}{y}=-\int x d x ; \ln |y|=-\ln |x|+\ln C ; \quad y(x)=\frac{C}{x}
$$

2nd step. Replace the arbitrary constant of integration $C$ with a function $C(x)$ to be determined:

$$
y(x)=\frac{C(x)}{x}
$$

3rd step. Substitute the new expression for $y(x)$ into the original equation and obtain an equation for $C(x)$:

$$
\frac{d C}{d x} \cdot \frac{1}{x}-x \frac{C(x)}{x} e^{-\int p(x) d x}+x \frac{C(x)}{x} \cdot e^{-\int p(x) d x}=x^{2}
$$

from which $\frac{d C}{d x}=x^{3}$.

4th step. Solve the obtained equation by the method of separation of variables: $d C=x^{3} d x$;

$$
\int d C=\int x^{3} d x ; \quad C(x)=\frac{x^{4}}{4}+C_{1}
$$

5th step. Write the final answer:

$$
y(x)=\left(\frac{x^{4}}{4} x+C_{1}\right) \frac{1}{x}=\frac{x^{3}}{4}+\frac{C_{1}}{x}
$$

2nd method. Apply the Bernoulli method.

1st step. Represent the unknown function $y(x)$ as a product of two new unknown functions $u(x)$ and $v(x)$:

$$
y(x)=u(x) \cdot v(x), \text { with } \frac{d y}{d x}=v(x) \frac{d u}{d x}+u(x) \frac{d v}{d x} \text {. }
$$

2nd step. Substitute the expressions for $y(x)$ and its derivative into the original equation:

$$
v(x) \frac{d u}{d x}+u(x) \frac{d v}{d x}+x u(x) v(x)=x^{2}
$$

and factor out $u(x)$ in the last two terms of the left side: $v(x) \frac{d u}{d x}+u(x)\left[\frac{d v}{d x}+x v(x)\right]=x^{2}$.

3rd step. Set the expression in the square brackets to zero: $\frac{d v}{d x}+x v(x)=0$, and solve the obtained equation by the method of separation of variables: $v(x)=\frac{1}{x}$. Here, the arbitrary constant of integration is not written.

4th step. Substitute the found function into the equation obtained in the 2nd step, to get an equation for the unknown function $u(x): \frac{1}{x} \cdot \frac{d u}{d x}=x^{2}$. Solve it by the method of separation of variables: $d u=x^{3} d x ; u(x)=\frac{x^{4}}{4}+C$. Note that on this step, the arbitrary constant of integration is written.

5th step. Write the answer:

$$
y(x)=\left(\frac{x^{4}}{4}+C\right) \cdot \frac{1}{x}=\frac{x^{3}}{4}+\frac{C}{x}
$$
informal_statement: 4.38. Integrate the equation $\frac{d y}{d x}+x y=x^{2}$ using two methods: the method of variation of arbitrary constant and the Bernoulli method.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4.38. Integrate the equation $\frac{d y}{d x}+x y=x^{2}$ using two methods: the method of variation of arbitrary constant and the Bernoulli method. -/
theorem calculus_143602 (y : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hy : Differentiable ‚Ñù y)
    (h : ‚àÄ x, deriv y x + x * y x = x ^ 2) :
    ‚àÉ C, ‚àÄ x, y x = (x ^ 3 / 4) + C / x := by

soln_description:
2. $2 x^{2}+3 x+5$.

Notice that the degrees of $f(x+1)$ and $f(x-1)$ are the same, and the right side is quadratic, so let $f(x)=a x^{2}+b x+c$.
Substitute into the given equation and compare the coefficients on both sides to get
$$
a=2, b=3, c=5 \text {. }
$$

Therefore, $f(x)=2 x^{2}+3 x+5$.
informal_statement:
2. Let the polynomial $f(x)$ satisfy
$$

soln_description:
Solution alternative $n^{\circ} 1$ We show, as in the previous case, that for the first question, at least 3 colors are needed and at least 4 in the second.

We propose here to generalize the previous coloring: we construct a coloring with the optimal number of colors to color the integers from 2 to $r$, with $r \geqslant 2$. Let $n \geqslant 2$, and let $n=p_{1}^{a_{1}} \times \cdots \times p_{k}^{a_{k}}$ be its prime factorization. We will color $n$ with the color $a_{1}+\cdots+a_{k}$ (note that since $n \geqslant 2$, we have $a_{1}+\cdots+a_{k} \geqslant 1$). Let's show that this coloring is correct: let $m \neq n$ be two integers such that $m$ divides $n$. Let $n=p_{1}^{a_{1}} \times \cdots \times p_{k}^{a_{k}}$ be its prime factorization. $m$ can necessarily be written in the form $m=p_{1}^{b_{1}} \times \cdots \times p_{k}^{b_{k}}$ with $b_{1} \leqslant a_{1}, \ldots b_{k} \leqslant a_{k}$. Since $m \neq n$, there must exist some $i$ such that $a_{i} \neq b_{i}$, hence $a_{i}>b_{i}$. Thus, we must have $a_{1}+\cdots+a_{k}>b_{1}+\cdots+b_{k}$, so $m$ and $n$ are indeed of different colors.

If $n \leqslant 8$ and $n=p_{1}^{a_{1}} \times \cdots \times p_{k}^{a_{k}}$, then $2^{3}=8 \geqslant n \geqslant 2^{a_{1}+\cdots+a_{k}}$ so $a_{1}+\cdots+a_{k} \leqslant 3$. The coloring uses at most 3 colors for the integers from 2 to 8, so for the first question, the minimal $k$ is 3.

If $n \leqslant 31$ and $n=p_{1}^{a_{1}} \times \cdots \times p_{k}^{a_{k}}$, then $2^{5}=32>n \geqslant 2^{a_{1}+\cdots+a_{k}}$ so $a_{1}+\cdots+a_{k}<5$ and since $a_{1}+\cdots+a_{k}$ is an integer, we have $a_{1}+\cdots+a_{k} \leqslant 4$. The coloring uses at most 4 colors for the integers from 2 to 31, so for the second question, the minimal $k$ is 4.
informal_statement:
## Exercise 6.

1) Alice wants to color the integers between 2 and 8 (inclusive) using $k$ colors. She wishes that if $m$ and $n$ are integers between 2 and 8 such that $m$ is a multiple of $n$ and $m \neq n$, then $m$ and $n$ are of different colors. Determine the smallest integer $k$ for which Alice can color the integers $2,3, \ldots, 8$ using $k$ colors.
2) Alice wants to color the integers between 2 and 31 (inclusive) using $k$ colors. She wishes that if $m$ and $n$ are integers between 2 and 31 such that $m$ is a multiple of $n$ and $m \neq n$, then $m$ and $n$ are of different colors. Determine the smallest integer $k$ for which Alice can color the integers $2,3, \ldots, 31$ using $k$ colors.

Determine the smallest integer $k$ for which Alice can color the integers $2,3, \ldots, 8$ using $k$ colors.
2) Alice wants to color the integers between 2 and 31 (inclusive) using $k$ colors. She wishes that if $m$ and $n$ are integers between 2 and 31 such that $m$ is a multiple of $n$ and $m \neq n$, then $m$ and $n$ are of different colors. Determine the smallest integer $k$ for which Alice can color the integers $2,3, \ldots, 31$ using $k$ colors. -/

soln_description:
Since the result must work no matter what positive integers $m$ and $n$ we choose with $m\frac{m}{n}$, so the answer must be (D).

(We could also prove this algebraically by starting with $m<n$, which gives $3 m<3 n$, which gives $m n+3 m<m n+3 n$, which gives $m(n+3)<n(m+3)$ which gives $\frac{m}{n}<\frac{m+3}{n+3}$.)

ANSWER: (D)
informal_statement:
Suppose $m$ and $n$ are positive integers with $m<n$. The value of $\frac{m+3}{n+3}$ will be

(A) equal to 1

(B) equal to 3

(C) less than the value of $\frac{m}{n}$

(D) greater than the value of $\frac{m}{n}$

(E) equal to the value of $\frac{m}{n}$
informal_proof:
Given integers $m$ and $n$ such that $0 < m < n$. We aim to prove that $\frac{m+3}{n+3} > \frac{m}{n}$.

First, we establish the necessary positivity conditions for the real number representations of $m$ and $n$. Let $m_{\mathbb{R}}$ and $n_{\mathbb{R}}$ be the real number representations of $m$ and $n$. The given condition $0 < m$ implies $m_{\mathbb{R}} > 0$. The condition $m < n$, combined with $m > 0$, implies $n > 0$, so $n_{\mathbb{R}} > 0$. Consequently, $n_{\mathbb{R}} + 3 > 0$.

To prove the inequality $\frac{m_{\mathbb{R}}+3}{n_{\mathbb{R}}+3} > \frac{m_{\mathbb{R}}}{n_{\mathbb{R}}}$, we can use the property that for positive real numbers $a, b, c, d$, if $\frac{a}{c} < \frac{b}{d}$ then $ad < bc$. Here, we want to show $\frac{m_{\mathbb{R}}}{n_{\mathbb{R}}} < \frac{m_{\mathbb{R}}+3}{n_{\mathbb{R}}+3}$. Since $n_{\mathbb{R}} > 0$ and $n_{\mathbb{R}}+3 > 0$, this inequality is equivalent to:
$m_{\mathbb{R}} (n_{\mathbb{R}} + 3) < (m_{\mathbb{R}} + 3) n_{\mathbb{R}}$

Expanding both sides of this inequality, we obtain:
$m_{\mathbb{R}} n_{\mathbb{R}} + 3 m_{\mathbb{R}} < m_{\mathbb{R}} n_{\mathbb{R}} + 3 n_{\mathbb{R}}$

Subtracting $m_{\mathbb{R}} n_{\mathbb{R}}$ from both sides gives:
$3 m_{\mathbb{R}} < 3 n_{\mathbb{R}}$

Dividing by the positive number 3 yields:
$m_{\mathbb{R}} < n_{\mathbb{R}}$

This final inequality, $m_{\mathbb{R}} < n_{\mathbb{R}}$, is true by our initial assumption $m < n$. Since all steps are reversible and valid under the established positivity conditions, we have proven that $\frac{m+3}{n+3} > \frac{m}{n}$.

Thus, the value of $\frac{m+3}{n+3}$ is greater than the value of $\frac{m}{n}$. This corresponds to option (D).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Suppose $m$ and $n$ are positive integers with $m<n$. The value of $\frac{m+3}{n+3}$ will be

(A) equal to 1

(B) equal to 3

(C) less than the value of $\frac{m}{n}$

(D) greater than the value of $\frac{m}{n}$

(E) equal to the value of $\frac{m}{n}$ -/
theorem algebra_274827 (m n : ‚Ñ§) (hm : 0 < m) (hn : m < n) :
    (m + 3 : ‚Ñù) / (n + 3) > m / n := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_274827 (m n : ‚Ñ§) (hm : 0 < m) (hn : m < n) :
    (m + 3 : ‚Ñù) / (n + 3) > m / n := by 
  have h1 : (m : ‚Ñù) > 0 := by exact_mod_cast hm
  have h2 : (m : ‚Ñù) < (n : ‚Ñù) := by exact_mod_cast hn
  have h3 : (n : ‚Ñù) > 0 := by linarith
  have h4 : (n : ‚Ñù) + 3 > 0 := by linarith
  have h5 : (m / n : ‚Ñù) < ((m + 3 : ‚Ñù) / (n + 3)) := by
    apply (div_lt_div_iff (by positivity) (by positivity)).mpr
    nlinarith
  linarith

soln_description:
Since $75=3 \times 5 \times 5$, we can factor 75 in three different ways:

$$
75=1 \times 75=3 \times 25=5 \times 15
$$

If $p q=75$ with $p$ and $q$ integers, then the possible values of $p$ are thus $1,3,5,15,25,75$. The sum of these values is $1+3+5+15+25+75=124$.

ANSWER: (E)
informal_statement:
When two positive integers $p$ and $q$ are multiplied together, their product is 75 . The sum of all of the possible values of $p$ is
(A) 96
(B) 48
(C) 109
(D) 115
(E) 124
informal_proof:
We are asked to find the sum of all possible values of a positive integer $p$, given that $p \times q = 75$ for some positive integer $q$. This means we need to find all positive divisors of 75.

The prime factorization of 75 is $3 \times 5 \times 5$. The positive divisors of 75 can be systematically found by considering all combinations of its prime factors. The divisors are:
\begin{itemize}
    \item $1$ (obtained by taking no prime factors)
    \item $3$ (obtained by taking one factor of 3)
    \item $5$ (obtained by taking one factor of 5)
    \item $15$ (obtained by taking one factor of 3 and one factor of 5)
    \item $25$ (obtained by taking two factors of 5)
    \item $75$ (obtained by taking one factor of 3 and two factors of 5)
\end{itemize}
Thus, the set of all positive divisors of 75 is $\{1, 3, 5, 15, 25, 75\}$.

The problem requires us to compute the sum of these divisors:
$$ \sum_{d \in \{1, 3, 5, 15, 25, 75\}} d = 1 + 3 + 5 + 15 + 25 + 75 $$
Performing the addition:
$$ 1 + 3 = 4 $$
$$ 4 + 5 = 9 $$
$$ 9 + 15 = 24 $$
$$ 24 + 25 = 49 $$
$$ 49 + 75 = 124 $$
The sum of all possible values of $p$ is 124.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- When two positive integers $p$ and $q$ are multiplied together, their product is 75 . The sum of all of the possible values of $p$ is
(A) 96
(B) 48
(C) 109
(D) 115
(E) 124 -/
theorem number_theory_268087 :
    ‚àë p in (Nat.divisors 75).filter (fun p => p > 0), p = 124 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_268087 :
    ‚àë p in (Nat.divisors 75).filter (fun p => p > 0), p = 124 := by 
  native_decide

soln_description:
Solution 1
In order to be a multiple of 24 , any number must be both a multiple of 3 and a multiple of 8 . Conversely, since 8 and 3 are coprime (i.e. they have no common factor greater than 1), any number which is a multiple of both 3 and 8 must be a multiple of 24 . It is therefore sufficient for us to count all the numbers of the required form which are multiples of both 3 and 8 .
The digit sum of 'pqrpqrpqr' is $3(p+q+r)$, which is always a multiple of 3 , so all numbers of the form 'pqrpqrpqr' are divisible by 3 (by the divisibility test for 3 ).
So now all we need to do is to count all the numbers of the required form which are multiples of 8 , since they will also be a multiple of 3 and hence a multiple of 24 .
By the divisibility test for 8 , we need the three-digit number 'pqr' to be divisible by 8 , and each three-digit multiple of 8 will give us a nine-digit number divisible by 8 . So all that remains is to count the three-digit multiples of 8 .
The smallest of these is $104(=13 \times 8)$ and the largest is $992(=124 \times 8)$, so there are 112 three-digit multiples of 8 and therefore 112 numbers of the form 'pqrpqrpqr' which are multiples of 24 .

Solution 2
As in Solution 1, we can establish that we need 'pqrpqrpqr' to be a multiple of both 3 and 8 .
Notice that 'pqrpqrpqr' $=1001001 \times$ pqr. 1001001 is divisible by 3 so every number of the form is 'pqrpqrpqr' divisible by 3 . Since 1001001 is odd, we need the three-digit number 'pqr' to be divisible by 8 .
There are 124 multiples of 8 less than 1000 ; of these 12 are less than 100 , so there are 112 three-digit multiples of 8 and hence 112 numbers with the properties given in the question.
informal_statement: H2. How many nine-digit integers of the form 'pqrpqrpqr' are multiples of 24 ? (Note that $p, q$ and $r$ need not be different.)
Find all odd natural numbers $n$ such that $d(n)$ is the largest divisor of the number $n$ different from $n$ $(d(n)$ is the number of divisors of the number $n$ including 1 and $n$ ).
formal_statement:

/- Find all odd natural numbers $n$ such that $d(n)$ is the largest divisor of the number $n$ different from $n$ $(d(n)$ is the number of divisors of the number $n$ including 1 and $n$ ). -/
theorem number_theory_605237 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : Odd n) :
    n.divisors.card = sSup {k | k ‚à£ n ‚àß k ‚â† n} ‚Üî n = 9 := by

soln_description:
In 20 minutes, the car would have traveled the distance the engineer walked twice. Therefore, the car met the engineer at $7:50$.

## Answer

50 minutes.
informal_statement:
7

An engineer arrives at the train station at 8 o'clock in the morning every day. At exactly 8 o'clock, a car arrives at the station and takes the engineer to the factory. One day, the engineer arrived at the station at 7 o'clock and started walking towards the car. Meeting the car, he got in and arrived at the factory 20 minutes earlier than usual. How long did the engineer walk? The speeds of the car and the engineer are constant.

#
informal_proof:
We are given two real numbers, `d` and `v`. The proof proceeds under the following assumptions:
1.  `d` is a positive real number.
2.  `v` is a positive real number.
3.  The ratio `d / v` is equal to the value of `8 - 7`.
4.  The ratio `d / v`, when added to `20 / 60`, is also equal to the value of `8 - 7`.

Let's simplify these assumptions:
*   From assumption 1, we have `d > 0`.
*   From assumption 2, we have `v > 0`.
*   From assumption 3, we simplify `8 - 7` to `1`, so we have `d / v = 1`.
*   From assumption 4, we simplify `20 / 60` to `1 / 3`, so we have `d / v + 1 / 3 = 1`.

Now, let's examine the implications of these assumptions. If we take the result from the third assumption, `d / v = 1`, and substitute it into the fourth assumption (`d / v + 1 / 3 = 1`), we obtain:
`1 + 1 / 3 = 1`
This statement simplifies to `4 / 3 = 1`, which is a mathematical contradiction.

The goal of the proof is to show that `d / v = 50`.

The method used to reach this conclusion is based on linear arithmetic. Specifically, when a system of assumptions contains a contradiction (as shown above, `4/3 = 1`), it is possible to logically derive any statement. This is a fundamental principle in logic, meaning that from a false premise, any conclusion can be validly drawn. The tactic employed is capable of performing these deductions based on the linear relationships between the given values. Therefore, despite the contradictory nature of the initial conditions, the target statement `d / v = 50` can be formally proven from these premises.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7

An engineer arrives at the train station at 8 o'clock in the morning every day. At exactly 8 o'clock, a car arrives at the station and takes the engineer to the factory. One day, the engineer arrived at the station at 7 o'clock and started walking towards the car. Meeting the car, he got in and arrived at the factory 20 minutes earlier than usual. How long did the engineer walk? The speeds of the car and the engineer are constant.

# -/
theorem algebra_181062 (d v : ‚Ñù) (h‚ÇÄ : d > 0) (h‚ÇÅ : v > 0)
    (h‚ÇÇ : d / v = 8 - 7) (h‚ÇÉ : d / v + 20 / 60 = 8 - 7) :
    d / v = 50 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_181062 (d v : ‚Ñù) (h‚ÇÄ : d > 0) (h‚ÇÅ : v > 0)
    (h‚ÇÇ : d / v = 8 - 7) (h‚ÇÉ : d / v + 20 / 60 = 8 - 7) :
    d / v = 50 := by 
  linarith

soln_description:
3. (C).

According to the problem, we have
$$
f(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
0, x=3,6,9, \\
1, x=1,4,7, \\
2, x=2,5,8 .
\end{array} \quad g(y)=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
0, y=4,8, \\
1, y=1,5,9, \\
2, y=2,6, \\
3, y=3,7 .
\end{array}\right.\right.
$$

Since $f(x)$ and $g(y)$ are both non-negative, to make $f(x) + 2g(y) = 0$, it must be that $f(x) = 0$ and $g(y) = 0$. At this time, $x = 3, 6, 9$, and $y = 4, 8$. The maximum values of $x$ and $y$ are 9 and 8, respectively, so the maximum value of $x + 2y$ is $9 + 2 \times 8 = 25$.
informal_statement:

(A) 11
(B) 22
(C) 25
(D) 27
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. Let $x, y$ be positive integers no greater than 9, the remainder of $x$ divided by 3 is $f(x)$, and the remainder of $y$ divided by 4 is $g(y)$. If $f(x)+2 g(y)=0$, then the value of $x+2 y$ is ( ).
(A) 11
(B) 22
(C) 25
(D) 27 -/
theorem number_theory_324336 (x y : ‚Ñï) (hx : 0 < x ‚àß x ‚â§ 9) (hy : 0 < y ‚àß y ‚â§ 9)
    (f : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï) (g : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï) (hf : ‚àÄ x, f x = x % 3) (hg : ‚àÄ y, g y = y % 4)
    (h : f x + 2 * g y = 0) : x + 2 * y = 25 := by

soln_description:
First, we try a few values of $n$ to see if we can find a pattern in the values of $t_{n}$ :

| $n$ | $\sqrt{n}$ | $t_{n}$ | $n$ | $\sqrt{n}$ | $t_{n}$ |
| :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: |
| 1 | 1 | 1 | 11 | 3.32 | 3 |
| 2 | 1.41 | 1 | 12 | 3.46 | 3 |
| 3 | 1.73 | 2 | 13 | 3.61 | 4 |
| 4 | 2 | 2 | 14 | 3.74 | 4 |
| 5 | 2.24 | 2 | 15 | 3.87 | 4 |
| 6 | 2.45 | 2 | 16 | 4 | 4 |
| 7 | 2.65 | 3 | 17 | 4.12 | 4 |
| 8 | 2.83 | 3 | 18 | 4.24 | 4 |
| 9 | 3 | 3 | 19 | 4.36 | 4 |
| 10 | 3.16 | 3 | 20 | 4.47 | 4 |
|  |  |  | 21 | 4.58 | 5 |

(In each case, the $\sqrt{n}$ column contains an approximation of $\sqrt{n}$ to 2 decimal places.) So $t_{n}=1$ for 2 values of $n, 2$ for 4 values of $n, 3$ for 6 values of $n, 4$ for 8 values of $n$.

We conjecture that $t_{n}=k$ for $2 k$ values of $n$. We will prove this fact at the end of the solution. Next, we note that $\sqrt{2010} \approx 44.83$ and so $t_{2010}=45$.

This means that before this point in the sequence, we have included all terms with $t_{n} \leq 44$. According to our conjecture, the number of terms with $t_{n} \leq 44$ should be

$$
2+4+6+\cdots+86+88=2(1+2+3+\cdots+43+44)=2\left(\frac{1}{2}(44)(45)\right)=44(45)=1980
$$

Note that $\sqrt{1980} \approx 44.497$ and $\sqrt{1981} \approx 44.508$ so $t_{1980}=44$ and $t_{1981}=45$.

Since $t_{1981}=t_{2010}=45$, then each of the terms from $t_{1981}$ to $t_{2010}$ equals 45 . Therefore, there are 30 terms that equal 45.

Thus, the required sum equals

$$
2\left(\frac{1}{1}\right)+4\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)+6\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)+\cdots+86\left(\frac{1}{43}\right)+88\left(\frac{1}{44}\right)+30\left(\frac{1}{45}\right)=2+2+2+\cdots+2+2+\frac{2}{3}
$$

where there are 44 copies of 2 .

Therefore, the sum equals $88 \frac{2}{3}$.

Lastly, we prove that for each positive integer $k$, there are $2 k$ terms $t_{n}$ that equal $k$ :

In order to have $t_{n}=k$, we need $k-\frac{1}{2} \leq \sqrt{n}<k+\frac{1}{2}$ (in other words, $\sqrt{n}$ needs to round to $k$ ).

Since $n$ and $k$ are positive, then $k-\frac{1}{2} \leq \sqrt{n}$ is equivalent to $\left(k-\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2} \leq n$ and $\sqrt{n}<k+\frac{1}{2}$ is equivalent to $n<\left(k+\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}$.

Therefore, we need $\left(k-\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2} \leq n<\left(k+\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}$ or $k^{2}-k+\frac{1}{4} \leq n<k^{2}+k+\frac{1}{4}$.

Since $n$ is an integer, then $k^{2}-k+1 \leq n \leq k^{2}+k$.

There are thus $\left(k^{2}+k\right)-\left(k^{2}-k+1\right)+1=2 k$ such values of $n$, as required.

ANSWER: (C)
informal_statement:
Let $t_{n}$ equal the integer closest to $\sqrt{n}$.

For example, $t_{1}=t_{2}=1$ since $\sqrt{1}=1$ and $\sqrt{2} \approx 1.41$ and $t_{3}=2$ since $\sqrt{3} \approx 1.73$.

The sum $\frac{1}{t_{1}}+\frac{1}{t_{2}}+\frac{1}{t_{3}}+\frac{1}{t_{4}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{t_{2008}}+\frac{1}{t_{2009}}+\frac{1}{t_{2010}}$ equals
(A) $88 \frac{1}{6}$
(B) $88 \frac{1}{2}$
(C) $88 \frac{2}{3}$
(D) $88 \frac{1}{3}$
(E) 90

import Mathlib

open Real

/- Let $t_{n}$ equal the integer closest to $\sqrt{n}$.

For example, $t_{1}=t_{2}=1$ since $\sqrt{1}=1$ and $\sqrt{2} \approx 1.41$ and $t_{3}=2$ since $\sqrt{3} \approx 1.73$.

The sum $\frac{1}{t_{1}}+\frac{1}{t_{2}}+\frac{1}{t_{3}}+\frac{1}{t_{4}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{t_{2008}}+\frac{1}{t_{2009}}+\frac{1}{t_{2010}}$ equals
(A) $88 \frac{1}{6}$
(B) $88 \frac{1}{2}$
(C) $88 \frac{2}{3}$
(D) $88 \frac{1}{3}$
(E) 90 -/

soln_description:
3. La risposta √® (B). Innanzitutto notiamo che $2024=2^{3} \cdot 11 \cdot 23$ deve dividere $n^{2}$, quindi possiamo scrivere $n=\left(2^{2} \cdot 11 \cdot 23\right) \cdot k=1012 k$, con $k$ intero di modulo minore o uguale a 9 , cos√¨ che $|n|=|1012 k|<10000$. Sostituendo nell'equazione abbiamo

$$
1012^{2} k^{2}+2 \cdot 1012^{2} k+2024 m=2024,
$$

e dividendo per 2024 si ha

$$
506 k^{2}+1012 k-1=-m \text {. }
$$

Il numero di soluzioni $(n, m)$ √® dunque pari al numero di interi $-10<k<10$ tali che

$$
-10000<506 k^{2}+1012 k-1<10000 ;
$$

infatti, una volta scelto $k$, l'intero $m$ √® univocamente determinato. Si osserva facilmente che per $k \leq-6$ o $k \geq 4$ la disuguaglianza non √® verificata, mentre lo √® per tutti gli interi tra -5 e 3 , che sono 9 .
informal_statement:

(A) 4
(B) 9
(C) 10
(D) 18
(E) 19
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. Determinare il numero di coppie $(m, n)$ di numeri interi di modulo minore di 10000 che risolvono l'equazione $n^{2}+2024 n+2024 m=2024$.
(A) 4
(B) 9
(C) 10
(D) 18
(E) 19 -/
theorem algebra_136770 :
    Set.ncard {p : ‚Ñ§ √ó ‚Ñ§ | p.2 ^ 2 + 2024 * p.2 + 2024 * p.1 = 2024 ‚àß |p.1| < 10000 ‚àß |p.2| < 10000} = 9 := by

soln_description:
Solution. First, let's find the derivative:

$$
x^{\prime} y^{2}+x 2 y y^{\prime}=0, y^{\prime}=-\frac{y}{2 x}
$$

Substituting the values \(x=1\), \(y=2\) into the right-hand side of the last equation, we get

$$
y^{\prime}=-\frac{2}{2 \cdot 1}=-1
$$
